I know my playtime doesn't look like much, but I have played this game on Xbox and on Mobile for collectively over 700 hours and have now purchased it for PC as well. I can't say this game's praise loud enough. This game has everything I need in a roguelike. Very challenging, incredibly satisfying and fast-paced combat that goes hand-in-hand with the game's solid platformer elements, gorgeous backdrops, a great soundtrack with some real bangers, crisp sound design (that dinging crit noise is a massive dopamine injection), as well as tons of secrets, easter eggs and references to other classic franchises that can easily take you over 200 hours of gameplay just to see them all. The game has a simple yet very rewarding affix system which allows you to create new synergies every run, is run by passionate developers that keep on dishing out fantastic content (the DLCs especially!), has an intriguing world and story, a very high skill ceiling and a custom mode if you just want to play with your favourite weapons or tweak your run in some creative ways as well as an accessibility mode for players who want a casual experience without much stress. In addition to all that, there is a huge amount of unlocks in the game that require you play on higher and higher difficulties just to get them all. Every single one of the unlockable weapons all play differently, and unlockable mutations give you additional upgrades you can equip in between stages. Even after unlocking every weapon, item and outfit in the base game, there's fun daily runs (which also grant you weapon unlocks), boss rush (with even more unlocks, arguably the most challenging to get in the game), and so-called "aspects" that alter the game significantly by giving you some really overpowered and fun abilites to play around with. Easiest 10/10 of my life.

If you enjoyed Castlevania: SOTN, Metroid on SNES or 2D sidescrolling roguelike games then do not hesitate to pick this up. Gameplay is spot-on, controls are tight, and replayability is near infinite. So many games these days cost $80.00 and then charge you more to unlock characters etc. As of this writing, Dead Cells and ALL of its expansions are only $50.00. That's a steal for how much fun can be had here. I have logged more than 100 hours on my Xbox, and 30 here on Steam. It's worth every penny!

Somehow I haven't written a review for this game yet... but I think it's safe to say Dead Cells is my game of the year for 2023. (Okay so that isn't true anymore, but Dead Cells is my 2nd best game of the year. Sea of Stars beat it lol. Sorry.)

Technically, I began playing it in 2022.. but it was for under 2 hours and then I stopped. As the new Castlevania DLC was coming out in March 2023, I was thinking then would be a good chance to pick the game back up and give it a better chance. After all, I didn't hate the game. I just stopped playing it for some reason (a strange trend I do when I start a game then proceed not to play it for an extended period of time)...

Regardless, about the game. Every part about it is absolutely delightful. The gameplay? Fun and challenging. Winning battles feels rewarding and even when you lose, you're still learning. The weapons? Fun to use. I was a brutality enjoyer when I first started, then I slowly started sinking into the survival class. I've never been a fan of tactics unfortunately... But the game is pretty balanced for the most part. You can also turn on some features to make the game a little bit more attuned to your tastes, to help you ease into the harder difficulties. When I started 5BC, I had been using the cursed chest aspect, but slowly overtime I began to stop using it (I wanted to be able to get gold costumes lol).

The amount of items that there are in this game comes nowhere close to what a game like The Binding of Isaac has (literal thousands of hours), but it also doesn't have a shortage of items. I'm 139 hours through playing and I still haven't found all the items (where's the ukulele!?). I know I could just use the item made to get blueprints guaranteed, but it doesn't feel as nice then. But it's always there if you ever want to get all the items.

The diversity in areas? Amazing! Of course if you don't own the DLC's, you'll only be going through the same one or two paths over and over. But with the DLC's, it offers you so many different paths to take and of course, all the other stuff DLC's have to offer. If you haven't picked up Dead Cells, I would suggest getting the DLC's with it. It makes the game so much bigger in so many different aspects.

And the music.. OH, the music. It wasn't as great as something like The Messenger, Hades, or Omori in something I would listen to again, but the music absolutely does not disappoint. And the Castlevania OST as well? Even more fantastic! I actually prefer using that one. The music on Fractured Shrines with the Castlevania OST on is my favorite track. Next to the music in the spoiler biome as well.

I'm pretty sure there's a LOAD of categories I'm missing about this game, but that just shows how much there really is to it. Just.. get Dead Cells. You won't be disappointed. I surely wasn't.

It really is one of the best roguelike-Metroidvania games I've ever played. The excellent musical score, amazingly responsive controls, huge variety of weapons, challenging bosses - the developers have really just put everything together in an amazingly tight package.

Props on the longevity of support, too - the game came out 2018, and there's a new free content patch that just entered beta testing this week.

Dead Cells has over 100 weapons, each fitting into at least one of the following categories: Brutality / Tactics / Survival. Brutality weapons tend to be fast, but hit for smaller amounts (swords and daggers, mostly), Tactics are almost all ranged weapons (bows, crossbows, and whips, mostly), while survival weapons are almost all hard-hitting, very slow weapons (mauls, hammers, etc.) Many weapons fall under two categories (for instance, most crossbows are both tactics and survival), so that you can wield multiple weapons using a single upgrade path.

You've also got two slots for skills, which follow the same rules as weapons, but can be anything from traps, buffs, magic attacks, or pets. Pets are handy because (with the exception of the Owl) you can just summon them at the start of a level and let them do their thing. Most of the other skills are more powerful, but require you to actually remember to use them when they're available to get the most utility out of them - which can be a problem in the hectic frenzy of combat that is Dead Cells.

Everything in Dead Cells, from the music to the timed doors at the end of levels, pushes you to be a whirlwind of destruction, endlessly running forward to kill everything before you. It's actually not a horrible strategy - if you can accomplish it without getting hit.

Dead Cell's major claim to fame is it's extended game - specifically, its system of Boss Cells. Acting as a New Game+ system, each time you win the game under an increased number of Cells, you unlock a new Boss Cell. These increase the difficulty of the game - mostly by introducing harder enemies and reducing and/or removing the healing stations between levels. However, they also increase the number of scrolls available (which can drastically increase the damage of your weapons) as well as unlock how many cells can be spent on the Forge, which can increase the potency of weapons that you find on a run.

It's pretty much the perfect game for when you just want to go balls-to-the-wall killing some dudes for half an hour. Expect most runs to end in failure, but those runs that do not are some of the most amazing adrenaline highs you'll ever experience.

First off, I just like to preface that I've replayed this game many times over the years and this game is the perfect rogue like experience where its hard as balls, but every death felt justified and earned as it was mostly my fault. For people who are struggling with the first few floors, as the expression goes "get gud" because this game is easy to learn and master, I also guarantee that there's probably a play style for you given the vast amount of items and weapons you can collect.  Also the development team has accomplished so much considering how small the team is and this game sets a very high bar when it comes to metroid-vanias and souls-likes and it really sets itself apart from all the others.

Great game overall.  The majority of the gameplay progression is exploring levels and finding items to better defeat enemies and bosses.  The player has some agency in routing through the dungeon by picking pathways that lead to predetermined "biomes" (i.e. If one wanted, one could go through the poison swap every run or the castle gates etc.).  The gameplay itself is very rewarding, with items and weapons all feeling fairly unique and having mechanics that encourage a certain style of play on a per item basis.  For example, the Baseball Bat deals more damage to stunned and rooted foes, so you seek out items that can stun and root foes, making combat be a setup for combos.  Simple but effective. 

I think most people who enjoy roguelites in general would enjoy this game.  If that's you, then give it a go. The DLC is not required to enjoy the base idea of the game, but they absolutely enhance the experience if you find the base game enjoyable. 


This below is mostly just a rant, which is not well written and you can reasonably ignore. I just had to b*tch:

My biggest, and really only, gripe is the platforming.  Most of the times it is benign, mostly acting as a medium to facilitate the combat more interestingly.  At other times there are small, mandatory platforming sections throughout levels that can be fairly dangerous, but these are mostly manageable as well.  However, there are some "optional" platforming sections one needs to complete to unlock additional items or to obtain additional scrolls that increase your damage.  And I write "optional" because I can't imagine the game expects me to NOT attempt to get the "fancy dinner jacket" outfit for my character.  Furthermore, on higher difficulties, not going out of your way to grab additional damage scrolls can make the run significantly more difficult, especially since damage scales exponentially in this game. The game does not offer really any items to affect one's platforming ability, so one just has to be good at the game, which is fine in its own right.  But I'm not playing Super Meat Boy where I can just retry a level.  Some runs take me, and I might just be a poor player, 30 to 50 minutes to get back to these "optional" sections.  And the game isn't a necessarily difficult platformer like SMB either, but it is just infuriating to lose a long run because I missed an unintuitive jump too many times.  And I have only died perhaps a few times to each "optional" section compared to bosses or mobs, but it is exceptionally demoralizing comparatively.  Get rid of this crap, man.  If the items don't really affect my ability to complete some challenge in a *roguelite* then that challenge shouldn't exist or should not be able to jeopardize my run.

Dead Cells is an absolutely great game, however it does have a few flaws.

The game itself is incredibly difficult (or it may just be the fact that im bad at video games), as it took me 250 runs to beat the Hand of the King (final boss) in normal mode. Getting to the hand, is no easy task, as you will have to go through a series of difficult biomes filled with deadly enemies (and jam-packed with a bunch of items from bows to shields to swords and even grenades). Bosses are one of the easier elements of the game however. For example, the first boss you encounter, the Concierge is very easy to dodge and predict its attacks. Dead Cells is a great game that requires practice, if you want to even get far. The rogue-like element to the game makes it one of the most punishing games i have ever played. I would highly recommend this game if you love raging at games, and feeling a sense of accomplishment when you reach a place you never had before.

After defeating all the bosses, I feel the quality of boss fights in significantly lower than Sekiro. There is no consistency in them, for example every unique area in the game has a remembrance boss fight but the other enemies in that area, their move sets/attacks don't contribute to that main boss, they could have designed in a such a way that every area makes you learn a unique skill/ability to get you prepared to face the main boss(Ex: Caelid just throws you some wild dogs and dumb dragons before you fight Radhan, and you just summon infinite summons and swing your sword aimlessly to beat him. Same with Malenia plus the added waterfowl dance which makes the fight more frustrating than fun.)
And I wish the game gave a little instructions on how to approach it. I accidentally went and explored Caelid before exploring Limgrave, and when I came back jacked up it was a just a cake walk and no fun.
68 hours of hell. I recommend :).

This game is such good fantasy. The one thing I always really liked about Skyrim was that it felt very retro. I often ask myself why I'd ever go back to Skyrim now. This game certainly is modern, but has still a very classic. Like all Fromsolfware games it frankly presents a challenge, but the combat is tight and consistent, so it's fun to understand the mistakes you made in fights. The games been out for almost 2 years now, and I haven't spent as much time with it as others but if your a fan of fantasy games and haven't given this a try then what are you waiting for? Truly a masterpiece and will go down as one of my favorite games ever!

Out of respect to everyone who worked on this game. I believe this game deserves a solid thumbs up.
It was worth buying at full price for the shear amount of layered content packing into one title. My main drive was collecting the armor, weapons and spells I came across. However the main story boss fights are such a mixed bag. "Git good" yourself. The global achievements % speak for the player base. I'm so torn between hating the staged fights and the exploring every inch of the map to discover some hidden item. I would have enjoyed the game more if they left out the over sized boss mechanics. Fixed attacks clipping through solid objects and invisible walls when targeting the player! I did not spend most of my time "rolling to win" as the simulator repeatedly punished me for time and time again. RnG does play a big factor in some but not all of the Story boss encounters.

I'll start off by saying this is my first souls-like game, at least FromSoftware. I've played Fallen Order before, but that's a different kind of souls-like game. I first started off hating this game, thought it was too hard. I bought and refunded this game I think twice.

My friends pressured me into continuing to play this game, and I finally started to enjoy the game for what it was. It began being fun to have something to work towards, and become much better at the game. (in all aspects) 
The bosses and mechanics in this game are something.. interesting to say the least. Takes a long time to get used to, and I've spent multiple days and weeks on one boss. Nothing better than finally beating a boss and the relief going by.

The game is enormous, beautiful, and so many different areas to roam and find new items. 
- Gameplay (10/10)
- Visual (10/10)
I'd 100% recommend this to anyone new to the franchise or not.
Just play it. Do yourself a favor.

The game has it's flaws, some parts are notoriously hard like Melenia but over all the game has a huge fun factor that is not found in most modern games, 10/10 would recommend!

Absolute embarrassment of a triple AAA company in terms of PC compatibility. I spent 2.2 hours in the tutorial just trying to figure out broken keybinds. Why in the heII would I want F binded to jump, then you can never jump and use D to go to the right. And thats not the only key, Capslock, Windows keys, Function Keys, and some random keys like G or T depending on your PC peripherals. This game doesnt even register my G502X mouse. Therefore if I wanted a keybind on my mouse I have to pick some random ass key on the keyboard thats not blocked and then inturn bind that to my mouse on my mouses software. This makes dual keybinds useless. 

At my time of righting this 10/25/23 I looked up sells on this game, 20 million units + at the beginning of 2023, at 60 dollars a copy that comes out to 1.2 billion. A billion dollar triple AAA company that limits FPS to 60, as another comment said, limits screen resolution to normal 16:9, beyond broken keybinds for PC, and no widescreen support among other things. 

I truly don't understand why this game is rated so high, I bought this game because of the rating and I cant return it because I went .2 hours over the trial period just trying to fix there game. And yes for anyone wondering if you can mod the game and fix the issues of widescreen or keybinds etc. Yes you can, but according to what I've read you can be banned for it. 

One random person can implement a mod fix for a triple AAA studio that they can't seem to do theirself and its against the terms and policy. My play hours may go up after righting this but its only because I can't return it for going 12 minutes over the "trial period."

In Dota 2 your objective is to desroy the enemy's "ancient" which is essentially a big tower.  To get to the ancient you have to destroy your way through four tiers of towers which are defended by the enemy team.  At the same time, you are defending your ancient.
The character models, spells and all around feel of the game are what keep me coming back, however the MMR system is complete garbage, the community is nasty, the devs punish you with low priority queue (Must play shit games with shit people with a character you don't choose) and the MMR (Match Making Rating) system never resets.
There are no leagues, so you can't feel like you're progressing in any other way than points and skins for your characters.  

Why do I mention no MMR reset being a negative factor?  Because if you unfortunately get too low of a rank at any point you enter the "Spiral of death".  You will be queued primarily with people who don't speak english and who have never played the game before.  
There is no reason someone who plays 4000 hours in a game should ever be paired with a teammate who is on his first day and doesn't know anything about the game.  However, exactly that will happen.
Once you're in this spiral of death it's nearly impossible to get out.  I've had games where I got 30 kills, 1 death, 14 assists and we still lose because the other 4 players are feeding insanely. 

The whole experience could be made much better by simply having seasons where the  MMR resets.  However, the dev's couldn't give two shits about that.  Their entire interest is to get you to buy skins and battle passes.  I've tried to contact the devs over the years on many occasions but never get any response.  And for that, they deserve a bad review.

====================================
Well look at that.  Years and many posts and tweets later -- Dota 2 has leagues with a seasonal MMR Reset.  It only took them 5 years longer than it should have, with me ramming the suggestion into every inbox they had, including facebook for years on end.

Good job dev team. You finally listened to your lord and saviour (me).

Dota 2 is Valve's MOBA title, which is to say it's a real-time strategy game where you literally play the one single map over and over again, but you play as one of 700 characters that in other RTS games would be lategame units or lynchpins of a player's entire army, individual games can take hours, and there's a shop/inventory system for some reason. As a couple of my friends put it, half the features are bugs that got left in because the dev liked them; it's a horrifying mess with a skill floor that starts where other games have a ceiling, and a skill ceiling that may or may not exist.

(Also, the lore depicts the battle represented in the game as a final cataclysm between good and evil that will destroy the world no matter who wins, which is amusing to think about considering how many times it's been played out by the game's millions of fans.)

Taken altogether, Dota 2 seems very much like a product of people who got so incredibly attached to one very particular experience that they built everything else around it - and this is the important part - warts and all. People apparently spend massive amounts of time and money on what is essentially a glorified Warcraft III mod that itself has many mods, though, so it at least proves the viability of game modding.

This is also the product that's mainly responsible for killing the old Valve, the one that produced quality games on a semi-regular basis. Thanks to the massive popularity of Dota, and to an extent Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, Valve was content to sit on their butts iterating on them while screwing around with VR and reaping that store/market/microtransaction money for an entire decade before they managed to stop pretending the franchise that made them didn't exist and release Half-Life: Alyx.

I at least liked the snazzy main menu and the Half-Life 2 doot noises. Inclusion of the Counter-Strike AWP firing noise on the other hand just bewildered me.

This is review for 2020 from perspective of pos 4 player that playes with team members only so this review is more about the competetive side of dota then your casual ranking.

Pros:

-much faster gameplay then it used to be

-with full squad Its still as fun as it used to be

-being one trick pony pays off more

Cons:

-Solo players and team players are 2 different species. If we play in a squad of 4, the random guy most of the time has no idea what is team play.

-Meta play got worse. What I mean by that is, that if you dont play meta heores, you will f*cking lose no matter how good of a player you are. In team vs team games Its all about game strategy, not individual skill and there is not much space for creativity because the op heroes are really op and average heroes are just not good enough.

-Jungle drops after 40 mins are unbalanced, some are really trash in every situation compared to others.

-most meta heroes are not fun to play all the time. Like who the f*ck enjoys playing Viper every game?

-Repetetive gameplay due to the need to pick the same 15 heroes all the time if you want to win.

-RNG, but I mean, that was there since the beginning but its getting progressively worse. Yea, Iam looking at you Ogre.

Conclusion :

I havent played solo in a few years but when it comes to full squad 5 on 5, It got more boring because at higher levels, you have to pick the same shit all the time, which is not fun, or you will lose, which is also not fun.

Fun if you play like 4 games per week, play more and Its boring.

The game as it is--is great. for its an upgraded version of the mod game Dota Allstars. To dota allstars veteran players like me, its a dream come true to perfect our beloved game and modernize it, HOWEVER the toxicity of the community is immense and unbearable, maybe because of the new young players toxic ethics. yes, the community was toxic before but ill tell you its WAY toxic TODAY. Ive spent some years playing league of legends too and ive seen how the community grew more toxic because of young immature players. Dota2 community unfortunately runs toward the same path, as dota1 veteran who plays Dota2 such as me lose faith in the community and lack of humanity. but as of today i still play the game with great passion as if i was playing Dota1 except all my team and enemy team are muted. In out of 50 games, there is only a 1 game where i unmuted my team because they communicate to win and collaborate as a team.  I love the game its a part of me you cant take away every match brings back a lot of good memory so no matter how bad the game is no matter how we clearly lose the game no matter how bad my team i still treat them the best i could i never quit  it never affects me because when i enter the match i become the hero i pick with a goal to win with or without a team to help me, but the community...its a trash more so if you play solo but im not removing the fact that there are humane players among the community.

So piece of advise utilize the mute button and dont get affected by your team and dont quit no matter what, just play the game its amazing master piece.

- ᴀs ᴀ ʙᴜʏ ᴀɴᴅ sᴇʟʟᴇʀ ɪ ɴᴇᴇᴅ ᴛᴏ ʙᴇ sᴜʀᴇ ᴛʜᴀᴛ ʏᴏᴜ ᴀʀᴇ ʀᴇᴀʟʟʏ sᴇʀɪᴏᴜs ᴀʙᴏᴜᴛ ᴛʜᴇ ᴅᴇᴀʟ ᴡᴇ ᴍᴀᴅᴇ ғɪʀsᴛ, ᴅᴜᴇ ᴛᴏ ᴍʏ ᴇxᴘᴇʀɪᴇɴᴄᴇ ɪɴ ᴛʀᴀᴅɪɴɢ. ɪᴠᴇ ʙᴇᴇɴ ғᴏᴏʟᴇᴅ ᴍᴀɴʏ ᴛɪᴍᴇs ʜᴇʀᴇ ɪɴ sᴛᴇᴀᴍ. ᴛʜᴀᴛs ᴡʜʏ ɪ ɴᴇᴇᴅ ᴛᴏ ʙᴇ ᴍᴏʀᴇ ᴄᴀʀᴇғᴜʟ ʙᴇғᴏʀᴇ ɪʟʟ sᴘᴇɴᴅ ᴍʏ ᴍᴏɴᴇʏ ɪɴ ʙᴜʏɪɴɢ ᴛʜᴇ ɪᴛᴇᴍs ᴛʜᴀᴛ ᴡᴇ ʜᴀᴠᴇ ᴀɢʀᴇᴇᴅ. ɪ ɴᴇᴇᴅ ᴛᴏ ʙᴇ sᴜʀᴇ ᴛʜᴀᴛ ᴡʜɪʟᴇ ɪᴍ ʙᴜʏɪɴɢ ᴛʜᴀᴛ ʏᴏᴜ ᴀʀᴇ sᴇʀɪᴏᴜs ᴀɴᴅ ʟᴇɢɪᴛ ᴛʀᴀᴅᴇʀ. ᴀɴᴅ ʏᴏᴜ ᴡɪʟʟ ɴᴏᴛ ᴊᴜsᴛ ʙᴀᴄᴋ ᴏᴜᴛ ᴀɴᴅ ᴀᴄᴄᴇᴘᴛ ᴏᴛʜᴇʀ ʜɪɢʜᴇʀ ᴏғғᴇʀ ᴛʜᴀɴ ᴍɪɴᴇ, ᴡʜɪʟᴇ ɪᴍ ʙᴜʏɪɴɢ ᴛʜᴇ ɪᴛᴇᴍs ɪ ᴏғғᴇʀᴇᴅ ʏᴏᴜ.

-ɪ ᴄᴀɴ ᴀʙʟᴇ ᴛᴏ ᴘʀᴏᴠɪᴅᴇ ᴘʀᴏᴏғ ᴛʜᴀᴛ ɪ ʜᴀᴠᴇ ᴛʜᴇ sᴜғғɪᴄɪᴇɴᴛ ʙᴀʟᴀɴᴄᴇ ᴏɴ ʙɪᴛsᴋɪɴs ɪɴ ᴏʀᴅᴇʀ ᴛᴏ ᴘᴜʀᴄʜᴀsᴇ ᴛʜᴇ ɪᴛᴇᴍ, ᴊᴜsᴛ ᴛᴏ ᴘʀᴏᴠᴇ ᴛᴏ ʏᴏᴜ ɪ ᴀᴍ sᴇʀɪᴏᴜs ᴀʙᴏᴜᴛ ᴍʏ ᴏғғᴇʀ.

If you haven't played this game, you owe it to yourself. It's one of the best written and immersive stories I've played in gaming. Geralt is such a great character. The rest of the cast, DLC included, is also a highlight. This is one of those games that justify being semi-open world. There's so much to do, but not only that, almost everything ends up in unexpected ways. It's a fantastic experience, however, I do have to warn new players cause that happened to me, so here are my bullet points:

* Even though the games makes an effort to introduce characters from the books in a digestible, it not always sticks the landing. Expect to read the glossary or wikis to get the full context. This might throw some players off. It's not necessary to have played the previous games or read the books, nevertheless, the Witcher 3 regards legacy players.

* White Orchard (the first area) is not well paced at all. It's long and the systems are not described well enough, thus it is easy to get lost. On top of that, it's a slow burner of a game. I encourage you to continue playing until you reach the bloody baron. At the risk of sounding like a typical obsessed fan: the game does get better after the 10 hour mark. 

* The combat is awful. Get used to dodge/roll/parry and then attack, depending on the enemy. Igni is your best sign so use it a lot. I do recommend using potions early on since Blood and Wine (the last dlc) is very potion/oil oriented. Get used to it during the main game or Heart of Stone. You'll thank me laters.

Overall, as I said, a fantastic experience. Although it's not one that will be enjoyed from the moment you boot up the game. Give it time and you'll find yourself in a game you will not want to put down until the very end.

I will leave this analysis completely spontaneously and from the foundation of the soul. Many games have influenced me and made me fall in love with them since childhood, but very few have moved my heart and spirit so much. I think this is the main purpose of art, it is to create an emotional manifest in a unique way in each being. The Witcher 3 is not only possibly the greatest game in gaming history, it is possibly the greatest masterpiece you will ever experience in an in-game virtual world. 

If we take all the foundations that make up a work, like a perfect cinema movie, we will evaluate soundtrack, photography, story/plot, dialogues, characters, costumes, sound, intensity, immersion, and so on. Well, you'll simply find everything here in this game, at such an exorbitant and impeccable level that it's even difficult to conceive how it was made, planned, thought and executed. Conclude the game, scrutinize it to the fullest, not only doing secondary Quests, but everything possible and I reach a final verdict here. 

The Witcher 3 is the best game in my life, it is the game that will move you in every possible way, it will make you cry, laugh, nurture joy, inspire, including for your own personal life. The complete experience of this game will make you reflect and look for something more in your life, live a great remarkable story full of adventures and wonderful stories. All this for a measly few of bucks, so stop buying crappy new poorly made game for expensive price, and be a grateful person for the rest of your life for finding my comment and having lived a once-in-a-lifetime experience (if you've never played). Do I recommend? I recommend it for people who want to live great stories in their lives.

Vou deixar esta análise de forma totalmente espontânea e do alicerce da alma. Muitos jogos me marcaram e me fizeram me apaixonar desde a infância, mas pouquíssimos mexeram tanto com o coração e o espírito. Acho que esse é o principal intuito da arte, é criar um manifesto emocional de forma única em cada ser. The Witcher 3 não é só possivelmente o maior jogo da história dos jogos, ele é possivelmente a maior obra artística que você poderá experienciar num mundo virtual in-game. 

Se pegarmos todos os alicerces que compõem uma obra, como um filme perfeito do cinema, nós avaliaremos trilha sonora, fotografia, história/enredo, diálogos, personagens, figurino, som, intensidade, imersão, e assim por diante. Bom, você simplesmente encontrará tudo aqui neste jogo, num nível tão exorbitante e impecável que é até difícil de conceber como foi feito, planejado, pensado e executado. Conclui o jogo, esmiucei ele ao máximo, não só fazendo Quests secundárias, como tudo que é possível e chego num veredito final aqui. 

The Witcher 3 é o melhor jogo da minha vida, é o jogo que vai te emocionar em todos os sentidos possíveis, vai te fazer chorar, rir, nutrir alegrias, inspirar, inclusive para sua própria vida pessoal. A experiência completa deste game fará você refletir e buscar por algo a mais na sua vida, viver uma grande história marcante cheia de aventuras e histórias maravilhosas. Tudo isso por míseros 20 reais, então para de comprar porcaria de jogo novo mal feito por 400 reais, e seja uma pessoa grata pelo resto da vida por encontrar meu comentário e ter vivido uma experiência única de vida (caso nunca tenha jogado). Se recomendo? Recomendo para pessoas que querem viver grandes histórias em suas vidas.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece, but you already knew that. What you might not know is that it's not just a game; it's a life simulator, a monster masher, and a Gwent addiction all rolled into one. Geralt, our white-haired, gruff-voiced hero, manages it all with the style of a medieval James Bond.

Pros:

Gorgeous landscapes: If you're not pausing to take in the breathtaking vistas of Toussaint or Skellige, are you even playing The Witcher 3?
Gwent: It's like the Pokemon of the Witcher world, and I gotta catch 'em all! Why save Ciri when you can build a deck and play Gwent with random strangers for hours?
Beards: Geralt's beard growth is like a plant that only grows when you're not looking at it. Don't blink, or you'll miss his five-o'clock shadow.
Roach: She's the best horse, the worst horse, and a teleporting horse all in one. Roach, you magical enigma!
Cons:

Witcher senses: Ever wanted to feel like a detective in a world where every crime scene is conveniently marked with a glowing red trail? Welcome to Witcher vision!
Bathing optional: Geralt will slay monsters, woo sorceresses, and conquer empires, but he just won't take a bath. It's like he's allergic to soap.
Romance complications: Trying to please both Triss and Yennefer is like trying to juggle flaming swords while riding a unicycle. Choose one and brace for a fury fiercer than any beast in the game.
In summary, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is the game that proves you can save the world, win Gwent tournaments, and be an epic lover all in a day's work. But most importantly, it's a lesson in multitasking: fight a griffin, play Gwent, get the girl. Just don't forget to wash behind those witcher ears.

[b] ABOUT | [/b] Geralt of the Rivia in the Witcher III, is assigned to track his law of surprise child. Ciri was hunted down by Eredin, the king of Wild Hunt.

[b] STORY: [/b] Can’t describe it. You have to feel it yourself how amazing the adventure of Geralt is. It is a rich story game with a bunch of plots that has every consequences. Every choice will decide the ending of the game. Sometimes you can choose, sometimes you do have any choices. There is no a good or bad decision, it is all on you. 
 
[b] GAMEPLAY: [/b] A great hack and slash game with a lot of combinations. You have two swords, signs, mutagen ability and utility that will accompany you through the entire game. Every aspect for combat in this game is important to be mastered. 

[b] GRAPHIC: [/b] Excellent, beautiful, and stunning visual.

[b] ACHIEVEMENT: [/b] All achievements can be gained through most of the time, but you need a lot of efforts. I finished the achievements within 270 hours. 

[b] PROBLEM: [/b] The next-gen update of the Witcher 3 is really stunning, but it will cost you a higher gear. I tried the classic version of the game that can be obtained through properties-betas-classic version. It has a better and stable performance if you have decent gear. 

Thanks for every adventure, White Wolf!

MY FAVORITE GAME OF ALL TIME

The Witcher 3 is an absolute masterpiece in the world of video games. From the moment I started playing, I was completely immersed in its rich, detailed world. The depth of the storytelling is unparalleled, with a gripping narrative that kept me engaged for hours on end. The character development is exceptional, with each character feeling fully realized and integral to the overall plot.

The game's open-world environment is breathtaking, with stunning landscapes that truly bring the game to life. Whether it's navigating through the dense, dark forests or exploring the bustling cities, every corner of the world feels meticulously crafted and teeming with life. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the intricate design of the armor and weapons to the subtle nuances in the behavior of the NPCs.

The combat system can be seen as quite simple and bland, but I think its fluid and satisfying, offering a perfect balance between strategy and action. The variety of monsters and enemies keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting, with each encounter presenting a new challenge that requires careful planning and skillful execution. Especially when playing on the hardest difficulty "Death march", that in my opinion makes the game shine the most. 

Moreover, the game's side quests are not mere fillers but engaging stories in their own right, often with unexpected twists and meaningful consequences that impact the overall narrative. The choices presented to the player are morally complex, making every decision feel weighty and consequential. I would repeatedly be stuck at many different choices during my different playtrues. 

It's a rare gem that combines exceptional storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and immersive gameplay seamlessly. With its rich lore, compelling characters, and unparalleled attention to detail, The Witcher 3 stands as a pinnacle of the RPG genre and sets a standard that few other games can hope to achieve. It's an experience that lingers long after the game is turned off, leaving a lasting impression that few games can match. Even got me, as a non-ordinary reader to read all the Witcher books and furthermore, play the previous games. Moreover, I would replay the Witcher 3 occasionally every year because its just so fun to jump back into! I would highly recommend this game to anyone, especially when its often on sale for a bargain of a price.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - A Riveting Tale That Defies Genre Conventions

In an industry often besieged by formulaic sequels and uninspired narratives, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a towering testament to the power of immersive storytelling in the gaming world. CD Projekt Red's magnum opus isn't merely another entry in a popular franchise; it's an expansive, deeply engrossing journey that defies the constraints of its genre, weaving a complex narrative tapestry that resonates long after the final credits roll.

At the heart of The Witcher 3 lies a narrative so intricately woven that it transcends the boundaries of video game storytelling. This isn't your typical hero's journey; it's a deeply human exploration of complex moral dilemmas, political intrigue, and the blurred lines between good and evil. The game's masterful storytelling allows players to navigate morally ambiguous choices, presenting a nuanced world where every decision has far-reaching consequences, making it one of the most captivating and intellectually stimulating narratives in modern gaming.

The game's meticulously crafted open world of Temeria is a visual and atmospheric marvel. From the sun-drenched fields of Velen to the hauntingly beautiful Skellige Isles, each locale is painstakingly detailed, brimming with life, and steeped in rich lore. The depth of the world-building is nothing short of remarkable, immersing players in a living, breathing realm where every corner tells a story and every character carries a weight that goes beyond their scripted lines.

Moreover, the expansion packs, "Hearts of Stone" and "Blood and Wine," aren't mere cash-grabbing add-ons, but full-fledged narratives that rival the main game in both scope and emotional depth. They seamlessly integrate with the base game, offering new lands to explore, characters to meet, and stories to unravel, demonstrating a level of care and dedication to storytelling that is rare in the industry. CD Projekt Red's commitment to delivering substantial, story-driven content without compromising the game's artistic integrity is a testament to their respect for the player's experience and a stark contrast to the predatory practices seen in contemporary gaming.

Despite its occasional technical shortcomings, such as minor glitches and performance issues, The Witcher 3's ambition and attention to detail far outweigh its flaws. It demands patience and investment, rewarding players with a deeply satisfying and emotionally resonant experience that lingers long after the controller is set down. It's a game that transcends mere entertainment, leaving an indelible mark on the player's psyche and challenging the very notion of what a video game can achieve in terms of narrative complexity and emotional depth.

Furthermore, The Witcher 3's evocative musical score, composed by Marcin Przybyłowicz, with contributions from renowned folk band Percival Schuttenbach, serves as a powerful emotional undercurrent, enhancing the game's already immersive world. The haunting melodies and rousing anthems underscore pivotal moments in the narrative, evoking a range of emotions that further cement the game's ability to resonate on a deeply personal level. The synergy between the game's visuals, narrative, and musical score creates an atmospheric symphony that transports players into the heart of the Witcher universe.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a seminal achievement in the realm of video game storytelling, offering a profoundly human and thought-provoking experience that elevates the medium to the realm of high art. It's not just a game; it's a transformative journey that reminds us of the power of interactive storytelling and the potential of the medium to provoke introspection and emotional resonance. For anyone seeking an unforgettable and deeply immersive narrative experience, The Witcher 3 is an absolute must-play that stands as a landmark in the evolution of video game storytelling.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a triumphant testament to the power of storytelling in video games, an epic journey that immerses players in a richly detailed world filled with unforgettable characters, breathtaking landscapes, and a narrative that keeps you engaged from the very beginning to the bittersweet end.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, the iconic Witcher, you are thrust into a realm that oozes authenticity and originality. CD Projekt Red's creation is a masterclass in open-world game design, meticulously crafted and teeming with life. The Northern Realms and beyond are a testament to the developers' attention to detail, as each locale, whether a bustling city or a quiet village, feels alive with its unique culture, history, and inhabitants.

But what truly sets The Witcher 3 apart is its unrivaled storytelling. The game's narrative is a dark, gritty, and morally complex tale that grips your heart and mind, refusing to let go. The choices you make throughout the game have real consequences, affecting not only Geralt but the world around him. The choices are never simple, and they make you question your own morality and the shades of gray that exist in this cruel and unforgiving world.

The characters in The Witcher 3 are nothing short of extraordinary. Geralt, the grizzled monster slayer, is both relatable and enigmatic, a hero burdened by his own flaws. The supporting cast, including the charismatic bard Dandelion, the fierce sorceress Yennefer, and the enigmatic Ciri, all come to life with remarkable depth and complexity. Their interactions and stories are as compelling as Geralt's, making the game's world feel dynamic and engaging.

Combat in The Witcher 3 is a thrilling ballet of steel and magic. Geralt's array of combat styles, potions, and spells allow for diverse and strategic gameplay. The monstrous foes he faces are varied and challenging, each with its own set of weaknesses and tactics, making every battle a test of wits and skill.

The visuals in The Witcher 3 are nothing short of breathtaking. The game's graphics and art direction create an unparalleled atmosphere, making you feel like you've been transported to a world of knights, magic, and monsters. The weather effects, day-night cycle, and the interplay of light and shadow all contribute to the game's immersive beauty.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Marcin Przybyłowicz, is a symphonic masterpiece that perfectly complements the epic scope of the game. From the haunting melodies that play as you explore the Skellige Isles to the powerful, adrenaline-pumping battle themes, the music of The Witcher 3 is a key element in creating an emotional connection to the game.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a triumph of storytelling, world-building, and character development. It's a game that not only sets a new standard for open-world RPGs but also demonstrates the potential of video games as a medium for immersive storytelling. With its breathtaking world, morally complex choices, and unforgettable characters, The Witcher 3 is a game that will be remembered as a classic for years to come. If you haven't embarked on this epic journey yet, do yourself a favor and dive into the rich and enthralling world of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. You won't be disappointed.

Very good, pleasant and beautiful game. Every gamer who respects themselves must pass the game. 
pros: 
1) Beautiful graphics, very good optimization almost all low end pc can run this game on normal settings
2) Impressive and extensive storyline that complements the books and previous games.
3) Medieval atmosphere that immerses you completely.
4) Really good English voice acting—far superior to the buggy and poor russian version.
5) Comfortable interface
cons: 
1) Casual fights, sigh abuse, roll abuse, potion abuse, etc. I completed the game on deathmatch mode very easily without side quests, potions, and rolling abuse. Only a few bosses gave me trouble, but after 2-3 tries, I passed them easily.
2) Rpg but without choices. There are only 3-4 major choices and that's all. Shame you had to pick 3 correct script choices to save Ciri, it's feels very stupid in the last cat-scene and that was the worst part of the game.

Overall the game is must play

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's a masterpiece, an interactive magnum opus that deserves to be celebrated as one of the greatest achievements in the world of gaming. After spending 48.6 hours navigating the treacherous yet enchanting world of Geralt of Rivia, it's evident that this game has set a new standard for open-world RPGs.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Geralt, you are transported to a sprawling, meticulously crafted open world that is nothing short of breathtaking. The Northern Kingdoms are a sight to behold, featuring diverse landscapes, each with its own unique charm. The dense forests, rolling hills, bustling cities, and windswept Skellige Isles make every corner of the world feel authentic and alive.

The narrative in The Witcher 3 is a saga of unparalleled depth and complexity. As Geralt, a monster hunter with a moral code, you are on a quest to find your adopted daughter, Ciri, who is pursued by an otherworldly force known as the Wild Hunt. The narrative is more than just a story; it's an odyssey that explores themes of destiny, family, and the blurred lines between good and evil.

What sets The Witcher 3 apart is the attention to detail in character development and storytelling. Every character you meet feels fleshed out, with their own motivations, histories, and moral ambiguities. You are faced with moral choices, each with significant consequences, and the game's ability to blur the lines between right and wrong is nothing short of brilliant.

Gameplay in The Witcher 3 is a well-crafted fusion of action, RPG, and exploration. The combat system is refined, offering depth and challenge. Geralt's abilities and Witcher signs allow for varied approaches to battles, from swordplay to the use of powerful magic. Hunting down and defeating the game's vast array of mythical creatures is an adventure in itself.

Gwent, a card game within the game, is a brilliant addition, offering an engrossing and strategic diversion that can keep you entertained for hours. The game's expansion packs introduce more Gwent cards and quests, adding depth to the experience.

The side quests in The Witcher 3 are not mere diversions; they are compelling narratives in their own right. Each quest feels like a story, with its own moral dilemmas and emotional weight. You can spend hours exploring the game's vast world, uncovering hidden stories, and helping or harming its inhabitants.

The game's audio design is another standout feature. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, composed by Marcin Przybyłowicz, adds depth to every moment, from the tension of combat to the melancholy of exploration. The voice acting is top-notch, with Doug Cockle delivering a performance that brings Geralt to life.

In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a work of art in the gaming world. After 48.6 hours of immersion, you've likely just scratched the surface of what this monumental game has to offer. It's an epic that defies expectations, delivering an unparalleled experience in storytelling, character development, and world-building. The game's refusal to shy away from the complexities of morality and human nature sets it apart, making it not just a game but a journey that will stay with you long after you've put down the controller. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming, and it deserves to be celebrated as a true masterpiece.

As a kid, I had a very dark soul, and the shadows of loneliness enveloped me. My solitary existence was my constant companion, leaving me feeling like an outsider in a world that I perceived as unrelentingly harsh. My solace came from Limp Bizkit's music, whose angsty tunes resonated deeply with my troubled soul. Fred Durst's raw and emotional lyrics were the soundtrack to my life, speaking to the darkness that consumed me.

But then, I discovered Dark Souls Remastered on Steam, a game that would alter the course of my journey. Just like Limp Bizkit's intense music, the game plunged me into a world of shadows, challenging me at every turn. It felt like I was confronting the abyss within me, just as Limp Bizkit's lyrics had done for years.

The brutal difficulty and relentless enemies in Dark Souls Remastered taught me lessons that Limp Bizkit's music couldn't. It was a reflection of my own life – failures, setbacks, and relentless struggles. And much like Limp Bizkit's music, the game showed me that even in the darkest moments, there are glimpses of light.

The game's intricate level design and hauntingly beautiful landscapes hinted at the hope that I'd never allowed myself to see before. It was as if Fred Durst's lyrics had come to life in the game, reminding me that even the darkest souls have pockets of brightness.

Just like Limp Bizkit's music served as my therapy, Dark Souls Remastered became my escape and a source of inspiration. It helped me confront the abyss within my soul and provided the strength to overcome it. I realized that, much like Limp Bizkit's music, there's redemption even in the darkest corners of life.

As I write this review, I can't help but draw parallels between my life, Limp Bizkit's music, and Dark Souls Remastered. They've all been essential in guiding me from darkness to light, proving that even the darkest souls can be remastered and can have spaces where it's bright and light sometimes.

TLDR: Limp Bizkit's music, like Dark Souls Remastered, shines a light on the darkest corners of the soul. Both have shown me that even the darkest souls can find redemption, just like Limp Bizkit's lyrics resonate in the darkest moments of life.

So the hours posted here are wrong. I've been playing this game way longer, but I originally was on Xbox. I actually have around 900 hours in this game, but regardless I'm not here to brag about playtime. I'm here to review one of my favorite games of all time, while also shitting on how this is a horrible remaster. This game, as a lot of people know, is absolutely amazing. From its interconnected world, to its methodical and intricate combat, this game is a joy. I don't want to go way too in depth over the game itself, as this is the REMASTERED version, not the original. All you really need to know is if you're considering Dark Souls, then buy it and give it a shot. Worst case scenario you can refund it if it's not for you! If this is up your alley, however, then prepare yourself for a magical experience until you kill O&S and it goes down to being just a pretty good experience (then it becomes a masterpiece then with Artorias of the Abyss). One other thing, though, this is a wiki game. Just like games like Terraria and Barotrauma, this game wants you to look at the wiki and learn about it, as it's super convoluted. Don't feel ashamed for checking out the wiki!
Anyways, onto the remastered part: it sucks. I wasn't lucky enough to get PtDE before it got delisted, but looking at comparisons they are next to the same thing given you install a performance mod for PtDE that is widely available and easy to use. If you own PtDE, this game is just as dead so don't bother getting it for the multiplayer. This was how I got started as a sunbro, but it's dead now just like the original. As with the Vampire Survivors review, I won't be putting a number score here because number scores are BS in my opinion, but my overall verdict is that it's still Dark Souls I, but if you already own another version of DS1 then don't bother.

Hard at first. But with each boss you kill, each enemy you slaughter, and with each time you yourself are ended. you will begin to learn the tells of a swing and the spacing of your sword. you will scrape at bosses until you grovel out a victory, you will make death runs until you can do it with your eyes closed, you will kill the same enemies over and over again. But for what you ask? It certainly is not fun to die and run back just to do it again. Well my friend, its when you first learn to parry the black knights, when you finally kill that one boss, when you find the coolest looking Armour, when you forge a great weapon out of souls and sweat, when after you have fought tooth and nail you come out on top. This game is great because its hard and unforgiving, This game is great because even though it was hard and unforgiving you didn't give up. Its great because it challenges you and respects the efforts you put into it. --- In short, I recommend this game to any who have not dared to play something so challenging, because it will show you what you can do if you really try. ---

What if you built an entire game around the respawn? What if THE RESPAWN were a game mechanic? I don’t know if this game is for me. I’m trying, but I feel as if the game punishes me for exploration. Combat is so rigid and tanklike, but not impossible. Still, every enemy does enormous damage and takes so many hit points to defeat. Took me a few tries to beat the first boss, but I did it. Everything after that has been so awkward. I meet skeletons, but fighting them is not worth it. What I’m reading about the game says it’s damn near impossible to conquer it without taking tips from the community, which tells me to avoid combat as much as possible and collect items instead. But what are these items? Why am I collecting them?

Why are minor enemies such a MAJOR EVENT to fight? Challenge stems from the clunky combat controls instead of anything deliberate. When I die, often it’s because the game didn’t respond when I wanted to roll, or didn’t block when I pushed the button. So far I’m not enjoying this, all of these stats and items. Why can’t I assign a throwing item to a quick slot for easy use? I can’t explore without facing enemies I can’t defeat. I can’t fight. I can’t outrun most of the enemies. What am I doing?

The whole game seems to be built around the idea of respawning: the game will kill you over and over, but that’s ok because you can just go back and figure out how to proceed from there. [b]When I progress, I don’t feel as if I’m getting better at the game’s internal logic, rather that I’m bypassing the game.[/b] What is the point of combat if you’re not supposed to fight most of the enemies? So far, I am not a fan of Dark Souls.

An undeniable amazing game of it's time, and still an unforgettable game 13 years later. Although the game severely falls flat in the egregiously unfinished second half of the game (Not including DLC). The bosses are rushed, the enemies are boring, and the level design is either unnecessarily frustrating or just plain out ridiculous. Don't let that take away from the experience of the game as a whole, the entirety of the first half of the game is near perfect, the soundtrack throughout stays consistently top of the line, and a memorable art/designs direction.

It's important to also take into account that this game is supposed to be a 'remaster', which is an absolute disgrace and money scam. It's a port with a a remaster on the price tag. 

Aside from the what i previously stated about the latter half of the game, the rest of the game is the exact opposite. An ingeniously connected overarching map, extremely hard but CONSISTENTLY fair enemies and bosses, innovative combat and movement, and an unforgettable experience.

As a essentially the father to the souls series, it's impossible to not notice the influence this game has had on the gaming industry as a whole. If the team had more budget to finish the second half of the game, this game would be a goddamn masterpiece. I would highly recommend a try.

100% completed. Excellent game for people wanting a challenge; reminds me quite a bit of Hollow Knight. It's very fun and worthy of spending many days on to fully complete its storyline and maybe even go above and beyond with the achievements. I will admit, however, I feel like there's a lot of functions in this game that's left unexplained and likely will leave the player to have to research things. There are a few places you need to go that can't be unlocked until you get certain things (which aren't specified), in order to cast pyromancies/miracles/sorceries you need to have the appropriate conduit wielded (which wasn't explained), the stats at the start aren't elaborated on nor is there really an option to see what they affect, and I had no idea until about halfway into my first playthrough that there are different paths you can ascend your weapons to (i.e. lightning, magic, fire, etc.). So unless you know a lot about Dark Souls in advance before playing, you may have some trouble figuring some things out throughout the game. However, these downsides are not enough to get me to dislike the game. It was incredibly fun even with these quirks. I highly would recommend purchasing this game, and maybe the others in the series too :)

I remember having first played this a few years ago back on the Xbox 360. I wasn't able to make it past the bell gargoyles, and actually was sorta hardly able to make it past the Taurus demon.

Well, that's changed this time around, I've finally beaten the game! It only took, what, 55 hours? I'm sure if I ever play it again, that it'll take maybe half the time. 

My thoughts on the game are vastly different than they were when I was playing this on my old 360; I had thought the game was wayyyy too difficult. Now I think that it's an experience of a game that most of everyone should play, or at least try to. The first half at least, the second half is certainly... Something. The whole game takes a noticeable drop of quality after Anor Londo, a criticism I'm sure that everyone under the sun remotely interested in DS1 has heard. If the entire game was built like the second half was, I'm sure that this game wouldn't have made as big of a ripple across the entire gaming scene as it did, in fact I'm positive it would have killed this entire series, and with it the souls-like genre.

But yeah, almost perfect game.

Honestly, I fucking hate this game. It's my least favorite Fromsoft game that I've played. It's not necessarily a bad game but a large part of the difficulty meme for this specific game is based off of how janky everything is. Hitboxes and collision are insanely inconsistent, my character would randomly fall off of rounded surfaces during platforming segments and then there's wild things like enemies backstabbing you from the side while you're in mid-air. A lot of the maps in this game are horribly designed (fuck whoever designed Tomb of Giants) and some enemies are extremely unbalanced. I've played through DS1 multiple times and every playthrough feels the same, the game is hard and frustrating because of it's legitimate difficulty but a larger part of it is the poor design. It would  be nice to see this get a proper remake like Demon Souls received.

[b]tl;dr[/b] - Play Dark Souls III, Elden Ring, Sekiro or Bloodborne instead.

Don't get me wrong: I enjoyed myself. This is a fun game that will certainly offer an experience you won't soon regret or forget. There's many interesting locations to explore, with a connected world that truly feels alive, and which brings all kinds of dark fantasy to life for you to enjoy.

That said, this game has aged like milk. The combat is clunky and at times unresponsive, and the difficulty of the game usually comes from being swarmed by a large group of enemies rather than any interesting combat mechanic.

Boss fights are surprisingly easy and just not very interesting. They're all too slow and pose very little threat compared to the swarm of enemies you've been fighting in the open world. The only three difficult boss fights include a coin toss in a tiny arena against some demon dude and two dogs, a not-so-fair 2v1, and a fight where the most used strategy is literally to save and quit.

Most of your time in the game will be spent running back to wherever you got killed, running pass everything and avoiding interacting with the game. You'll spend way more time just running back to your corpse or a boss arena than exploring or actually fighting anything, and it gets grating.

I couldn't tell you what the plot is about. Almost all important plot points are way too cryptic to understand at a glance, which is a shame because the stories this land has to tell are actually really interesting... too bad the game doesn't really want to tell you about them. A game shouldn't have to rely on fan content for you to make basic sense of its story.

[b]Don't make this your first Souls game[/b] and only play it once you've got some experience with future (better) games and only if you're curious to see where Dark Souls started. If your friend wants you to play this game blind, chances are they wanna see you suffer and have fun at your expense.

Everything this game does, is done better in future games. Dark Souls III, Elden Ring, Sekiro and Bloodborne have way more responsive and engaging combat, way better movement, and stories just as interesting. Play those instead, and only come back here once you know what you're doing.

Dark souls is my first fromsoft game and boy has it completely changed my view on gaming.
This game would break your soul, your controller and maybe even your monitor, and its worth each one of those things. its a once in a lifetime experience. To think that a game released 13 years ago, would not only stand up to modern gaming standards, but far surpass it, tells you all there is to know about this one.

the good - 

The NPCs of this game are some of the best ones i have encountered in any game. You almost start to connect with them and root for them to achieve their targets.

the combat is by far the best combat mechanics i have ever experienced. I was playing lies of P and dark souls side by side, and it is mind blowing how this 13 year old games combat matched, if not surpassed, the latest edition of soulslike on the market.

the bosses - some of the best. you need to strategise and analyse each one of them and plan your attacks accordingly. gives one a weird feeling of achievement for defeating a virtual enemy.



the bad -
that being said, the game is EXTREMELY frustrating. there are very few checkpoints and for some bosses you need to fight a dozen soldiers before you get a shot at them again. but its all about getting it.. once you get it - believe me this game would still beat your ass and humble you : D.

looking forward to the second and third iterations of this game!

I've been a fan of the Souls series for years, and have played all of them from Demon's Souls to Elden Ring. However, one game in the series always stood out as unique from the others--specifically, in that I hated it. For years, I not only considered Dark Souls 2 to be the weakest entry in the series, but also considered to be an outright bad, poorly designed game.

However, after hearing online that the true problems with DS2 lay in its "remaster", Scholar of the First Sin. So I gave Vanilla a chance, and I was shocked to discover that I absolutely loved my experience. The overwhelming ganks and thoughtlessly-placed enemies were nowhere to be seen. Instead, the game actually felt like it was designed to be a fair challenge, as opposed to a dogshit Kaizo Dark Souls ROM hack.

Is DS2 a perfect game? No. There are still weird choices such as the need to level up Adaptability, the bosses tend to go for quantity over quality and are all kind of clunky and too easy. The areas can be a bit bland, and the level design somewhat flat and forgettable. But Dark Souls 2 is still a really good game. You just gotta get this version--NOT Scholar.

I used to play this game quite a bit and I enjoyed it. But that was back when Dark Souls: PTDE was the only alternative which at the time still had major performance issues and was still using GFWL for online play.
Dark Souls 2 offered a stable experience and working online.

Something that Dark Souls 2 also had was better build variety. I remember playing Dark Souls 1 and trying to use the dragon bone fists and having a miserable time. But in Dark Souls 2 you could use whatever and still make it through the game without issues.

I did a lot of PVP in this game, probably more that I did in the other titles. I've heard people say that it has the BEST pvp, but to me it is not because the PVP is good but rather Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring did a worse job with it. Even back in it's prime invasions outside of the main pvp areas were really rare, probably because people had to farm eye orbs, and those who didn't want to do that just stuck to the arena and bell towers.

I stopped playing after Dark Souls 3 came out and never came back until many years later to play with a few friends who had never played it before. 
Having stepped away from the game for a while and then coming back made me realize that I had ignored a lot of the flaws of the game just because the game offered a few things that Dark Souls 1 did not. But now that Elden Ring and Dark Souls 3 are around they also offer the same things, so now it's now longer unique to Dark Souls 2.

What unique things Dark Souls 2 had left are mostly negative.
Lets start:
-Level design isn't great. A lot of the areas are a pain to explore and a slog to get through. I've heard people praise the game for being non-linear but that really isn't true. It's true that you have some paths to choose in the first half of the game, but the paths themselves are pretty linear and the second half of the game is entirely linear.
- The bosses aren't so great. There quite a few bosses in this game and the average one is pretty mediocre with less than a handful being actually good. Even some of the major bosses are forgettable.
- Weapons are made of glass. Your weapons break very frequently.
- Armor isn't worth it. Armor provides very little protection against physical damage.
- Adaptability was a bad idea. No point in wearing lighter armor for more I-frames because you still need to level ADP anyway.
- General hitbox and reaction issues.

There's probably more that I can't think of right now.

There really isn't anything this game has to offer that makes the slog worth it. And it's a long slog.
I also feel like a lot of praise I hear for this game is either reaching really hard, being disingenuous, or outright false. I don't believe that this game is good let alone "the best" anything.

After trying Sotfs and utterly despising it, I'd heard that actually the vanilla game was better, for having less petrified npcs, less ganky enemy locations and a whole host of other things. And yes it is better.
It's still dogshit though: on my sotfs playthrough, I managed to get to the sinner's rise and couldn't kill the boss due to being massively under-levelled, and then couldn't progress any further due not having levelled adaptability (no guide run) and not having enough fragrant branches of yore to literally open up one of the mandatory routes. In this run, I got all the way to the Iron Keep and was making runs on Smelter Demon, it took me about 7 hours to get there due to the fact that life gems break the game's balance and let me first try every boss (and if you say "don't use them then", the game punishes you for using estus only due to how slow they are to use and actually heal you). Once making runs on the Demon I'd had it and finally did myself a favour and quit.
I could list all the minor - and major - complaints I have with this game but my biggest one is just that it's boring: the world is devoid of life, and not in the way that it should be in a Dark Souls game, I was always aware that I was playing the game, unlike in other FromSoftware games where I'm able to get into the world. Every area seemed to consist of one, two if lucky, or three at an absolute max bonfires and were so small that they weren't anything but just different textured pits where enemies could be put; there was no creativity to be found in them, the odd npc but even then they were all foreigners who had no tie to that area of the game. And on top of that, it seems that I'm dissuaded from actually engaging with the lore through item descriptions and so on because this game seems to want to hammer home the whole "did you get it? did you get that nothing lasts for every? nothing lasts forever and you'll go crazy and the world doesn't make sense!" line. What's the point of trying to learn about all the different kingdoms, Mirrah being one, only for you to know that the answer will just be "it doesn't make sense isn't it so cool".
There's nothing of substance to this game, it's built on gimmicks on gimmicks; and the foremost gimmick is the misunderstanding of what Dark Souls, and in a larger way FromSoftware is about: difficulty.

DS2 is the least enjoyable out of the Soulsborne games made by Fromsoftware. 

It has some positives: build variety, interconnected levels with initial freedom, dual wielding, NG+ features. 

It has some odd choices: losing max health on death, "physics", clunky tutorial, life gems, no choice to start offline.

And it has some shi~~y things:  Adaptability, very 'videogamey' levels, inconsistent enemy design (scorpion people, elephant people, dwarfs, fire strippers, weeb knights.) Gank squad bosses, hoards of enemies plonked in the world to overwhelm you,  Copy/Paste DLC that doubles down on a lot of the negatives from the base game.

But that said it's still Dark Souls and if you've played and replayed all the others then you'll play this too.

Multiplayer is full of immortal cheaters so don't believe people who say DS2 has the best multiplayer.

Also i don't think the Scholar of the First Sin version is superior it's merely modified.

Edit: I also forgot how awful the DLC is. Both times that I've played DS2 I've checked out playing the crown of the weeb king. The DLC is low quality cash grab plagued by reused assets and zero creativity.

DS2 is.. unique. I think I enjoyed it more than the first. I definitely had a lot more fun mechanically.. but there are a few faults. 

For one, I played in offline mode which made getting through some parts of explorations dicey since having to do a certain thing to make a boss more bearable wasn't immediately obvious and caused me to have to run around lost for a good while. Also enemies stop spawning eventually unless you join a covenant to farm with, which was kind of annoying since I didn't figure that out until nearly done with the game and was starved for souls and materials later on.

My biggest gripe would come from the end of the 3rd DLC though, where they put you in a snowy biome and  then blind you with white for 30 seconds only to let you see for 3 seconds. All the while you're being bombarded by enemies that spawn in the snow-fog. They did give one location to figure out where to go though... in the form of a blinding white light on top of the blinding white snowstorm. \o/

As far as souls games go, I liked it about 30% more than Darksouls 1, but I haven't tried ds3 yet.

What a pleasant surprise

My journey in this series started with Elden Ring. After that i played DS3 and DS1. I was a bit hesitant to buy DS2 because, well...it's by many considered to be the worst of the series. With the latest sale i thought "what the hell - lets do this" and bought it - and i am really glad that i did.

To be fair, the start of the game is a bit rough and for the first 1 or 2 hours i was not really happy with what i was playing. But the more i got into the (sometimes rather contrived) mechanics of the game, the more i enjoyed it. Even after finishing it, i'm still puzzled by some of its design mechanics, but those never ruined the gameplay experience for me. 

What really stands out to me in this iteration of Dark Souls are the visuals. The world of this game is beautiful with gorgeous vistas and sublime colour usage. I'm no saying the game looks cheerful in any way, but DS1+3 tend to be very dark and gloomy.  The soundtrack complements the feeling of those areas very well. The voice acting is also done at a very high standard - nothing to complain here.

Combat feels more like DS3 than DS1. Its a bit more fluid and responsive and usually works very well. Sometimes the tracking of attacks is rather weird, and the autotargeting will get you killed a few times. Movement feels good as well and the platforming which is sometimes expected of you is usually not an issue. 

Level and boss design is also pretty great most of the time. There is the occasional runback to a boss which gets annoying after a few times (especially since you can get hit while trying to traverse a fog-gate).  Overall i would say this game (without its DLCs) has probably the easiest suite of bosses whilst having some of the toughest dungeons/stages to master. I did enjoy the boss-fights though. No stupid mechanics or overly wonky hitboxes, no unfair deaths or other cheap tricks - just enjoyable combat which still punishes you if you fail to learn the mechanics. 

To sum it up, it's not a perfect game by any means and there are a few design choices which drag the gameplay experience down a bit. But after hearing and reading that DS2 is supposed to be a terrible or subpar game, i was really surprised how well this game plays. I really enjoyed my time with it and will probably return for another NG+ or 2. 

8/10

Ater finishing this game my opinion of it changed, somewhat at least. 

I still think the beginning is just plain bad and game throws too much at you while you do not have access to tools to actually enjoy the gameplay. And that's around first half of the game.

But around middle to late game, game improves significantly in most areas. Storytelling gets a better direction and story begins to affect you, with some of the strongest beats in the series thus far (I have yet to play DS3). You also finally get tool variety to overcome challenges in creative ways and begin to form a very personalised build that you can actually defeat foes with. It has a lot of good elements, beneath the clunk, frustration and annoyance that sadly cannot be defended that is.

DLC Level design as well is immaculate, sadly bosses, except final ones, tend to disappoint. The ending is also really interesting after it all, though I think More npcs in DLCs would be welcome.

Overall, this game is in a weird place, where I would not recommend it for its extremely frustrating first hours and several locations seemingly made out of spite, but i would recommend it for (most of the) later half and clever structure it achieves then as well as sheer amount of gameplay customisability. I think the positives outweigh the negatives, but at the same time I doubt I will be doing a NG run again.

If you don't mind frustration so long its for a pay off down the line, give it a try!

Dark Souls II feels like playing baseball with a familiar, worn-in, comfortable mitt, only the rules of the sport have been slightly tweaked. Anyone worried that the sequel might rein back on the difficulty in favor of targeting a wider audience can sleep easy tonight – Dark Souls II is every bit as punishing, demanding, and ultimately rewarding as its 2011 predecessor. Its new ideas for both single-player exploration and helping and tormenting others in multiplayer don’t always quite click, but enough do to make this an exceptional game and an irresistible challenge.

As a person who earned both the "To Link the Fire" and "Dark Lord" endgame Achievements in the original Dark Souls, I have no shame in admitting that Dark Souls II put me down hundreds of times throughout the massive, 60-hour journey. But like the original, no death was ever in vain. Each moment of failure taught me more about how Dark Souls II works that helped me get better. From learning to exploit enemy attack patterns to picking up the signs of environmental traps, the high difficulty almost never felt insurmountable.

I say “almost” because developer From Software went a little too far with a penalty that decreases your max HP every time you die. This can be counteracted by using a Human Effigy, but those items are few and far between in the early half of the campaign. While undoubtedly a hardcore feature, I found it frustrating because it slightly stifled my urge to explore the world with a fear of being too harshly penalized for failure. True, this system is similar to how it was in Demon's Souls, but I'm a much bigger fan of how the original Dark implemented it.

But I pushed through and was rewarded for it, because the sprawling and diverse world of Dark Souls II proves to be ripe for non-linear exploration. One of my favorite elements here is that you always have at least a handful of different routes through the world at your disposal. Stuck at haunted dock full of fire-wielding marauders? Well, you can work your way down a well and find a tomb full of talking rats. Can’t get past a particularly tricky boss? Maybe head down another path to the Shaded Woods instead, and come back once you've leveled up.

The world of Drangelic is massive and filled with a wide variety of different locales. You'll travel between crumbling seaside kingdoms to marshes layered with thick coats of poison to what feels like the bowels of hell itself. While the variety in places to fight and explore is great, the world of Dark Souls II lacks a certain cohesion that was present in the original. 2011's depiction of Lordran felt it made sense in a geographic sense -- no matter how fantastical the setting got, it all seemed to fit together naturally. With the variety here and the ability to fast travel on a whim, Dark Souls II feels more like a large collection of levels than one natural single world.

Despite this schism, it’s definitely a nice world to look at. Dark Souls II's updated engine emphasizes the role of lighting in exploration. The game looks gorgeous when you're roaming around outside in a naturally lit area, or carrying around a torch. At any bonfire, you can choose to remove your shield in favor of lighting a torch. Not only does having a flame in your hand illuminate dark corners, but some enemies will cower in fear before your light. A choice that makes such a visible impact is cool, but oddly enough, the torch creates a strange tradeoff. Do you want to play it safe and carry a shield, or risk death and create a more visually interesting experience?

But these lighting conundrums don’t take away from just how great it feels to play Dark Souls II. It builds upon the challenge, scope, and mystery of the original in so many different impressive ways. While it looks great on 360 and PS3, it's particularly gorgeous on PC. The improved textures, lighting, and minor environmental effects like the way wind whips through the grass make it one of the most visually impressive games I've ever played.

Pretty terrible for fromsoft standards. Controls are often clunky and hitboxes can seem like complete bs at times. The adaptability stat is pretty much required for dumping a few levels as it improves dodging and healing animation speed, but you would have no way of knowing that on your first playthrough. However the most infuriating part of this game is the boss runs. There are some fun and cool boss fights in this game, but there is no fun to be had from running long distances over and over again through an army of mobs that can easily kill you if they get a hit in as you run by. Some boss fights are hard or annoying only because of what you have to go through to get back to them if you die (smelter demon, chariot, ruin sentinels, etc). I will probably end up finishing this game because I've already put 23 hours in, but I will NOT be happy about it.
