I'll edit this if I change my mind, but I actually think this game is poorly made.
While map and NPCs are something very interesting, basic game mechanics, animations and audio design are made as if with laziness and seem like it was not given enough effort.
I don't think ADP is bad nor good, rather, it makes the game just different from the others, and I can understand the point of it.

But it seems like every animation was poorly made, from the basic walking & running ones to bosses and enemies' attacks. It feels weird and wouldn't be particularly bad if it wasn't a souls game, which requires a well-polished combat due to its intrinsic high difficulty. Also, I should add that the player character doesn't even move when hit...? (when it has enough poise to not get stunned) That made being hit something very confusing that many times made me check my HP bar to see if I was really hit or not...

Audio design is... Unfinished, it seems? A lot of actions do not have any audio and a lot of important sounds seem like they're just placeholders until something better was made, like the running sound that seems very generic and even attacks from bosses that do not have sound at all.

I do praise the creativity put into the game but it has a lot of failures on fundamental aspects that make it unenjoyable, at least for me.

Extremely under the radar game due to the complaints from niche Soulsborne fans. If you like the formula but don't mind some tweaks along with a side of sandbox added then this will still be a great experience. I had a fantastic time with the original version and personally prefer it over the Scholar of the First Sin edition due to less mob ganks. Story kept me engaged and everything about the world and npc's still kept the spirit of Dark Souls for me so overall would highly recommend this to anyone looking to scratch that souls itch left from the void after completing the others. In my humble opinion, lighting is done the best in this game compared to others it really shines in places like Draeglic Castle when the lightning flashes on the reflective armor of the Looking Glass Knight. I also enjoyed the uses of torches for puzzles and sources of light for areas where visibility is slim otherwise. 8/10 in my book for being a souls game with a few blemishes.

Vanilla version is still great even though it currently has way less players on than SotFS. What is funny is the fact that for so long i never got around to playing this game and heard is was so terrible compared to the first and third installments, and I can't see why. It is definitely different, but it is not a bad game by any means.

Honestly this game gets too much shit. I won't lie, Dark Souls 2 looks kind-of ugly and the reuse of bosses and enemies in some areas comes off as lazy, but there is a lot of things DS2 got right. DS2 has this mechanic that no other souls game has called powerstance (search it up). TLDR: Wielding two of the same weapon will allow you to swing both of them at the same time and can even offer you new moves that you normally wouldn't have while holding 1 of that weapon. Another thing I like about DS2 is the range of new and obscure items you can use (I don't know why I just find it satisfying to use some of them for certain occasions even if they may be overall useless.) Interesting interactions: If you kill Sir Alonne without getting hit he will commit sepuku because he is disgraced that he cannot hit you, and if you wear Velstadts helm to Raimes fight he would enter phase 2 immediately since they hated eachother, these are details for a game that is beloved!

I was waiting for my slice of a generic pepperoni pizza that occupied that taste quality between approaching fast food and 'several chemical properties removed from plastic.' I got my slice and was about to turn away from the window when my baggy pants caught on my shoe and they fell to the floor. The first summarized feeling that I can express is that it seems to be bigger and a bit longer than original; but to my suprise Steam's statistic shown nearly exact same number of 66 and 62 hours for sequel and first installment respectively.

Before we go further I must warn you, that this comes from PVE-carebear who finished this game once and has no intention to do all those crazy NG+ stuff like many hard-core fans seemingly would. I died… well I can't really say a lot, but that's mostly because I summoned two phantoms for every boss and high-faith-lightning-spears-throwing build seems to be incredibly overpowered for beating AI. And I switched to it immediately after things got a bit tough. 

Before that I approached the same leveling as I did in first game: lots of strength and relying on heavy two-handed weapon (I bouth Pursuer's Ultra Greatsword). That was halfway through the game if you're wondering. I already killed Old Iron King, did both Belfrys, and made it through the Warf, Forest and Bastille. I even finished Grave of Saints. Anyway, it was a pure-melee character. And I encountered those flaming lizards, you know them, probably, if you finished the game. They were hard for me. Like really hard. I did little to none damage to them, but a few tries and that rolling around did the trick: I killed the first one, and then the second one. Third one stomped me. The narrow passage, the death-bringing fire spits, the horros, the wrong time to drink Estus. You know how this happens. The whole way back from the bonfire I hoped that they are treated like mini-bosses, and don't respawn. They did. I realized that either I can spend another hour trying to beat what seems like the hardest challenge I met in the game or I can visit them later. Some poison-arrows, some ranged stuff, which I was lacking. And that's where things got interesting. Rather than finishing later there is third option in sequel, one which original lacked. You can just redistribute your spents souls. And my inventory was crawling with all kind of stuff suitable for caster. And in a thirty minutes I was newly-born battle-cleric.

That sweet feeling of smartly overcoming the problem is good enough for me. It may be not as challenging in terms of perfect reaction, precise directional control and ability to automate sequences of same movements, but it doesn't matter for me. What I like in metroidvanias is that little hidden secrets left by developers. And in that sense Dark Souls is a proud member of the genre. Hidden walls, locked doors, smart usage of enemy attacks for opening new passageway, vulnerabilities of certain enemys — and most of those things not only present you with another glimpse of actually rich lore but make you more powerful or capable with dealing with some problem. And that's it, you just have to think and look for clues.
Second game's world became a bit more widespread, more star-shaped like with a central hub, that's it. It feels slightly more sensible or easier to decipher, but and in a many ways sequel actually is. Ability to change character build was already mentioned. And then there's less-restrictive weapon upgrading, and special rings that increase your chance to be summoned by your friend rather than stranger. It never goes as far as forcing you to navigate through complete dark area with deadly cliffs all around. That was what first game did. And while I admire this non-compomising approach of the developers, it was not fun. Yes, you could actually find a source of light before heading there, but that was so obscure, that I didn't. And I seriously doubt anyone on first playthrough without a guide would. So Dark Souls II changed a lot of stuff, that wasn't fun. It still sometimes isn't, but at least it doesn't irritate, and that's good. 

It's steal hard to the limit, that I felt satisfaction beating it. It required time, dedication and work of thought. And it was worth it. It still is in a lot of ways beautiful. With that oblique beaty, that you won't find on the first look. This style develops with progressing in the game, rather than trying to blaze all guns at you at the first second. Of course it's technically crappy, and some locations look even horrible, but the overall design atones it all. It comes a long way from minimalism to grotesque staying true to itself and game atmosphere. And despite all transformations it never looks like an eclectic mess.

This post-apocalyptic fantasy world is still deep, depressing and has a lot of history it doesn't really want to share. Or at least it won't if you won't work for it. But that's okay. That's how metroidvanias work.

My main issues with the game are things such as the enemy placement, combat, bosses, its approach to difficulty, and world design. There will be some spoilers below, mainly boss names, area names, and intro spoilers.

Enemy placement:
This game has a lot of enemies in a lot of places that serve as a "challenge", rather than making the actual enemy placements and engagements challenging.

Combat:
This ties into the first point, because your weapon's durability drains so easily (whereas in DS1 it was an occasional issue and DS3 it's a non-issue) there's a very real chance you will be in the middle of a boss fight and your weapon just breaks. You either have to carry repair powder with you or you have to carry 2 weapons. There's a ring that mitigates this slightly, but combined with the health drain ring it basically makes it necessary to use 2 out of your 4 ring spots to be able to not be as punished for simply playing. Queueing up inputs is very inconsistent, they seem to randomly decide when to work and when not to work. At some points, there's a complete lack of feedback from getting hit. You'll see your health bar go down, but you won't hear a noise, you won't see any particles from your character or see your character affected in any way.

Besides that, I've found myself very often getting hit by an attack the frame after I stagger the enemy. I played with a Strength build for my first playthrough and very often I found myself going for a swing, hitting them, and then seeing my health bar drained a bit /anyways/ even though the enemy got staggered. Additionally, enemies traversing the boundaries of time and space so their attacks hit you when you roll behind them is very annoying.
There's also an issue with the AI being able to immediately attack the moment you go for a heal, I've seen clips of enemies literally going out of their death animations and killing a player.

Another issue is with the healing: Both the Estus Flask and the infinite supply of lifegems the game gives you which trivialises things a lot of the time. The Estus takes ages to consume and the health isn't instant but goes up slowly, this means that a lot of the time you'll start drinking at a time that it seems obvious you should be able to drink, but get smacked down instead. Lifegems simply trivialise healing, as you have access to an infinite supply (even early game). 

Bosses:
Now when it comes to bosses, it's very simple. There are a ton of bosses to the point where most of them don't really feel special anymore. They start becoming glorified enemies who have dedicated music and a big health bar. Out of the 32 bosses, 17 (arguably 18 or 19) are just fighting a humanoid with a sword. That's not counting multiple bosses in 1 arena as a separate boss (such as the 3 grave robbers or the Sentinels). The summons are also insanely terrible, they don't have a brain whatsoever. They run at the boss and hug it until they're dead. They just keep swinging, do terrible damage (they don't scale with NG level either), and just get themselves killed very easily.

The boss runs themselves are also some of the worst in the series, but can be partially mitigated by killing all the enemies 12 times, but it's incredibly boring to do so.

Approach to difficulty:
This is mainly the cause of the awful boss runs. This game's philosphy is "people liked Dark Souls 1 because they died a lot, so let's kill the player constantly" and it achieves this through gank squads, straight-up removing max HP on death, and the continuous invasions. 

The way this game treats difficulty is very obvious from the start, the intro cutscene talks about how you'll "lose your souls over and over". The achievement for dying is also called "welcome to Dark Souls" and it feels like the developers massively misunderstood what the difficulty in the game was meant for.

World design:
While I think this game has some really interesting places (Majula is the number 1 hub out of all the games, or the castle being visible throughout a large portion of the game), I think overall its world design leaves a lot to be desired. 3 examples I can think of is the placement of an entire castle changing when you go through a tunnel, going under sea level but somehow ending up at a pier, and going up an elevator (that you can't see from the outside) to a mountain with a big lava lake and castle (that you can't see from the outside).


"Quick" points:

A lot of animations look weird and stiff and the movement feels off a lot of the time (both animation-wise for the player/enemies, but also when controlling). 

ADP and the i-frames tied to it may be the dumbest thing ever invented. Completely unnecessary. There's no benefit for this mechanic.


Every time you die, you lose 5% HP up to a maximum of 50%. This is just punishing for no real reason. From a quick Google search, this mechanic in Demon's Souls (as it's a PS-exclusive, I have not played it yet) seems to have a lot more of a purpose besides "Here, get punished for no reason, you idiot". Dying is one of the main ways to learn the games and its bosses, punishing you this heavily for dying is just contrary to the Souls series. As stated earlier, there's a ring to reduce this effect to 75%, however it requires you to use 1 out of your 4 ring slots . The fact that there are 4 ring slots means rings are much less powerful than in DS1 (understandably so), but then having 2 rings that are basically needed to have a decent experience means you are basically just running nerfed rings.

Alternatively, you can use Human Effigies (the DS2-equivalent of DS1's humanity and DS3's Embers) to completely remove it, but it's not like those are infinitely available like Lifegems. DS3 did this system way better with rewarding the player for using an Ember by giving them a lot of extra HP, but losing it upon death.

Multiplayer is terribly done. Soul Memory is a sh¡t mechanic and you can get invaded whenever so I've been invaded by the same person 4 times in a row and had to physically pull out my ethernet cable in order to get them to stop (they were twinking, so I had no chance whatsoever). There's no way to turn off online mode in-game, instead you have to either go offline mode on Steam, have no internet connection, or pause the network process via the task manager's resource manager. It doesn't help that you have to spend an Effigy to PREVENT being, so it's an opt-out multiplayer instead of opt-in.


There are some things that I think DS2 does good:
Certain animations are really cool, such as the riposte and backstab animations.
Bonfire ascetic and powerstancing are really cool mechanics that I wish they brought back.
It has NG+ content, which makes it feel a bit more unique.
The lore is really cool, with some characters like Vendrick, Raime, and Velstadt being super cool (and one of my personal favourites out of the entire series, Aldia).
Majula is probably one of the best hubs designs, similar to DS1 it's the main hub where a lot of the NPCs gather, but it feels like a really cozy place due to the sunset and music.

Listen, I'm not your typical "git gud" f**king nerd; I am a realist with life demands.

Realistically, I can rate this an easy 8.5/10 coming from a ds1/2 completer (I don't do NG+).

(back story below)
Okay, I avoided Dark Souls for many years because people TAG their reviews as "Dark Souls like"; and to me, the (slightly above average) gamer, it doesn't mean much; UNTIL I played Elden Ring a couple of years ago.  

That play through re-invigorated a desire to discover the source material of "dark souls" (and I'm glad I did).  Dark Souls remastered; which is nearly a 10/10 for me, but the predecessor falls short ( like many things ) and only reached 6.5 in my personal opinion.  

Dark Souls III is remarkable; why?! - how can you say that and have NOT beat the game yet?! 

... Well, here's how:

The game rewards you for for accomplishments (big or small); DS 3 is graphically superior; and ( G** almighty the CONTROLS) the interface/controls are spot on.  

Definitely DS 3 is a 8.5/10 only because I haven't finished it myself and I have such short playtime, but from what I read and watched online, I am in for a blissful surprise come the final boss.



My original playtime is approximately 9 hours of not knowing what the f**k is going on, I defeated the first boss and farmed a bit, but that is it,  I am SO looking forward to this.

Even after playing Elden Ring, Dark Souls 3 holds up to this day and is one of my favourite games of all time. The Story is a superb conclusion to the trilogy; tying up loose threads and wrapping up story elements from the prior two games. The game play is some of the best of all time with the most astonishing bosses in the series; Twin Princes, Friede, Gael and more are all A+++ bosses. 

The DLCs are incredible, both poignant ruminations on the entire trilogy - the Ringed City in particular is one of my favourite environments in any game world and I applaud FromSoftware for finishing this special series in such immaculate fashion. 

What else is there to say that hasn't been said? The emotion, the music, the art, the bosses and gameplay are all some of the best in gaming.

I should preface this review by stating that I like Dark Souls 3 as a whole. What I dislike about Dark Souls 3 come largely down to story and mechanics, namely the massive system changes that occurred from Dark Souls 1 to Dark Souls 3 (and 2, though to a lesser degree).

To begin with what I like, the level design is a stand-out, as is the art direction and general graphical effects of the game. In comparison to prior games, 3 definitely feels like the most pretty and most like Dark Souls 1 in terms of level design with sprawling maps that always seem to have a way back to your origin point. It is, overall, one of the best games released in its year. 

On what I dislike about the game,

1. Changes to PVP and Health: In Dark Souls 1, you use Humanity at a Bonfire and become Human. This enables both PVP and Co-op in the world, and you can be invaded at random. There is no real mechanical bonus to being Human outside of turning on these mechanics and you can go the entire game without ever becoming Human.
In Dark Souls 2, the whole system is muddied and frankly terrible. There's no distinction between "Invasion On" and "Invasion Off," though the game prioritizes Human players to invade based on Soul Memory... It's a mess.
In Dark Souls 3, Embering gives you bonus HP [b]and[/b] turns on PVP. This means that in order to get access to additional HP beyond the amount granted by Vigor, you have to turn on PVP and risk being invaded at random. You are automatically Embered after every boss kill, meaning that you get bonus HP... But also run the risk of invasion. PVP would be okay if lag and other issues weren't present, but being forced into the system by design means that PVP players go up against unsuspecting PVE players and Embering is arguably more detrimental than beneficial, bar the health boost that can help with tackling later game zones. In a word, the whole system is awful and I can see why they abandoned it for Elden Ring.

2. Firelink Shrine. In Dark Souls 1, Firelink Shrine was a sort of hub where you could go to get more uses of your Estus and it was functionally connected to everything. At the same time, you never really had to go back there other than for ease of access to certain zones.
In Dark Souls 3, Firelink Shrine is now a necessity. You have to go there to level up. You have to go there to improve weapons. It's all hidden behind a loading screen, meaning slower systems will have to stare at lore on repeat throughout the entire game. The worst part by far is the repetitive dialogue any time you want to level-up. It was a problem in Dark Souls 2, Bloodborne and a problem here. Elden Ring wisely did away with this system (at least for leveling) and that's a far better system. Dark Souls 1 did it better with the Bonfire level up too. It's a problem that never goes away and just gets more annoying the more you play.

3. Lore: Dark Souls 3 is too focused on being a sequel to Dark Souls 1 (not 2, it references it occasionally, but it borderline ignores it) where it feels that the focus is on the ramifications and results of the original game and not on the lore of the new one. Dark Souls 2 had this problem to what I would argue is a lesser degree, albeit it was a bit too heavy-handed. Dark Souls 3 just name-drops important characters from Dark Souls 1 and copy-and-pastes an area from the first game into the third. This is okay because that area is still cool, but it feels a bit... Tired. I would have preferred something new, something completely distinct from what we got.

It feels like two games. One game is trying to have new lore, new experiences and new things while the other game is trying desperately hard to flash the words "DARK SOULS 1 IS HERE" in your face whenever it can.

4. Ignoring Dark Souls 2's Cool Bits: Dark Souls 2 is a divisive entry, and for good reason. However, it had some neat ideas, particularly hyperstancing weapons. This basically meant that, with the right stats, you could wield two weapons of the same type and gain access to a new moveset. Dark Souls 3 cans this entirely and gives you paired weapons. While this does open up the ability to use a stat-improving shield, like the Grass Crest Shield, it removes the unique flavor of hyperstancing entirely. Covenants are also back, but I feel that they're a little bit tacked on and less important this time around. No more Arenas for the Blue Sentinels or the Invaders, no more Covenant of Champions to turn on hard mode. There's also no real rewards for a no-Bonfire run (which is impossible anyway due to the design of the game) or for never dying, both of which Dark Souls 2 had.

Particularly disappointing is that NG+ in Dark Souls 3 does nothing but increase difficulty (and add higher level varaints of rings), whereas Dark Souls 2 revamped zones with new enemy placements new item drops and more. Dark Souls 2 felt like an entire new game in NG+

5. The Bloodborne Effect: This one is a bit more mixed for me. This game clearly has some Bloodborne in it, which is good on one hand because Bloodborne is great. It's bad on another because it feels like they didn't go hard enough on making it Dark Souls and not Bloodborne. The speed of the game is increased, but Shields are back so you can be more passive. Armor doesn't matter as much because of lack of upgrades, and the Poise system being kind of terrible (only activates on swinging some weapons) means that there's less incentive to actually be a big tanky hero like in Dark Souls 1. The lack of a Rally system (damage enemies to replenish recently lost HP) also means that being in close is punished. It's a bit confused as to what it wants to be, in this regard. Workable, as I've beat the game several times, but it feels unrefined. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In closing - Dark Souls 3 is a sequel to Dark Souls 1. It's not bad, but it's not hitting the same highs as Dark Souls 1, Bloodborne or Elden Ring for me. Bear in mind that, with all of the things I dislike, none of the Dark Souls games are truly awful and all of them are incredible purchases, well worth your time. I just so happen to dislike Dark Souls 3 the most of them all. 

Granted, most everyone has already bought this game, so this hardly matters anyway.

If this is your first Souls game then by all means! Buy it, love it, cherish it, and get gud. Just skip 1 and 2. There's a reason why DS3 is my least favorite in the franchise. I like Sekiro more than DS3. The reason why I don't like DS3 as much as I love DS1, DS2, and Bloodborne is because From Software didn't offer anything new with DS3. They simply grabbed DS1 and DS2, put them in a blender, sprinkled some Bloodborne action in there, and slapped DS3 on the bottle. DS1 and DS2 are worlds apart, and Bloodborne is an entire universe onto itself. I was expecting DS3 to be a whole new thing but it would seem From Software tried to play it safe by giving us their greatest hits album titled Dark Souls 3. But again, if this is your first Souls game that is also good, just don't bother playing DS1 and DS2, and Bloodborne because DS3 is pretty the sampler package. Just move on to Demon Souls, Sekiro, and Elden Ring.

Dark Souls 3 is a great introduction to Soulsborne games (At least for me), back in 2019 DS3 popped up on my internet feed I saw a couple of YouTube compilations of players raging at the game but at the same time I was not sure at what I was watching; as someone who was still new at gaming at the time and only started playing FPS I was not sure it was for me. 

I bought the game on special (I think it was 80% off back then lol) , without a Xbox controller I attempted to kill tutorial boss, Gundyr. It was painful on KB&M but I managed after many attempts and luck, it was not satisfying. I quit the game once I got to the first real boss. Fast forward to 2021 I attempted the game again but I cheated (I used WeMod forgive me😞) I finished the game but got banned for using Wemod(whatever it called) I had to delete my save to be un-banned since it was my first & only offence . I deleted my save in shame.

Fast forward to 2023 I'm playing the Lies of P demo on KB&M, the visuals were stunnning and the hype was real I said F**k it im getting a Xbox Controller it time I actually play these soul-like games as intended. The difference was day and night the movement felt natural, the "mind to controller connection" felt organic however I was still terrible. Then it clicked I actually need to learn the animation, patterns how to trigger certain enemy movements  to my advantage etc.

I applied what Learned from that demo to DS3 after 4 weeks I finished the base game on my own. Once completed I looked up the lore to find out what I missed from the flavor texts the bug I caught from playing the game grew, I wanted more there is still more to delve in (Still to play:DS1 remastered & maybe DS2, Bloodborne[PC???] ). Blasphemous 1 was my next game in souls-like journey it was a blast a  genre I once thought I would never like I end up loving, It all I play nowadays(currently playing Ringed city at time of writing this review)

Looking forward to DS1, Cuphead, Sekiro mmmmaybe DS2 & soon to be released Lord of Fallen

Dark Souls 3 might be one of the easiest games I've played. From the straightforward combat to the predictable enemy patterns, there were very few challenges that posed a threat. The bosses? Simply a walk in the park. Overall, if you're looking for a game that requires minimal effort, Dark Souls 3 is the one for you.

Great world tho.

-Garry

I think it has some of a the best bosses period, the fast paced and fluid combat compliments them very much. Another thing that elevates the boss fights is the boss music, there are so many masterpieces within this one game it's actually insane.

As for the areas, which is my favorite part about Souls games (bosses being a close second), most of the areas are very unenjoyable to traverse like Farron Keep, Cathedral of the Deep, & Irrithyl Dungeon for ex. Now the game does have a few areas I LOVED like Irrithyl Valley, Ringed City, High Wall Lothric, & Anor Londo. It was so cool revisiting places like Anor Londo or going down to the Smoldering Lake and seeing Capra Demon and Stray Demon carcasses, I was so happy to see all the callbacks to DS1 and even DS2.

That pretty much sums up my feelings for DS3, I have no problems other than a lot of the areas.

Hollow knight is simply amazing. Art, story, visuals, soundtrack and game mechanics are all beautifully done. I play this game on the steam deck, and with a controller this game truly thrives. I love almost everything about this game, from the dialogue to the bossfights and unique characters, but there are some things that I find annoying. One is that it's pretty easy to get stuck at a point in the game where you don't really know where to go or where to get certain abilities you need. The parkour in some areas is a little unforgiving, and I feel like I'm playing Getting Over It sometimes, but besides those things I love this game. Get it. Now. 9.4/10, would recommend.

I just finished Hollow Knight, and I can confidently say that it is one of the most special games of all time. I did not expect for me to like this game as much as I did. It is now one of my favorites. Keep in mind that this game was only made by 3 people, and performs many, many triple-A developers. There is a lot to talk about in this game. So let's get started with the review. 

[h1] The Combat [/h1]
- The combat at first is simple, which is good when you are playing a new game. You do not want to be overwhelmed with a ton of combos, and attacks. You get more attack options as you play the game (since it is a metro-vanilla.) There are many different spells, and gear that you get through the game that makes combat more deep. The combat overall is extremely fun, and something that I would come back to. 

[h1] The Enemies [/h1]
- One of the aspects that I would say makes or breaks a combat system is the Enemies. With Hollow Knight, There are 150 different enemies. Of course, there are some similar enemies, but a lot of them are unique, and make you think about how you should encounter them. There are also 46 bosses, that have their gimics. Most bosses in this game, in my opinion, are well-designed, and fun to fight. 

[h1] Lore [/h1]
- The lore is hard to follow, but in my opinion not as hard to follow as other games. My overall lore of this game is very interesting, and I like it

[h1] Is this game a "Souls-like" [/h1]
- Yes, and no. This game shares many aspects with the Souls series but also has its unique ideas. Here are some things that are inspired by souls. 

[h2] The World [/h2]
- One thing that is inspired by the series is the open world and navigation. Something that I love about this game is how you are not forced on a linear path. There are many different paths, that you can explore. 

[h2] The Difficulty [/h2]
- I will try not to be cocky here, but on my first play-through ( if you do not count the 3 hardest bosses in the game) I probably died less than 20 times. However, this game is still very hard. The average player will die a lot of times. However, the difficulty does not feel unfair and feels very rewarding when you beat a boss that you are struggling with. 

[h2] Dark Theme [/h2]
- You can tell via the trailers that this game is dark, almost like a medieval game compared to other metrovanilas. However, this does not mean that there are very colorful places, that do not feel like souls. There are many places, such as dark areas. 

[h1] Music [/h1]
- The score for this game is very beautiful, fits the game very well, and sounds amazing. Also, it was made by one guy.

There are many other aspects that I did not talk about. If you want to know if you should get this game. Then 100 percent yes. YES YES YES YES YES. THIS GAME IS WORTH THE PRICE and IS A STEAL WHEN IT IS ON SALE. 

[b] 95/100 [/b]

It's such a fucking good game, man, just play it. Perfect controls and mobility options, captivating ambiance, many customization options for different playstyles (in the form of charms), upgradeable skills and weapon, cool lore, great boss fights, memorable NPCs, Metroidvania done right. Outstanding game design, with a mix of cute and creepy. Fair but challenging difficulty, big map to explore, plus the content added via DLCs throughout the years is a wonderful addition to an already amazing game.

I've been playing videogames for over 20 years now and I have to say Hollow Knight has probably the best, most satisfying controls I've ever experienced. Moving around the map using the Crystal Heart, Shade Cloak, Monarch Wings and Mantis Claw feels SOOO right, so fluid.

I just finished a Steel Soul mode (and Steel Heart) run (100%+ game completion and defeat the [spoiler]Radiance, true final[/spoiler] boss, without ever dying in that savefile), it's been an exciting ride from start to finish.

Hollow knight is one of my favorite games. One of my fondest memories is my brother walking me through the beginning. I (at the time of this review) have a 106% complete save file, with hundreds of hours on record. Each of those hours were filled with fun. Download this game. You might struggle at the start, but believe me, it might become one of your favorite games.

Okay, past all the "emotional biases", Hollow Knight is amazing, but not perfect. But that barely affects the game. No game is without flaw. My only real gripe with the game is that in some starter areas, they do provide enough hints for needed accessories (ex: the lantern) I personally didn't have trouble with this, but I have noticed that I am MUCH more observant than most.

Other than that, the game is quite frankly a gem in metroid-vainias. The combat, exploration, and rewards all work together to make a beautiful atmosphere. Going back to the combat, it is absolutely gorgeous! One of the most elegant combat systems I've seen, (outmatched by Dead Cells, but that game is almost ALL ABOUT the combat, and hollow knight is much more separated.) All the areas, even if you aren't focused on lore, make sense for the game! The game's art style plays in tandem with the gameplay elegantly.

Okay, lets talk about the music for a second. Two words. HOLY SHIT! This music is beautiful! The motif work is AMAZING, and if you don't have a good reason like I do (listened to every track like twice and like to watch videos while playing,) PLAY. WITH. MUSIC. ON!!!!

Thanks for reading all of this long review, I just had to get my overwhelming love for this game out into the world. Have an amazing day!

[h1] This game is an absolute masterpiece, from start to finish. [/h1]
[list]
[*]The atmosphere, the story, the music, everything about hollow knight makes you want to come back for more.
[*]The difficulty adds challenge, and rewards you when you figure out attack patterns and different badge combinations to help you overcome an obstacle you were stuck on. 
[*]And don't get me started on the game's soundtrack. Every boss fight has so much emotion packed into it with the musical score, it really adds to the experience, and it makes it feel like a true souls game. I could spend hours listening to the OST, from the title screen to the [spoiler] Hollow Knight [/spoiler] fight. 
[*]The world building is also amazing, it feels like you're playing inside of a fully fleshed out world, one which has been struck by tragedy and you are seeing the aftermath. Not to mention almost every major decision you make has an impact on the world around you.
[/list]
I fully recommend this game to anyone who likes 2D platformers, along with anyone who loves games with a big challenge.

"A Truly Epic RPG Masterpiece"

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

As a devoted gamer with a passion for immersive storytelling, "Divinity: Original Sin 2" has left an indelible mark on my gaming experience. Larian Studios has outdone themselves with this RPG masterpiece, offering a world of limitless possibilities and captivating narratives.

From the moment you set foot in Rivellon, the game's richly detailed world, you are thrust into a mesmerizing and complex tale. Character creation is a work of art, allowing you to mold your heroes in both appearance and backstory. Every choice you make, from your character's race to their class, has a profound impact on the unfolding narrative.

The story is a compelling epic, filled with deep lore, memorable characters, and moral dilemmas. The game's intricate web of relationships and alliances creates a dynamic world that reacts to your choices. It's a role-playing experience like no other, where your decisions genuinely matter.

The gameplay mechanics are equally impressive. The turn-based combat system offers a deep and strategic challenge. Elemental interactions and combinations add a layer of complexity, rewarding clever tactics and teamwork. Co-op play is where the game truly shines, allowing friends to join in and face the world of Rivellon together.

Visually, "Divinity: Original Sin 2" is a masterpiece, with detailed environments, breathtaking vistas, and stunning character designs. The game's atmospheric soundtrack and sound effects transport you to this magical realm, enhancing the immersion.

One of the game's standout features is its mod support, which provides an endless stream of user-generated content. This extends the replayability and allows the community to shape the game's experience even further.

Larian Studios has proven their commitment to quality and their fans by continuously improving and updating the game. They actively listen to the community and work to make "Divinity: Original Sin 2" better with each patch.

In summary, "Divinity: Original Sin 2" is a true gem in the world of RPGs. It's a testament to Larian Studios' dedication to storytelling, depth, and innovation. If you're a fan of epic adventures, complex narratives, and challenging gameplay, this game is a must-play. Embark on a journey in Rivellon, where your choices define the world's fate.

DNF because once I was area-locked into the final boss fight, unable to leave or change party comp or get more supplies, one of my companions decided he no longer wanted to help and left the party. He was one of my regular companions, I spent so much time with him, and then he just f'ed me over with an eleventh hour betrayal :(

At the time I was so upset about spending almost 90 hours on a playthrough, having a good party comp and (what I believed to be) good relationships with everyone in the party, only to be unable to finish that I just walked away from the whole game and haven't touched it since.  I don't mind difficult combat, or fights that might take a couple of tries to win, but the final fight is literally impossible without a full and balanced party. Might try to return to it someday, but starting a new playthrough is a big investment if there's always the risk of being unable to complete it.

[i]Disclaimer:[/i] I played this with the "Divinity Unleashed" mod; the only "gift bag" I activated was “The Four Relics of Rivellon” (totally recommended, by the way). 

While everybody was talking about "Baldur's Gate 3", I came back to finish this spiritual predecessor, left unplayed for over 3 years because I was burned out after going through  [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/heybabyxxx/recommended/373420]the first one[/url] for almost 170 hours.

As a sequel should be, it's bigger (216 hours on my 1st playthrough, without finishing all quests or seeing everything _ I took at least one big shortcut unintentionally) and better than the previous title; many things are familiar, like some spells and skills (and there are a ton of new ones), besides the reappearance of some old characters, like [spoiler]Jahan, Arhu[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Braccus Rex[/spoiler]. You can play this one without experimenting the earlier title, but that's not advised; actually, if you can stomach cRPGs released more than 20 years ago, you may start with "Divine Divinity"... 

In "D:OS 2", there are 6 "origin characters" with their own questlines, meaning that the game was meant to be played at least twice: the developers recommend that you create a character from scratch and choose 3 of the origin characters as companions: 2 of them are mages, 2 are melee fighters, 1 is a rogue and 1 is a ranger. I recommend that you create a party of 1 of each of those 4 classes, distributing skills and items and levelling up and positioning them on the battlefiled accordingly. There's also crafting, but you don't really need it _ don't bother picking everything that you find, or your inventory will become a nightmare. Remember: exploration is the main thing here; go everywhere (teleportation is a must!), speak to everyone (even the animals) and search every nook and cranny. Discoveries abound. 

Even though I don't consider this a story-heavy title, the plot is OK. There are [spoiler]3[/spoiler] main endings; I chose the most unusual one and I was pretty happy with the conclusion. Combat is challenging (enemy AI is pretty good), but gets easy by the end, when you reach high levels (I finished at level 20, playing on Normal difficulty, here called "Classic"); way more difficult are the puzzles (several of them demand trial and error and thinking outside the box). I intend to replay this title one day, on vanilla and with Tactician (Hard) difficulty. 

The most obvious drawback for me is that this one is less co-op inclined than the first; sure you can still play co-op (with other 3 people at the most), but "D:OS" had 2 characters as protagonists (who would debate on what to do and dispute who would have the upper hand, even if you played solo), and this has only 1, so you can play solo and not even realize that co-op was a possibility. Still, this is a great game (not a masterpiece, though), totally worth the full price. 

[i]Pro tip[/i]: like the "XCOM" series, "D:OS" looks and plays better with a controller. If for some reason you never tried to play a cRPG with a controller, give it a shot and enjoy yourself more than you thought it was possible!

This is simply one of my favorite RPGs of all time. I wouldn't trade away the hours I've spent in this game for anything. Such a beautiful game that really made me love video games all over again.

While DOS2 offers enjoyable moment-to-moment experiences, the slow combat combined with the large and densely packed maps turns what should be a fun game into a slog. The writing, the voice acting, the visuals and combat are all very well designed. But in this case, the whole is less than the sum of its parts, as the micromanagement and memorisation required by all the gameplay mechanics adds up to an overwhelming experience. It's the sort of game where you are best served writing an extensive notes document as you go along, and even then it is very difficult to come back to after taking a break. And it's not like a typical RPG where only completionists need to explore the whole map and complete all the quests; in DOS2, enemies do not scale with your level, the amount of experience and gold available is limited, and being under-levelled makes fights much harder. One final complaint: the dialogue trees are awfully designed. Very often when speaking with an NPC, choosing one option, even as simple as a "hello" or "are you alright", will needlessly lock off from the other options, sometimes even if they are quest-related. Why on earth Larian did this is beyond me.

Ojala todos los juegos fueran la mitad de buenos de lo que es Divinity Original Sin 2. Una aventura como muy pocas que desborda excelencia en casi todos sus aspectos. El juego es mas lineal de lo que parece, o al menos lo que yo esperaba, pero creo que es la decisión correcta porque esto hace brillar todos sus apartados. La atención al detalle es magistral, todas las líneas de dialogo con actuación de voz, la cantidad absurda de situaciones emergentes, las distintas rutas narrativas y un sistema de combate muy rico y divertido.

Un RPG increible y una aventura que ojala todos vivieran.

Por decir algo malo es que a pesar de tener buenos tutoriales, siento que muchos jugadores pueden experimentar confusión o abandonarlo por ciertas barreras de entrada o picos de dificultad muy puntuales.

I really recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good, story rich, RPG. However there are a few caveats:

1. Consider a full physical or magic damage party. The game is much easier this way that with a split damage party.

2. Don't be afraid to cheese any fight in the game. There are many ways to win a fight, and the game rewards thinking outside the box.

3. Gear can be very expensive and needs to be replaced frequently. Consider taking advantage of anything that results in your party becoming filthy rich (eg. crafting, mods, stealing, exploits).

I recommend this game because it gave me my money's worth, but apart from some aspects of the combat, it is not a game worth remembering.

I got to act 4 the first time I played this game, but I never finished it. Two years later, I couldn't remember much about the game, but having no misgivings about playing it again, I gave it a second try. Again, I got to act 4, and I simply didn't care enough to finish it. Although the combat is fine, the characters feel shallow, and the world is extremely undefined, at least when compared to something like Pillars of Eternity. Every book you open has only a few lines of text, not contributing much lore, and even after a lot of time in game you're asking yourself basic questions like: "What's the name of this kingdom? Is it a kingdom? What are the names of the neighbouring lands? Is this bishop Alexandar really the top dog, or just some local boss?"
This disconnect is bearable for the first two acts of the game, with the map design and quests being somewhat engaging, but by act 3, you're beginning to feel that you're just running around on an island and doing stuff, not because you want to, but because you have to, just to progress. In act 4, it feels like the designers have been obsessed with making every encounter a "Haha, gotcha"-moment, which gets old really fast, and both the city, its vendors and its NPC's feel uninteresting.
It's fun, it's complex, it's hard, it can be confusing at times and yet it's nothing like the RPGs i had played before. Definitely go for it.

I feel a little bit bad living a negative review for this game. It's charming, well programmed, it has good combat mechanics, and its soundtrack is superb... But I seriously couldn't have fun playing it after the first act.

You'll basically read a lot that this game gives you a lot of freedom and that choices matter. They do, but for the wrong reason. You either approach a quest at the right level, and finish it, or approach it at the wrong level (too low) and get slapped. To proceed in the game you will basically have to choose in which order do (almost) all quests. Also those you find boring or useless, or you won't have enough XP to level up and get the next quest done.

So, you can end up grinding and wasting your time with little reward. I'd suggest making levelling up less important for the next game.

It is a nice game which you can play with your friends or by yourself. There are lots of positives for this game: Graphics are pretty good; voice acting, music and sound design is great, world is detailed and pretty big, there are lots to discover with variety of quests which brings a long playtime, lot of skill options to choose from. However, there are some negatives also: The first one would be the Launcher. The one of the most unnecessary things to have. Other than that, there is a problem with the quests. The quest log doesn’t show anything useful, especially with some side quests. Armour set DLC quests are the worst, since it doesn’t give you the place that you can find the next piece and if you have passed the chapter without finding it, that quest line pretty much fucked up. As another point, there is a huge problem with the balance and usable builds. You can build your character however you like but that does not mean that making a geomancer archer viable, since you have to rely on Finesse and Wits. That makes the build options pretty much useless. Most of the time you are granted some attribute and skill points at the level up which is far from being exiting, since you have to go for a certain part. Also, some of the builds are pretty weak, like an archer. These are really important at the hard difficulty, since the most you can do will be fighting an enemy at the same level which is another problem, because the difficulty curve is not balanced at all, especially at the last chapter, one of my characters were one-shotted at beginning of each fight, game forcing some fights with the fixed positions made it even worse. One other thing was the items. Item randomization is a really bad choice for this game. Especially there are intelligence required items which gives skills like huntsman. We had more than 300k at the end game and wasn’t able to purchase anything for a long time also. So, money will be useless after a while. Another problem was main characters’ stories which are a bit short and scattered with a couple quests only. It felt like a feature added as a DLC. Lastly, achievements, decisions, companions and persuasion are not a great mechanics at multiplayer. They are not implemented greatly to the game and it doesn’t feel smooth at all. Still, playing this game is a nice experience overall.

This is one of those cases where I really wish there was an in-between score. So why negative in the end?

The game starts out amazing, the first 20 hours of the game are such a pleasure, story is engaging, characters are interesting and the combat is really satisfying. But... as the game progresses, the story slows down to a point where I forgot what was even happening. The combat goes from interesting to just pure frustration. It felt like a chore to boot the game up at a certain point which is when I chose to put it down for good.

The crafting system is the most confusing I've ever experienced and there are no instructions on how to use it. So I ended up just completely ignoring it.

I've restarted the game several times thinking I was missing something (hence the high playtime) but ultimately, it feels to me like they front loaded the game with all the good stuff and didn't care much about the middle/end.

If you've already played the game and are poking around for an opinion (spoiler warning): The game is awesome until you leave the starter island, then it feels like a completely different game, in a bad way. For me at least.

I was walking a line between an up/down thumb on this. There's a lot of positives in the game and for me, unfortunately, more negatives.

On the plus, the game looks and runs well, even in 2023. I did not suffer any crashes and load time was acceptable. I played both modded and unmodded, being careful which mods I used since a majority of them will cause you crashes now (got to love how someone puts out a mod and then abandons it). There's a decent amount on content and depending on how much of a speed runner you are, you can definitely get a lot of hours out of the game. For the most part, you can run around about anywhere you want. There's a decent number of quests throughout. Combat is generally enjoyable. The open world is persistent, so all your actions stick around.

On the cons, the questing system drove me nuts. It's a very open world and more often than not, you'll complete one quest that keeps you from either starting another quest or prevents you from completely a completely separate quest. Wondering around and help someone to their grave? You may have inadvertently ended another quest. Decide to go farming some guys for gear and gold? You may have just wiped out the guys you needed for a quest. You are very much punished for exploring without reading every fine print on quests and even ensuring you picked up every possible quest. Since quests are really the only meaningful way of obtaining experience, you can cut yourself off quickly.

Since the world is persistent (no respawns), the world soon feels very void. Your only choice is to push forward. Wanting to practice your skills? There's a target dummy here and there... 

Questing feels a bit like an afterthought, even though its central to advancing in the game. The quest tracking feels like something Minecraft would have where you often have obscure text that doesn't always tell you much of anything. I can understand wanting players to experiment a bit, although with the persistent nature of the game, if you experiment a bit too much, you fail the quest (no do-overs) or end some other quest that was around the same area. Your actions have a few too many consequences. 

Any game that requires you to have some wiki or search engine up constantly should just rethink how they work. Want to craft things? It you like mindlessly trying random combinations in a rather archaic crafting mechanic, you're in luck. Else you are stuck searching wikis and figuring out whether that stick you picked up is worth the effort of combining with a shell. Can't decipher the cryptic text on a quest, back to the wiki. Can't figure out why the tomb won't open, back to the search to find that you shouldn't have off'd that character because that locks the quest out. This had to be the most aggravating part of the game for me. I just don't want to have to think this hard in a game to enjoy myself.

If you love to save every couple minutes and reload saves, you are in luck. If you don't remember to save every couple minutes, it will suck to be you. It's not really that cool to figure out you did something wrong (death, quest or otherwise), think well, I need to go back a bit and find your last save was an hour or more ago. I tried mods with auto save, tried to keep in my head to save often and still would find myself having to roll back or just accept that I'll have to skip content. 

Lastly, this isn't the fault of the game, although I want to throw it out there. I was surprised about how poor the mods are for this game in 2023. Given the age of the game, I would have thought most mods would have settled and there'd be a large selection of stable offerings. What I instead found was most stopped updating in 2018 and somewhere between then and now, they either never worked correctly or stopped working due to game updates. There are some gems out there (couple overhauls were interesting), although you have to be prepared to start all the way over if you find a mod crashes your game or doesn't fit what you want.

I did enjoy a lot of my time in the game. I spent countless hours trying to figure out builds and synergies between powers and of course many, many hours on sites looking at recommended builds because the game is a bit too open on cherry picking your build and absolutely possible to easily build a set of characters that would be lucky to battle crickets. If you enjoy min/maxing, here you go.

Narrator - After finishing the game you are overflowing with emotions. You are reflecting on all you have experienced during your playthrough. Random loot in a game where you cannot grind your gear. 90% of encounters being an ambush. Scripted events lead to infinite knockdown, forcing you to save and reload. Not to mention encounters that would be impossible to get through if it weren't for a character in your party that had the "right" spells. You recall a time when you were chopped to death by an out-of-combat entity during an enemy turn. Combat itself was mostly repetitive, favoring an enemy, and highlights on spell boundaries did not reflect the true range. Roleplaying in the game was destroyed by a lack of visual variety for your equipment and character, robot NPCs, and almost all your choices having impact only on the next line of the dialog they were chosen in. Since you played with your friends, it was even worse. Getting through repetitive dialogs or forced exchange of a dialog was common practice. You find it funny that when you got the final and the only impactful choice in the end you couldn't even see your teammates' opinions to further strategise your final decision like you have been doing through the course of the entire game. Last but not least, the main story of the game and basically every dialogue felt extremely generic and shallow. Like they were written by a drama school dropout for an 8-year-old. You cannot but wonder. How can a game with so many shortcomings get an "Overwhelmingly positive" rating with 150k reviews? You notice only 11% of players have finished the game on any difficulty and check other reviews. The final question comes to mind. Is Larian's fanbase full of white knights praising its unfinished product and awarding negative reviews with a jester emoji even though it's already six years after release, or is this game beyond your understanding? You may never know.

LICH d&d 
Traits
Legendary Resistance (3/Day): If the lich fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

Rejuvenation: If it has a phylactery, a destroyed lich gains a new body in 1d10 days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the phylactery.

Spellcasting: The lich is an 18th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save DC 20, +12 to hit with spell attacks). The lich has the following wizard spells prepared:

• Cantrips (at will): mage hand, prestidigitation, ray of frost
• 1st level (4 slots): detect magic, magic missile, shield, thunderwave
• 2nd level (3 slots): detect thoughts, invisibility, acid arrow, mirror image
• 3rd level (3 slots): animate dead, counterspell, dispel magic, fireball
• 4th level (3 slots): blight, dimension door
• 5th level (3 slots): cloudkill, scrying
• 6th level (1 slot): disintegrate, globe of invulnerability
• 7th level (1 slot): finger of death, plane shift
• 8th level (1 slot): dominate monster, power word stun
• 9th level (1 slot): power word kill

Turn Resistance: The lich has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

Actions
Paralyzing Touch: Melee Spell Attack: +12 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 10 (3d6) cold damage. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or be paralyzed for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Legendary Actions
Can take 3 Legendary Actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time, and only at the end of another creature's turn. Spent legendary actions are regained at the start of each turn.

Cantrip: The lich casts a cantrip.

Paralyzing Touch (Costs 2 Actions): The lich uses its Paralyzing Touch.

Frightening Gaze (Costs 2 Actions): The lich fixes its gaze on one creature it can see within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw against this magic or become frightened for 1 minute. The frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the lich's gaze for the next 24 hours.

Disrupt Life (Costs 3 Actions): Each non-undead creature within 20 feet of the lich must make a DC 18 Constitution saving throw against this magic, taking 21 (6d6) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

TLDR: many many positive aspects that are ruined by improper balancing of multiple aspects of the game. Game is fun through the first 3 acts but act 4 ruins it all.

------------

Great game overall with solid gameplay, voice acting, combat and roleplay elements but it's riddled with balancing issues in many ways : 

->Certain abilities and synergies are just too good to not have equipped. Unless you min-max using a guide, you will more than likely not be optimal and the endgame will be a frustrating experience. And I say that as someone who normally loves to find ways to min-max but, in this game, you have to be sweaty-tryhard min-maxing into pigeon-holed builds. Anything that isn't that will be severely handicapped. If you don't follow a build guide, be ready to spend the majority of the game "cheesing" most of the fights by abusing the AI's dumbness (like hiding behind a doorway where AI enemies will rush you 1 by 1). 

->Too many fights near the endgame will have enemies be completely immune (or even heal) from certain elements. As there's only 4 elements in the game, if your team happens to use a lot of spells (like mine with 3/4 of my team being mages) some of your characters will become pretty much useless as their main element deals no damage. 

->Too many cursed elements/surfaces in a lot of fights. Your whole screen will often be completely filled with necrofire or other cursed element. This will cause your own elements to not work more often than not (ie: you want your water mage to fill the field with some water and/or freeze enemies? not possible because the whole f-ing map is filled with necrofire that cannot be extinguished unless you spend your limited source points only for it to become filled with necrofire everywhere once more a round later). 

->Certain semi-generic enemies (mainly voidwoken) will DESTROY you in act 4 with attacks doing 1/4 of your whole hp+armor (even with resistances) while attacking twice per turn and multiple of that enemy type is present in the fight. Have fun chugging through your (limited) resistance potions to just not be oneshot!

->Lots of quests are too hard to complete unless you follow a guide or read the wiki. Too many quests require you to find something or do something and it's really not well explained even if you take the time to read the dialogues and books/notes/clues. 

->Difficulty scaling between the acts is all over the place for combat. Act 1 (mainly the beginning/for new players) can be really hard, act 2 is well balanced overall, same for act 3 but act 4 becomes extremely unpleasant with overtuned enemies and enemies coming at you in far greater numbers than your 4-men party size can handle (unless, again, you're rocking one of them perfectly min-maxed parties or always cheesing). 

->Certain enemies are overleveled to the point where it's impossible to beat them at the "natural" level that you happen to encounter them unless you know (in advance) that they are there and you prepared accordingly with a cheesing tactic specifically built for said fight. Those kind of overleveled and overtuned enemies will be evident, when you meet them, that they are literally there to piss you off. Most people will lose to the encounter multiple times until they say "F that" and decide to come back later once they overleveled the enemy. That is so badly designed. 

->Lots would come in the game's defence saying "simply lower the difficulty". Yes, I can lower the difficulty, but it takes the game from "too hard" to "baby easy". There's no in-between properly balanced difficulty tier.

These days [b]Larian Studios[/b] ain't some unknown video game studio, [i]Baldur's Gate 3, anyone?[/i] Roots of their passionate game development and designs are also enjoyable in the previous release; [b]Divinity: Original Sin II Definitive Edition[/b].

[i]Skipping Story section of this review to not have any spoilers. Other sections can contain some spoilers.[/i]

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
From choosing a pre-made characters or creating your own, developers won't restrict your early choose and will provide later an respec option.

From fully voice acted dialogue with fantastic narrator voice, each conversation is intriguing to go through and learn all of the information these can provide. Some are totally silly and some contain encrypted information, how you proceed the information is totally up on your mind.

What about the combat, you may ask. Being a [b]Larian Studios[/b] game, only your imagination is the limit what can be created and done. Follow tutorial norms on each fight or lay traps on the battleground for your enemies and watch whole world burn.  

Explore the world, have conversations with random NPC's, fight, loot and hoard every items turning yourself to pack mule, complete the storylines and have fun.  

[h2]Soundtrack[/h2]
Oh my lord, the soundtrack hits so hard. From the beginning to turn of the events it will open each of your Eight Gates from your brain to legs till very end to your heart and you will feel the power of perfection in a fight when they are pushing your party to the limit.

Lastly, this game is one of the best co-op tactical RPG experiences available at Steam, thou check the latest perfection named as [b]Baldur's Gate 3.[/b]

[h2]Final score: 10/10[/h2]

Extremely good game. If you enjoyed BG3 then you'll also really enjoy this game. The fundamentals are little different but the same charm, wit, engaging gameplay that Larian is known for is still present. 

I have less of a desire to replay this game than I do BG3 but definitely got my money's worth.

Combat mechanics are great, very fun and engaging. Story is pretty good, some inconsistent lore stuff but that can be ignored. There's some limited opportunity for rp with the origin characters but it's not the focus of the game. Combat encounters and quest completion encourage outside the box thinking, there are some very effective and fun ways to fight and many quests have multiple ways to solve them. I've played through two full times and expect to come back to it at some point.

Alright, I had to change the review to add in a few more details after 4 hours of gameplay and adding in my original thoughts. 

The game is wonderful, its just a lot of fun. The longer I play in it though there is for sure an element of difficulty that sometimes prides itself on being a type of Dark Souls breed and its usually in the form of bosses as they can be stupidly tough to beat. The level designs are nothing special and you can get absolutely murdered with the wrong build, which this game hinges on. The proper build = easier victories. Not guaranteed, just easier. Its a lot of fun and since there is no "leveling" up per say its just progressing the story and trying to get new parts. This adds to the longevity of the game for sure which is a unique element here. The game isnt wanting you to play through long levels that are massive in scale. The levels are specific, short and to the point. This helps with the replayability and swapping out builds to try, this is a brilliant choice in gameplay. It does come with some frustration since some builds can go together like facebook and free speech and others like fromsoftware games go with fun, they either really work or they really dont. 

Edit: Building for bosses is extremely frustrating. You can go into one build through the level and then need something entirely different then the boss. Also, the back and forth of trying to build for a boss trial and error just sucks. Its the one thing that actually does frustrate me very much. 

The game looks pretty good on 4k though the backdrop is bland. It looks more like a game from the late 90's at least in the architecture and such. The story is there to fill in gaps and music isnt really here. 

Overall such a solid experience from FromSoftware. I much prefer this and Sekiro over Elden Ring and Dark Souls, all coming from the same developer, its just a great time. Appreciate the game FromSoftware!!!

Clicks in the same way Sekiro did, in that a switch labeled "Violence" will flick on in your head. Before you know it you'll be running dual zimms, dual sweet 16s on a lightweight mech with reverse bipedal legs. No one can stop you, and no one *will* stop you, because no one is left to stop you.

I'm a big Gundam fan and this is the only game ever made that comes to close to making you feel like you're piloting one.. EVEN THOUGH the IP isn't that at all! I hope Sunrise takes notes and copies the way they did the combat in this, because it is spectacular, the best mech action game ever made.

If you're a Fromsoft aficionado expecting a Soulslike game this is not it, don't come in expecting one. The game is mostly fairly easy by design and plays completely different. There are however some amazing bosses in this, so that part of the Souls DNA is mostly there. 

Also if the game might seem very short, but it's meant to be completed THREE TIMES because there are three endings, with the third playthrough unlocking the chance to get the third elusive ending.

The franchise struggles to embrace epic mech combat when its such a grind. It started fun and has ended bitter.

Armored Core VI Fires of Rubicon

Personal Enjoyment Rating - 8/10

Completion time - 38hrs True Ending/16 hours first ending

Suggested for fans of the Armored Core series, general consensus seems very positive. If you like the idea of playing a solo mech and speccing it out with countless weapons and various body parts while managing ‘weight’, ‘power’ and a whole slew of other stats..this game could be for you. It’s a fast paced action packed game with bosses that will stomp you in the ground until you adapt skillfully or quite often...selecting the right build. As a souls vet that’s never played previous AC games, I can safely say I hope to see more sooner than later. 

[h2]Premise[/h2]
Armored Core VI is a long awaited sequel to one of FromSoftware’s earliest franchises. The premise is that you are a mercenary controlling a single mech to complete jobs for the various factions on the planet Rubicon. Being a merc, you aren’t exactly choosing favorites here. It’s a fast paced action packed game with bosses that will stomp you in the ground until you adapt skillfully or quite often...selecting the right build. As a souls vet that’s never played previous AC games, I can safely say I hope to see more sooner than later.
[h2]Graphics[/h2] 
-Looks good, mechs are pretty detailed
-Not much color variety in the environments, could say it looks bleak
-Some of the scale of the environments can be awe-inspiring
[h2]Music/Sound Design[/h2]
-Composed by by Kata Hoshino, alongside Takshi Onodera and Shoi Myazawa 
-Music fits the bleak setting, though nothing much stands out too much for me, doesn’t mean it’s bad
-Lots of Electronic/synthwave
-Mech dash, rocket salvos and some melee weapons sound awesome
[h2]Narrative[/h2] 
-In true FromSoft fashion you are not met with a lot of exposition
-To describe the story I think would spoil the essence of their style of storytelling
-There are very subtle choices in the game, but until NG+ nothing really matters until that final choice.
- Biggest criticism would be that you need to beat the game in NG+2 to get the ‘True Ending’
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
-High octane prepare for lots of dodging and explosions
-This game is not made to have a single cookie cutter build to blast through the whole game
-Players must get comfortable with switching parts when things get tough, otherwise they will have a bad time
-Bosses can feel unfair at times, again evaluate the build and try something new
-Definitely the most fast paced Fromsoft game I have played
-Mission based, most super short..can finish them within 5 minutes
-You can/should replay missions to get an ‘S’ and ’A’-’F rank. Higher rank reaps higher rewards
-Exploration is super minimal, I can count on one hand how many chests I found with parts in them and they all were very obvious locations on the way to the quest marker
[h2]Performance[/h2]
-Played great on both Steam Deck and Desktop
Thankfully Fromsoft is one japanese company that isn’t forgetting PC performance is important also
[h2]Steam Deck Specific[/h2]
-stable 30fps, medium settings ran and looked good
-I can see text being hard to read for many, it took some adjustment for myself

Not saying that there shouldn't be these souls-like style bosses, just that some of them are a little annoying to fight.

Oh and hard lock doesn't work with mouse and keyboard because if you even move your mouse  a thousandth of an inch when you go to fire, it will break your hard lock and not track the target, which is infuriating. 

Otherwise 9.5/10 game with great story, interesting characters, fantastic gameplay, extensive customization, and progression.

I can recommend this game, even though I don't like it being projectile based most of the time. I have never died to a normal enemy, and never more than twice to a boss. 

On the other hand, I enjoy trying out different configs, as you can customize basically every aspect of your AC. I've never tried any mech games before this, and I'm impressed with how good everything feels about operating the AC, managing stamina and go for cool plays. It's a blast!

I have never touched AC before this game, so this was my first forte into the game. On the very base level, I had so much fun. The gameplay is addicting and the story is entertaining. I had times where I was having trouble stopping. This game is with flaws though, ill list them out.

1. The story is mediocre when it comes to the writing. From Soft's attempt at making an cohesive story went generally pretty well, compared to their very subdued method of storytelling in the Souls games. That being said, I have qualms. The story seems to be missing.... something. Im not sure what it is, but there is an awful lot that I feel is not told. This is not usually an issue, but in a story where your being far more direct about the games matters it feels like im missing important details. The endings also leave much to be desired. The first two endings left me feeling like I was once again missing something. They were too sudden. The third was much better though in that regard.

2. Gameplay is really fun, but theres some really annoying mechanics. The stun mechanic by far is too unforgiving. The From Soft special on hard games may be a way to justify it (cause yeah this game is genuinely hard), but in multiplayer it is awful. The stun mechanic single handedly created the meta builds for this game. It seriously should be toned down. In a game where movement is focused on heavily, overbearing stun mechanics are infuriating to play against.

3. The gameplay progression is atrocious. The difficulty is all over the place, even regardless of your build. Especially the bosses, you can go from fighting the hardest bosses of the games to some easy throwaway bosses like the difficulty spikes are all over the place.

4. NG (even up to +3) provides very little extra challenge. When your that far into the game and most likely have established builds, I could get through most missions without a single repair kit used, even in NG+2.

5. Special mention towards end of Walter ending, come on From Soft repeating bosses again. They never learn.

With those gripes in mind, this game is extremely fun, but there definitely is some potential that could've been taken advantage of more effectively. As a massive Souls fan, I was really happy with the chance to try one of their other exports, and this did not dissapoint.

ive played 3, 4, and for answer, played too little of 1, 2, and 5 (played some verdict day) to consider them truly "played," for reference my favorite in the series is for answer and... i really like this game. some things were lost and some things were gained, such as the frenetic, fighting game level movement tech of for answer and the general skill ceiling/insane build customization being somewhat (but not ENTIRELY) lost but ac6 just... being a really polished modern fromsoft title being gained, i suppose. even if some features are sorely missed, i really am enjoying what's here a LOT more than i was expecting. easiest recommend from any modern game ive played in years.

About 22 Missions in have B rank arena unlocked and have to say an alarming amount of people seem to be dogshit at games. Unless there is some massive spike in the game I haven't hit yet,it isn't that hard. Seen some paste eaters complain about "needing energy weapon for boss." It's a phenomenal game. Another masterpiece from FromSoft.

There is definitely a learning curve with this game. It makes me think of those old action games from the 90s that didn't hold your hand, and if you wanted to beat the whole game you had to do it in one sitting. Some people don't like the mission based format, but to me, this is a breath of fresh air in our "open-world" saturated content with a million map markers. I prefer the straightforward nature of this game. It knows what it is, and it does not apologize for it.

It took me about 4 weeks (I have a life) to get past the first few bosses, Balteus and Sea-Spider in particular. I'll admit this was frustrating, but after I became more and more familiar with the game and it's controls, it began to click, and I cannot tell you how satisfying and rare that is in today's games. When you start to get the controls and mechanics of this game it can become impossible to turn off.

I can confidently say that this will be one of the few games in my library that I feel motivated to 100%. This is partly due to the fact that they are all very achievable, and secondly, the fact that there are real game and story beats you are rewarded with for getting that far. Fantastic game. I can't put my controller down.

Oh yeah, I play with a controller. Some people will greatly prefer a keyboard and mouse approach. I prefer the controller (one with grip paddles) so that I can press more weapon buttons without letting go of my movement and aim controls. If you are good with target tracking, you will dominate PvP. I don't care much for multiplayer, I have close to 80 hrs in the game and have yet to play a single match. The single player gameplay is just that good.

Aside from a few lock-ups and crashes (my setup is experimental), the game is wildly stable. I can't stress this enough for an action game like this to be so rock solid.

If you have been looking for a fantastic action game that rewards patience and skill, look no further. Also, the customization abilities given to the player are like a whole 2nd game by themselves. Looking forward to AC7!
Typical Fromsoft BS. Super easy missions, with boss fights that you have to try a dozen times to beat. Completely disrespectful of players time and nothing like the original.

Sea Spider, just go in right under him and he won't hit you much, then use whatever you have equipped with a pile bunker. 3. Ibis series (4th chapter boss), dual stun needle and pile bunker+ whatever else you want, maybe Zimmerman. There are 3 endings to the game so don't go worrying when you finished it the first time thinking it wasn't worth the money. Also, there aren't many bugs, and personally I've had none, but i know some others have.
