This is by far one of the best iteration of the mech genre ever done. The speed of the gameplay, the utilization of every button on your controller or many buttons on your mouse and keyboard, to truly feel as if you are piloting a Core in this game.

The length of the missions is perfect, not too long while retaining difficulty on some missions/fights. The game also encourages multiple playthroughs to allow for different outcomes/missions available depending on your decisions.

The variety of builds you can create from the diversity of the types of weapons and core parts is vast without being too numerous. Seemingly unlimited combinations that can work, depending on your play style.

Armored Core 6 encourages switching up your play style/builds to make missions easier/more fun; which in my opinion, makes a phenomenal mech game. Being that, if you put the effort and time into creating ACs (builds to switch between) instead of being stuck on a boss for days/weeks on end it can be cut down to minutes/hours by switching between the builds and eventually finding a weakness for the boss/stage you're on.


Without getting to deep into the weeds, TL;DR: This has become one of my top favorite games I've ever played. If you have ever wanted to play mech game and be a gundam/mech/core of your own creation, buy this game.

Having now 100%'d Armored Core VI's content, I can say with confidence that this has been one of the best games I have played that was released this year. While its mission-based gameplay can cause hiccups in story pacing, the ability to design and pilot a mech- sorry, AC, based on my own preferences was an absolute blast. Fine-tuning your AC for whatever the game can throw your way is fun in initial playthroughs, and optimising for S-ranks is equal parts frustrating and rewarding.

I've heard from some that the story feels lacklustre, to which I disagree. In your face stories have never really been Fromsoft's style from what I'm told, so having lore take a backseat to the action while permitting the dedicated sleuths to discover more of the setting through exploration and repeat playthroughs felt just fine. Just because there isn't a steam achievement for finding all the data logs doesn't make it any less rewarding to get those tidbits of info.

Cannot recommend this title enough. Whether you buy it on sale or at full price, this will be money well spent.

As someone who grew up on the series since the first game released, I can easily recommend this entry. Why? Just play it. In the first hour you will recognize mechanics from the old games mixed with From Software's experience over the years blended in nicely, making an awesome title that deserves to be included in the series. Has it changed some things? Sure, read the absolute mind numbing list found on both the forums here and in Reddit that details way more than I care to. But it doesn't subtract from the overall amazing job the developers have accomplished with this game. Give it a chance. You will most likely enjoy it and appreciate everything the game brings to the series. Enjoy!

*Update 10-20-2023*
Apparently the complaints of a few outweigh the many. Boss battles have been changed/made easier, weapons have been debuffed and/or buffed for multiplayer sake... the normal spill by this point, with anything released in recent years, sadly. Does it matter? Sorta. I still recommend the game. But know that your build one day may completely be garbage the next. A go to strategy, part choice, or tactics WILL change and/or become obsolete depending on how people complain and demand change. So keep that in mind.

Whew. That took a while. I completed all the missions. Got all the endings. Got all the upgrades. It's been a while since a game got me this hooked.

Here's what you should expect:
* This is not Dark Souls.
* This is a fast-paced mech game. The game's much faster than the likes of Mechwarrior, think more Gundam, but the mechs are more like fighter jets or tanks.
* There's a ton of customization: a decent amount of body parts, a very broad arsenal of weapons, incredible flexibility in terms of paint palettes and decals. It's not as open-ended as the previous 3 games, though - no weight-balancing to ensure your mech can turn fast in all directions.
* Not all mechs will be right for all missions. In the end I found the one that matched my playstyle and mostly stuck to it, but some missions need custom builds or benefit a lot from them.
* There's tons of replayability. You can replay any mission you've already beat. When you beat the game, you start from the beginning with all your unlocks, ready to try the missions you skipped last time. In fact, you need to do this at least three times to unlock everything.
* There's PvP - 1v1 or 3v3. Seems fun, not my thing.

Some tips:
* You *need* to learn to customize your mechs. If you use the same build for every mission you're going to have a bad time. It's a little daunting at first, with all the numbers to each part... but they're very well explained. You'll learn what to care about. Look for Crightt's videos on YouTube, he does a great job explaining how parts work and what to pick.
* Don't grind, you don't really need it. Sell the parts you're not using, you'll get all your money back every time.
* Explore, try new approaches. Give Iguana a bad time.

I'll take a break before trying to S-rank every mission.

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is a relentless masterpiece. Its stunning visuals, intense combat, and rich narrative make it a must-play for anyone seeking a challenging and unforgettable gaming experience.
beeg fish annoying

A masterpiece. It pulls you in with beautiful landscapes and places you get to explore, then challenges you to epic boss fights. Of course, you'll die, and die again. But the deaths felt always deserved, it's always clear where your mistake was.

There are consumables, upgrades, skills to unlock. Every one feels impactful and interesting - no minor stat boosts, going from 14 Dex to 15 Dex. But all that is secondary - the more you play, the more you realise you don't need any upgrades to to beat the game, you just need to git gud. And because of well-placed respawn points, no grinding or long walking stand between defeat and trying again. 

Let yourself be abducted into a divine, fantastical version of japan, that is colourful and very, very deadly.

I was afraid, but I tried anyway,
And I did it, I beat the game.
Sekiro, you tested me,
But I refused to break.

Your bosses were tough,
Your enemies relentless,
But I persevered,
And I became relentless.

I learned to deflect,
I learned to counter,
I learned to dance with death,
And I emerged victorious.

Sekiro, you are a masterpiece,
A game that challenges and rewards,
A game that makes you feel like a true shinobi.

Thank you, Sekiro, for the journey.

Sekiro stands out as both the most challenging and surprisingly accessible game in the FromSoftware catalog. The initial playthrough can be a relentless onslaught, where hordes of enemies can be just as demanding as some bosses, like the Akimbo Monkey in Ashina Depths.

However, as you gain experience and grow accustomed to the game's unique mechanics, subsequent playthroughs tend to become considerably more manageable. In my case, after completing my first playthrough with the Immortal Severance ending, my second run with the Purification ending felt notably easier. Additionally, taking on all the gauntlets of strength contributed to this enhanced sense of control and mastery.

In essence, Sekiro's progression encourages players to "get good" by developing their skills and adapting to its intricacies. It's a game where, once you've refined your abilities, the difficulty curve becomes more satisfying, transforming the once seemingly insurmountable challenge into a rewarding experience.

I just finished my first blind playthrough at 25 hours. This game is really close to knocking Elden Ring out of my #1 spot. The combat flows incredibly well and rewards aggression. The process of mastering each boss fight was fair and most of all, fun. There really isn't any souls-like that even comes close in terms of combat mastery.

Funnily enough, I played Lies of P before playing Sekiro and I think that made me appreciate the parry system in Sekiro much more. LoP was great but I had a lot of gripes with their parrying system.

I agree with the general consensus that the game is probably the most difficult title FromSoft has put out. But as long as you're emotionally stable, learn from your mistakes and know how to read, you'll be fine. If Asmongold can beat this game, so can you. Don't give up!

I want you to know I mean this with all sincerity, Sekiro is a bad game.
They put an incredible amount of effort into making a bad game, it's poorly built and leaves it to you to make up for its shortcomings by persistence, and by all accounts this is done intentionally.
It presents you with a new and complex combat system and does everything it can to make learning that combat system as lengthy and laborious as possible. Ridiculous damage levels, unbalanced overworld encounters, lazy ganks/crowd positioning, unintuitive progression paths, narrow combat options, detrimental and/or misleading visual cues, absurdly restrictive recovery options and the persistent Fromsoft refusal to provide you with even the cursory knowledge necessary to engage with their games, it's just tedium on tedium on tedium. The amount of time this game insists you waste, for no other reason than it says so is staggering. This was never an issue of git gud, this is an issue of how little space you're given to git gud and why in the fucking world you would ever want to. Adding a 5 minute timer to every death in dark souls would make beating a boss take longer as well, what value does that add though? The run to the boss again didn't add anything but tedium, and it feels like that sensation of having to run your ass back over and over permeates almost the entire entity of sekiro. The stealth is mediocre but when I have to redo a stealth section each time I want to give a mini-boss another try before he deletes me in one 2 hit combo that required me to already know what his tell meant ahead of time, with a warning sign that could mean 3 different things and blocks your vision of the animations, while I'm equipped with a healthbar and a half's worth of healing I'll never get to use, suddenly the stealth feels a lot worse, and so does the gank squad he'll spawn with, or the sniper on the roof I have to deal with beforehand every time, should I be so lucky that there's only one. The game also has an obsession with excess healthbars and most minibosses hit harder than the bosses proper which just feels like the overworld design team and the boss design team were too busy gangstalking schizos on their lunchbreaks to communicate to each other whether you're supposed to be 1shot by everything in the game or just 76% of everything. This game is bad until you master the combat, and it makes sure mastering it is as slow, laborious, tedious, dull, miserable and painful an experience as possible. I wanted to beat this game just so I could say I still hate it for what it is and what it represents, but I honestly don't think I can force myself to do it, I've spent weeks of my life scrubbing rust off the bottom of trucks in the middle of winter with a wonky drill attachment that would fly off every 10 minutes fall down next to my head and take off down the road (which I'd have to go get only to repeat the cycle) and that feels like a fond memory in comparison. The fact that I paid for this, and an entire 60 god damn dollars is insane, and the only thing more insane would be continuing to play it when it gives me whatever the exact chemical opposite of dopamine is, solely to convince people on the internet my opinion is valid when they already made up their own damn minds. Call me what you like, and if you got something out of this game I envy you, but that changes nothing for me, this game was the worst piece of media I ever spent money on and it's not even close. It's so bad it somehow bled into elden ring and made that an unlikable experience too, which I didn't even risk buying myself since I was made aware by this game that From software has concluded its balancing efforts and decided they don't make games anymore, just money. That perhaps is the only compliment I can give it, it was the red flag to signal me to never give From a cent again. I'm better off paying for CBT sessions, same experience except I actually get to feel the touch of a woman for once, which for the fellow soulsborne enthusiasts out there, is a truly novel experience.

TL;DR Game's shit unless you fetishize suffering like those dudes that do no hit runs of entire games or even franchises, them I can understand liking this. To the rest I would say your time and money are better spent learning to whittle or bake, perhaps even touching grass.

Sekiro™: Shadows Die Twice, scoring a 6/10, delivers an engaging experience reminiscent of Dark Souls 3 but with its unique allure. The game’s distinct charm sets it apart, offering a different flavor of challenge and excitement. Its stunning visuals are a testament to its craftsmanship, immersing players in a beautifully crafted world. However, the absence of a co-op mode feels like a missed opportunity, limiting the game’s potential for shared adventures. Despite this shortcoming, Sekiro™ remains fun, showcasing FromSoftware’s mastery in creating visually captivating and immersive gaming environments, making it a worthwhile journey for solo players.

Game's crap, utterly overrated. Here are my points.
For context, I tried to endure through this game and gave up on it 4 times completing only one boss,
on the fifth try i finally could make it, got through all of the bosses in 5 or less attempts with the demon bell enabled except Corrupted Monk which took 10~ tries and Isshin the Sword Saint where i had to turn off demon bell in 20~ attempts.
1. Gameplay.
People say it's fun and it's a rhythm game, i can agree on the rhythm part except it's without music and completely relies on combo memorization, play osu!mania without music and just memorize the combination to complete the map, not very fun.
And when you get hit it's usually 50% and up to 80% of your hp, which decimates your posture which forces you to sprint from the boss to heal and start building up his posture all over again. Sure when you memorized all attacks it looks and plays fun, pity thats like 2% of total gametime. If you don't wanna die and game highly incentivizes you to try to hang on to your life by taking half of your current skill point progress and half of your money WITH NO MEANS TO RETURN THEM and occasionally inflicts Dragonrot which is completely unnecessary and useless mechanic when you can literally cure it for 200~ sen, it's just annoying hassle, sure it's not impactful and i had to only cure it once, but why have it in the first place?
So if you don't wanna die you try to play most efficiently, right? The problem is the most efficient tactic is to cheese the fuck out of the enemies, for example, early in the game you encounter chained ogre, most of people had troubles dealing with him initially myself included, and what's the most efficient tactic to beat him? You kill the guards, aggroe him, go away far enough and deal a stealth blow, half of the work done, but if you die and do all the steps all over again repeteadely, this gets annoying really fast, you basically have to do 30-60 seconds of prepwork each time before an actual attempt and it happens too frequently in this game, Long-arm centipede Sen-un, where you have to kill 5 smaller centipedes each time while boss is also trying to kill you while youre at that, and not dealing with them isn't an option either, gank fights are nearly impossible in this game, runbacks to mini-bosses who are frequenly harder than the actual bosses are terrible in this game. In boss fights you also are incentivized to cheese them, you find one or two moves where you can deal damage, do so a couple of times so their posture breaks at an adequate pace and do this process 2 or 3 three times, depending on the boss, alternalively you bash your head against the wall 10 or 20 times so you perfectly guard his every move, i can't find this fun. Also you only get one weapon and most fights are 1-2 attacks, deflect, 1-2 attacks, deflect, 1-2 attacks, boss makes his "black-flame-360 degree-way of the phanthom dragon-mortal strike" move while you jump on his head, deal 2 attacks and all over again.
I don't understand the praise for the Isshin the Sword Saint fight, boss has 4 healthbars and 3.5 movesets, this is just toxic difficulty, basically your prepwork is first two healthbars which ideally last 60 to 90 seconds and then difficulty spikes rapidly, you just try to memorize the moves little by little every death, how is this any fun? Spending minute and a half to get to the actual boss is bad design, real difficulty is your mental state, i felt exausted at the end of the fight, i didn't feel like i've beat the odds and overcome the challenge like i did when i beat Malenia (no spirits, no freezing pots, two-handed Nagakiba, 120~ lvl, if you assume i didn't fight "the right way" or that im a casual, i would argue not). Okay enough of the gameplay, i already wrote too much.
2. The World
Sure the world looks beautiful, but i got kinda bored of it and sometimes lost (namely in Ashina Castle) because of the repeating architecture, i feel like there could be more variance, subjective, not a big flaw.
The enemy placement, it's bad, like, you place 5 F***ing okami warriors in the same place? How are you supposed to fight them? I wrote about gankfights earlier, i don't think i could take 2 in a fight, and you place 5? Theres also a moment in foutainhead palace where you encounter 2 nobles and a lightning naginata okami warrior in a wide corridor and no means to run through them or get around them, the problem is this warrior doesn't chase you in a safe place from nobles and one of the nobles is behind a fence which makes it impossible to kill him from a distance, it makes the encounter very annoying and painful. Or the s**tton of Fencers in ashina castle, difficulty just for the sake of it, basically you have to cheese again or just run through them which i started to do at some point, there's just no reason to fight common enemies, considering the effort and reward.
3. Customisation
You get NO cosmetics for your character and your only weapon, until you completed the game and beat gauntlets,
even Lies of P, which gets too much hate i feel, has some limited customization and it's enough to freshen things up.
It's not a major flaw of course but i got a little tired in the end, you don't get the feel of progression, you're the same ragged shinobi as you were at the start of the game.
4. Movement
It feels slippery and i felt like i couldn't rely on it, especially catching ledges and inintuitive seemingly random grapples.
I played on the MnK for the context, maybe it's better on the controller.
Its a souls game but the real twist on this one is that its fair and balanced

as of writing this review i have completed the game on one of its endings and am at 52hrs
this game is great. if your looking to pick it up and have some concerns please read my 2 cents:

its not a game where you can immediately go for long hours on, pacing yourself and giving yourself time to rest before taking on the challenge again is a good start to training yourself slowly  on the combat. (untill you get better) 

its also a game i highly recommend searching on how to play,
 basically there are two ways of killing the enemy
deflecting there attacks so there posture bar fills up which will lead to a deathblow winning the fight, 
or deplete  the health which will give you a chance to deathblow allowing you to win the fight, BUT its like a dance with each battle having there own flow, if you just defend then your posture might break

if you just attack you will die because the enemy hit hard no matter what,
learning the flow really helps with the battles its how the game was made to be played.
so if you do pick the game up please take what i have said into considerations, and if you do you will find a masterpiece of a game, one with a great story and game-play.

i did download this mod to just give me some quality life improvements mostly just borderless window and fps unlocker because it dose run on 60fps and i WANTED MORE hehe, also the auto collect cause im lazy
hears  the link in case you want to do the same: https://www.nexusmods.com/sekiro/mods/13

i also found looking up ways to defeat the character was really helpful,

like i said before its like a flow
spamming will give you troubles
and blocking aswell
slowing  the pace and learning what the enemy dose will help you get there quicker, anyway

I have been gaming for a long time, and I hardly ever take the time to leave a review. However, this game absolutely blew me away and will probably always be one of the greatest and most challenging games I have ever played. This game introduced me to FromSoftware and impacted how I play video games. now every other game I play has to be on the hardest mode or I will get bored, no joke. 

Do yourself a favor and play through this game until the bitter end. It is thoroughly challenging, so be prepared to die a lot. But also be prepared to win over bosses you thought you would never beat. This game has amazing art, graphics, and combat. I cannot emphasize enough how this masterpiece is an absolute MUST play.

Probably pretty fun when you can see.
Camera is fucking awful though in cramped areas and you can't see shit.
Vsynch cannot be enabled in game leading to terrible screen tearing unless you do some jank shit to your graphics card.
No way to view the information cards unless you're currently loading, which in the modern era via SSD's, means you won't see it at all.
Want to play with a controller? That means unplugging most of your peripherals as the game continues to detect mice and keyboards as controllers.
Don't forget all the fun of resetting your own monitor settings, as for some unknown reason, Sekiro disables Gsynch, HDR, and others after closing the game.
Garbage that requires dozens of hours to learn the intricacies of it is still garbage.

This game is a work of art from a game design perspective.

While the combat may be a bit confusing at first to those who have played the other Souls titles, stick with it. Once you figure it out, it becomes easily the most enjoyable of the entire series in my opinion. It is lightning fast and smooth as butter. Instead of constantly staring at your opponent to wait for your chance to dodge and get a few hits in, the game actively rewards you for being the aggressor and attempting to break your opponent's posture before the same is done to you.

I will say, this game is even more reliant on raw reaction time than the other titles. If you are not snappy with reactions or good at learning boss attack patterns, you will struggle with this one, at least to start.

However, it is definitely worth sticking through this one. Once the combat finally clicked for me, I had the most fun I have ever had with a melee combat game. This game has perfected the art of making you feel like  an absolute badass, and you deserve it, too.

As far as the negatives go, there aren't too many. I do wish the game wasn't locked to 60 FPS, but we've all come to expect that from FromSoft PC releases. If you don't go out of your way to beat minibosses and acquire items and upgrades, some fights can be an absolute slog, but they are very few and far between.

Overall, an easy recommendation to any that enjoy the genre. Give it some time to click for you, you won't regret it.

The moment this game clicks for you, the feeling is unparalleled. it will take courage to attempt, however. every encounter in this game feels daunting and perilous, and as if if you survive, it will be only barely. It compels one to focus intensely on the game's combat fundamentals to the point of aestic discipline.

It's csgo but worse.
Still lacking a lot of features like the workshop, making stuff like aim training much more cumbersome and potentially dangerous as you have to download random files from the depths of the internet.
Custom game modes like arms race, gun game, etc are also still missing as you can only play diffuse on a rather limited selection of maps (RIP Trains, Cache, etc) or hostage on Office, that's it.

CS2 should've been either delayed and get more fleshed out before release (at least to feature parity) or be its separate thing, not completely replacing csgo. You would've thought the industry had learnt the lesson when Blizzard replaced Warcraft 3 with the Reforged but I guess companies always have to do the mistakes themselves to (hopefully) learn.

This is the same CS we all love or hate just with a fresh coat of paint, so you know exactly what you are getting.

On the technical side, for my fairly powerfull PC (As in 2080/7700K etc) it's still very choppy and there is severe tearing I have not been able to diagnore yet. So there is still much work to be done here. Do not expect the same flawless performance of CSGO (Which did took years to achieve if we are to be honest).

Now on the ethical side:
Removing CSGO entirely from the library (Which in my case was a game I actually bought for 15 euros on release) and keeping it's stelar reviews for CS2, many of which no longer aply, I find it very shady. I bet if EA had done that they d had hit the headlines as the most hated company.

Removing CSGO achievements, which in my case were 100% done after 1000s hours of play, many happy memories etc without even some badge or regongition in their place, also extremely scummy.

The dev's passion is commendable and no doubt the game is loved by many. This is a personal problem and I want to make that clear from the start. 

The enemies aren't fun to fight against. I cannot comprehend the way they move and attack. There are no wind-ups for most of them and the devs use the exclamation mark as indication. I don't wish to condemn their capabilities but relying on an "!" leads me to believe they know the issue as well. 

Seeing a tiny "!" in a room filled with many types of enemies, with the explosion of colors and particles the game showers the screen with just doesn't feel fun. 

Another issue I have is there are no "items". Almost all games in the genre have items that modify many aspects of a run but in this one, it is only ever gear. Weapons and tools. No items. There is nothing to look forward to in a run. you got a nice weapon? You won't be looking at anything else. 

No wonder they lean so heavily towards speedrunning. And I have nothing against speedrunning. This is just an observation. There is just nothing worth finding in the areas.

In the end, the game just doesn't feel fun for me.

In the realm of gaming, a tale unfolds,
Of a rogue who's not quite what you're told.
"Dead Cells" they call it, a curious delight,
A pixelated world where you'll die, take flight.

With every demise, a lesson you'll learn,
As your character's fate takes another sharp turn.
You'll hack and you'll slash, you'll dodge and you'll roll,
In this procedurally generated deathly stroll.

The enemies swarm, like bees to a hive,
But you'll laugh as you slay, feeling oh so alive.
A whip, a bow, a sword, or a shield,
Choose your weapons wisely, the power to wield.

The humor is dark, the visuals so bold,
A mix of the grotesque and the comically cold.
The graphics are stunning, pixel art grand,
In this ever-changing world, you'll make your last stand.

The soundtrack, it thumps, like a heart in your chest,
As you fight through the levels, never knowing what's best.
The boss battles loom, challenging and grand,
With patterns to learn, as you face the next brand.

So if you seek laughter in the face of your doom,
"Dead Cells" is your game, in pixelated costume.
It's quirky, it's tough, a true rogue-like surprise,
With humor and action, under death's watchful eyes.

So here's to the cells, both living and dead,
In this game, they've been masterfully wed.
A humorous romp through dungeons and halls,
"Dead Cells" is a gem, worth many applause!

Played this back when I was on xbox and I'm having just as much fun playing it PC. This game has endless replay value - not just for the quaint humor and bits of lore you find around the procedurally generated maps, but for the absolutely flawless combat system, synergies and styles. It's snappy and clean, making your dungeon runs a veritable joy. Even when you die after having gotten the perfect loadout collected and you wanna pull your hair out in the reloading screen, you will quickly get over it because it's just that much fun to try again. The DLC isn't very expensive and if you buy it along with the base game you'll way more that enough variety to keep you going. 10/10 easy.

Fun game with tons of replay-ability, where you learn and get better over time. Where the game gets harder, sometimes it doesn't feel like it, not because the difficulty increase is minimal, but because you've learned and trained yourself to expect it, and flow with it perfectly.
It's a wonderful game that I am still awful at.

I have realised that this game's gameplay loop becomes very boring and repetitive after a while. The difficulty is fun at first but becomes extremely tedious when you put in an hour and a half of work in one run only to have it thrown away because you made one slip-up. This is not a skill issue, it's just boring after some time. There is an assist mode but using it makes you feel like you're cheating and defeats the game's central hook even when making minor changes. This is currently the second-most-played game in my library and I am leaving a negative review. This game gets stale like many other roguelikes. The core gameplay is fantastic but there isn't enough variety and the DLCs are underwhelming.
Note: This was written with 85 hours of play time.

What is Dead Cells? It's, like, a roguelike souls-like metroidvania-like, like you know? Modern buzzwords aside, Dead Cells is an action platformer with procedural levels that grant you infinite replayability. It's one of the best platformers with the smoothest movement, the most epic combat and some of the most beautiful 2D pixel graphics out there. It's refreshing to see a developer try and innovate on oldschool visuals like this, just shows how far we've come. This game has also taken huge inspiration from classic games and learned all the lessons of the days of yore, taking this knowledge and combining it with modern technology and experiences to create something classic but polished and approachable. It's like the ideas of classic action platformers finally realized to perfection. 

Dead Cells can be brutally difficult, but considering how fluid the amazing combat is and how crisp the controls are, it's a pure test of skill. If it gets too intense, don't forget to just stop for a bit to take in the beautiful art and amazing music. Hell, I wasn't really a fan of Metroidvanias, Souls-like games or 2D platformers in general going into this, but this game is so good, I loved it anyway and it changed my mind on all of those. I feel like with this experience, I might try and conquer an actual Souls game now, and maybe a Hollow Knight or Shovel Knight on the side. Until then, I will always know that I have one of the best roguelikes on the market to fall back on.

P.S. After you inevitably get seriously invested and then seriously addicted to this game, research the lore! It's kind of hard to experience it within the game itself because of the random dungeons and difficulty, but Dead Cells has some of the most fascinating lore ever! And a very shocking twist near the end too! So research it separately, it's worth it!

Elden Ring... the game we've all been waiting for, the unicorn of the gaming world, a collaboration between the brilliant minds of George R. R. Martin and FromSoftware. But if you're expecting a peaceful stroll through a fantasy meadow, think again. Elden Ring is like a never-ending game of "Whack-a-Mole," except the moles are massive, nightmarish creatures, and you're armed with a rusty butter knife.

The story is about as clear as a muddy pond, which is just how we like it, right? You're a Tarnished, an outcast from a mysterious realm, and your job is to explore the Lands Between, uncover secrets, and battle epic foes. Good luck deciphering what any of that means because, frankly, I'm not entirely sure either.

Now, Elden Ring boasts a beautiful open world, but don't let that fool you. The moment you step outside, you'll be swarmed by grotesque monsters who seem to be on a strict diet of adrenaline and caffeine. You'll die. A lot. But that's okay because death is just a minor inconvenience in this grim and perilous land.

The bosses, well, they're the real stars of the show. They're like the mean older siblings of the Dark Souls bosses, and they have an ego the size of a dragon's horde. You'll scream, cry, and maybe even throw your controller a few times, but when you finally conquer one of these monstrosities, you'll feel like an absolute legend. Until you meet the next one, that is.

Speaking of legends, the horse riding in Elden Ring is nothing short of legendary. You'll gallop through forests, fields, and the occasional pit of despair while trying to make your mount understand that "straight" means going forward, not sideways. But hey, it's all part of the fun.

Now, the game's lore is so deep that it's practically a bottomless well. You'll meet characters with names like "Lady Marika the Ashen" and "Swordmaster Oleg the Desolate," and you'll forget who's who within five minutes. But you'll nod along and pretend to understand because the game's atmosphere is so immersive that you'll feel like you're in a Game of Thrones episode.

In a nutshell, Elden Ring is a masterpiece that's as challenging as it is mystifying. It's a game that takes you on an epic, punishing journey, and when you reach the end, you'll feel a mix of exhaustion and exhilaration. It's the kind of experience that will leave you pondering the meaning of life, or at least the meaning of "you died" on your screen. So, dear Tarnished, sharpen your rusty butter knife and prepare for a wild, mind-bending ride through the mystical and perilous Lands Between. Good luck. You're going to need it.

Before going through what I think of the game, I want to clear the air about how you should look at this game going in. It is NOT Sekiro or Bloodborne so don't play like you did with those games. Put most of your effort towards grinding souls (runes) and exploring to handle mainline bosses. If you really are having a tough time at the game, just do a mage build and reek havoc. 

I love the art style and how filled the open world is, which makes for nearly endless content. The story is pretty good, though it treads the same story beats as a souls game. Combat is that of dark souls but now fully polished for better game feel. Bosses are cool and interesting until the game starts reusing them. Its the best SOULS-LIKE game from software has ever made and great for anyone new getting into the series. Even though its far from perfect, It's one of the best games to come out in recent years.

I do have problems with the game that I don’t think make it a masterpiece in my book. It’s a amazing game and everyone should at least try it, though to say it’s the best game from software has made is just not true. My bias lies on the fact I love sekiro and bloodborne, which I believe are masterpieces in their own rights. The following is a list of problems I have with the game: 
-frame rate issues
-delayed inputs
-game tabs out 
-when torrent (the horse) dies in battle, to summon him again you have to answer a yes or no prompt which is stupid and distracting.
-some enemy AoE animations dont match to hitboxes (it radiates in waves, which makes sense, though some animations don't tell that to the player)
-dungeons are boring and uninspired 
-slow rolling in general 
-too heavy of an emphasis on exploring rather than narrative progression (personal opinion)
-too many repeat boss fights

There’s more personal opinions that I think don’t make it a masterpiece that some others may over look or not worry about. It’s a very long game and you are not going to finish it over a weekend. I do really like this game and it’s super rewarding at times, though I cant help but feel I’ve played better.

It took me 30hrs of playing to actually understand why Elden Ring is so good. I come from never playing any FromSoftware games, so it took me a while before I got a handle of the combat mechanics and overall pacing. The time spent discovering various mechanics for the first time has been insanely rewarding. The combat is very enjoyable, which is the reason why I feel so engaged while playing Elden Ring. Magic, sword parrying, backstabs are all awesome mechanics that I love so much. 

I definitely think this game has a horrible system for discovering the uses of items in the game- as well as how to proceed through quests. I find myself having to google guides on how to find locations in the map, complete quests and find key items that would help my character's build be stronger. This would be fine if you've played through a game several times, but I still am on my first playthrough, and find it annoying that I have to alt-tab out of the game constantly which leaves me unimmersed. My other critique would be that the game is simply too depressing at times. There are many moments of death, decay, blood and rot, infected humans, and war. This has caused me to feel hopeless and sad at times-- which I can understand the point and connection these themes have with the lore, but to me it can be a little much at times and forces me to sigh and take a break from the game. But hey, it is sometimes funny getting one-shotted by a mechanized iron maiden that kills you but engulfing you with its festering tentacle arms. 

In my honest opinion, this game is a waste of money if you don't have 30+ hours to spare and don't mind the chores that come with finding items and completing quests. You also need to be fully ready to embrace the lore and challenging gameplay system that the developers have created.

I suppose this game, the, what, eighth iteration of The FromSoft game, has done me a favor, because it tells me I'll never spend another dime on another "Souls-like" as long as I live.  This is beautiful and intriguing and epic and exhilarating and none of those things are a drop in the bucket next to the sheer irritation of effectively being told, "Learn this boss this way or you can't move on," 165 times.  I happily ignored that, slapped on an easy-mode mod, and played something that was at least an approximation of a game I could enjoy, because the base version of Elden Ring is, well, not that.

Where did this company go wrong?  I think it was nearly right away.  Demon's Souls, for instance, can be a fairly broken game once you learn how the leveling system can be turned to your advantage, and I found it rather fun to hammer almost every boss in the game with magic.  The runbacks didn't bother me (because hardly anything killed me anyway), maybe only one zone felt unfair due to stairs (looking at you, Ritual Path), but I feel like they were onto something that they promptly ignored.  Yes, you can likely break Demon's Souls harder than just about every other game of theirs, but that's what worked for me: knowing the bosses were unfair, and that I could be just as unfair as them.

Now?  Eh.  AI that can read your button commands and respond to them?  No thanks.  Multi-hit combos that exist to bait *you* out rather than the other way around?  No thanks.  Speed just for the sake of speed and reach for the exact same reason?  No thanks.  Hard didn't have to be the new normal, but now it is.  I'd rather cheese your fucking game than play it your way; that's how obnoxious your way is, folks.

I would love the Elden ring with the mechanic and easy to understand collectable system from god of war.


Merging the intricate and rewarding gameplay mechanics of Elden Ring with the more intuitive and user-friendly collectible system from God of War could indeed create an engaging gaming experience. This fusion could potentially offer the best of both worlds: the challenging and expansive gameplay of Elden Ring, paired with a more accessible and straightforward approach to collectibles and progression from God of War. Such a hybrid could cater to a broader spectrum of players, retaining the depth and complexity that seasoned gamers seek while providing clearer guidance and a less steep learning curve for newcomers or those who prefer a more direct gameplay experience.

That would be a great expention of the game that I would buy 

Absolutely, such an expansion could enhance the accessibility and user-friendliness of Elden Ring while retaining its core gameplay mechanics that many players enjoy. By simplifying the collectible system and providing clearer guidance on item usage, akin to what is seen in God of War, more players might find it easier to immerse themselves in the rich and challenging world of Elden Ring. Moreover, this could potentially attract a wider audience to the game, including those who might have been initially deterred by its steep learning curve and complex item systems. This scenario illustrates how developers can draw inspiration from different titles to refine and expand upon their own game's design to cater to a broader or different audience segment.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
• Elden Ring offers a breathtaking open-world experience that constantly surprises and rewards curiosity.

• The organic side stories, rather than the grand overarching plot, keep players enthralled with characters' unique agendas and goals.

• Freedom is the cornerstone of Elden Ring's design, allowing players to explore the vast world at their own pace.

• Legacy Dungeons provide a blend of wide-linear levels and challenging encounters, reminiscent of Dark Souls.

• The combat system introduces new elements like guard counters and jump attacks, adding depth and variety.

• Enemy design and variety, coupled with impressive boss battles, contribute to a challenging yet satisfying gameplay experience.



[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Bad[/h1]
• The lack of in-game journal or quest log makes it challenging to fully digest the grand story on the first playthrough.

• The open-world design, while refreshing, may cause regret for missing out on some stories due to the absence of quest markers.


[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Ugly [/h1]
• The regret of missing out on certain stories or quests due to the lack of in-game guidance and markers.


[hr][/hr]

AI GENERATED: Once upon a time, in the tropical paradise of Banana Island, there lived a charismatic banana named Benny. Benny was no ordinary banana. He possessed a unique charm and a zest for adventure that set him apart from the other bananas on the island.

One sunny day, as Benny was hanging from his favorite banana tree, he noticed a beautiful pineapple named Penelope. Penelope was the most exquisite fruit Benny had ever seen, with her vibrant golden color and spiky green crown. Instantly, Benny felt an inexplicable attraction towards her.

Determined to win Penelope's heart, Benny swung into action. He devised a plan to impress her with his talents. Benny knew he had to showcase something extraordinary, something that would make Penelope notice him amidst the sea of other fruits on the island.

With the help of his banana friends, Benny organized a grand talent show. Fruits from all over the island gathered to witness the spectacle. Benny, dressed in a dashing tuxedo, took to the stage with his yellow peel shining brightly under the spotlight.

He began juggling, effortlessly tossing fruits into the air, creating a mesmerizing display of agility. The audience cheered in awe as Benny's juggling act reached its climax. But Benny had a surprise up his sleeve. With a swift motion, he juggled Penelope herself, spinning her delicately in the air. The crowd gasped in amazement, and Penelope couldn't help but be impressed by Benny's audacious display of skill and devotion.

As the talent show concluded, Benny approached Penelope with a bashful smile. "Penelope, you are the sweetest fruit in all the land. Will you be my pineapple, and allow me to be your banana?" he asked, his voice filled with hope.

Penelope blushed, her pineapple cheeks turning a shade of rosy pink. "Benny, your talent and courage have won my heart. I would be delighted to be your pineapple," she replied, her voice filled with affection.

From that day forward, Benny and Penelope became inseparable. They went on countless adventures together, exploring the hidden wonders of Banana Island and creating memories that would last a lifetime. Their love story became the stuff of legends, and the fruits of Banana Island admired and aspired to find a love as extraordinary as Benny and Penelope's.

And so, in the land of ripe fruits and tropical dreams, Benny the banana and Penelope the pineapple lived happily ever after, their love shining brighter than the sun that bathed their island home.

The pinnacle of FromSoftware's souls series.
This is the best souls game ever, and very possible game of the decade.

It has some performance problems, it sometimes freezes for a split second while loading what i presume is something new.

But this does not take away from the amazing experience that this game is.
Its big, beautiful and full of places to explore.
The biggest  problem is with the size, its ginormous, and the reality is running around is one of the weaker aspects of the game, while being inside castles and caves is the fun part.
The addition of a horse does not really help the game, it makes exploring less dangerous so the game becomes exponentially easier and you are less likely to experience the areas if you can just sprint through them.
Its also the easiest souls game ever, so i guess journalists finally got their wish.
While you can respond with "Just dont level so much", what, you want me to intentionally suck?
It would also seem that bandai namco america has had some influence on the wording used in the game, please try to keep american values out of good games. We dont want to neuter good jp games like they've done to do with mortal kombat and numerous other titles.
Guilty of dumbing down their character creator.

So in short, it was worth the hype.

I'm enjoying it. There's a lot of bloat though. I mean a LOT. So many consumables to be collected that you'll never use. Like dozens upon dozens of them. So many recipe books to find and collect to make said useless consumables. Materials to make those consumables. "Bells" (shop unlocks) to collect so you can buy those materials instead of running out and farming them. In order to make the world as big as they did here, they basically had to add a bunch of junk that you'll never use. The more you play, the more you realize the best move is to just skip everything and run straight through to the boss or next checkpoint.

As well, From Software games are known as "difficult". Fair but tough. This one, I dare say, tips the scales into the "cheap" category more often than not. One of the problems, as I see it, is that there's a contingent of the player base for which nothing is hard enough. They're out making YouTube videos beating their games in 11 minutes without getting hit and using nothing but their fists. Or something like that. And then gaming media covers that stuff. So, From keeps upping the difficulty - I mean you can't be known as the "difficulty" game company if everyone is trivializing your content! Here in Elden Ring, that translates to enemies having just overwhelming, over the top aggression. Claw-tail swipe-jump up drop the hammer of doom-breath weapon of insta death covering the entire battlefield. Repeat. No break. Ever. You need a certain amount of armor just so you can drink a potion and tank through the inevitable hit you're going to take while drinking it. Previous games were a lot more thoughtful in the combat, but here it's pretty telling when you go to YouTube and look at Elden Ring builds and every one of them has "Overpowered" or "Broken" in the title in order to goose the algorithm. The game often feels so cheap, that the player feels justified in putting together an equally cheese build. Things like shields, carefully checking your surroundings...feels like a mugs game here. Just go two handed and put together some cheese build that deletes a boss in one or two applications of a weapon art and otherwise just run and skip through all content.

In summary, I feel like this game has been mostly just made for YouTubers who need to make tier lists. I got this on sale for around 35US. Kind of wished I'd waited for the sub $20 sale though. If you're a superfan, you've already bought this. If you're merely a "fan" who likes to maybe play a From game now and then I'd wait for a steep discount. 7/10

I wanted to put off my review of this game until I was at a place that I felt I really truly could shed light in on this subject. Having just 100% the game, I feel as if now that time has come. Here is the review:

I recommend this game for anyone and everyone. The "difficulty" of the game is not a game problem but just another barrier that you are trying to figure out how to overcome. Never stop. Always keep pushing forward, even if progress is slow and it feels obsolete, keep pushing. You must become the Elden Lord. No problem, encounter, boss fight, skill issue, or road block can slow down the Elden Lord, so... Go claim your throne, Brave Tarnished.

-A wanderer of the Lands between.
POGGERS

I have tried everything in the book to get this game to stop stuttering and lagging. Their decision to include that horrible easy anti cheat is beyond me. Yes, you can bypass it...but here it is, late 2023 and I still read all over the net that From Software has still not optimized this 2022 game. I still want to play it through, but it takes a lot out of a game that requires fast moves. For that reason, I cannot give it a full thumbs up. It is very impressive as an open world game...but the dungeons are way too simple, while on the overworld...getting from point A to point B can be a real pain. You see giant stuff in the distance and if you are lucky enough to get there, a lot of it you cannot even enter. Why does everything have to be so giant in this game? Sometimes it seems like Gulliver's Travels. This is my first souls game, and considering how much hype the previous games get...I hope, if I buy one...it will work better.

Do your job Fromsoft...

Man, what a game. 

This was my introduction into the 'souls like' genre and I am personally a big fan of this game style. Ever since I began playing Elden Ring, I always wanted to keep playing it, even though I was getting absolutely flattened by everything, which is a rare feeling. 

Elden Ring's bosses are uniquely hard and challenging in their own way, meaning you never get bored. The sheer size of the map is incredible with separate underground areas, catacombs, caves and tones of other interesting and diverse locations. Fromsoft games have a reputation of being very re-playable and Elden Ring doesn't fall short of this fact. 

Elden Ring's game-play is nothing like I've ever seen before and it's really awesome.

Also, be prepared to open Youtube because there's so much stuff that I found difficult and was confused about on my first playthrough, its just so complex. 

I have experienced a lot emotions while playing this game, one of them being anger, a lot of it. But when you finally defeat that boss that you have been at for hours, it is so rewarding and makes you feel like you've accomplished a great acheivement. 

Elden Ring does have a fair few bugs and glitches in it and I wouldn't say it's a perfect game at all. But the re-playability and entire atmosphere that it brings with it just makes it a wonderful experience.

In short conclusion, Elden Ring is by far the best game I've ever played.

When I first picked up Elden Ring, i had not really touched a From Software title, and I was probably in one of the lowest points in my life, But as I beat a boss and then beat another I started to realize that, Shutting up and keeping moving forward is all you can do in a hard time and continue to get back up when a great challenge knocks you down. Towards the end of my playthrough I felt like I did not have what it took to complete the game and a boss, try after try continued to defeat me. But instead of giving up it started a over 1000 hour training arch through Sekiro, Bloodborne, Darksouls 1, 2, and 3 and aswell as Demon souls, I actually ended out platinuming Sekiro when I was finished. I completed all these tasks and guess what I came back. Stomped all the Achievement based bosses in Eldenring and giving that bastard that gave me such a hard time a run for its money. Moral of the story is, Never give up, keep pushing forward and the love God my brothers and sisters. Never go hollow, Never allow shura's evil to grab ahold of you and make you his puppet. Best of all Praise the Sun, it will always rise in the morning. Much love to your art, you saved my life Hidetaka Miyazaki. I know you will never read this but if anyone told you in life that its just a game you will never make a impact in real life, Just know you made a impact in me and i know you made a impact in many other soulsheads.

If you want a complex, deep, and time sinking moba, then you should probably take a step back and look at your life choices.

After that you should play Dota.

Compared to most mobas, the learning curve is steep. With a multitude of playable characters and none of them behind a paywall, your initial games can be overwhelming. The number of different systems is also intense, from Shops, Side Shops, Secret Shops, Lanes, Jungle farming, creep spawning/stacking, etc.. It can be too much.

Thankfully the revamped tutorial actually helps in this aspect, letting new players gain a grasp of what's going on.

Not to mention the numerous arcade games to help players gain an understanding of various systems without risking time in actual games.

I highly recommend Dota.

Dota 2 is probably the best online game I've ever played. I've been playing Dota 1, both online and offline, and it took some time before I tried Dota 2. But when I tried Dota 2, I immediately decided to stick with the game.

For Dota 1 players, you will find transitioning from Dota 1 to Dota 2 quite easy since Dota 2 is very much like Dota 1 although significantly improved. The game is as exciting as Dota 1 since players will have to use their wits and skills to beat their opponents in battle. 

This game will test not only your hand and eye coordination but also your ability to make quick decisions and good strategies. And because you will have to work with different players in your team with varying personalities, you will ultimately learn or acquire valuable traits like patience, leadership and the quality of being a teamplayer.

Therefore, for me, this game deserves 5 stars!

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - A Timeless Epic Masterpiece

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

As a passionate gamer who revels in grand adventures and deep storytelling, "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is a testament to the pinnacle of the gaming industry. CD Projekt Red has crafted an absolute masterpiece, a world teeming with breathtaking landscapes, intricate tales, and characters that resonate with players long after the game's end.

From the very first step into the shoes of Geralt of Rivia, players are transported to a world of dark enchantment. The Continent is a vast and intricately detailed realm, pulsing with life, mysteries, and danger. It's not merely a setting; it's a living, breathing entity where every blade of grass, every tavern, and every forest feels tangible and authentic.

Character development is an art form, granting players the power to shape Geralt's skills, moral compass, and the course of his relationships. Geralt himself is a beautifully complex character, surrounded by a supporting cast that is equally fascinating. These characters are brought to life with exquisite writing and voice acting, ensuring that their stories are as memorable as they are profound.

The central narrative is an epic tale filled with personal quests, political intrigue, and ethical dilemmas. What sets "The Witcher 3" apart is its unflinching respect for players' intelligence and choice. Every decision has far-reaching implications, and the complexity of these choices is a reflection of life itself.

Combat is an exhilarating dance of blades and magic, where mastery of Geralt's swordplay and supernatural abilities is key. Battles against both mythical monsters and human adversaries are intense, challenging, and require cunning strategy.

The game's ethereal music and voice acting are the finishing touches that bring this world to life. The evocative melodies and superb voice performances elevate the experience to a level of immersion rarely seen in the gaming industry.

While "The Witcher 3" is an undisputed masterpiece, it's not without minor imperfections. A few players have encountered occasional technical hiccups, but these are mere blips in the grand tapestry of the game. The sheer size and scope of the world may be overwhelming for some, but it's a testament to the game's depth and scale.

In conclusion, "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" is not just a game; it's a timeless epic that transcends the medium. Its opulent world, multifaceted characters, gripping narratives, and demanding combat make it a landmark achievement that will resonate through the ages. If you seek grand adventures, intricate storytelling, and immersive open worlds, this game is not to be missed. Embark on a journey in the realm of Geralt of Rivia, where your choices determine the fate of a world that will etch itself into your heart.

Tried to get into it several times, both on console and PC, since everyone on the internet says it's so great. The combat sucks objectively, and subjectively I don't like the lore, world, or Geralt. Also they say it's an RPG but for me it's a CGI movie with multiple cuts or, more accurately, a choose your own adventure book. It's not for everyone and people should stop recommending it to people who enjoyed Elder Scrolls type RPGs. You might love it if you are the target audience, but don't expect something like Zelda where you can self insert doing your own thing or something like Oblivion or Fallout where you feel you own the character and the story. Which is fine, if you like the story and character and setting, but if you don't you are out of luck. It is what it is.

I'm only 13 hours in, but already I can say that this game is fantastic and deserves the praise it gets. I was hesitant at first due to my preference for games where I can create my own character, but being Geralt is a blast. I never played the previous games or watched the show, so I was slightly worried about being dumped into something I didn't understand. Thankfully, it hasn't been a problem at all, and I'm enjoying learning as I go. 

The only problem I do have is that I frequently stop just to admire the game's beautiful scenery. It's seriously distracting. It's such a lovely setting that I don't even try to binge the game. I don't feel forced into long sessions to enjoy it. I can hop on for an hour, run around exploring the world, find some random places, kill some bad stuff, watch a few cutscenes, and feel like I've had an experience.

If you haven't played this yet and you're on the fence like I was, give it a shot.

This RPG is my all time favorite. It has it all. Captivating story in which somehow they managed to combine sci-fi and medieval-ism, immense size (if you  want to do everything including side quests and exploration), nice character development system where you get different results based on your actions (that includes more than 5 different endings). To top it all off it used to have great graphics in its time and recently got a revamp and it is still majestic to look at - nothing beats its landscapes. And that's only Wild Hunt. Once you're done with it you have a couple DLCs you can play which are practical another separate game on their own.

I have played through the main game and all DLC multiple times and find myself coming back to it after the latest graphical additions that have been added.  CDPR is STILL putting effort and money into this title all these years later.  That tells you its a company passionate about their product, which is excellent news for gamers.

This game already has the story and gameplay down, now that the additions of Raytracing, DLSS, Frame Generation, Ultrawide Support (Incl in cutscenes) have been added, it looks as good as it plays.  

This is the game that got me into PC gaming back in the day, and its a the reason why I've upgraded my GPU.  I don't like the Netflix series but I LOVE this game.

I'm really hoping the next story in the saga is as fully developed as this game has been.  Good on you CDPR, thanks for all the memories!

ts a masterpiece, Not many games can drive me to explore as usually I go from point A to point B as quickly as possible. This game forces you to explore to find interesting gear and punishes you for not preparing to conquer areas ahead. However, while doing that exploring never feels like a chore. You never feel like "god just let me go through already" the enemy placements will at first, force you to stop and look ahead and make you think about how to challenge them. The game also doesn't hand you any wins, there are no participation trophies here, everything you collect in this game you earned. whether it be 10 souls from killing a rat or it is a boss weapon that you forged from beating the boss that took you 50 tries to beat.

The enemy design is very simple at times with wyverns, rats, skeletons etc. but at other times it is also very intriguing and some of the most abstract designs in video games with bosses and other major enemies. This is a plus as when you see a very unique design in the game it serves as a warning, and it also drives your curiosity to find out how it fights but more importantly, how you can beat it.

This game also makes you feel like an adult, it tells you the controls and nothing else. Everything you need to figure out on your own. You need to explore and find things that tell you where to go, whether they be NPCs or the description on items. The only thing limiting you in this game is your drive to explore and learn more about the world.

Let me paint a picture for you:
You've attempted this fight 30 times each time falling short. You make your way back to the boss arena, you've mastered the area before it maximizing your health entering the boss fight. The music kicks in, a beautiful orchestra accompanied by a choir of operatic chants. The stage is set, you know all of the bosses moves, you know exactly how the fight is going to go, you planned your strategy ahead of time, you use your buffing item that you learned the boss is weak to by reading the texts in the game and inferring with the knowledge you've accumulated over countless battles. The only thing to do now, is execute your plan to perfection. You start out strong dodging his moves and weaving in some counter attacks but you get a little greedy and get punished for it. your down, but not out. you fall back to recover but the boss doesn't let up. he keeps pushing you and you find yourself crumbling under the pressure, your plan is faltering. You pull off some miracle dodges and the boss finally calms down enough for you to stabilize. you get your bearings back, the buffs wore off but you still have plenty of life You start taking it slower, only going for 2 hits when you feel you can go for 3. slowly the boss is whittled down. The health bar is so low now. only a couple more hits and its over. you push your advantage you dodge aggresively. you swing, swing, swi- the boss counter attacks, waiting for the moment you got greedy and he hits you hard. your down to your last legs. both of you 1 combo away from death. the blood is pumping, the fear of having to do this again, the adrenaline of being so close to victory everything is telling you different things you cant get a thought into your head without contradicting it. "play safe, run in, dodge and counter, bait an attack" all of your options are in your head, the bosses hasnt done anything as if hes waiting for you to crumble under your own fear so he can finish you off. Then as the music swells, he charges in. the move you've seen countless times before, the move you've sworn to never die to again comes. you know exactly how to dodge it, where to optimally position your self after it to guarantee a counter hit. You feel it in your soul. you dodge, counter. its not enough your one hit away, the boss charges up his next attack, its coming, you have no time to decide what to do "dodge or hit ? dodge or hit ? dodge or hit ? dodge or hit ?" in under a second this one question bounces in your mind countless times you give in to your instincts and right as the bosses weapon is going to hit you, you swing your weapon and strike him down. You've conquered not only the boss but your doubts as well, you overcame it. the relief kicks in its finally over, the battle is won, but more still awaits.

One of the best games ever, and nearly a masterpiece.

Ever played Zelda? Do you remember that feeling of adventure and discovery you experienced in those games? Well, dial that feeling up a notch and add in a lot of brutality. In short, that's Dark Souls.

With tons of interesting weapons and cool armour to choose from, you can come up with so many new builds to always keep the game fresh.

Even to this day the PVP scene is alive and well and I regularly get into tons of thrilling, often nail-biting matches with other players.

And unfortunately on rare occasion you do find cheaters, but overall, it's rare.

I cannot recommend this game enough, it is so much fun and extremely rewarding with its progression and challenges.

was recommended after enjoying dark souls 3 a lot! sadly this game is barely a prototype to what became of the series by DS3, so much wrong with it. most bosses were simple and cheese-able and went down on the first try with little to no effort. most areas were uninspired and awfully designed which made exploring awful; poor pacing on bonfires and obscure spots for important entrances and exits helped keep meaningful progress to a minimum; and the ridiculously tedious runbacks to bosses that didn't immediately melt first try kept me from enjoying the experience entirely. hoping DS2 solves a lot of these issues - if it had properly placed bonfires and lets me warp between them right away, it will already be a better game. Overall I would give DSR a 4/10 - worst game fromsoft has made to date for sure.

edit: went back to finish all achievements, played nearly 50 extra hours across 3 NG cycles. i can safely say two things: 1) its a great game, and 2) ds2 and ds3 are far better experiences

[h1] Dark Souls Remastered (Manuvision) [/h1]

Review by Unam 

Ah, good old Dark Souls. 

I'm a huge fan of the genre, playing and beating all of Fromsoftware's classics and I've enjoyed all of them (Yes, even Dark Souls II). Hell, I've even done an SL1 for Dark Souls III, and it was the most bittersweet experience of my life. I keep coming back to these games because I appreciate them as pieces of art and for being plain fun. Dark Souls is the second of the Soulslike genre, only being predated by Demon's Souls for the PS3. While not my favorite of the trilogy, Dark Souls is still a masterpiece and will likely hold up for ages to come. I adore this game, and I could end the review here and give it a 10.

[b]BUT[/b]

I'm reviewing this as a remaster of the original game, and that is where the package as a whole lacks. I'll review the game and then the remaster separately, and give it a single score. 

[h2]Part 1: Dark Souls [/h2]

In this portion, I'll discuss the original game. The game is a masterpiece. I find it incredibly amusing that this was only the second time Fromsoftware was dabbling with the genre. [b]They have managed to craft such an important landmark in gaming history, and their efforts and passion should never be unjustifiably doubted [/b]. I'll start with discussing the world, as that is my personal favorite part. Like other Soulslikes, the game offers extensive creation settings, allowing you to play whatever you want. The game also has a lot of different gameplay styles, including magic, pyromancy, miracles, and basic swords, axes, knives, and shields. You can literally play whatever you want to play, and it really helps with providing a lot of replayability. Out of the entire trilogy, Dark Soul's world remains the most interesting and innovative. All of the areas are so unique, from the soothing melodies of Firelink Shrine to the bloody atmosphere of Blightown and the haunted feels of New Londo Ruins, everything here feels so special and they all fit together perfectly. One of my favorite parts about the world is that it is all interconnected, and you never follow a straight path. As an example, in one playthrough I went straight to Undead Burg, which is most commonly the area where new people go, and in another playthrough, I went to the Catacombs. Sure, some areas are harder than others, but you can tackle the world in whatever direction you want, only being stopped by having to hit certain checkpoints along the story. What helps bring the world to life are the enemies, that are never recycled and are proprietary to a certain area, and they all fit with the tone of the environment. Along your journey, you will meet a few characters, and they all help guide you and give a brief description of your surroundings [Insert "Praise the Sun" joke here]. These characters tend to give you a glimmer of hope in this dark depressing world, which helps alleviate the player and gives tidbits of lore.  

Now, you can't go talking about Dark Souls without mentioning the bosses. While it doesn't have my personal favorite selection, some of the bosses are super iconic. There are roughly 26 bosses, with a few repeated ones. This is honestly a lot, but out of those 26, there are only 10 which are really good, with the rest ranging from decent to annoying. While this is fine, most tend to be super difficult, this is why most people use the phrase "This is the Dark Souls of [genre]', speaking of which... 
Let me rant about the [u]DIFFICULY[/u]. The difficulty in Dark Souls is balanced, mostly dependent on the player's skill and willingness to repeat the action to make the difficulty. I'll set an example; You can literally grind the same enemy for 100 hours to get to level 300 and literally destroy anything in your path with a single hit, or, you could send yourself at level 1 and most certainly get destroyed in a single hit, it's up to you what you want to do. Personally, I would recommend against grinding unless you're feeling like you are under leaves for an area or boss. That's why I don't like the phrase "Dark Souls is the hardest game ever made" because it isn't and everyone that says that has probably never played the game. Hey, if you think it's the hardest game, all power to you, but you cannot deny its difficulty revolves entirely around the player. n

I especially adore the theme of [b]Perseverance[/b] in Dark Souls. [u]You are going to die, that is a fact and there is no way around that,[/u] but that is ok. The game is all about patience and not giving up. You are literally placed into one of the most demoralizing worlds ever and are placed against unsackable odds, yet you surpass them little by little, and adventure to find balance. This is what I love about Dark Souls. This is why I will never get tired of Dark Souls. [b]This makes it a masterpiece. [/b]

Dark Souls also received 1 piece of DLC, [u]Artorias of the Abyss[/u] and while you might groan, let me tell you that this is one of, if not the best, pieces of DLC I've ever played. It lets you explore new areas, battle new enemies, gather new weapons and spells, and fight new bosses. Bit of a spoiler, but Artorias and Manus are up there in my top 5 bosses of the entire series (My number one is Slave Knight Gael from DSIII if you're curious). It is an amazing appetizer for people that wanted more, and at the time of release, it was retailing for around $15 dollars at the time of release, which was a steal and puts into perspective how gamers are being mistreated nowadays, with DLCs of the same price only adding minimal content, a real shame. This is more Dark Souls, and if you loved the original experience you're going to love this. 

This is my review of Dark Souls and like I said before, it is excellent, I genuinely don't have a single complaint. I would give it a 10/10, but...

[h2] Part 2: Remastered Edition[/h2]'
[u]I don't like Dark Souls: Remastered.[/u] Let me put it into perspective. The original game came out in 2010 everywhere, where it was released for 60 dollars, like most other AAA games, and like other games, it became heavily discontinued after a few years, usually retailing between $15-$30 dollars. That's all and fine, but then in 2019 Bandai Namco alongside Fromsoftware announced a "Remaster" of the game. I put this in quotation marks because considering this a Remaster is a disservice to all Remaster. They literally slapped the game on Steam again, updated some textures, gave you the DLC, and called it a day. Now I'm going to list all the new features, ready?

1. ...

What's that? Do you think I made a spelling mistake? [u]No, the Remaster literally adds nothing new.[/u]. I wouldn't be complaining so much if they didn't delist the original version from Steam, furthermore, they didn't even give this as a free upgrade to the original owners, which is a complete spit in their faces. 

Here is what they should have done:

1. Rebuild the movement system so that it feels more fluid, much like Dark Souls III
2. Add a few more enemies and rework some of the bosses to give them a few more moves and make the fights more dynamic and make them feel less clunky.
3. Fix some of the glitches that the original game had.
4. Fix (or remove) Capra Demon. 

Not hard guys.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
 
I adore Dark Souls, it is one of my favorite games ever. It will forever remain in my heart. It has created a community of hardcore fans that respect and love it. Its world and bosses are some of the most interesting in the area, and at the time it was released it put Fromsoftware on the map. It created the best trilogy in gaming and its monumental achievements cannot be understated. However, this Remaster is terrible. 

I give Dark Souls: Remastered a...
