I started my From Journey with Bloodborne, then played Elden Ring multiple times. I decided to take a journey back and play the original Dark Souls and it was rough. I straight up quit several times, uninstalling the game and yet each time I found myself a couple of days later reinstalling it. It took me well over a month to get through this game but the rewarding feeling I had when I finally completed it was well worth the frustration. Great game!

Man i really tried to like this game holy hell, but honestly everything about the game feels clunky, frustrating and tedious. Your attacks never hit how you want them too, controls are god awful with many things bound to the same few buttons (though i hear its much nicer on controller). constant backtracking for seemingly no reason, awful collision with enemies constantly blocking your path in tight spaces and your weapons bounce off walls so you can barely do anything about it.

Now i dont usually do reviews but im writing this mainly because i genuinely want someone to tell me why people like this game, none of the steam reviews say anything more specific than very general statements or just praising the difficulty, none of my friends who like the game can explain anything specific either. I think this game originally came out at a time when games were getting easier and all the reactionaries loved this game because it felt like a 90s game (probably the only game series for which saying it feels like its from the 90s is praise somehow), so it feels like people are more praising the game for some philosophical reasons rather than the actual gameplay itself. 

The only thing i hear people say is fun is "getting better" at the game but honestly when the gameplay is so clunky and tedious i feel like its more a case of needing to get better in order to even be able to progress in a game that is at it's core just a mediocre action game. And ok this may be the most problematic part of this review but honestly the game isn't even really difficult despite that being what everyone praises, as almost every death feels much more like you dying for some stupid reason and every time i'd die i wouldn't think something like "i need to read the enemies attack better" or "i need to be more precise in my movements", but instead something like "damn i was stuck in a corner and couldnt do anything against 3 enemies when i couldnt even swing my weapon without hitting a wall and got stunlocked to death".

I might be missing or not getting something in which case i'd happily let someone change my mind because it seems like all the aspects people praise is much more them coping than anything, with common praises being things like "it doesnt hold your hand", "it feels like a game from the 90s", "the game is challenging", but when you look at those statements none of the is praise its just a statement like the game has open exploration, feels dated and is tedious. Most people who praise the game just say something like "oh yeah youre just bad if you dont like it" or something of the sort but honestly ive played way harder games that were way more fun but the reason why those games were fun is because the core gameplay was always interesting, and it always felt fair and deserved, while dark souls 1 combat isn't particularly interesting and deaths feel more undeserved than anything, and the controls as well as not getting bored and impatient pose a bigger threat to you than the actual enemies in this game.

Honestly maybe its a sunk-cost thing, where you spend countless hours battling the controls and running through the same areas, and by the time you learn how to actually play the game, you make yourself believe youre having fun so as to not admit you wasted all that time on a mediocre game, and nobody wants to admit it so instead everyone just collectively decided to pretend to enjoy it or something and that all the bad game design is somehow actually incredible game design if you have 3 shots, squint your eyes really hard, and repeat the phrase "its hardcore" 99 times in front of a mirror.

I must admit however the one thing i can't comment on is the story and soundtrack since i definetly havent played enough to really get to see a lot of it so even though i don't find them anything special, ive definetly not progressed far enough to either hear the "good tracks" or witness the story or something. This is a pretty important point as i have many times played through games with awful controls and many tedious elements because the story and music were really good so i could see that changing my mind.

Once again, I ask someone to change my mind because i've genuinely tried really hard to get into these games and see anything positive but I just cannot, no matter how hard I try.

not fixed issues:

**- jumping: the game originally was in 30 fps and if u play the PC version u get 60 fps, but the jump distance is halfed **(seems fixed, had no problem with the longer jumps on 2nd playthrough)
- lagging multiplayer (lagstab)
- multiple ledges/clipping environment still exist (ie great hollow, lost izalith, ...)
- alt tabbing still doesnt work: game will either refuse to switch tabs or go in windowed mode to do so, which you need to change in the options every time it happens

I've played all the other souls like games that From Software has made and I gotta say, Dark Souls 1 is one of the best experiences I've had. Its genius level design, chilling atmosphere and tragic story all play an insane role immersing and making you invested in the game. While its bosses (except O&S) aren't a big, difficult, spectacle like other From Soft games, they are still enjoyable and enable you to express your skill in different ways. 

It now makes sense as to why DS1 was always highly regarded by fans - it's the beginning of the souls trilogy and it's a banger.

I will say, I don't understand the hype around this game. In all the other souls games I've played, I've rarely felt cheated or cheesed. I lost count of how many times I got hit my attacks I felt I dodged, got combo-ed by a boss or stun locked by normal enemies. With that being said, I did find myself laughing at some of these deaths and I did enjoy my time in Lordran.

Gonna try and do some pros and cons I had with the game I guess:

[h2]PROS[/h2]

- The bosses felt fair for the most part and all were fun to fight
- Enemies are relatively easy to dodge and backstab looping is always a blast
- Upgrade materials are readily available until late game, costing an appropriate amount of souls to buy and are dropped somewhat regularly from normal enemies
- The setting is great

[h2]CONS[/h2]

- The lack of early game fast travel leads to some fun instances where you spend 30 minutes running between areas of the map just to unlock the ability to upgrade your weapons more or to allow you to upgrade your flasks (since you can only carry one fire keeper soul at a time...)
- Boss run-backs are atrocious. I hope you enjoy running for 5-10 mins to get back to the boss and then spend 3 seconds fighting it before getting true combo-ed.
- Many areas felt barren or pointless, they were only there to add needless complexity or to add difficulty getting back to the bosses
- You need a consumable to kill certain enemies that costs 4000 souls (stupid ghosts in new londo)


Honestly, 7/10

Masterpiece ahead.

It took about 10 hours for the game to really click for me and that's when I started enjoying it. I really didn't like it at the start and didn't get the appeal. By now, I finally understand why people like the souls games. I still really dislike the PvP though. Having someone with 1k hours in the game just destroy you randomly sucks. At least you can entirely avoid this by just being hollow most of the time and only being human when you need it and don't care about dying.

Surprisingly, I haven't gotten super frustrated with this game. With the exception of PvP, when you die, it's at least 95% of the time your fault and it feels fair. Failure doesn't feel as bad when it was the result of your own actions. I get much angrier at multiplayer FPS games.

As for this being a "remaster," it's pretty much the same as the original game. Just a different lighting system that changes the game's feel in an overall negative way, but the game runs at a stable 60fps even at 4K resolution for me so it doesn't really matter as much. If it ran poorly AND looked dated, then I would have an issue with it.



For anyone who is reluctant to play the game or isn't enjoying it yet, all while likely being told to "git gud" by the gatekeepers of the community, just keep going. It'll take a while for it to click, but you'll steadily improve and your experience will get better alongside your skills. The game never lets up in terms of difficulty, but you'll get better at handling all of the doodoo feces it likes to throw at players until you can just clown on all the enemies. Don't be afraid to look at guides when needed if it makes the game better for you.

Best game ever

As you know by now, this is a great game with really good storytelling and world-building that is just waiting to be discovered.

After the tutorial stage, you are just left on your own to discover everything that the world has to offer. Everything in the world will try to get you, and you need to push back hard so that you won't get swept up and go hollow. The storytelling is cryptic, and you won't really get it unless you really start piecing together the story that comes from the item descriptions and the environment. But unlike some modern games, the story is worth the effort, and it is like a puzzle mini-game inside the game itself, so I enjoy it.

Combat feels much more basic, heavier, and strategic compared to its succeeding genre offshoots like Nioh and other games in the Dark Souls trilogy. I was literally thrown off at some point by how heavy the combat felt, and when I went back and played a session of Nioh, which revolves around fast-paced combat, I couldn't play the same fast-paced combat again. But this does not detract from the godly first experience that you will have in this game. The feeling of exploring some area where you feel that you can't escape and then finally finding a shortcut or a bonfire is exhilarating and fun. The environment will kill you most of the time, and that's fine with me because it adds to the experience [spoiler](except for Anor Londo Archers and Sen's Funhouse; those two will always be a nightmare for the first playthrough)[/spoiler].

This game encompasses all of my favorite things about video games. Good combat, an amazing story, the feel of discovery in an open world (technically, it is a semi-linear open world), and finally, an experience to remember. Overall, I really can't recommend this game enough; it is worth its full price, and you can get an even better deal if you buy it whenever it is on sale.

I believe I've come to the realization that the true goal in this game is to save Knight Solaire. It requires you to know the game's ins and outs, what paths to take, what bosses to kill (or not), in what order, the interconnection of the world, etc. I put in maybe some 1000 or so hours into this game back in the Xbox 360 days. His quest-line always alluded me, and I never bothered to look it up (or maybe I did but it's been such a long time and I have terrible long-term memory). It didn't help that I would mostly base my play-through on what kind of build I was going for and the online aspects of the game in general. Suffice to say, I was quite terrible at following NPC quest-lines in general but I would one or two with each new play-through. 

Now after all this time, I came to play this gem again, it's soooo much easier than I recall and my new overall take on it is that it's a thinking man's game. And after all this time, although mostly incidentally, I saved Knight Solaire. And it hit me, and I just started thinking about the game as a whole and it all makes sense now.

我游玩的顺序是环、狼、魂3、魂1。玩了魂1后，我感到我对环的赞誉反而要降低些了——没想到一代的魂就有这么高的完成度，乃至于后续的作品显得有些在“吃老本”。
本作最大的特点是非常出色的地图设计，整个地图自成一体：不同地区往往以意想不到而又合理的方式连接在一起，而地区内部和环境相融合的路径也非常巧妙。
与地图相比，其他方面则显得稚嫩逊色了。前期地图显得过于”开放“，能去好几个地方，但有的路如果等级不够会很吃苦；怪物设计的动作、交互方式都较为简陋；此外，本作人物翻滚性能较弱，盾的性能则过于强大，盾反判定非常简单，反而成了“万用解法”。
受苦方面，本作篝火非常稀疏，且前期没有传送（这也和地图特点有关），阴人的地方也不少。不过我感觉还好，主要是因为我使用刷魂bug刷了蛮多魂，升到了一百多级，容错率大大提高。对于现代来玩的玩家，我觉得用这种方式可以规避无意义的受苦，获得更好的游戏体验，值得推荐。

You know how in any Souls game when you would run by a blind corner and an enemy you couldn't see would jump out and get a free hit or two on you? That's the entirety of Dark Souls 2. 

The hardest part of the game is enemy placements but this is balanced by almost every boss being a cakewalk compared to anything you'd find in a more modern Souls game like Elden Ring. I'd routinely die in each area by getting swarmed by 8 enemies I couldn't see or falling down a very annoyingly-placed hole or an enemy smashing through a wall and one-shotting me only to finally reach the boss and faceroll them 9 times out of 10. 

Game can be more annoying than difficult. Still pretty good, but you're not missing much if you skip it. Play this Souls game last.

The worst game in the series. It is just unplayable compared to Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring:

1. The game has a poor location design. They are just stuffy (enemies are weak but there are a TON of them in every place, and that is why this is tough, not because mobs are challenging, which is unbearably disgusting).
2. Input is lagging and weird, at least on the keyboard and mouse. Every time I start the game, I need to open the settings and re-adjust the mouse clicking because it is not working at every opening of the game. Whenever I try to attack, it does the action with a 2-second delay until I change the mouse settings back and forth.
3. I played with a two-handed halberd and it was awful because of the weapon breaking. It was breaking after like 20 hits and there is no spare titanite to upgrade an alternative weapon, at least for the first half of the game. For the second half of each location, I played with less powerful equipment. Nice!
4. The hollowing system... For half of the game, I had not had enough effigies to cure it, so my health bar was 50% of its original size. As a result, two hits and I was dead. Nice!

DLCs are good, though.

Sir Alonne > Fume Knight > Ivory King >> Smelter Demon > Looking Glass Knight > Vendrick > Ancient Dragon > Aldia > Darklurker | Nashandra

Dark Souls 3 > Elden Ring >>> Dark Souls 2

Dark Souls 2 is the black sheep of the series but despite this, that series is still Dark Souls so this gets a thumbs up from me. The animation of your character is noticeably different to the other games, there are a lot more covenants and bosses which lead to most of them being mediocre but this game also introduced things like power stancing with two weapons, torches, destructible environments and even the dreaded adaptability stat. Dark souls 2 is not only the black sheep of the series, but for sure the most experimental of the series and whilst I like the first and third better, it's honestly not a bad a game as everyone says it is.

I would definitely recommend the game if you're going for the whole trilogy, but for me personally ds2 way differs from other instalments. The whole plot is somewhat very depressing, even though i really enjoyed the ending.
          The locations are great, but some of them gave me that rushed development vibe for some reason.
In comparison to the ds1 though, which brought more joy, the story feels deeper and more well written I guess. 
        Characters are also cool and their presence is just enough to not distract you from achieving some main tasks.

This game gets bad rap despite fixing a lot of the really annoying problems in DS1 like arbitrary lack of warping and long annoying boss runs (for the most part). That said, playing this game after DS3 and Elden Ring, the combat is more antiquated and clunky. Enemies are much less animated and interesting, and the pace of the fights is much slower. Overall this game is probably the easiest of every fromsoft game I have played, although thats probably because its DS1 - stupid bullshit = slightly easier game. While the world is more chaotic and less coherent than in dark souls 1 (or 3), the story is actually very interesting and different than the kind of story those were going for, beyond a superficially similar general premise. 

The DLCs are absolutely fantastic and taken by themselves some of the most compact and juicy this series has ever seen. 

The negatives mostly come down to some of the bosses not being winners (twin dragonriders, congregation fight, didnt even fight the big dragon tbh everyone said to skip it) some stupid things (i love losing half my health when i die thats fun, i love that they kept how in DS1 ur character looks like beef jerky when they are hollow, why do enemies despawn if you kill them 15 times that so arbitrary, what in the lords name is the "adaptability" stat) 

I think if you liked DS1 and dont have some bizarre psychosexual attraction to how that game did specifically everything, you will really like this game too, perhaps even more.  Probably not more than 3 tho.

As someone who has beaten SOTFS 15+ times between console and PC, I decided to give the vanilla a try because, why not more Dark Souls?

This is the better version of the game.  The enemy placement is much more practical. This is especially noticeable in areas like the Iron Keep. SoTFS dumped a significant amount of random enemies throughout the world that just served as an annoyance - I am no longer consistently dying to frustrating ganks caused by enemy spam. I also find myself clearing out areas more strategically, as opposed to running straight through which i did frequently in some of the annoying areas of Scholar.

Furthermore, the use of the fragrant branches makes much more sense. There are multiple statues that exist in Scholar to block you from progressing that simply don't exist in the vanilla version. I remember in Scholar having to backtrack multiple times to find a fragrant branch, so I can open up a blocked path (example: Lost Bastille before Ruin Sentinals, Black Gulch 2nd bonfire). 

Lastly, the visuals are exactly the same. Frames are fine, textures are fine, it all feels like the same game. 

TL:DR; When compared to SOFTS, Vanilla DS2 has better enemy placement and world design, and runs exactly the same for me from a performance standpoint. It's sad that FromSoft re-released this game with a new price tag on it, yet seemingly made it worse. Vanilla DS2 is simply a more pleasant experience.

I got both endings to DS2, and I think it's more underwhelming than just flat-out bad like many people say.

DS2 is led by two directors with Miyazaki placed in the Supervisor role, and I think it's cool that they allowed others to bring their vision to life in the world of Dark Souls & expanding on the world with it, but I think if Miyazaki was a bit more than a supervisor, things may have been a bit better. That doesn't mean just fire the directors and give Miyazaki the role, but I think he could've been more involved considering Dark Souls is his child.

DS2 is a decent game and is more underwhelming than bad, and it's not nearly as bad as many people say I think. It could be much better, but the directors had a vision and when it comes to story & narrative, they did a good job. Just think if Miyazaki was a bit more involved, things could be a bit better.

DS2 is also full of it's own lore and for a while none of it seems connected at all to Dark Souls 1, but the farther you get and the more research you do, you will see the amount of connections that there are. It's cool!

I enjoyed my time with DS2, but it's definitely flawed and nowhere near perfect. Not as bad as many say.

Having never played Dark Souls 2 before, I decided to venture into the world of Drangleic by starting with the vanilla version instead of the Scholar of the First Sin (SOTFS) edition. Many Souls veterans recommended this approach, and I must say, I have absolutely no regrets.

Despite the significant amount of criticism Dark Souls 2 has received, I found it to be a solid entry in the series. While it may not reach the same heights as its predecessor or successor, it is still a thoroughly enjoyable experience that does not deserve the hate it's been given.

Having completed my first playthrough, I am eager to continue exploring the game's intricacies in New Game Plus (NG+). Overall, Dark Souls 2 is a worthwhile addition to any Souls fan's collection, and I encourage anyone who hasn't tried it to give it a chance.

Will I ever play the Scholar of the First Sin (SOTFS) edition? After some reviews and very useful youtube comparison videos, I see no point in that. I will grind NG(s) in the vanilla.

We may have gotten more Souls games in this style if the series didn't somewhat merge with bloodborne from DS3 onward. Try DSII, it is... Dark Souls: 2.

The increased speed of Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring turned me off, DSII is the perfect opposite; they won't make another game with the same philosophy again.
Tactical, slow and with an atmosphere that breaks with the traditional brooding nihilism of the other Souls games. DSII is not a bad souls game, it was Dark Souls forking out toward a different design direction. I think it succeeded in being the next logical evolution to the Souls formula. Again, try it out, it's the fork in the road not a mistake.

Easily the best of the Dark Souls trilogy, nothing tops the gameplay and admittedly obscure lore of Dark Souls II and anyone who says otherwise is on copium

(This does not, however, apply to Scholar of the First Sin, which is a poor excuse to add minor details that could have been attached to this game, but hey, greedy business practice.)

My favorite things about this game is the aforementioned lore and the viability of each weapon and armor, and you can boast whatever fashion and weapon you like and feel like a total badass fighting what are, in my opinion, tougher bosses than Dark Souls I or III have to offer. As usual, the DLC is far superior to the base game as the base game's final boss is meh.

Unfortunately, I will say that the multiplayer is pretty dead now (though it depends on your Soul Memory - essentially the matchmaking mechanic based on how many souls you've accumulated over time) and is much more alive on Scholar of the First Sin, so if you're reading reviews between this game and that one, I urge you to purchase the games based on this:

More enjoyable PVE experience: Dark Souls II
More multiplayer: SoTFS

Aside from multiplayer effects, SoTFS has nothing better to offer than this game other than slightly improved lighting. 

Good luck.

I enjoyed Dark Souls 2. I haven't played the SOTFS version and this was my first time playing Dark Souls 2.

Overall - great. Tons of variety. Every weapon is viable which is wonderful because there's no end to the builds you can put together. Combat is fast and fun. 

Yes, it's tough but not as tough as I thought it would be. There were only one or two sticking points I encountered, but I felt that the game provided me with numerous ways to solve those problems. Me being a total scrub, I relied a lot on summoning phantoms for boss fights, which made a lot of the fights incredibly easy. Between boss fights, there were a few areas where I decided to farm the enemies to extinction (they don't respawn if you kill them 12 times) to make my life easier. It was a good way to level up and also made the boss runs simpler.

Story: I feel like this game was quite disconnected from the first one. Dark Souls 2 focuses on a corner of the established world rather than the sweeping universal threat that Dark Souls 1 places an emphasis on. The world isn't as dead as the first game, which was a welcome change. 

I do feel that Dark Souls 2 lacks that sombre, melancholic, wistfulness the first game managed to capture so well. In general the world design is nice but it did leave me scratching my head at times (entering an area via a tunnel and when you turn around, it's just open ocean). Where Dark Souls 1 was this believably interconnected world, Dark Souls 2 is kind of all over the place. Teleporting between bonfires was a very welcome addition.

It was fun. I'll miss it as I venture into Dark Souls 3. I'll miss the waves crashing on the shores of Majula, and I'll miss Shanalotte telling me she'll be by my side "until hope fades".

Over 200 hours on this game and not even close to done with it yet.

+ Huge weapon arsenal and most weapons are quite viable
+ Magic looks majestic and hits like a truck
+ Crypt blacksword
+ Bonfire ascetics and powerstancing are amazing features and aren't in most other souls games
+ Some of the best NG+ content I've ever seen
+ First half is very non-linear and allows you to go to many different path simultaneously (second half is more linear, but also had some great locations)
+ DLCs were very challenging and masterfully designed
+- Most of the difficulty comes from fighting multiple enemies at once (I personally liked it, but understand why others might not)
- Adaptability, which makes rolling easier and lets you heal faster, is very important, yet poorly exlained
- Soul memory is a big hassle when trying to do jolly cooperation
- Bosses are not very challenging, and some are reused
- Frigid Outskirts

First off, quick PSA: DO NOT GET SCHOLAR OF THE FIRST SIN. BUY THIS VERSION, SCHOLAR IS A SCAM.

Scholar apparently does a couple balancing tweaks here and there, which may sound nice except that the main thing that Scholar changes is enemy placement. Scholar adds significantly more enemies to certain areas, making those areas exponentially more difficult and unfun. This is a major problem as Scholar promotes itself as the "definitive" version of Dark Souls II, meaning gullible new players (such as myself) will buy it, thinking they're getting an authentic experience, only to ragequit after the first few levels because of the ridiculous enemy spam, which only serves to compound the divisive-at-best reputation this game has. Vanilla Dark Souls II (this version) actually has smart enemy placement and a reasonable difficulty curve, making it much easier to deal with some of the games (admittedly significant) flaws, and even actually have fun. This version also still has the DLC, so you aren't missing out on that if you don't get Scholar. 

Moving onto thoughts on the actual game: I enjoyed it way more than Dark Souls I, however it's not as good as Dark Souls III. Your mileage on the game will depend on your playstyle. This game is slow. Your character is slow, but enemies are also slow, so you're encouraged to take a more strategic and methodical approach to combat. As a result, you're often expected to deal with larger groups of enemies at a time, and it works surprisingly well if you take the time to learn it. A big thing that helps surprisingly, is to not use the lock-on feature, as you have more range of motion when locked off, so you'll be able to dodge attacks more easily, and enemies are slow enough that you're able to move the camera yourself. If you're willing to take the time to learn this style of combat, you'll likely have a good time with this game. 

That being said, this game does have some major flaws that will understandably turn people off. They certainly turned me off when I played Scholar and had to deal with the BS enemy spam. 

1. Hitboxes. The hitboxes for enemy attacks are often very large, while the hitboxes on your weapons are seemingly pixel-perfect. As such, sometimes you'll get hit by attacks that it looked like you dodged, and smaller weapons like the broadsword have trouble comboing because the first swing knocks some enemies out of range of the second. Playing locked-off can usually mitigate this issue, since the larger range of motion will give you a wider dodge. 

2. Healing. This game introduces a new healing item known as lifegems, and they essentially make your estus nearly obsolete. You can move while using it, while estus locks you in place for a painfully slow animation. They also heal you slowly, meaning you can pop a few of these at once and essentially have a passive regen effect, allowing you to tank way more damage than you otherwise would be able to. Finally, while they are consumable, there's an NPC you unlock in the early game that sells an infinite number of them, so you'll literally never run out. I don't see why they couldn't have just made it so that you could move while sipping and left out the gems altogether. 

3. The Curse. Every time you die, your max health decreases slightly, and caps when you reach half health. To get your health back, you have to pop a Human Effigy, which is this game's equivalent to Humanities/Embers/Rune Arcs, etc. And these things are pretty scarce in the early game. They do get more common later, and there's a ring that caps the debuff to 3 quarters health instead of half, but it's still a pretty dumb punishment for death. Dark Souls I and III had a better system with their equivalent items. 

4. Adaptability. This game introduces a new stat called Adaptability, which controls the amount of invincibility frames you get when you roll. In the previous game, your i-frames were determined by your equip load (light/mid/fat), and it later titles like III and Elden Ring give you the same amount of i-frames for each type of roll, and the speed of the animation changes more drastically. Dark Souls II still has those 3 tiers of roll, but the i-frames are entirely dependent on that Adaptability stat, and you NEED to level that if you want a decent roll, especially with this game's hitboxes. It's an interesting idea, since you could potentially do a dodge build and have an overpowered roll, but considering how rolling is such an integral part of souls combat, it really shouldn't be something that you have to actively dump levels into and change drastically over the course of the game. I've found for a decent Dark Souls III style roll, your Adaptability should be around 20-30, although you can get by with less. 

5. This isn't really a flaw, I actually really like this about the game, but some people might not like it. A vast majority of the enemies and bosses in this game are big dudes in armor that are mechanically similar to each other. I like it since the armor is cool looking and they're fun to fight, but others might not like it as much. 

TL/DR: Dark Souls II is a fun game if you're willing to put some time in to learn it, and enjoy the style of combat that it promotes. In my opinion, it's better than the first game, though not as good as the third. Don't make my mistake and get Scholar of the First Sin. It's a scam.

I can’t speak for Scholar of the First Sin, but this version of DS2 is an incredible game. Aside from a brief adjustment period to some new mechanics, DS2 is a creative and strong entry in the DS series. 

Often called the weakest of the three, that by no means make it a bad game. My biggest gripe so far is there are a few really miserable boss run backs but the caveat is most of the bosses are super approachable. But make sure you invest points in your ADP early !! It’s an easy mistake to make, but doing it early makes the game really approachable as a whole.

The lore is some of the most engaging in the series, and while there aren’t characters quite as memorable as Solaire, others like Aldia, Vendrick, Lucatiel, and Nashandra all bring gravity, humor, and tragedy to a world that exists on cycles of light and dark.

Overall I highly recommend this game, it’s an essential for any fan of FromSoft games, in particular the DS series.

Dark Souls 2 is everything a player can expect from a Souls series game. Extremely challenging, great gameplay and a great setting to explore. You'll probably die a few hundred times before you reach the end, but that's as expected. What matters is that these deaths will never be free and that you will feel like the best player in the universe when you overcome each of the great challenges imposed by this game. Although it does not have as many innovative ideas as its predecessors, it is a mixed, bigger and better version of these same games.

Easily the worst in the series but still a good game overall. The pros are that it is still a Dark Souls game with all the good that comes with that, the cons are as follows. The biggest issues are the bosses and annoying difficulty design. There is not much to say about the bosses, most are relatively easy and boring with nothing to write home about. The other games in the series are not designed with the express intent of difficulty, rather they focus on creating a fun and interesting challenge for the player. Dark Souls II does not follow this philosophy and there were a lot of instances of really annoying artificial difficulty just for the sake of it.

There were a lot of other nit picks that just seemed off to me about this game. Lots of animations felt stiff and awkward. Mainly on my character when walking with a weapon, my character would dramatically swing their shoulders in a weird fashion. The way they hold their weapon also looked off, especially when in power stance. lots of weapons would miss their target even when locked on, and the action in general just felt a bit weird. I couldn't find any armor that I liked until almost the end of the game. When you get hit, sometimes you can lose up to half your health without any sort of reaction or anything from your character which always came off strange. All that being said easily the worst design choices in the game are the health and rolling i-frames. I hate how you are punished with reduced max HP every time you die, and this just takes away from the try and try and try again until you succeed loop. You get enough items to get your health back to max that it usually did not matter, especially because most of the bosses are not very hard, but on those rare occasions of a hard boss I really hated this mechanic. And not much can be said about the i-frames issue, besides it makes early game feel really shitty until you get that stat raised to 30. If you play this just keep in mind it will be a flawed experience, but still a good one overall. This game is not nearly as bad as I was lead to believe, and am still glad I played it.

One of my favorite games of all time. As my second game in the souls-series (after Elden Ring), I really enjoyed almost every aspect of the game. The gameplay is as smooth as possible with many different fun weapons. In comparison to Elden Ring the game is linear which in my opinion made it way more balanced when it comes to not be overleveled for bosses. (which I hated in Elden Ring since story bosses (except a couple like Malenia, etc.) just became too easy because you tried to explore and got too much souls.)
In general the bosses in this game are just great [spoiler] (Abyss Watchers, Princes, Soul of Cinder, Sister Friede, Midir, Gael, Pontiff only to name a few) [/spoiler] Both dlcs but especially The Ringed City are worth the money and unlock several bosses which are probably some of the best in any souls game. 
The only thing I dislike about Ds3 is the fact that in order to get all of the achievements, you had to grind many covenant awards which consisted of either of multiplayer fights or killing the same enemies for like 2 days and hoping that they drop a Covenant item.

All my friends agree Dark Souls III is the best of the IP. While I have to agree that Dark Souls III does a lot of things the best: the combat and build variety is peak, and this game easily has the strongest lineup of bosses in Fromsoft's discography -- maybe even in any game I've ever played (bare in mind I have yet to play Elden Ring) -- I also think that Dark Souls III lacks the magic of the first game. Exploring Lordran (DS1) is such an immersive and emotionally potent experience and while Lothric (DS3) is beautiful and wonderfully detailed it just lacks the wondrous feeling of trekking down a lonely path and ending back up in Firelink. That said, Dark Souls III is definitely the more FUN game and I would personally put them on par with each other as tied for the best dark souls; they each do something better than the other.

Yeah, really good souls game.

You run around a big world killing stuff.  You can use a sword, magic, shields, punch stuff, hammers, axes, bows, spears; I think there's even a whip in the game.

The game really does let you play however you want, and the combat always feels rewarding.  Enemies don't just stand single file and fight you one at a time.  If there's 3 dudes fighting you, they'll all attack you at the same time.  You have to really take your time to learn the game, but once you do, you feel awesome for winning every fight.  The game is difficult, but fair.

If you've played any other Dark Souls games, Elden Ring, or Bloodborne, you'll like this one a lot.  Otherwise, if you just like playing difficult action RPG games, definitely give this one a go.

It's unclear whether you have to do all of these things or only some of them. For the record, I tried a combination of all of them and performance was obviously affected while streaming due to hyperthreading kind of being a necessity. I then re-enabled hyperthreading but kept the graphics setting changes and it appeared to work. What's unclear about this, is I had already killed the resource intensive dragons causing all the lag.

Either way, an enjoyable game in itself.

The game is a masterpiece, and I can safely say that it's my favorite game. A lot can be said, but I'll focus on two things:

1. It doesn't demand the same amount of dedication and time from every player. If you want to play it casually and just finish the base game, it will not take a lot of time (10 to 20 hours, going in blind) and it's not going to be super hard. But, if you want to get some sort of a "true ending", lore-wise, it's going to be much more challenging. If you fall in love with the game, like I did, and want to beat 112% and maybe all achievements, get ready to be humbled. In summary, the game doesn't feel too overwhelming for a newcomer, but it will take a lot of time to enjoy everything it has to offer.

2. Since the game is not 3D, and the mechanics are so fluid and rich, I never blamed the game for getting hit and dying. In so many games, it feels like it's the game's fault, but in Hollow Knight it's always clear what went wrong and, eventually, what you could have done differently. It kind of ruins most of other 2D games.

So first thing first I want to start by saying that I did not finish the game, I can't (EDIT: I DID WITH HELP FROM A FRIEND I STILL DON'T LIKE THE GAME THO)
I will explain why but first let me give you a bit of context:
This game was recommended to me an insane amount, every other person saying that it's "The best game" or "My favorite game" so naturally my expectations went high and I was happy to start playing it.
The first few hours of the game were normal, nothing too interesting just walk and slash and explore a large map and I mean a LARGE map and this is where my first problem start to occur, you have to walk back and forth a lot on top of that you have to remember where you need to go, I am a person with very short memory and because I played this game weekly (2 3 hour-long sessions every week) I kept forgetting where I need to go the game is not clear at all on where you need to go now, so most of my time in the game I spent was just walking and trying to find where to go, and sometimes it's not about memory that gets me confused on where to go, sometimes you just have to guess that the slightly shaking rocks you saw 3 hours ago will now break to the new upgrade you got, and I don't know about you but I don't always remember or care if I saw rocks shaking like my reactions the first time was "Oh this rock is a bit unstable" and forgot about it immediately, why would I remember it? Also speaking of getting upgrades, the pacing were you get upgrades/new abilities is painfully slow so for the first hours of the game it feels so samey, sure the environment changes but you, the player stay the same for the most part, most upgrades are there for you to expend the map and not to make the game more fun in any way. (Like down smash and crystal heart)
So in short I kept getting lost in the map with the game being extremely unclear, I kept not knowing where to go combined with the pacing of the game being very slow I was just stuck in endless boredom.
I know a lot of people enjoy this game and I'm all for it, but sadly it just wasn't for me.

EDIT: I would also like to add that the platforming never gets more intersting except getting a double jump and a dash (which should be the basics) you never get any cool new abilities (form what I played at least) that make the platforming fun, it will almost always be just run and jump, which I think is subjective if you like that or not, but I think if your game is a platformer the platforming should be fun and should not be skiped when considering in development.

TL;DR
I spent 90% of my playtime trying to find where to go than actually playing because of my short memory and the platforming never got better

Hollow Knight is a game that starts off feeling rough on the controls and gameplay, but quickly grows on you through the story, the tightness of the movement and combat, and the amazing boss fights. The amazing worldbuilding has started YouTube careers solely focusing on the world.

All that being said, I wouldn't recommend this as your first metroidvania (but still a must play metroidvania). I've seen new players get stuck and frustrated thanks to the lack of handholding in the game (which is really good actually). Would recommend you try out something like Ori and the Blind Forest first, then come back for Hollow Knight (and hopefully Silksong)

This is more than a great game, this is a piece of modern art. You sink into this world, discovering more and more reasons to love it and to keep returning. It's the best in its genre of metroidvanias - exploration-focused, non-linear games. So much work, love and care was put into its creation, from level design, to visual art, to music and dialogue. What deserves most praise perhaps, is the game's story.
Hollow Knight has a beautiful and deep lore that captivates despite its innate tragedy, themes of grief and loss.

[Spoilers ahead]
It can be read as a cautionary tale about the dangers of rebelling against nature and time, a reminder that nothing does and nothing can last forever. The foolish King who though himself above Nature sacrifices everything he has to delay the inevetible, turns into a tyrant and dies alone, abandoned, just like his Kingdom.

It can be also perceived as a deep personal tragedy of a man who failed to be a god his people needed him to be, who was forced to sacrifice his own child, whom he loved, in order to save everyone else. A tragic story of Hollow Knight, who was never just a Vessel, a weapon against Radiance, but a living human being, struggling to meet impossible expectations. Finally, the tragedy of Seer, penanced for the crimes not her own, but of her people, against their creator and mother. Suffering alone, gaining some sort of redemption, only to be ultimately forgotten and lost forever.

But Hollow Knight is a mature story that knows the light side to its dark one. It's also a story of everyone who followed Pale King and gave their live for Hallownest. It's a story of witnessing wonder and learning to love a dying world, finding comfort in its gloom and new meaning in life. A story praising perseverance and strong will, showing the meaning of true heroism, sacrifice and love. It's a story of ascension and growing into a great hero, into a righteous leader.
[End spoilers]

There is no overstating how wonderful this game is, how much I love it and how much positive influence it had on my life. So don't delay, descend into Hallownest, fellow traveler, and let's meet again on the road ahead.

Many years ago, Nintendo dropped the ball on platformers, I thought that was the end of it, but.

One good day, some guy who goes by Pixel picked up this ball and, all by himself, made it roll again. Though he didn't expect it to be much. He didn't really know how much of a shockwave this little gesture was gonna make.

The snowball got stuck in a yacht one day, it was a big chore to Shovel it away, away into a well. A knightly effort if I might add.

Now that snowball is here, down a big bug kingdom, it went through a lot more places than the few I'm mentioning. It was quite the ride.

Let's wonder where this big snowball will go next.

To start off, this game has some of the best art and music that I have ever seen in a video game, period. The dark, gloomy atmosphere combined with the somber soundtrack automatically gives this game extra credit, and it only gets better from there. The combat, while simple at first, only becomes more complex and satisfying the more abilities you unlock. Almost every enemy and boss feels different from the last, and almost every boss so far has been immensely satisfying to defeat. While this game is hard, it is also fair. No challenge is impossible, as long as you keep trying. Now, if this game sounds fun, then stop reading reviews and go buy it, and I doubt you'll regret it.

[i]Hollow Knight[/i] is a great game. 

Throughout the experience, [i]Team Cherry[/i] showcases their mastery of the metroidvania gameplay, world design, and overall tone and atmosphere.  The experience is at its best when you slowly piece together ways to traverse the world, overcome the challenges of new enemies, and prevail over the various boss fights the game has to offer. I'd say that [i]Hollow Knight[/i] plays its exploration gameplay loop exceptionally well among these elements; if you're familiar with how puzzle games and their goal of making the player feel smart for accomplishing simple tasks, this is the philosophy that powers the exploration puzzles and forms satisfying solutions to each challenge.

As for [i]Hollow Knight[/i]'s difficulty curve, this game is consistently on the higher side of difficulty and you will always feel as if you're pushing a boulder up a steep hill at minimum or barely clinging onto a cliff edge at maximum. The game does offer a multitude of power-ups that will make the experience easier, but often these upgrades coincide with unlocking more difficult areas, resulting in a difficulty curve that remains at the same high throughout the game (with small exceptions). 

However, [i]Hollow Knight[/i] does have two primary issues throughout the game: pacing and narrative execution. At [i]Hollow Knight[/i]'s late game, the exploration portion of its gameplay loop disappears and you are effectively only left with challenges, either in special areas or bosses. While these challenges are still fun to go through, the shift immensely slows down progression as the game forces you to acclimate and overcome these challenges to get further progression. This portion felt like trying to demolish a brick wall with your fists. Despite this, the game gives you all the tools to succeed in these challenges, it is up to you to learn how to use them to their maximum efficacy. I suspect this problem arose due to all the bosses added throughout the years in DLC.

[i]Hollow Knight[/i] contains a more prevalent issue throughout its runtime: narrative execution. Throughout a large portion of the game, narrative is presented through in-game tablets and artifacts scribbled with cryptic messages in foreboding tones, along with typically somber character dialogue. The game expects a lot of effort from the player's part to unveil its story and follow along the journey. The issue with this execution is that it tends to be on the vague side and will leave you lost unless you ardently keep track of the game's events. I struggled to get hooked into [i]Hollow Knight[/i]'s story, which meant that when the major story beats of the game come your way, they often-time feel limb and weightless and as if events are happening on your screen simply to happen. 

This is a shame because [i]Hollow Knight[/i] does not bring a weak story to the table. If you ever do make the effort to piece together its narrative from the strewn-about sources, it can make those same emotionless moments feel riveting and powerful. However, due to the narrative insistently being presented in vague dialogue and inscriptions, the game failed to hook me into its climatic story beats and left me feeling as if I watched the end of a story without its beginning and middle. I believe this could be addressed by sprinkling strong story beats throughout the game rather than backloading the majority of them and hoping the player put in enough effort to be absorbed by them.

In face of my critiques, [i]Hollow Knight[/i] still offers a solid package. The metroidvania gameplay loop is perfected to an extent I've not seen before, with an interesting world and engrossing atmosphere (produced mainly by Christopher Larkin) predicating everything. 

I've said what I've said: [i]Hollow Knight[/i] is a great game.

After 310hrs on this game and only one achievement missing (P5... I'll get you one day !), I can safely say : I recommend it. 
The story telling is compelling, you need to search within the world for pieces of lore and you are not held by the hand through each step. It actually makes you think and plan ahead, which I find quite refreshing. Dying is punishing, and in the beginning you will die quite a lot but it gets easier and easier as you go through more and more challenges.  I love the soundtrack and art work, the teams in charge of this did an outstanding job. Moving around and combat are super satisfying once you unlock abilities and you have different endings possible depending on how much trouble you want to go through. This is a game that I love to revisit regularly, and thanks to the Godhome DLC, the game can have a very long life if you enjoy grinding through the pantheons. 
The first 1 or 2 hours felt a bit long for me in the beginning especially as I was not used to the lack of hand holding, but it's definitely worth it to hang in there. First play through is usually between 30 to 40hours, depending on how thorough you want to be and how much % completion you want. Then, you can easily get maximum completion in just a few hours (without speed running skips). 
Now, the only thing left for us to do is wait for Silksong... in the meantime... I'll be grinding P5...

TLDR:
A gloomy grimdark tale of a young bug that takes on the role of a knight trying to figure out what has turned the kingdom of Hollownest into an infected bug-version of Blighttown.. In short, Hollow Knight is an Amazing Metroidvania and you should go play it immediately. On top of that you should recommend all your friends and family to play it as well, and on the double! Gently drown Team Cherry in cash so that we might get Silksong out faster! 

Hollow Knight is a game that truly defined what a great Metroidvania is all about. It is one thing to burst out of nowhere and bedazzle an already saturated market, but to do so and simply excel in all aspects available is nothing short of brilliant. Everything from the story, the worldbuilding, gameplay, artwork and graphics, upgrade system and general flow are polished to perfection and there is hardly a flaw present in this amazing game. First and foremost, I adore the storytelling in this game. It reminds me of the best parts of Dark Souls with its emerging narrative about a darkness manifesting in a realm at its peak only to descend into turmoil and madness. The characters you encounter each add to this story like layers of an onion in a perfect symmetry until it all ends in an epic finale. The handcrafted environment and cartoony yet dark presentation is truly magical and never has such a monochrome game been so colorful and rich in character, presence and atmosphere. The music is simply sublime and every song is perfectly encapsulating its area. The first time I entered City of Tears it actually brought tears to my eyes.. 

Combined with the aforementioned stellar presentation is a gameplay that's fluent, fast and elegant that really rewards the player for learning the rhythm of the game. The loop of fast and snappy combat combined with great traversal makes every bossfight come down to skillful execution and finesse rather than brute force and every step of the journey a joyous experience in gloomy contemplation. The power ups might be all familiar in this day and age but the intricate system of brooches that you can apply to give a slight edge on your journey are varied and unique enough that no two gameplays need be the same. Sure there are better ones but that only bothers the pure number crunchers in the community.  

As already mentioned. I highly recommend Hollow Knight. It is a stellar example of the best that Metroidvania has to offer. No other game has come close to the flawless package and even though some might find the atmosphere to bleak for their taste none can ignore the true beauty that has been exhumed from the bottom of a brooding entomologist collection.. Go get it, what are you waiting for!

Thee most well rounded modern cRPG experience. Probably the best 2010s cRPG on the market. 

-Choices matter
-Replay value
-Character writing depth
-Quality of life design choices

And perhaps the game's biggest strength - The sheer amount of ways in which you can approach any task laid out before you. There are so many opportunities to think outside of the box and man, I just love that. The many ways to approach combat, to solve or completely avoid puzzles etc... I got 112 hours off just one playtrough.

However, I am not a fan of the setting, main plot premise and the tone. I prefer less colorful more serious small scale adventures with more emphasis on adventuring and quest design rather than character drama.

Pains me to leave a negative review as I love CRPGs and a high quality CRPG like this should be an amazing game but I just can't get myself to finish it. Encounter design is just pure garbage and the main reason why I'm giving up on this game.

I got to level 14 and almost finished act 2 but I just don't want to play any more.

The good : 

- Graphics are pretty good.
- Music is amazing.
- Voice acting is really good.
- Progression system is decent enough if nothing super groundbreaking or exciting.
- I like the action point based system where each action during a turn cost a number of action points and you can essentially spend them however you want.
- Origin characters are pretty good and IMO there's basically 0 reason not to play an origin character since you can spec anyone however you want and can only take 4 characters with you into later acts.
- Story is ok but not groundbreaking and its not that hard but not super easy to follow, I played DOS 1 years ago and don't really remember what happened so I am having a hard time following the world's story and lore.

The bad :

- Loot system is just plain bad, having random diablo style loot in a CRPG where enemies don't respawn is incredibly stupid and I actually remember it was one of the reasons I stopped played DOS 1 years ago. Random loot works in ARPGs like Diablo and PoE because that's the whole point of the game to infinitely farm enemies to get loot. In CPRGs you not only cannot do that but its not the point of the game either, that is why actually good CPRGs like BG, Pathfinder games, and OG Bioware, Obsidian CRPGs have static loot. In this game RNG can just screw you being stuck for multiple levels without getting any good gear meaning you're gonna struggle.
- Encounter and enemy progression : Also really badly designed, there is no actual enemy scaling but there might as well be. This game is like made to screw you over. I was playing going full murderhobo doing all the quests and then killing all the NPCs for maximum XP and yet I could never outlevel the enemies, everywhere you go enemies are always either as high level or higher level than you. You can get off the boat in act 2 and be around level 8 or 9 yet the game makes you quickly face level 11 to 13 enemies that can kill your characters in 1-2 or 3 hits. Many times the games will do this and place really tough encounters in areas with easier ones meaning unless you follow a guide that will not do a linear progression of quests and encounters you will face unbeatable encounters for your level often so you have to reload and abandon them and go to other areas to scrounge up XP.

The ugly :

- Encounter design : This is actually the main reason I'm stopping playing the game, most encounters feel pretty much the same but that's the least of their problems. You basically have to prepare and heavily cheese every encounter and have prior knowledge of what's going to happen otherwise you will fail.
This means that basically you need to quicksave every 30 seconds in case something happens, then you let it happen, figure out how this encounter is gonna screw you over, and then reload to try to counter that, meaning you will be constantly quick saving and quick loading, it gets incredibly tedious.

I'm gonna draw a comparison to BG3, in BG3 there are a couple of "Ambushes" that you could fall into, but your characters actually get a perception check to detect the enemies and you can then turn the tables on them, enemies will also not basically 1 shot your characters. In DOS 2 you get constantly 1 or 2 shot, pretty much 1 encounter out of 2 is gonna be a random ambush where you advance into an area and enemies just magically jack-in-a-box appear out of nowhere and surround you immediately with no way from you to detect those enemies or prevent getting ambushed. Insanely dumb encounter design. And if you think we'll why don't you use the environment to your advantage, in tactical games you might think to use a chokepoint with a tank and keep your weaker characters behind out of danger. None of that works in this game because most enemies can instantly teleport anywhere and immediately appear on your wizard and pummel him to death in the same turn. So you're basically forced to just use cheese tactics like starting a conversation with the enemies and then while the conversation happens just switch to another character and teleport enemies far away from the others and kill them 1 by 1. 

Some times you can attack the other enemies outside the conversation and their boss will just stay in the conversation with your 1 character while you kill all his underlings, then you can heal up and take on the boss solo. Its just really stupid that they force people to cheese this way otherwise some fights are just impossible. I did the Aeterna fight last night and its one of the worst boss fights in the game, basically this boss will 100% kill your entire party easily if you even let them do anything, so again you are forced to cheese her and freeze her during the conversation, then just use a soul bond and cheese kill her drinking potions because she's and undead and takes damage from healing potions, boss fights should be fun and exciting. Boss fights in the pathfinder games and BG3 are fun. None of the boss fights in this game are fun, just insane high burst damage that will instantly kill you if you take any damage. Imagine playing Elden Ring like those guys that do a no damage run and they have to restart if they take a single hit, I mean sure some people might enjoy that but most people don't.

[h3] A Epic Journey Through Rivellon: Divinity Original Sin 2 Review [/h3]

[b] TDLR: [/b] Divinity Original Sin 2 is a monumental achievement in the RPG genre. With its unforgettable origin companions, masterful storytelling, and innovative game-play mechanics, it 100% helped to set a new  standard  of what an RPG can achieve - the path to BG3 if you will.  While the armor system may have its drawbacks, it's a small price to pay for the grand adventure that awaits in the world of Rivellon. Larian Studios crafted a masterpiece that will be remembered as a classic for generations to come.

Divinity Original Sin 2 should be - in my humble opinion - considered as one of the masterpieces in the realm of RPGs. It expertly weaves a tapestry of immersive storytelling and innovative gameplay that captivates from start to finish. 

For me the standout feature of DOS2 lies in its meticulously crafted origin companions. These characters are not just party members; they are fully fleshed-out personalities with rich backstories, motivations, and real connections to the world of Rivellon. Whether you're navigating the moral labyrinth with the conflicted Red Prince or delving into the dark depths of Fane's enigmatic past, each companion feels like a living, breathing entity, adding layers of complexity and emotional investment to the narrative.

The high-quality writing that underpins these characters is also very strong - you can in hindsight really see where they were heading narratively now we have had the pleasure of playing Baldur's gate 3. Larian Studios' attention to detail is evident in every line of dialogue and every piece of lore scattered throughout the world - I am obsessed with reading any book I can find in order to pick up another titbit of world building lore. The nuanced storytelling allows for meaningful interactions and choices that carry just enough weight, giving players a sense of agency rarely found in RPGs. The interwoven narratives of each origin companion and their personal quests provide a level of depth that is seldom achieved, making every decision feel impact-full and every revelation a momentous event.

Game-play in DOS2 is a testament to Larian Studios' commitment to innovation. The reactive surfaces system is a stroke of genius, introducing an element of tactical depth rarely seen in RPGs. The dynamic interplay of fire, water, poison, and electricity adds a layer of complexity to battles that demands strategic thinking and adaptability. This system elevates combat giving it a high level of tactical and strategical depth particularly on the more difficult modes, making each encounter a thrilling puzzle to solve.

The classless character system is a breath of fresh air, allowing players to craft their heroes with unparalleled freedom. This flexibility encourages experimentation and fosters a sense of ownership over your character's growth. I felt like the system really pushed me to create and try unique builds that suited varying play styles. This I think has helped my two two journeys through Rivellon so far have not ever felt the same.

However, one blemish for me on this otherwise almost flawless canvas is the armor system. While intended to add a tactical layer to battles, it can sometimes feel overly restrictive and lead to frustrating moments, particularly in the early stages of the game. It's a minor quibble in the grand scheme of things, but one that stands out in an otherwise seamless experience.

9/10

I beat BG3 two times and decided to see what else Larian cooked in the past that is good. Found DOS2, I like the graphics and decided to try it out. This is a monster of a game! Definitely unlock the developers gift bag, at least the mirror, so you are able to change your characters and play around with different builds.  My favorite was act 2 and act 4, the end game.  There is a lot to do, the fights are mostly different each time, the enemies are smart, the environment can be against you, you need to think to survive. The story is very interesting, and not cheesy or linear.  I am hoping to see DOS 3 in future.  Definitely recommend this gem.

For all the hype about this game being a masterpiece, it's just not that good in terms of basic game design.

-The tutorial is tucked away and not in an obvious place
-Trading uses a slider instead of just typing the amount of gold you want to spend
-Your inventory gets moved around between the backpack and trade screens
-Your elemental spells will hit everybody: fire and ice everywhere
-There's a low-level shield throw skill that becomes insanely overpowered
-There's no reason for a necro to have more than 3 points in necro
-members of your party will disappear permanently if you don't complete their quest line before moving on to the next map
-If you move ahead too quickly, it will be much harder to find enough fights to level up on the next map
-You are told if you are blinded and cannot see a target but not told you your spell is targeting the banister of a stairwell and the the enemy you are trying to hit 
-In a turn-based game, some enemies have near infinite movement per turn
-Your party's movement outside of combat is probably the worst I've ever seen
--There is this chain/unchain system that switches states without you adjusting settings
--One character will enter a doorway and begin combat while the rest of the party sits outside out of combat
--Party members will not follow you across dangerous terrain, but the character you control will jump in lava to get to the place you clicked on another part of the map

And this is all present in the definitive edition.

The writing is far better than you usually see in similar games, and I was genuinely surprised to find out that the Red Prince has the best story arc in the game: he was not my favorite in the beginning because I'm not a fan of characters that seem to exist only to make things harder for everyone else, but the writing made progressing through his story an unexpected joy.

My only complaint: the backpack mechanics are terrible, and item storage could be greatly improved. However, the rest of the game made it worth dealing with many times over.

[h1]Divinity: Original Sin 2 - Definitive Edition Review[/h1]
[h2]Macbook Pro LAN Edition[/h2]

[b]Graphics:[/b]
While it may not fully harness the might of your Macbook Pro's stunning screen with HDR, Divinity: Original Sin 2 still manages to look impressive, like the gleaming surface of Tripticon. The game's attention to detail and intricate world design shine through, even without the full potential of your Mac's display.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
As for the gameplay, it's like a Decepticon's strategy meeting—complex, engaging, and filled with unexpected twists. The LAN support, allowing you to join forces with Soundwave on his PC, is a testament to the versatility of your Mac. Cooperation between Mac and PC, now that's something Megatron himself would appreciate.

[b]Sound:[/b]
The game's audio, like a Decepticon's battle cry, immerses you in its fantasy world. The atmospheric music and voice acting add depth to your gaming experience.

[b]Performance:[/b]
It's unfortunate that HDR doesn't fully utilize your Mac's splendid screen. However, the fact that you can still enjoy this epic adventure on your Macbook Pro is a testament to its capabilities. It may not be Metroplex, but it gets the job done.

[spoiler]And remember, even if your Mac can't unleash its full potential with HDR, it's still a valuable asset in your gaming arsenal, much like a loyal Decepticon companion.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

In summary, Divinity: Original Sin 2 - Definitive Edition on your Macbook Pro is like a Decepticon adapting to new circumstances. It may not reach its full potential with HDR, but it's a commendable choice for LAN gaming with Soundwave and a testament to the versatility of your Mac. I'd give it a Starscream rating of [b]8/10[/b], acknowledging its strengths while considering the missed opportunity with HDR. Keep on gaming, and who knows what other adventures await in the world of Mac gaming!

This is the mixed bag of all mixed bags. 

The game has great art direction, graphics, music, voice acting, writing, lore, and character customization. But the entire game has one major, huge, tremendous, absurd flaw. 

Its combat.

In my opinion, this game has even worse combat than Divinity Original Sin 1. The problems in the first game are even worse here.

Enemies can still waltz through an entire screen's worth of oil, make a couple detours, and still have enough AP to attack your back line. And then steal your special spell casting resource, even if they don't have anyway to actually use it.

Just to annoy you. 

CC (Crowd Control) based combat is even more prevalent, but is even worse than the first game. Hypothetically, the armor mechanic in the game is supposed to protect both you and the enemies from being CC'd to death on the first turn. Not a bad thing, if the combat wasn't centered around the entire concept of "you need to CC all enemies immediately or they will shove their boot up your backside". However, the worst part is that the enemy will always go first, at least in any fight that actually matters. They'll immediately cast their strongest spell, wipe your your entire team's magic or physical armor, and then still have enough AP to follow up and stun your entire team. 

On top of that, most combat encounters are like clown cars. You'll see one enemy, or sometimes none, and then that one enemy will summon 5 friends outta nowhere. 

TL;DR: Decent game that's worth playing, but the combat is not worth respect. Cheese every encounter, its not worth your effort. 6.5 Outta ten

Surprise! It's still on. Why, yes, he is charging into the death fog like it isn't there. Why, yes, death fog is a central theme of the game.

They clearly learned from a lot of things that didn't work well here. Turn battle mode on? Great addition to future games. Non-lethal strike mode? Another great addition to future games. Zoom in conversations that actually show the characters involved and not just a torso ('cause Beast is shorter than who he talks to)? Fantastic for immersion in future games. Tooltips that don't take up significant portions of the screen? Wonderful. Does -this- game have any of that? No, but it does have several encounters that require you to plan attacks, to strike but not kill people, and interface with the world (HI I AM A TOOLTIP) in exact ways. The game is long with weird pacing and all that going on the whole way. It turned out not to be worth it to me. Glad it led to better things, though.

This is clearly a game made with passion, the enviorments are pretty and the developers thought of every little thing, for example if you heal a few injured characters at one point they will later help you fight, and theres no quest for it or anything, one of my favourite aspects is the skills/spells, anyone can make their own build around any type but more importantly hybrid types of magic or any of the other schools, together with the elemental system this works very well in my opinion, an example of something i did at the start of the game is dual wield wands, in my right hand i had a water wand and in my left an air (electricity) wand, since the right hand attacks first my enemies will get the water damage and also become wet, making them recieve more electric damage from my left wand, the same can be done with earth and fire wands, this is just one example of the amazing things you can do in this game, the writing is also top notch, you can find anything from heartwarming stories to a sheep having flash backs of the great war, one last thing though, this game is very slow and will tale up a lot of your time if you invest in it, so consider that if you plan to buy.

Picked it back up after 3 years due to BG3 release/hype. Decided to come back to this while they patch up BG3 before i give that game a shot. I remember back when I first started DOS2:DE it kicked my you know what, so I quit. Now, I was determined to give it another go and I'm glad I did. Got a feel for how the game operates and the story is addictive, along with the feeling of executing during battle. I've got so many hours in the game and I'm still in the middle of Act 2. 

You can save whenever so if you want a quick fix or a longer session, either is viable. Side quests are well done and fleshed out. Even though it's not all acted out like BG3 (it's more of a narrator describing things happening and you use your imagination to depict the details), the dialogue sequences give a variety of options on how you want to proceed (good, evil, sometimes good, neutral, selfish, selfless, etc.). I'm glad I came back and gave it another shot. 

If you have trouble at the beginning due to being new at this type of game, I'd suggest looking up general things on how it operates, and the type of ways you take advantage of different paths, It will get easier to understand the more you play, make mistakes, and learn from them. Great game overall.

I started playing DOS2 to get rid of that BG3 itch(if you know you know), so this review is for people like me who played BG3, loved it, and wanted to play something similar.

In my opinion, it's not even close to as good as BG3.  My two main issues: combat is stifling, and there is often a "correct" decision when talking to NPC's.

Combat: There is too much fire.  God forbid you want to play anything except a pyro tank, because you will encounter fire literally everywhere.  Good luck trying to spread any terrain effect around the battlefield when it'll be set on fire as soon as the enemy gets a turn.  Oh, did I mention literally every single enemy has fire scrolls?  You'll be in a fight with bandits near the beach and the field will be ablaze just as much as if you were fighting Hephaestus himself.  "Just use rain," people will say.  Well, very early into the game you'll encounter necrofire, which can't be put out by water.  "Just bless the fire and put it out," people will say.  Well, bless costs SP which isn't unlimited, and what's the point when the next enemy turn will just be oil + fire + curse?  Your only real solution is to embrace it and put fire resist on everyone, which is a pretty shitty solution if you ask me.

Add onto this the armor system.  In DOS2, physical and magical armor are separate.  You have to get through your respective armor before doing damage.  Let's say you invest 200 damage into breaking the physical armor of a boss.  Your mage is now essentially doing dogshit nothing because any damage they do will be blocked by the magic armor.  The game very much incentivizes you to play either full magic or full physical damage, which obviously isn't very fun for variation.  To add on to this, once armor is gone, CC works at 100%.  The game becomes very easy once you realize every fight is: pop one type of armor, CC lock the enemy.  If you don't do this, you can be sure as hell the enemy will.

Choices: I will admit that I like min-maxing; I often search up guides on what decisions will lead to what result, partially because I don't want to replay the game to see the other choices.  I would say in 90% of NPC interactions, there is an objectively "best" choice.  That is, there will be a choice that gives you the most EXP + rewards, and it won't be close.  You are strictly losing out on EXP + gear if you choose anything except these "correct" choices.  It really makes decisions feel inconsequential, because generally the best option is to choose the "best" choice and then do whatever it is you would've done(like kill the NPC).

To be fair to this game, if BG3 wasn't such a masterpiece I probably would've enjoyed DOS2.  It is, after all, made by the same studio.  If you are also looking at this game after playing BG3, I'd highly recommend looking up some DOS2 gameplay before committing to buying the game.  I strongly disagree with all of the reviews praising it as one of the best games of all time.  $45 is a large investment, and in my opinion it was not worth it.

Do you want to burn the entire battlefield with constant flames, or maybe throw a shield so hard that you concuss two guys at once? what about having such a high vamp and thorns rate that taking damage heals you? Maybe even talk to a cat that calls himself booply-bear, or arrange a date for a rat and a tortoise? 

Do any of those sound cool? play this game, and do all of them all.

This game is genuinely enjoyable and I think it's a must buy during steam sales. 

The combat system is really fun with everything being limited to your AP (Action Points) which range from attacks to just moving around in the process of a fight. Honestly while this may seem a little weird to point out but having the ability to move around while casting spells / attacking physically gives so much more freedom and strategy to play around with.
Even more, you can defeat enemies you weren't even supposed to fight if you play your fights really well. Being able to set up before a fight and making preparations which give you an edge over you enemy is so satisfying.

To make it even better, the amount of creativity this game gives you with your character is absolutely phenomenal. While you may not get to customize your looks as much as I would have hoped, there is just so much more you can tinker with when it comes to your abilities and stat line. For example, is it better to upgrade my thievery which gives me a chance to get hidden loot I never could have gained? Or should I focus on upgrading a combat ability which will allow me to more easily melt through enemies? There are benefits and downsides to both, but overall it's just a fun experience to mess around with and see what's optimal for your personal playstyle!

It's as good as everyone says. I wasn't sure I'd like this type of RPG but it's too good not to like. If you're on the fence, play it right now.

The amount of freedom in D:OS2 is astonishing. The way you progress, the way you interact with the world and its characters, and the way you build your own character, both in terms of roleplay and stats; it's all up to you. The fact that I could just kill off all the main characters at the beginning of the game just cause I felt like it... not many games let you do that.

Exploration is done incredibly well. Every discovery feels intentional and important, but at the same time, they're designed in a way that makes it really feel like a discovery. 

The voice acting is great, especially the animals. Take the Pet Pal trait. The writing, too, especially the way they describe magic, is great.

There were three main things that bothered me about D:OS2:
- It can be frustrating on occasion, especially the combat. The decay debuff makes me yell and say big cusses.
- Leveling can be a pain, and being underleveled sucks. It sometimes takes ages to get XP, and it seems like you have to do literally everything in the game if you want to be properly leveled for the ending on higher difficulties.
- The story can feel a little bit overcomplicated, messy, and unfocused at times. None of it detracted too much from the experience though.

I'll definitely be doing another playthrough. Probably two, or three, or four. Maybe five.

If you're coming from Dragon Age like I was: Dragon Age does a better job with its stories and companions in my opinion, and is meant to be more cinematic, but regarding everything else, D:OS2 leaves Dragon Age in the dust, and it still does a fine job with it's story and companions.

I love the depth of this game. I love turn based games like xcom but those are launch mission and return to base vs the open world style in DOS2. I'd say I'm def more of a fan of the open world style. DOS2 takes the crown as my favorite turn based game ever. I'm going to play Baldurs Gate 3 next but I'm glad I was able to enjoy this experience!
