This game is a masterpiece. Like other Fromsoft titles, it can be brutally hard, but it does a very good job of giving you the tools to overcome those challenges, if you are willing to put in the time and experimentation to find them. Rather than an RPG where you steadily improve a single build over the course of a play-though, this game is all about finding many builds, whether specialist or generalist, and using them to address specific sets of problems. The different parts can impact each other (a core with boosts to reactor output can take a weaker generator with better combat stats and allow it to support a far heavier equipment load, for example) and parts which seem to have weaker performance statistics can have valuable benefits that are still worth including. Your speed, for instance, is influenced by three things: your overall weight, your core part's 'booster adjustment' stat, and the equipped booster. perhaps a slower booster with better vertical performance can be accounted for by keeping to the lighter parts elsewhere, to keep the speed high while enjoying the booster's other benefits. Every part feels like it has a place in at least one build, and tinkering to find new combinations and better understand their interactions is a big part of what I enjoy here. The ability to replay any story mission you've beaten is fantastic, not only because it'll give you a rating for completionists to maximize but because it'll pay out again so that early on you can pick up more part variety, and later on it'll let you go back and beat up on bosses who gave you trouble before you found the ideal tools to reduce them to metallic dust. The result is a game where the challenges feel great to interact with, because it's a matter of learning what strengths or skills will make addressing those challenges easier. There's more I could go on about, but I'd honestly like to post this and go back to playing it!

A question like "do you recommend this game?" feels tricky for a game like this, because Armored Core is NOT like most other games. In Armored Core, there's an emphasis on experimentation, trial-and-error, etc. Basically letting you do whatever you want and not telling you what to do. You can make the stupidest, most useless AC in existence and the game won't reprimand you for that or tell you what you should do instead. You learn everything on your own. Yeah, there's a tutorial, but it only gives you vague ideas of what you can do.
If you enjoy having freedom of choice in a very technical and demanding game, then yes I do recommend this game. If you prefer something more streamlined and accessible, then you should know what you're getting into. This is absolutely an Armored Core game, and I'm so glad FromSoft has revived my favorite mech franchise ever.

The best compliment I can give Armored Core 6 is that it feels like a real video game I might've bought for my Xbox when I was younger. The difficulty spikes can be abrupt but they keep me on my toes and the feeling of fighting a boss over and over until you beat and and finally finding a build that works for you is awesome.

The last AC game I played was AC3 with some friends way back in the day. It was a blast going head to head in custom mechs blasting each other to smithereens. I went exclusively to PC not long after, and unfortunately, the AC games never got ported over.

Enter AC6: Fires of Rubicon. I appreciate FromSoft finally throwing PC gamers a bone with recent games, rather than making us wait for half-assed ports, if any at all.

AC6 is pretty much what you'd expect from an AC game- large, destructive, quick moving mechs laying waste to everything in large, open environments. The controls are tight and responsive, the combat is fast paced, fun, and often challenging. Customizing and optimizing your AC can sometimes be fun.

I do have some criticisms, despite really enjoying the game.

Balance (as others have mentioned) could use a LOT of work. The vast majority of weapons become obsolete very quickly. One of the reasons for this is the Stagger mechanic. Once you get weapons that do high Impact damage, there isn't much reason to use anything else, leaving you with a long list of weapons that you'll never use. The biggest casualty of the Stagger bar are fast, lightweight builds, as there aren't any decent weapons that your mech can carry to put high strain on enemy ACS. You'll be using Bazookas, Heavy Missile launchers, Laser Cannons, Grenade Launchers, or the Zimmerman, and that's about it, so you're pretty much left with Medium-Heavy to Heavyweight builds if you actually want to be effective.

Rather than nerfing the powerful weapons (they SHOULD be powerful), I'd like to see them buff the weaker, lower impact weapons to make lightweight builds more viable. Some of us like piloting fast mechs, but don't want to rely on just melee to build ACS Strain.

Mission balance is another issue. You'll breeze through a lot of missions with little to no challenge, and then BOOM...in comes the infamous FromSoft Sadism. You'll be stuck retrying a boss or rebuilding your AC over and over before you finally take down certain bosses. Looking at you Balteus and Sea Spider.

All in all though, AC6 is a fun game, the graphics are great, the performance is great, and the bugs are minimal. I'm certainly glad that FromSoft is releasing complete games, even if they need some fine tuning.

you may have heard people saying that fromsoftware should add an easy mode to the game and felt offended by the idea. heres the thing tho. they did. its called zimmermann and pilebunker mode. having trouble with the hardest bosses in the game? go pew pew and then pointy stick. you win every single time. but what about pvp you ask? yes, zimmermann and pointy stick makes it easy too, unless theyre going with a bumblebee build to directly counter it. fromsoftware truly cares about everyone
besides that, great game. rusty is best boy

on a more serious note, yes, this is a great game. art direction? hell yeah. this world is a bleak distopia and it shows tho it always feels a bit silly how this world is made for ACs. its huge. gigantic.

the music is pretty gucci. some of the tracks are fine and get the job done but good lord some of them are bangers

 combat is fun, simple to understand but with a high skill cealing. a good player will trivialise any boss regardless of their build but like i said, some builds will make the game very easy.  the missions surprisingly dont feel like rinse and repeat. theres ONE stealth mission and it fits, awkwardly, in the game. theres ONE escort mission. despite the game having only so many mechanics, no mission feels the same. thats quite the flex imo. if youre familiar with fromsoftware, you know the bosses will suplex you. a lot of new people who came into this game blind were, as we say, filtered. if you got filtered by balteus, i understand. you got filted by the tutorial boss? thats embarrassing...anyways! the boss fights are pretty neat! some a gimics and others are just straight up duals but some are harder than others. the final boss in the *happy* ending was a joke. i beat them on my first try but i was beaten emotionally. they broke my emotional ACS and landed a direct hit into my tear ducts. i assure you, if you keep trying to learn their pattern and youre willing to customize your mech, you will win. theres plenty of busted builds out there for you to copy and trivialise the game with anyways. beating these bosses is an achievement and you will very likely become good enough to farm them for money and trying out builds. theres a mission where the clock is ticking for you to defeat two high level opponents before a third one joins the fray. my build was way too slow to beat them so i changed his guns. the mission went from wanting to tear my hair out to a cakewalk. it wasnt a broken build in any shape or form. i choose a different assault rifle and it changed everything. thats it. assault rifles arent even powerful in this game for some reason. the burst fire one is pretty gucci but my point stands

ONE OF THE BEST THINGS ABOUT THIS GAME IS THE CHECKPOINTS! 
the reason why i lose my mind with darksouls is having to get back to the boss. its torture. this game, has none of that garbage. you die to a boss? THE CHECKPOINT GETS YOU RIGHT BACK INTO THE ARENA HELL YEAH BROTHER! also you get a full restore so that helps makes the game easier and before you complain that this will make the game too easy, you cannot get a perfect score if you use a checkpoint. the full restore is essential for the skill challenged ones of us who play this game, including me but eh at least im not a meta slave

you may hear some complaints once in a while about the game not having a story but thats coming from people who need to be spoonfed everything. the story is solid as you would expect from a fromsoftware game and as cryptic as one. well, its not really that criptic but some details may fly under the radar if you arent actively listening. the third ending will likely confuse you so just look up a lore video like every fromstoftware fan will do in their free time anyways. this game plays way smoother than it should. the characters in this game are great and just like everyone and there mother will mention, are compelling even tho you never once see their face. i cant really think of a single character i didnt like. even the characters youre supposed to not like, SNAIL, are good characters. one moment im playing a game about big robots going pew pew haha stuneedle goes brrr and the next im crying on my first play through, ugly crying the words ''f-fl-fly high bu-buddyyy! I love you!''. the voice acting in this game is stellar. the story would feel so much weaker if these characters didnt have such clean performances.

ive maybe seen one single bug? a boss used a specific attack that collided me straight into me but for some reason i didnt get hurt. it was a direct hit and she dragged me for a bit but nada. i was fine.
 
you get a lot of pieces to build your very own mech and the paintjob system is *chefkiss*. i do feel like a lot of the pieces are just extra variations of missiles and maybe theres a bit too many and we could use more variaty instead in other departments? maybe its just me but i feel like theres a bit too many missiles and a lack of other stuff. im pretty happy with most of the mechs i built and i think they got some good style as well. as a fromsoftware fan, fashion is a must. they all feel distinct and like MY creations. a really neat detail i must share is that everything you see in the trailer is in the game. all the frame pieces, the weapons, the ennemies. its all in it. yes, you can use that really cool bomb satchell! i like to call it the chinese pocket sand. the chinese weapons are blunt but a lot of fun to use and thats coming from a dex scum

 pvp is pretty alright. the matchmaking system is pretty barebone but the gameplay is worth it.

 im sleep deprived and depressed so im not able to express myself as fully as id like to but hopefully i managed to convince you this game is worth your time regardless if you are a fromsoftware fan or not.

PvP is garbage either due to the way you connect to opponents (inconsistent with what is being displayed to each player) or just the way they designed the game. #1 people can kick you when they are no where near you. I've often had people kick me when there was a 50 ft gap between us or speed their AC up when they kick, beyond what their AC can achieve with assault boost #2 The guns have inconsistent fire rates in some matches. Sometimes my gun wont even fire until 2-3 seconds after I've hit the mouse button, other times they work flawlessly  #3 Stun locking is on another level, what skill does it take to cycle through 3 attacks that keep people frozen. Needs a serious debuff, same with this new stagger system, that also needs a debuff. It limits the AC builds that require actual skill. #4 Your gun will make the noise and show the animation of you firing but if you get staggered before your bullet makes contact with the enemy then your bullet magically disappears and does no damage #5 Sometimes when quick boosting sideways the enemies bullets will turn at you and follow you as if they were homing missiles. #6 Again with the kicking... you can just keep tapping the assault boost button on players and in some cases just kick the other player to death and they can't even move? #7 The fact your AC gets showcased to your opponent before every match like you invited them over for tea and crumpets. LAME. #8 Full charged weapon builds need to get overloaded longer after firing all guns on charged. Pretty cheap way to win a lot of matches. Spam charged weapons, if you hit the enemy with one barrage they die. barely even have to move around. Lots to fix with PvP. I can win 20 matches in a row and still be mad and disappointed. Some of the stuff is just painful to watch unfold and leaves me saying "okay now that's just cheap" even when it's me doing it. Definitely takes away from the satisfaction of killing someone when you're getting stressed out from phantom kicks and homing bullet. Fortunately the single player is good. Very fluid and haven't noticed any ridiculous things like I see in multiplayer. The campaign is okay if you like new game + play style. I would prefer to get my story line in one play through and not have them make you start a new game over and over just to add a few missions until you finally figure out whats actually happening. In its current state I can't recommend the game. If you have the extra money go ahead, it's not a horrible game and can be fun. But if it's between this or another game. Probably pick the other game

Great game, almost a gold standard for a AAA game release. 

One major issue is the easy anti cheat, with it my fps constantly fluctuates and has micro stutters. The worst part that forced me to disable EAC and mostly play offline was the fight against the honest fellow who was a brute. Every time I looked at the light source in the arena my frames dropped dramatically to what felt like 10 fps. After disabling it, near solid 60 fps.

With that out of the way, although tough, it is a fair game with a cool art style, plenty of customisation and a nice, thoughtful, and not too long story. A definite 8 out of 10. 
The intrusive anti cheat that kills frames really sucks that it forces a decision between stability or multiplayer, but since the singleplayer and personal approach is the main draw, I think its definitely worth the asking price.

This game is perfect as a first introduction to the mecha genre. It's also a great game in general. It runs great, and the difficulty is hard, but not too hard. The story is engaging, but can be ignored totally without impacting the gameplay. The graphics aren't the highest quality, but the art direction more than makes up for it, setting the mood for every level, while maintaining visual clarity. (Plus is has photo mode, which was not something I missed in games until I played AC6. Now I wish I had it in everything.) My only issues with this game are that the controls are clearly ported from a console, and feel clunky at times on PC, and the PvP feels a bit lacklustre. Overall I would rate this game 9/10, and I think it is absolutely worth the (admittedly expensive) price. (No microtransactions too!)

Been a fan of Armored Core 4 (AC4) and Dark Souls 3 (DS3). This game brings the qualities I liked from AC4, along with some FromSoftware staples of DS3 into a great game. Lots of customisation, a surprising amount of replayability, and the grittiness of both games gels great.
My literal only gripes are a lack of mech turning speed as a stat and how energy from a generator can't replenish while in use (although I understand why it was done this way - for healthy PVP gameplay).
I'd highly recommend picking up this game if you enjoy mech games, customisation and softcore souls-like games.

After getting all the endings for the game. I can honestly say that Armored Core 6 is going to be a good contender for game of the year. This game goes out of its way to make YOU feel like the BEST pilot in Armored Core 6 all with the dialogue, the music, and the challenging fights coming together to make a wonderful whole. This game had me moving in my seat to dodge attacks in game! It's been a good minute since a game has made me do that. This is one of the first times I've seen a 3D Bullet-Hell done right. 

The deep customization for your personal mech is one of the defining features of the Armored Core franchise and I'm glad to see that the customization has not been skimped on in any sense of the word. You can create your own emblems COD BLACK OPS style and even put them onto your AC to make the color palettes a bit more intricate than the standard color selection. Customization allows you to think outside of the box to personalize your AC to make you feel like you're actually part of the story. Another well done self insert character.

The story takes many twists and turns with different routes making replaying the game all that much more rewarding. Each choice giving you basically a completely different end-game. The characters were also pretty good. They're voiced really well and that's basically necessary because all of the characters are faceless, hidden behind their AC/ Emblem. That isn't a bad thing though. I believe that this game uses that to it's advantage because the game is ALL about the ARMORED CORE. You can often see the personalities of the characters reflected off of their AC builds even once you unlock them in the arena. This game much like many FROMSOFT games have many different attention-to-detail things that make their games feel extremely immersive no matter how they present the story. 

The multiplayer is a nice addition, seeing all the other players builds and fighting against them is basically the heart and soul of the AC community. It's all great fun.

With all of this said, I'm willing to say that Armored Core VI goes Hard Core VI.

I give FROM props for designing the movement well, but this is, in the end, a serial boss run. They could've just made it an arena with bosses, for what little they did with the actual "missions" and "levels" of the game.

Despite having fun original elements that are part of the AC series, the game levels are repetitive, combat becomes stale after awhile, a few weapons are overpowered compared to to others so the mech builds all feel similar. The controls on a controller are frustrating and YOU CANNOT CHANGE THE GAME CONTROLS! Some commands on controller are permanently locked, making the game frustrating to play and feeling slow to respond, you are fully locked into how they want you to control your mech and there is no way to change it. SO much opportunity to build something amazing and expansive but it just feels like another game made on a budget to rope in people who like the series but not actually offering a lot in terms of a really well developed game. Unless updates and large expansions are added i'd recommend spending your time somewhere else.
I want to like the game, but the setting is irredeemably depressing.

Before this game came out I played most of the previous Armored Core games and as a result I have grown an immense appreciation for the series. This latest entry in the long line of Armored Core games reached my expectations and then some. Whether you are completely new to the series, or are a returning vet, Armored Core VI: Fires of Rubicon is an excellent game for everyone with its comparatively easier learning curve, compared to previous entries, and its excellent overall game feel.

The story is a natural evolution of how previous Armored Core games handled it, with the main focus being on getting into the action and utilizing your own custom mech. Speaking of, the customization is absolutely bonkers and people who like to make their own "character" or customize things in games won't be disappointed.

The multiplayer is pretty light and you don't unlock it until around the midway point of a single run of the story. It consists of only a 1v1 and team deathmatch mode, but is still pretty smooth and enjoyable.

The one big downside/hope I have when it comes to this game is that I wish they would update the multiplayer to have more content and replayability as it can sometimes get stale fighting other players in basic arenas over and over. Even something like a co-op mode or a bigger variety of pvp modes would be nice. But the main focus, like in every other Armored Core game, is mostly on the single-player story, and this game delivers quality in that department in droves.

If you are on the fence, I say that this game is well worth the $60 price point and then some.

Sooo. My relations with this game are .... complicated

Let's start with pros:
- the game is great
- gameplay is VERY cinematic and engaging
- the lore is nice
- that feel of being a pilot of a BIG MECH WITH GUNS - it is there, boys. It is right there
- AC bosses are very interesting to fight against

But here they are, non-AC bosses VS my lightweight build:
- 10 faster than you
- 10 more health and stagger meter
- no cooldowns
- input reads
- takes 60% of your health in one attack
- that hits back to back thx to RNG
- the area is a small square with nowhere to hide and breath
- so, eat cheap damage/stagger ALL THE TIME
- camera WILL screw you
- your bullets ricochet but their NEVER (be closer -> eat more chip damage)
- take your light AC+blade+shield and shove it into your own A$$ since it is TANK LEGS + GATLING GUN META
- cheese is the only way here
- or invest 2h+ into fight untill you win just because of statistics
- WTF would AC even exist in this world, when these monsters are lurking around? Lore? Please?

Solution (and advice for newbies): not everything works against Non-AC bosses. Deal with it. But to reduce the amount of frustration: you should have 2 builds ready for every mission: kinetic/missiles for high stagger, and energy for high dps. Once you die - you can change your build. USE IT

The game plus non-AC bosses - 10 lazzzer blades out of 10
Non-AC bosses - "meh" every single one of them

I love this game. I bought this specifically to reminisce on my youth as I played AC3 as a child. Glad to see it has only improved from a mechanical standpoint; no pun intended. Now's a good time to mention my comma key is not working so I am using semi-colons to compensate.

I have a few issues with the game and they are as follows.
1 - My main problem right now is the sound cutting out. It's maddening; so much so that I actually resorted to listening to something else to confirm it's just the game doing it; but I have no way to fix it. It's a real issue given that the story is told via sound; I have subs on so I circumvented that; but also that you have audio/visual cue's to respond. If I don't have audio; I cannot which forces the difficulty forward.
2 - While I like the "Every gun fits" mentality; I wish there were more times where a gun does not fit; and where a build does not work. I also wish there was more visibility on replaying missions to earn credits as I only found that out after at least a quarter of the game being played.
3 - Patterns / aesthetics. The first 2 were major issues; this is minor. However; I would like to see more customization within the unit itself. I like how mine looks; but I know it could look better.
4 - Voice lines. Not sure how this passed dev; at one point someone says "this is the biggest pain in the ass" which felt like the most genuine voice line of the entire game. Everything else was a wash; I would rather them just say "this is what you need to focus on"; feels like a lot of half-baked speculation on the voice lines that are there; also; you suddenly go from no one to someone; and the game doesn't do well about telling you that. Or maybe my sound skipped so much I missed it; tough to tell. FYI this happens even after verifying my files.
5 - Versatility/Variety. I wanted to make a spider mech. I genuinely launched the game and said "today's the day; spider mech is comin'" I can't do that though. The bosses can; however I cannot. Big bummer; the options make sense however are few in number.. opportunity is high here.

Overall the game is nice; I really wish I didn't have sound skips that for whatever reason occurred later on; outside of that I have played every chance I get this week. I feel this game/series could be expanded on a lot more and I hope the developers take a hard look at their opportunity here. they could make over-heads that have similar features that would be successful at a fraction of the cost/labor to produce. I would easily pick up an X-Com similar Armored Core game. If they are dead-set on having a FPS Mech game than the details should not be overlooked as they have a monopoly on this currently that many have left behind.

after 1.5 years...

Wish I had played this sooner. When it came to Sekiro I kept telling myself "maybe later". Four playthroughs later I can honestly say that this is one of the best games I've ever played. I've played Nioh, Elden Ring, and plenty of other RPGs before Sekiro, but Sekiro just clicked with me in a completely different way. Artistically the game is breathtaking but the main highlight is the combat mechanics. Many RPGs give you a lot of flexibility with how you can approach combat, but Sekiro is more linear. Instead of drowning you in loot, there's more of an emphasis on improving your ability to use what you already have. You still get consumables and allocate skill points to obtain different passive and non-passive abilities, but success is really measured by your ability to parry precisely (not just block), strike sparingly when it really counts, and manage your posture. This creates a more focused experience where you're forced to consistently be aggressive and engaged. You'll often be punished for tip-toeing around and playing it safe. Ultimately this makes for a more rewarding experience and I found myself going back time and time again. If you have the patience to push through and give it a fair shake, it's worth it.

even after ~500 hours, [i]Sekiro[/i] remains evergreen.

[i]Sekiro[/i] boasts stellar combat with near-infinite depth.
ridiculously precise hitboxes, open-ended movement, and the focused design of its limited scope, leads to a wealth of advanced tech.
feels like every time i play this game, i learn something new.

the game is [i]almost[/i] perfectly balanced imo.
having to purchase Spirit Emblems is asinine, i don't think Combat Arts should cost Spirit Emblems to use, and some Prosthetics are a little too expensive per use.
but those are relatively minor balancing nitpicks, easily fixed with mods. the core game mechanics are extremely polished.

the story/lore of this game isn't quite as detailed as the Soulsborne titles, but it still boasts some evocative character moments.

an all-around excellent experience, well worth its full price tag.

The negative reviews for this game completely baffle me. So many say that the game is good but because they find it too hard it isn't for them and so they leave a negative review. That just makes no sense. This game is fair and completely based on skill. In fact, I found it to have the best combat out of all the souls-like games. It isn't hard to learn at all, just takes time to master, and once mastered it's extremely satisfying. You also get a sense of accomplishment when beating bosses and overcoming challenges. The game doesn't play itself you're the one playing, and honestly being op and one shotting everything or having a summon to help you with the fights would make for a very boring experience.
Also this was hands down the coolest story in Souls. Loved how it wasn't just based on lore, but an actual story with you not being just a nameless character you make yourself, but an actual person with an objective. If you're up for a challenge, I highly recommend this game. If you're looking for a game that plays itself, then don't bother.

Probably the most perfect game I've ever had the pleasure playing. You got the most satisfying and gratifying combat system ever paired with incredible, jaw-dropping, and finely-tuned boss and enemy encounters in a visually splendid Sengoku era setting. The fights in this game are like a dance with the rhythmic clashing of swords and emphasis on timing and precision. Every encounter is extremely engaging and encourages a hyper-aggressive, fast-paced, play-style.  

You will die, yes, but so will you thrive. Mastering the combat is like learning how to ride a bike; it seems impossible at first, but once it clicks, you'll be having the time of your life. The challenges put on your path are nail-bitingly difficult, but are pure euphoria. 10/10

Sekiro is a game that requires you to arguably do only one thing. Parrying/deflecting your enemys attacks until their posture damage is so huge that you are then allowed to deliver a killing blow. this is the main core game mechanic you use to defeat the numerous bosses and enemies in this game. and it is executed wonderfully and is an ingenious game design. It forces you to have to get to know your opponents very well until you know every move they have in their arsenal until it no longer feels like you are fighting an enemy as much as you are just knowing an old friend, as my first ever fromsoft game the difficulty took some getting used to but i was ready to handle it as i knew what i was getting into. From the moment i beat genichiro i knew that i had fallen in love with this game and i absolutely recommend it if your looking for a good game in general i give it a solid 10/10 i truly have nothing but praise to give this game.

kim yaptı lan bunu

One weapon, one way to play Sekiro: Clear the area to get everything. Run to the boss. Instead of learning the attack pattern by trial and error, open a video "how to kill [boss name] fast" and do what you are told for easy victory. Go to the next area and repeat.

Undoubtly, Sekiro is FromSoftware's most difficult and most boring game. Difficult, because attacks hit hard, healing is very limited and grinding is no option. Boring, because the lack of build variety means every fight feels the same and the world itself is uninteresting.

Closing statement: Sekiro has 95% positive reviews, but 51% haven't beaten more than 1 full-fledged boss. I agree with the 51%, who stopped playing for good reasons.


EDIT: 29/34
Follow a guide to not miss upgrades. Early-game is tedious. End of mid-game feels balanced. Don't believe anyone that you have to git gud to beat Sekiro. Many enemies can be spam deflected, spam attacked or cheesed, even some full-fledged bosses. At least, Sekiro is fun for achievement hunters.

EDIT: 34/34
Honorable mentions: Divine Confetti, Ichimonji Double and Shinobi Firecracker.

It's not a bad game but the garbage cheater-filled playerbase is what makes it bad. Don't waste your money on this game until something is done about cheaters.

UPDATE 21 NOVEMBER 2017: More cheaters than before, but at least we have new skins and rank emblems!

UPDATE 26 JUNE 2019: CS:GO is free to play now. There are even more cheaters than before. We have even more skins and ranks are even more messed up now.

UPDATE 5 FEBRUARY 2021: FACEIT Premium and ESEA has more "legit cheaters" than ranked matchmaking, which is hilarious. The anticheat in the game has gotten better, but there are still cheaters in about half the matches I play, sometimes less, sometimes more. Skins have taken over the game basically. Because of the high skin activity, the inventory servers are down very often. I still love this game, but until the cheater problem is dealt with, I can't give it a positive rating.

UPDATE 29 OCTOBER 2021: Still full of cheaters. Exceedingly rare to get a match without at least one. I think nothing will ever be done. Counter-Strike is THE best competitive shooter out there, but it's dying. The only part of this game that's still relatively alive is e-sports, and even there cheaters sometimes pop up. If an invasive anti-cheat were introduced, I would play this non-stop. Don't waste your money on this game, whether it's on Prime or on skins. Skins are used for money laundering.

UPDATE 14 NOVEMBER 2021: Multiple cheaters in every single ranked match. I'm parting ways with this game. I never wanted to leave, but it's unplayable. 10 years since release, and we still have this problem. Unacceptable.

UPDATE 18 MAY 2023: Still cheaters. Screw this game.

UPDATE 27 OCT 2023: CS2 has been out for about a month. Still cheaters.

Great graphical upgrade but Volvo being Volvo - the new matchmaking and ranking system makes no sense whatsoever. You are getting challenged with players at twice as many points as you, while not being in a premade team. Reward for winning? +100 points. Losing to a 1% ranked team in the world? -500 points. Thrust factor is a complete joke, you may be thrown into the game with a guy who just bought this one and only game with a few thousand boosted commendations that singlehandedly carries the team with 90% headshot percentage and 40 kills. What's more, most of the content avaliable in the CS:GO is missing, but I suspect this is a subject to change as many of the maps previously seen are not remade in Source 2 yet. The demos are currently broken as well as the Overwatch, so you have no way of knowing if your opponents were playing legitimately, and VAC is your only hope to get some justice. Would not recommend.

This might've been VAlve's direction but they definetly forgot about us who dont have the best of the best technology to play games. I have a 1MB/s (90-50ms) and most games run like butter, so did CS:GO but with the new "sub-tick" the connection between my pc and the server is miserable. Bhops are literally impossible because the sub tick sometimes doesn't even register my imput, sometimes it even teleports me back like i would have ~300ms or severe packet losses. Let's not even get to the actual gameplay (combat) my bulets tend to become flying spirits passing trough whats important and in exchange I get killed after getting into cover. I still don't understand this movement of "sub-tick" hell even 64 was enough but this current state of the game just hushes away players who don't meet the requiremets, I can't just move my house to get a better connection to play cs2, it's a shame that valve still praises this as a new and better factor to the game. CS2 is broken:
- Insane peakers advantage
- Sprays don't work properly anymore
- Tracers don't go where your bullets go
- Absurd grind for getting ranks on competitive mode
- Desync deaths behind cover are too common
- Movement can feel really sluggish at times compared to GO
- Even Faceit has to use sub-ticked 64-tick because of Valve enforcing it

Four of those issues (peakers advantage, sprays, desync, movement) are clearly tied to the shitty sub-tick system they developed over just upgrading to 128-tick servers. Now it just feels worse than 64-tick. 
Other complaints:
- No War Games
- No big community servers
- No workshop maps

These will be added eventually so I won't count it against the game that much but it's worth mentioning.

Boring indie rubbish. Stages are randomly generated, making them lousy and forgettable, with no true design. The "music" is droning with no real melodies or tunes. Just orchestral ambient sound like every other indie/western developed game! The graphics and aesthetics are terrible. Sprites and backgrounds are incredibly basic, while modern bloom and other lighting techniques are applied to pour excrement onto the already mediocre graphics, making the overall presentation nauseating. The environments themselves are also poorly designed and entirely unmemorable. The gameplay has the potential to be good, like the variety of weapons at your disposal. Unfortunately this game controls like Wayne's World on SNES. I'm not one to complain about short games, but I reached the ending of this in a mere 2 hours. Nothing compared to the intricately designed maps featured in the Castlevania games, which feature true exploration and puzzles. At the end of the day this game is just a shallow imitation of the Castlevania games released on the GBA/DS. Do yourself a favor and play those, and stay far away from this game.

Incredibly fun game with plenty of progression, lore, and gameplay, getting progressively more difficult, and loads of options for builds, as well as great balance. Would recommend to people who enjoy fast paced action, platformers, and dungeon crawlers

Dead Cells by far is one of the most unique rogue-like games I've had the pleasure of playing. Personally, the combination of a roguelike and a sidescroller game was a delightful combination that I didn't think could work well together. This game is naturally hard but given enough time and practice swift mastery isn't an implausibility. Needless to say the challenge of this game is what makes it so fun to begin with not to mention the inbuilt mechanic where to build your arsenal with each attempt. Overall, don't be intimidated by the difficulty of this game because failure will inevitably lead to success.

the game has great value on its own with lots of content and the DLC expansions add even more to it. In my library filled with tight platformers, great mechanics, and even greater stories, Dead Cells falls short on nearly all of them. It does nothing great, and every negative far outweighs anything good from a game that barely even has a story.

If you only have $10 and plan to spend the rest of your time playing a repetitive, unbalanced, not-even-Metroidvania, this is the game for you.

Yes, you'll be using the wiki quite a bit, it doesn't help anyway. There are very clear build paths that you're supposed to happen upon without help in blind a blind 'playthrough.'. 

The item descriptions don't make any sense in regards to synergy or how they're supposed to work half the time.

The worst part, is that you'll be spending hours getting to the same area you were before just for 3 minutes of new content and unless you lucked your way into a nice build, you'll be spending another hour to get there. This isn't even 'Souls Like' levels of wasted time. This is padded out nonsense with 95% of your items being useless, and a completionist's hellscape.

This game has JUICE, man. And so much character! I'm not a huge fan of 2D platformers, but this game doesn't ask too too much of you in that regard so I'm alright with that. I admit that I had a bit of a bias going in because this game is a rogueLITE, and I'm a tiny bit of an elitist when it comes to roguelikes. That's a personal thing, though. The roguelite elements are fun, and similar to the likes of Hades or Binding of Isaac. Not handholdy at all. I hadn't realized that this game is a bit of a metroidvania, and am very much enjoying that part of it. 

I mentioned character. Honestly, the trailer for the game communicates the game's tone pretty well. It's set in one of the most depressing settings I've ever seen in any media, but the tone is still very lighthearted and fun. And this is the first non-rpg I've ever played where the main character flips off an NPC. (Don't worry, it's pixelated. The whole game is.) I love the references to other games, and I am in love with the sheer breadth of content.

One of the best roguelikes I've ever played. Ridiculously addictive, fast, fluid, and fun combat. I recommend everyone try this hella fun game!

I do not recommend it for its end game difficulty increase modes since it puts too much of an emphasis on playing perfectly with its ever so dwindling supply of health potions for the entire run, and getting rid of ways to restore your health after boss fights, which is made more punishing by there being a chance of getting weapons that are too weak to do the later parts of the run and thus making fights lasting longer than it should.

Despite Dead Cells's ascension modes being too difficult, even for a roguelike, I still highly recommend it to anyone who's into action games!

This game changed how I viewed a whole genre... Was always nervous to try out playing any Rogue-lite/like games because the thought of dying and losing all progress seemed like the complete opposite of what fun sounds like to me. My only experience was that I tried Binding of Isaac and thought it was okay. Then one day I was hanging out at a friend's place and she asked me to try it out, I sucked pretty bad but I liked the movement and combat. It didn't matter that I died though because it wasn't my file, so I tried a few more runs and thought it was neat that you didn't actually lose everything. Then I got home and had the urge to try it again but had to wait until I visited again. I played it a couple more times over there and each time I left I wanted to play more but didn't want to wait until I was over at their place again so I eventually bit the bullet and bought it for myself. At first I thought I wasn't gonna have as much fun since I had to start from square one, then I played it and time and progression flew by quick! This has become one of those games where I can keep going back to time and time again and start playing whenever I have nothing else to play. Basically everything about it is great from art direction to controlling your character and even the option to make it easier or harder if you want. I ended up buying all of the DLCs which I think says something for a game I was hesitant about getting in the first place. So this game has earned a special place in my heart because it showed me the amazement that this genre can be!

Galloping on your horse to new areas, you might just find a new boss, or a new side quest that rewards valuable in game items. There are no limits to the PVE experience in Elden ring. PVP is just as fun as PVE, with Elden Ring and souls games having the best PVP combat I have ever experienced. Superior combat mechanics and constant weapon/spell balancing make PVP a very enjoying and rewarding experience for those who have played the PVE enough. Overall, a must play game. At this point, there should be no doubt that this game is a triumph. FromSoftware pulled out all the stops for this one, and it shows. 

Every time I boot up the game, I feel as if I have been pulled into a deeply deranged dream. The Lands Between are gorgeous, meticulously crafted by careful hands that understand what makes human beings want to push further into the unknown. 

At first, I was skeptical about the shift to an open world. Having played through Dark Souls II and III, I knew that tightly planned levels were FromSoftware's bread and butter. Would the existential claustrophobia of being trapped in a twisted nightmare come through if I were gifted a horse along with the "if you see it, you can go there" concept? 

In the end, the freedom I was given actually contributed to my sense of despair. It enabled me to lose myself in the Lands Between, stumble into places before I "should" have gotten there. I was pleasantly surprised to find many closed dungeons within the vastness. Oftentimes, this game felt like a good book, as all I needed to do to feel as if I had been transported inside is give my undivided attention. 

FromSoftware has implemented some new mechanics, including respawn points near bosses and crafting. Getting PvP invasions while playing solo and durability are gone. One of the most important changes is the invention of spirit ashes, which allow regular AI summons. Personally, I did not use them much because they can trivialize the game, but I understand why someone new to this type of game might want to have them. The problem is that a lot of encounters feel balanced around your ability to summon spirit ashes, so if you are someone who wants to avoid using them altogether your playthrough is going to be more difficult and a good chunk of your exploration will be functionally useless because the rewards along the way are often upgrade materials for spirit ashes or spirit ashes themselves. 

I also feel like melee-only builds are at a huge disadvantage in this game, as fighting from range is much safer. The enemy AI is not that sophisticated, so even just having a few throwing knives to lead enemies away from a larger group allows for easy mode. Once enemies are in melee range, being able to stance-break them makes all the difference because it allows for critical hits. There is no indicator for how close you are to achieving this, so a lot of the time you just have to hope that you will get lucky. Over time, I got a sense of how to get consistent stance-breaks with my particular build, but it was not easy to build this intuition at all and it still felt inconsistent sometimes. Of course, this mechanic existed in previous Souls titles, but I relied on it a lot more for this game because it was much easier to do and more important than ever given the faster combat.

This is not a perfect game, but it is up there. Elden Ring is more repetitive than previous Souls titles and does not feel rough around the edges, but going through a complete playthrough of this game is an experience that will transport you somewhere else if you allow it to.

Amazing graphics, music, world design, enemy design, progression, boss fights, everything you could want in a game. The bosses are just difficult enough that you are extremely excited when you finally overcome the challenge, but not difficult enough that you dislike the fight (Yes I mean Malenia and spoiler boss). The exploration is amazing, because most POIs you need to get to are visible on the map. This brings the challenge of exploration from the process of searching every nook and cranny for something (cough cough, totk, cough, cough) to figuring out how to get to a location. Usually in the process of getting to the poi, you end up finding caves filled with goodies or NPCs with long rewarding questlines to fufill. Elden Ring manages to perfect all of the different game genres that it is made up of, resulting in easily on of if not the best games of all time.

Elden Ring, the latest creation from the masochistic minds at FromSoftware, is here to make you question your life choices and laugh like a lunatic while doing it. As a player who's endured countless "You Died" screens.

Gameplay (11/10 - Seriously):
If you thought Dark Souls was challenging, Elden Ring is here to remind you that you're not even in the same league. It's like FromSoftware gathered all the game testers in the world, locked them in a room, and said, "Let's make this harder!" The joke's on you, though, because there's something oddly satisfying about dying over and over again. It's like a Dark Souls-themed stand-up comedy show where the punchline is always "You Died."

World Design (9/10):
The open-world concept is fantastic. The world is so interconnected that sometimes you'll find shortcuts that make you feel like a genius and other times, you'll get lost and ponder the meaning of life. It's like a never-ending maze, and the devs are the maze masters, cackling as they watch you wander around aimlessly.

Storytelling (8/10):
The storytelling in Elden Ring is like that cryptic inside joke you just can't seem to get. George R.R. Martin and Hidetaka Miyazaki must have had a blast conspiring to confuse players. They sprinkle hints here and there, but it's as if they're saying, "You'll never guess the ending." So, you just go with it, accepting that you're clueless in a beautifully crafted and confusing world.

Graphics and Sound (10/10):
Elden Ring is a visual and auditory feast, but sometimes it's so good that you forget to dodge incoming attacks. It's like a beautiful distraction from the impending doom that surrounds you. The landscapes are breathtaking, the lighting is glorious, and the enemies look like they just walked out of your worst nightmare. The hauntingly good soundtrack only makes it better – it's like an eerie lullaby that makes you feel right at home in a world where death is your neighbor.

Technical Performance (7/10):
Occasionally, the game stutters or glitches, as if it's trying to be funny. It's like the game itself is a stand-up comedian who's a little tipsy on performance-enhancing estus flasks. But it's nothing game-breaking, just minor inconveniences that add to the quirky charm.

Multiplayer (10/10):
Co-op play and invasions are where Elden Ring really shines in the humor department. You can summon a friend to help you with a boss, and they'll probably die in the first five seconds, giving you a good laugh. Or you can invade someone else's world and scare the living daylights out of them as they scramble for safety. It's a multiplayer comedy show, and you're the star.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a game that doesn't just challenge your skills but your sanity as well. It's a rollercoaster of death and laughs, a mix of despair and delight. If you're willing to embrace the absurdity of it all, it's a hilarious adventure that you won't forget. Just don't take it too seriously, or you'll end up crying in a corner, surrounded by your virtual corpses.

Let me start off by saying aesthetic is this game is amazing, has epic boss fights, huge open world, skill based progression (significant item upgrades only in late game), plethora of varied weapons with different play stiles and AMAZING COMBAT! The game will keep you on your toes when delving into any of the hundreds of dungeons, tons of hidden areas in plain sight, you will find new items, bosses, dungeons, quests or lore that you missed in each new play through!

       The game does not hold your hand, has no linear progression, not very straight forward, if you want to learn about the story, or even know which way to go next to progress, you have to figure it out. There is no quest log for you to check what's left to do in the game, or to remind you about that one npc that asked you to do something and you forgot where the npc was, a few days later.

        This game is a masterpiece even tho it can be pretty fokkin hard at times, that being said, I just want to add that if your definition of "having fun" in a game is not dying and being called "champion" every time your character wipes their ass, this game is not for you. If dying gives you IRL ptsd and makes you feel like a failure, this game is not for you. In Elden Ring you try stuff, die, learn from that and we GO AGANE!

1st souls game; Truly enjoy how this game is tough yet still gives plenty of options in how to beat the game.  For example you can summon spirits to fight along side you and pull aggro from bosses to give the player extra time to heal/buff/ or create an opening for attack.  Most of the best summons once upgraded can solo many of the bosses.  Also most bosses have a "cheese" strategy which makes it possible for lower skill players have an edge; i.e. the Godskin Duo (one of the toughest bosses in the game) can be trivialized by crafting sleep pots and smacking them while they're asleep.

Elden Ring is a stunning open-world fantasy game, reminiscent of the Souls series, offering hundreds of hours of content to explore and experience. As someone who has invested countless hours in various Souls-like games, I can confidently assert that Elden Ring stands out as one of my personal favorites. The game strikes an impressive balance between challenging gameplay and rewarding experiences, providing not only valuable treasures but also an immersive journey through its breathtaking world design.

Souls-like games are renowned for their demanding and intense gameplay, and Elden Ring is no exception. If you appreciate beautifully crafted game worlds, captivating characters, well-designed adversaries, thrilling combat encounters, hidden treasures, Easter eggs, and challenging boss fights, then this game is tailor-made for you.

Elden Ring is an unparalleled masterpiece in the world of gaming. FromSoftware's iconic gameplay is taken to new heights in collaboration with George R.R. Martin's world-building expertise. The result is nothing short of breathtaking. The combat betrays the classic Dark Souls mechanics, with new and cleaner sword art and animations. It feels a lot smoother and fluid than older dark souls games. If you're a huge fan of FromSoftware's storytelling, you will be rewarded with possibly the most intricate and captivating lore. Highly recommend binge watching VaatiVidya's Prepare to Cry Playlist of Elden Ring, to connect deeply with this game.

If you like the Dark Souls series - go for it!
If you like Dark Souls 1 the most - absolutely go for it!
If you like D&D mechanics turned into an engaging action - this is your thing.
If you like a challenge - go for it.

If you like horseback riding - go for it!
If you like open world games with some challenge - go for it!

If you like fighting large and frightening enemies - go for it!
If you want to fight dragons while riding a horse through a shallow lake - absolutely go for it!

The meta-difficulty of the Dark Souls games is reduced. Resources for adventuring can be found. Instructions can be found. Falling after crossing a LOT of terrain... not an issue.
The annoyances are reduced but the difficulty is there.
If you don't want to practice with a difficult boss for hours - go multiplayer and have some veterans do it for you!

It's a bit less morbid and depressing than Dark Souls.
I've expected WAY more novelty and bigger differences.
Nope. This is a Dark Souls sequel with some variations, but way more fidelity.

Complaints?
1. Tanking isn't as viable as I'd like it to be.
2. Most tough enemies just require you to dodge a LOT through plenty of combos so you can grab that ONE quick attack and wait for another combo to get depleted. It gets tedious.
3. There's way less ad hoc solutions for tough enemies and bosses than there was in Dark Souls 1.
4. There's more repetition of enemies than with traditional Dark Souls.

The complaints aren't that bad. It's still a good game.

Elden Ring is like a long-anticipated reunion with an old friend you've missed dearly. FromSoftware and George R.R. Martin have delivered something truly exceptional.

The gameplay is quintessential FromSoftware, maintaining the brutal and rewarding combat mechanics that fans adore. Yet, the open-world element adds a new layer of freedom and adventure. Riding your trusty steed through the vast, eerie, and fantastical world of the Lands Between is a revelation.

The story and world-building are engrossing. Martin's touch is evident in the rich lore that unfolds in a non-linear, cryptic manner. The world is a tapestry of intriguing factions and demigods, each with their own history and motivations.

Visually, Elden Ring is a masterpiece. The graphics are top-notch, and the art design is hauntingly beautiful. Exploring this dark, dynamic world with its changing weather and day-night cycle is an immersive experience.

The sound design and music further elevate the game. The ambient sounds, the clatter of horse hooves, and the ominous background tunes all contribute to a deeply atmospheric experience.

In short, Elden Ring is a dark fantasy gem. It encapsulates a brilliant blend of storytelling, world-building, graphics, and sound that immerses players in a captivating and memorable adventure. If you're a fan of FromSoftware's previous titles or just love a good fantasy epic, Elden Ring is a must-play.

Long Story short, it is still a worth it game in 2023 (only on sale, though): 8.5/10 from me!

Now, long story long....

Story: Great story, characters and their back stories too, a little long story though but it makes up for the immersion that it offers you and you don't feel like you have nothing to do or just sit there and let the cut scenes play and pretend that it is a movie. No, it is not like that. Every choice the game offers you, impacts your journey in one way or the other and the ending as well. So, it is totally up to you how you want to act in situations and shape your own destiny and relations with other characters.

Gameplay: Good game-play and mechanics once you get used to it. I got into this game after playing and completing Assassin's Creed Origins, Odyssey & Valhalla so it took me a little while to adapt into the systems of this game. 

Exploration: I have only done the exploration while completing the story but it is great & I mean it. While the horse and boat are the two main ways to boost your time in exploring, they don't feel that much satisfying to use instead, they felt like hampering my speed and being an obstruction in my play style.

Battle/Combat: Don't except it to be phenomenal like Dark Souls but it is engaging and feels good.

Dialogues/Conversations: This stuff during a mission/quest feels so much natural! The characters behave so natural during conversations like their mood when talking, their body language, their facial expressions ,etc.

Conclusion: Overall experience is AMAZING! Good Job CD PROJECT RED and to my friend who recommended this legendary title to me!

Top 3 issues with game.

1. The combat is some of the dullest most boring combat I've come across in a RPG, how this is when its an action RPG I dunno, but it just feels slow and off like they were trying to make KOTR but got it all wrong..,...

2. The Gfx, this game is hyped for amazing gfx, but even on ultra, all I see is a old DX9 game running really poorly on DX11\12 hardware... the gfx are not amazing and very wasteful on gpu  power consumption as there not optimized for what they are.

3. Story... Extremely Generic. I read alot of fantasy novels so... I'm harsher here then many and nothing about it got me hooked to want to keep playing.

Thoughts....

This is a review of the base game, i will update as i finish the dlcs.
i have just finished the game on the hardest difficulty, and will comment on it.
it took about 40 hours completing the main story and every sub quest apart from gwent related ones. the main story is incredible and all the characters are interesting and great to meet. but were the game truly shines is the secondary quests, as they most of the time have an interesting twist. the immense freedom this game gives you in when and how you accomplish most things is incredible. most actions will have a repercussion in some way or another. they are many mechanics made for you to have an easy time running around without having to think too much.

the bad : horse riding is clunky, very little control and many bugs. playing ciri in the main quest is a fun twist but annoying to see all the hours of grinding to make it all easy disappear.  the scenery is fantastic only if it wasn't raining all the time in-game. 
overall, this is definitively on of the best games out there, heavily recommend.

completion of dlc 1 hearts and stone : the main story line was interesting, and it was all easy to guess if you followed the lore are hints given left and right. i enjoyed that is was short and efficient. now on the bad side, some boss fight were frustrating, as they didn't compliment the combat style of the game. they were very few secondary quests i found while doing the main, and the price to start enchanting gear is crazy high, which doesn't make you want to try different builds.
DLC 2 : beautiful scenery, really hoping the next game keeps those vibrant colours. the main story was interesting and efficient, with multiple endings again. 
overall, a fantastic game, that gives me great expectations for the next one. i thought it was a nice end for the geralt story line as well

Besides that, this game is just amazing and I'll be playing it along with the other Souls-born games for years to come. Best RPGs ever.

Title: An Epic Return to Darkness - "DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED"

Rating: ★★★★★

"DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED" by FromSoftware, Inc. is a masterpiece that needs no introduction for fans of the souls-like genre. As a seasoned undead adventurer, I've delved into the abyss of Lordran once again, and this remastered edition is a testament to the timeless brilliance of the original game.

Graphically, "DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED" breathes new life into the dark and atmospheric world of Lordran. While it doesn't overhaul the visuals entirely, the improvements are significant. The enhanced lighting and textures make every corner of this grim, interconnected world more captivating than ever before. The character models and environments are more detailed, creating a more immersive experience while still preserving the iconic aesthetics that define the series.

Gameplay-wise, "DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED" remains the benchmark for challenging and rewarding gameplay. The combat mechanics are as tight and precise as ever, demanding mastery of weapon types, timing, and strategy. The sense of accomplishment when conquering formidable foes or navigating treacherous terrain is unmatched. The game's notorious difficulty is not arbitrary; it's a beautifully crafted challenge that forces you to learn and adapt, making each victory all the more satisfying.

The level design is, once again, a standout feature. Lordran is a sprawling, interconnected world filled with secrets, shortcuts, and hidden lore. The non-linear progression allows for diverse playstyles and encourages exploration, making it impossible to resist the urge to revisit areas and uncover every hidden gem. The world feels alive, brimming with mysteries waiting to be uncovered.

The online multiplayer aspect remains a unique and integral part of the experience. Jolly cooperation, tense invasions, and cryptic messages from other players continue to add an extra layer of depth and unpredictability to the game world. Whether you're seeking aid or plotting the downfall of other adventurers, the multiplayer interactions are a testament to the game's enduring appeal.

"DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED" is more than just a nostalgia trip; it's an essential upgrade for both newcomers and veterans alike. The technical enhancements, while not groundbreaking, improve the overall experience without compromising the game's original vision. It's a testament to FromSoftware's dedication to their fanbase and the legacy of this iconic series.

In conclusion, "DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED" is an unforgettable journey into a dark and challenging world that continues to stand the test of time. It's a must-play for anyone seeking an immersive, punishing, and ultimately rewarding gaming experience. Whether you're reliving the past or embarking on your first adventure, this remastered edition is a definitive way to experience the masterpiece that started it all. Praise the sun!

"Mmm...mmm... Mm! Oh-hoh! Ahh, where did you come from? Splendid news, I tell you. First, I hear a great roar. And, voila! The path is open. Just goes to show. Good things come to those who wait! Hah hah hah hah!"

- Siegmeyer of Catarina

===================================================================

My first ever Soulsborne Game! At first, I was thinking that "Dark Souls is hard" is such an overused phrase, but I realize now that this Game can really be punishing whenever it gets a chance to. The "hard" part is that you actually have to think before you do anything but at the same time you almost don't have a chance to think at all, especially when you're faced with Boss Battles. There are things that will make your life more difficult in this game, like accidentally hitting NPCs will make them hostile towards you (NPCs are really helpful in this game) and facing enemies in narrow spaces feels like hell because your character's attacks bounce off of walls.. BUT, I enjoyed the game so much! The feeling of finally defeating that one annoying enemy after several attempts can be really rewarding and actually makes me want to explore more of what's ahead after.

As for the LORE, it is just magnificent. I can't get enough of the Lore this game has to offer and the Game doesn't just give it to you only by text but also by the world-building (Game Level and NPC Position) within the Game. The reason why something happened is always intriguing from the beginning 'till the end. I can't wait until I finally get the chance to play Dark Souls II. Oh yeah, a little bit about the Game Mechanic and Character Build, the Battle is "easy to learn, hard to master" kinda mechanic but there's no one OP weapon or Armor Set, so try to use whatever you fancy. My suggestion is always try to balance between melee and range attacks. In my case, I used Pyromancy/Uchigatana/Arrow Combination and this is really helpful to defeat many kinds of enemies.

===================================================================

I'm gonna give this game a "Great Grey Wolf Sif" out of "Artorias the Abysswalker"

[OBLIGATORY SPOILER WARNING]

Things that are good:

- The first half is genuinely good designed, including environmental storytelling, intuative 
  leads towards the intended path and interlooping map design.
- Any of the many builds available can work if you know what you are doing.
- Primary gameplay loop is actual fun while still being challenging, a very new and innovative 
  concept for AAA games these days...
- Story is one of the best in gaming history. Prepare thyself for many hours of hunting down 
  every bit of lore.

Things that p*ss me off and will trigger you too:

- Why the f*ck is the dodge direction bound to the camera lock? When unlocked you can
  dodge in any direction you input, but when you lock on you can only dodge in 4 directions 
  wich will f*ck you when facing later bosses.
- Why THE F*CK is the lock-on distance different in every area? Not much of a problem if you 
  have a melee build 'cause you can play unlocked but if you play a mage of some kind you 
  basically HAVE to play locked-on and in specific areas like the Duke's Archives you cant lock 
  on shit even if its only a metre or two in front of you.
- Yeah, a game from 2011 has kinda shitty hitboxes sometimes. Not as bad it sounds 
  though...
- The second half just falls flat and dips its sh*tty little nose in some sh*tty little Izalith lava 
  before dropping in a sh*tty little hole in the sh*tty little dephs.
- After you gain the ability to warp from bonfire to bonfire you will be asking yourself why tf 
  you can warp ONLY to specific bonfires. Backtracking will become a chore since the level 
  design aint as good as it was in the first half.
- Speaking of wich, in the later half most boss arenas are outright hostile to you be it through 
  too little space, the arena being filled with enemies IN ADDITION to the boss, unavoidable 
  drop damage or the game suddenly becoming a platformer with no dedicated 
  jump button. F*ck Nito and the Centipede Demon and f*ck the Bed Of Chaos in particular.
- The game mechanics outside of basic controls are not explained to you. Like, not at all. I 
  strongly suggest 
  watching/reading a guide after you arrive in Firelink Shrine 'cause the game is about as 
  eager to explain it 
  all to you as Gwyn is to let the Age of Fire die.

All in all: 
Good game today, great game yesterday. It has gone a bit senile after all these years and I would gladly suffer through it all again.

THIS GAME DESERVES A REMAKE, NOT THIS.

Did you ever played the original Silent Hill 2 for the PS2 and then years later bought the HD Collection and were like: "Wow!, this looks worse" well, I've got bad news for you, this "Remaster" makes SH2:HD look decent.

The special effects are better overall and the game runs at 60 fps so, there was a try, BUT, it feels like they improved that and at the middle of the way said: "that's it, we're done, the Remaster is complete". They implemented a new and better lighting system to the game so, the game must look better, right? Well, it  kills the original atmosphere in a lot of areas and also it makes almost everything look worse. For whatever reason a lot of armor sets and armor that the enemies are wearing look worse as if they directly tried to downgrade them. Some NPC's faces look better and less polygonal but most of them look worse. Then we've got the textures of the environment, a lot of them got improved but others look as if they tried to make them worse.

Only about 20% of the new stuff looks better than the original and for that I don't recommend it. If you have the original version just mod it so it runs at those magnificent 60 fps; if you don't, well, time for some heavy modding so this doesn't look like the downgraded version of the original.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
Gwynevere.
It's Dark Souls.
Musics are aight.
No performance issues.
Pretty good for the first game in the series
Open levels design which lead to surprise shortcuts.
Graphic is alright for a remaster of a really old game.
Really hard, probably the hardest one in the series, but* -> Cons.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
Inventory management is a nightmare, the UI is cursed, could have got a rework to be more like DS3.
No fast travel until half of the game, even then you can't fast travel to all bonfire, collecting items and running to vendors are very tedious.
Some of the worst boss designs in the entire series, some of them aren't even worth being called a boss.
Dated, slow combat, you can only dodge one time, chaining dodges isn't possible, you have to take a break after every dodge.
*Quite boring, bosses have like 5 attacks at best, combat play out like a turn-based game, boss attack -> you dodged -> you attack, rinse & repeat.
Your experiences may vary depends on which area you choose to go first, pick the wrong area and you'll want to uninstall the game, playing this game blind is the worst thing you could do which is the opposite of other games in the series and Elden Ring.

To sum up, it's a souls game with minimal enjoyment, much more boring and annoying to play unlike other games in the series but it's not a bad game that deserve a negative review, give us a Neutral option STEAM. Play this if you want to appreciate how far souls games have come otherwise ignore this game, you won't be missing out much.

The classic first installment that would kick start the entire Dark Souls trilogy.

Gameplay ages like fine wine, and while the graphics aren't obviously cutting edge now, the art direction carries it and still manages to be beautiful. The open level design is obviously what this game does better than the other souls games. But it is an inconsistent experience with a couple of questionable gameplay elements that is more inconvenient than challenging. If Dark Souls 3 is everything FromSoftware had learned fit into one condensed finely tuned package, then Dark Souls is the raw experience that crawled to let Dark Souls 3 run.

I would prefer rating this as "Neutral", but since I spent a lot of time with it, positive is fine.

So, let's start with the bad stuff:

[list]
   [*] Controls are clanky at times. I know the game is supposed to be slow and thoughtful while also reactive, but sometimes it just feels weird.

   [*] Bonfires. They're awesome in general, but 2 things I hate about them: 1. They're never (except one single time) right in front of a boss. Every god damn time, you after you die to a boss, which will happen, before fighting him again, you need to walk for 5 minutes. The way isn't a challenge anymore after you've done it 3 times. 2. Their warping ability. It's a great mechanic and I like that you get midgame and not from the beginning. But god damn you can only warp to a couple of them, so more walking... 

   [*] Stamina Bar. It's always annoying. Sure it is intended to make you think etc and be careful with your resources but there are better ways to solve this.

   [*] The skill system. Overall it's okay, but some details about it are strange. Resistance for example seems completely useless. Also, the higher your numbers get, the less they will increase. I already started NG+ and I had to do a lot of farming to actually feel a difference in my damage numbers. You also can't upgrade weapons further in NG+, so I guess you just have to hit more.

   [*] After a certain point, the game becomes less enjoyable IMO. To be precise: [spoiler] The new areas after you get the Lordvessel are not as exciting as the game is up to that point, Especially Lost Izalith/Demon Ruins and the Duke's Archive [/spoiler]

   [*] It is quite a task to compare items/equipment, expecially when you don't know what some of the stats are actually meaning. I mean these unusual stats are very nice and should be added to more RPGs, but overall it's not too easy to decide what to use or to even realize what's your best option. And not even to start with how you want to upgrade your stuff, especially weapons.
[/list]

But, that aside, there's also a lot of good stuff that kept me going:

[list]
   [*] Obviously the difficulty. It teaches you to be considerable about your actions. Not only in battle but also with the quests the game offers. It makes you learn what your enemies are doing so you can react accordingly. Every hit you take or deliver can be crucial.

   [*] Combat, even besides the difficulty, is awesome. You have a lot more weapon types than in typical RPGs, you can chose between wielding all of them one or two handed. You can choose to block, parry or dodge attacks. Although bows aren't really meant as a main weapon you can still use them occasionally. Magic is also a little weird, as your spells have limited uses and you don't have something like Mana. If you're out of spells, you have to have an alternative.

   [*] The world is great. You can visit basically like 90% of what you're seeing (except very far background), it's interconnected, not repetitive, atmospheric and interesting. I would like to see some more NPCs just to fill some places, but it's fine as it is. But the NPCs that are there already are very nice already.

   [*] Basically right from the beginning, you get awesome looking gear. At least for some classes/build, most weapons and armor look fantastic! You can actually start the game with fully fleshed out knight armor.

   [*] And one of the aspects which FromSoftware is know for: Bosses. They are incredible. Menacing, awesome looking and with great variety!
[/list]

I've have always had beating this game on my list.

Why?

Elden Ring (ER), that's why.

Granted, I believe they made Elden Ring more of my style because this s**t was hard.  Not that ER was easy, but I did not have to run down a chasm to repeat a boss fight in Elden Ring.  I'm happily satisfied that the devs made that change for ER, but DS is the OG so... yes you have to run down a chasm, hoping not to take too many hits, to repeat a boss fight.  

Anyways, I hold the record for most refunds for Dark Souls Remastered.  TBH, it's going to take 10-20 hours to really feel the "feels" if you know what i'm saying. . . And once you do, you'll agree that Dark Souls is easily one of the best games ever. 

Trust the guy who has refunded this like, 17 times.  I also killed all the NPCs in the starting shrine out of frustration which I would NOT recommend doing because, come to find out, they sell you useful items later in the game (Doh!) and you can't respec. . . So, me losing my 49,000 souls (repeatedly) from non-boss fights, sent me into a black-out rage.  Once I came to, they were gone; do not do what I did.

Don't roll knight, roll pyro.

I came to this title after playing and finishing Sekiro and Elden Ring. I was so enthralled by this genre, so hooked  to the world building and gameplay; and the satisfaction of finally killing a boss after trying and dying so many times, that I couldn't help myself be eagerly waiting for the Dark souls franchise sale. The sense of victory and achievement of overcoming insurmountable odds really drew me to this game.

If i want to keep it brief, I would just say The Dark souls Remastered is a masterpieces, thru and thru. From the beginning on the undead asylum to end of the kiln of the first flame, this game was captivating and mesmerising. I could only wonder how much a vast and detailed world of Lordran was created for us, the chosen undead, to be a part of; to be the one saving or dooming it as we see fit. The game, the lore, the combat, the equipment and stat system, the inter-connectivity of different areas was really a joy to explore and experience. 
Its evident why this was amongst the titles that gave birth to the sub-genre called 'souls-like'.

I don't know why i have not played the dark souls trilogy before, but now when i am, i just couldn't get enough of it. Playing and finishing this game made me realise why these series by Fromsoftwares are so popular and I myself am in love with it.

Thus began the age of men, the Age of Dark.

Dark Souls is great game and you should play it.  The reason why I gave it a thumbs down is because this "remaster" was minimal effort.  Textures are higher resolution but some look oddly "bumpy" (see the ladders or the cogs in the Duke's Archives).  The shaders are more advanced but ruin the original moody lighting.  The bonfire fire looks more realistic but lost its original mystical look (just look at the bonefires at the bottom left of the loading screens).  If it wasn't for the fact that they stopped selling the original release and ended its online service, I would be recommending it instead.

So many flaws but is considered the best dark souls game? 

-Terrible claustrophobic and narrow areas where the developers find it necessary to have either a hard as hell enemy waiting, or hordes of easier enemies who spam all at once, getting multiple hits in on you. This doesn't help when you are halfway through an attack animation but is canceled if they hit you (they will hit you).

-Random trap floors that can screw you over and cause you to lose souls and humanity, landing you in the nest of enemies but not only that, but for some reason you get fall damage for falling through these unsuspecting collapsing floors. One example is when returning to Undead Asylum and you fall through the floor to fight a boss, but the game unfairly causes you to lose health upon hitting the floor, leaving you vulnerable to be hit a single time from the boss that will send you back to the bonfire.

-Backstabbing (by far the most broken mechanic) is complete sh**, so many occasions where a random will invade and somehow get back-stab after back-stab. This wouldn't be as much of a problem if it was fair, but I encountered countless enemies and invaders who somehow managed to activate these back-stabs even when looking directly at me or when I have rolled out of the way of their attack but the game registers it as a back-stab.

This game has its moments where I find enjoyment from playing and exploring, but this is heavily watered down by the ridiculous design choices and bugs that commonly occur throughout your playthrough. This being said, it is not the worse game but also not the best of the series, it has spirit and love put into it, and I do recommend others to try it and judge it for themselves, this is only my opinion based on my experience with the product
