So, I have been playing all souls games a lot and I have to say DS2 is my favorite game to come back to:
* The combat is well refined and fun. 
* The difficulty curve is well-balanced and good both for beginners and advanced players. 
* There are plenty of weapons and spells that offer a lot of replayability.
* There are (almost) always multiple paths you can take through the game, so you are unlikely to get stuck. 

On the negative side, the graphics have not aged so well and some areas are just plain ugly. There are also some boss fights which are recycled later on in the game, which is a bit underwhelming. But all that being said, I can recommend this game a lot. It offers a lot of content and feels pleasant and challenging to play.

In comparison with original Dark Souls, the sequel is weak. Locations not properly connected between each other. Bonfires quantity way much more than in Dark Souls 1, so distances between them now less. Healing with Estus is slow, and healing stones are a safe option in this game, and you can have 99 of each (like grass from Demon's Souls). But not only Estus Flask and healing stones are an option for replenish HP bar, this game has a lot of items that have healing status. Miracles also included. Game also have death penalties, with each death HP bar will decrease to maximum 50%. Almost like from Demon's Souls. But, in the beginning of the game, you can get a ring that increasing HP bar while being Hollow (like Cling Ring in Demon's Souls). And speaking about Death in Dark Souls II, it's still not a big deal because in the sequel there are a lot of Rings of Life Protection that prevent losing souls and human form after death. And they can be repaired with Blacksmith, when in first Dark Souls they got broken and there was no option to repair them.
Hit boxes in this game are trash, and for i-frames (and speed of drinking Estus) there's now a new attribute to level - Adaptation. So, If you want more traditional amount of i-frames, you need to level it.
Also, you can now being invaded by players while being Hollow. PvP is okay. I'm not a fan of it, so I cannot describe it with details. And about online multiplayer. For matchmaking/summoning, there's a new gameplay mechanic named "Soul Memory". This mechanic tracks the total number of souls you obtain while playing on one character, and it makes life harder If you want to play with friends, and you want to play solo and farm some stuff. If the difference between yours and your friend's Soul Memories will be big - you can't play with each other.
PvE is mediocre. Almost every enemy is a humanoid with basic design. There are a lot of bosses, but the quality of them can be Good to Copy+Paste gang mobs.
But still, Dark Souls II have some good stuff too. Like, Weapon Stances - you can wield weapons with both hands in same time. Items now have multiple levels that normally can be obtainable in NG+ or in DLC. NG+ now a little bit differs in comparison with NG. Not that much, but still it's better than nothing. Armour sets in Dark Souls II, more "fashionable" that it's also good.
Did I have fun while playing this game? Yes. Kinda... Not the same amount as with Dark Souls 1. Still, I would say that If you want to play FromSoftware games, I would encourage you to try Dark Souls sequel. You will love it or going to hate it.

I brought this because III is supposed to be an awesome game and II was part of a bundled discount.  Hoping III is not the PC lemon that II is!

I'll say upfront that I consider myself a die hard fan of the series, I've played through Dark Souls and Dark Souls III several times over and have a 100% completion in Elden Ring for what its worth. Beyond that I want to add that I have attempted to approach this game in earnest 4 separate times now and while I have nearly completed it as of writing this, I will say that I feel that I have more than enough time invested to have a thoroughly informed opinion.

I'll simply put it this way, Dark Souls II AND the Scholar of the First sin do not exist in a condition that put it at the same level of quality as the others in the series. Oversights run amok such as strange hit boxes, haphazard enemy placement and strange attack animations that somehow manage to look both lethargic and fast.  Environmental hazards are only ever presented in a way that readies the player for a challenge when they find a message left by someone else who already dealt with it. Ambushes and ganks are far too common and challenges go from feeling like carefully balanced and crafted encounters of the other games to someone's poorly laid out home brew D&D campaign made into a video game. I'm willing to give developers the benefit of the doubt up to a point. Making games is incredibly difficult and making a good game on top of that is nothing short of a miracle at times and that's not factoring pressures from publishers with budgets and deadlines.

All that said, there's an amateur feel to much of the game's experience. I won't comment on how life gems and other healing items destroy the balance of the game or trample over Demon's Souls/ Dark Souls sacred ground, but they do feel like a hasty choice made by designers who were pushed into creating artificially inflated difficult areas and realizing that the Estus Flask alone would not be enough to get players through significant portions of the game, especially with how difficult it seems to be to find Estus Shards. Beyond that, the layout of levels feel like they came from people who took extensive notes on the previous games overall world design and when it came time to put things together, realized it was too late to actually do anything about it beyond stitch them together and hope it would pass. I know there are a multitude of examples you've already seen because if you're reading this review, you've almost certainly read/ heard it from someone else who can actually pay their bills to write this extensively about a game that's almost 9 years old at the time of writing. The Iron Keep has been almost turned into a buzzword for how nonsensical this game can feel at points, not only in the transition to the level, but for the fact that it doesn't even feel like a keep and closer to a video game level centered around a castle full of lava, though I find that to be true of most castle environments in the game. In an example I haven't seen mentioned, arenas for the Demon of Song, Rotten and Duke's Dear Freya all had small cave like exits dug into the walls that weren't even all that easy to see. In the case of all three of these spaces I naturally thought I must've hit the dead end of that path and left only to find out after Googling that I had actually missed the exit as it appeared to blend into the wall around it with the texture and weird lighting.

I won't comment on things like the story outright because everyone will take something different away from that and frankly no part of the Souls Series will ever do this in a way that makes everyone happy. I don't have a problem with the opening or even Aldia's musings on the nature of the world the character inhabits. What I found deeply convoluted was everything after King Vendrick's encounter. While I don't really care about how linear or open a game is so long as it's good, I do care about feeling a drive as to where I should be going so that I can propel the story further and experience more of the game. The only other ending can be achieved by killing Vendrick. I never tried attacking him without having done the Memories of the Ancients first, but in what might be the greatest twist of my evening is as I write this I didn't know this was all completely optional UNTIL I looked it up to write this review. Seriously. Why else would I be given this ring to open doors to more levels was my thinking. I assumed that I was working towards a greater goal that would get me to the end of the game but in the end it turns out it was for something I wasn't actually interested in doing in the first place.

This leads me to my last real gripe with this game and that's time. I sunk over 50 hours into attempting to complete this game on this one save, not counting other attempts on the Scholar version. That's quite a few, but I put in just shy of 60 in DS1 and that includes the DLC and starting a New Game+ run AND waiting around to help a friend with bosses. I'm going to hit roughly that same amount of time by the time I have finished the first save without doing any DLC. This thing gets monotonous at points. Running back to some bosses is a marathon if you assume you've already killed every enemy to the point they stay permanently dead and even that is a major time sink depending on the area. I don't find bosses engaging, just a larger special looking enemy whose health I chip away it. Enemies aggro inconsistently and some times far too aggressively making the trek back to bosses as arduous and risky as your first attempt at reaching the fog gate and if you're like me and get drained of your life gems you go to an easier area and farm souls just to buy more, taking more time out of actually experiencing something new as you try to get around another place you're stuck in.

I haven't even mentioned the downright deplorable business practices being taken by selling what is essentially a somewhat modified version of the base game with a graphical fidelity that should've been in the base game at launch when it comes to Scholar of the First Sin Edition. It isn't helped at all when it is touted as the definitive version of the game which means everything else that might be a real flaw that needs a closer look is now a double down on the choices made by all involved from what I can see as an outsider and what I've listed in this paragraph are the reasons why it's hard to take zealot defenders of this game in particular in good faith. Don't get me wrong, every Fromsoft game has flaws but this one has a few too many straws that breaks the camels back for my liking. I deeply care about this series, but this one just isn't up to scratch like the other releases.

I cannot recommend this game on its own merits, even as a Dark Souls game. I especially cannot recommend purchasing Scholar of the First Sin in good faith from one consumer to another. I'm glad to be living in a time where DS1 and Demon Souls aren't the only other games I can point to for good Souls-likes by From and I highly recommend giving those ones, DS3, or Elden Ring instead.

Thank you for reading.

Dark Souls II has been widely criticized for many reasons and while I partially agree with most of them. Dark Souls II is still a pretty good game. Now I originally played this on an Xbox One and it was the SOTFS version first because it was only available on newer consoles and that is not a good thing. SOTFS version, while it is better in graphics and performance, what it severly lacks is the fun and progression that this first one has. The main reason being that in SOTFS the developers intended it for people who already played the og DS II so they put harder and more ridiculous encounters in the game expecting that new players will be able to beat them. After failing to complete DS II SOTFS on xbox and I switched to OG on the PC. I had much more fun playing and while I'm certainly not at the end I must say that THIS is the best version of Dark Souls II and now you should even get the DLC's free with the base game (or at least I have). This may not be the best game from the souls series and I think for starters games Like Dark Souls 1 or Bloodborne are better. Dark Souls II is still a pretty fun and challenging game for both seasoned Dark Souls Veterans or People that have never played any Dark Souls Game.


Also as for technical Issues. The game may drop frames a bit in some areas but only for a few seconds so it's not a big deal. The game on fullscreen also has screen tearing so putting it on Windowed and downloading the borderless gaming app is the best option to stop it.

Dark Souls 2 is a weird sequel to the first game, adding in new mechanics and a new cast of characters to boot, all packed into a whole new land to explore. Yet is despised for its clunky combat, unforgiving areas, and just some other personal utter bullsh#t. Even then, Dark Souls 2 is a Souls Game and should be treated as such. Not saying you have to like it, fu#k change but hear me out will ya. Dark Souls 2 in all its flaws, shines the brightest when comparing it to the Scholar of the First Sin Edition of the Game. Scholar of the First Sin, does adds a few shortcuts, moves some items around, and looks sexy as fu#k, but its jammed pack with bullsh#t enemies placements that makes you wanna scream nig#er at the damn screen. Luckily, you're reading a Dark Souls 2 Review and can easily buy the OG Dark Souls 2 and get a FAR better experience than the so called new and improved, Scholar of the First Sin - A 40 Dollar Heap of Garbage. Sorry for sounding like a hater recording some dumb Youtube video. I just want to make sure you're spending your money wisely while also keeping your sanity intact. So buy Dark Souls 2 and if you read on Reddit that the Scholar of the First Sin is better, they're lying and are just crying a river that Me and any other Chad who buys this version of the game, are having the best times with Dark Souls 2. With that all Said and Done, Thanks for Reading! Buy the OG Dark Souls 2 and Have Fun!

If you are a fan of the Souls Series be sure to play it. But I have to stress this: This game is easily the worst of the whole franchise, just after Sotfs. Yes, you can have fun here, its subjective after all. But EVERYTHING DS1 and 3 do is done here, but worse. And it doesnt even compare to Bloodborne, Sekiro or Elden Ring. 
The areas are short and not crafted very well. The most difficult thing is getting swarmed by enemies while trying to traverse a level and the boss runbacks are the WORST as you cant run past the enemies on your way as you can get damaged out of the fog-entering animation. 
This game was designed to be annoying and kill the player the most amount of times possible. Its noticeable. 
But as I said, if you like Souls you can probably find some joy here. Very little imo but maybe its for you. 
Just dont buy Sotfs.

Let me start this off as clear as I can be: Dark Souls 2 is easily the worst Souls game. It has every questionable game-play decision the first does, plus its own terrible additions. Every boss is either a push-over or the hardest boss you've ever fought, the map is incredibly confusing to traverse and there are very few signs on where to go, Strength builds are trash until the end-game, and the weapon durability system is nothing but a terrible annoyance. But, like... it's still Dark Souls. The main game-play loop hasn't really changed, so it's still fun. I wouldn't play DS2 until you've beaten all the other games, but if you enjoy them you may just like this game too.

For people who have played SOTFS, at least try this one out.  It may seem the same, but the game takes areas like the Shrine of Amana and Iron Keep and makes them actually fun areas. Overall an actually good addition to the Dark Souls trilogy.

edit- dark souls 2: scholar of the first sin is my favorite dark souls game. demon's souls is my favorite souls game but dark souls 2: scholar of the first sin is absolutely fantastic from the ground up. it is one of the best action rpgs ever put to console... and then ported to pc (still waiting for bloodborne, best if not my favorite souls game, on steam, rip). every single complaint anyone ever had about this game is a) a skill issue or b) they changed something from dark souls 1 for the better. because dark souls 1 wasn't perfect. dark souls 1 was heavily HEAVILY flawed from beginning to end, and scholar fixed nearly every single problem.

but this is not scholar. this was a mistake. this was rushed so hard. tanimura did what he could by cutting every single corner in order to make a playable- if irreparably broken- game. but what an achievement. it's fallout: new vegas levels of impressive. but it's also fallout: new vegas levels of jank. playing scholar before this made this so unfun [like playing og metro 2033 AFTER the redux]. the levels are so empty of anything to do or fight, the progression through the world is a lot more narrow and uninspired, and some of the key placements are the absolute worst. especially the DLC keys which are just popped into your inventory. enemy placements are also questionable at best. and worst of all you have to buy the DLC separately.

do yourself a favor. play scholar instead.
In many ways, this is the Dark Souls 2 of the Dark Souls series.

unfunny review: woww i keep dying this game must be a souls game

actual review: i like it, after playing every souls game on console and 100% 4 of them ill always return to dark souls 2 as one of my favorite games. Without this game i would have never been able to join this fuck-fest of a community and franchise and i'm happy i did decide to play it while on my brothers account, best 12$ i spent at the time.

Ill never forget the memories i had with this game, especially the shit multiplayer systems.

I recommend this game as your first souls experience and it doesn't deserve the hate it gets.

Personally I prefer the second game but can see why others could choose the first.  Fast, brutal combat paired with wonderful design and world-lore define Fromsoftware's "Souls" series.  Prepare to die as they say, it's going to happen.

So, after getting Dark Souls Remastered on 100%, I told myself to play every Soul Game. After 1 follows 2...

What do I say? 
DS 1 was a jewel. The lore, the characters (Sif T . T , Artorias has beaten up my a**, love that dude) , the combat, the bosses. I thought DS 2 would be even better. Damn, I was wrong. 
The whole Overlay reminds me more on Gothic, than on Dark Souls. Some Friends warned me about this title, now I know why. The whole Movement feels kinda clumsy compared to part 1. I felt awkward playing this game.
The double weapon mechanic was kinda fun tho.

Skipping to Dark Souls 3 then, as it's way more better than the second game from what I've seen.
its the greatest souls game in the series.

Mfs hate this game despite its majestic grandeur. Highkey the best Dark Souls game. It's the most high-fantasy and it has roughest edges, but both of those things contribute to it being #1 undefeated G.O.A.T 10/10. It really feels like a game that came out in 2007 in almost every way, from things like the difficulty to the graphics to the lack of hand-holding etc., and it all comes together to create this awesome old-school Gamecube-y kinda atmosphere. If you're not into that then it probably won't resonate with you as much as it does me. But this jawn goes crazy!!! The combat and especially the lore and story and tone and everything is tuff. Work of art tbh.,

This could be a good game but there are so many baffling decisions.
1. The servers don't work right? that's very bad and games shouldn't be abandoned like that especially without a good way to host servers, but whatever, I bought the game knowing that. The baffling thing is why does it try to connect every time! it takes a full minute to fail and then a have to click cancel to continue the game (god forbid you click continue cause it will try again for the full minute). I'm pretty sure the devs could have released a patch when they shut down the servers.
2. Why can't I change the FOV I am not playing on a TV and I am very close to the screen why do I need a mod to have basic functionality
3.  using the keyboard shouldn't be this hard, changing the camera sensitivity is impossible as it always reverts to the original, parrying REQUIRES TWO CLICKS why would you bind one of the most difficult actions to a combo of clicks??
4. Last of all the games crashes at least once every hour, is it fixable? probably but when the playing experience wasn't fun before it crashed I don't really have the motivation to do so.

I know it supposed to be a difficult game but the difficulty should not start before you have started playing, I would get a refund but sadly it took me too long to start playing (or try to) I have a controller

Honestly a very fun game. I am not going to say the flack it gets it not in many cases justified, but I honestly had a lot of fun with it. However, there is a big down to the game. I only had fun with the game when I was playing for the first time and when I started a new game as a new character. In other words NG+ also known as Scholars of the First Sin is not fun at all. It just adds more and harder enemies in different locations which only makes the game take needlessly longer and be more of a nuisance than anything else. 

Now, there are some heavy issues. Combat is extremely slow compared to Souls 1 and 3, just drinking from the Estus Flask feels like it takes ages and it does not heal you right away but slowly creeps up which is a major downgrade. The bosses are at least a little bit slower as well but it still feels like players reaction time was sacrificed more than that of the boss ones. So it feels they have more of an advantage where they should not have. 

But there is something this game has that does not really appeal that much to me when it comes to Souls 1 and 3. It is wanderlust and comfortable grinding. Now, the wanderlust thing I kind of feel with Souls 1 as well while the wanderlust is not as much existing in the 3rd game. But I really enjoy the story it tries to tell and honestly I can see it making sense in the lore as something that would take place after Souls 3 when it comes to the cyclical Age of Fire and Age of Darkness just taking new forms. 

As for the grinding, honestly, with the bit of a slower pace, I feel the game is a bit more chill and relaxing and just nice to grind. I can watch videos while grinding away for items or souls. Now enemies eventually dying out after killing them enough times is a problem, it can at least be solved with a Bonfire Ascetic. I am not fond of difficult grinding like Destiny 2 or other games where you have to constantly be at it to keep up, I appreciate the more slow ones where you build yourself up in single-player as you go along. So yeah, the game is a pretty chill one for me. 

I do love the other Souls games as well and when it comes to combat and boss fights, Souls 1 and 3 are definitely far superior to Souls 2 no questions asked. But this game, I just found it to be relaxingly fun. That was the feeling I felt after playing the game for the first time, then lost that feeling once I started NG+ but then regained again when I started the game as a new character~

I tentatively recommend this. I played Elden Ring first and saw plenty of reviews saying this game is better. I largely disagree. The music is better and the general world feels more fleshed out than Elden Ring and that's about it. Overall the bosses have been worse, the enemies have been worse, and the level design has been worse. This makes sense because it's 6 years older than Elden Ring. But I can't help but feel oversold on this game. A lot- and I really mean a lot -of people told me the bosses were better and rival Elden Ring. I just have to disagree. So far the only one I've felt is even close were the Abyss watchers. But after getting a bit into the game (and having my save deleted, thanks From) I just really feel let down. This is my own experience, but I just want to warn people that if you loved Elden Ring, you might rub up against this game. Overall Dark Souls III is a fantastic game, but just feels outdated in almost every way from Elden Ring. Just set your standards in a realistic place and realize this game won't challenge you as much and won't feel as good, and you'll probably have fun.

It's Dark Souls, so it's a tough game. I'm enjoying it (even though it frustrates me)! I was able to lower the graphics enough to run the game quite well on a computer that doesn't take kindly to all games. The only downsides I've been having is a single technical camera glitch and a tutorial issue regarding keyboard controls. The game doesn't detect if you are playing with the keyboard, and will only display button prompts during the tutorials and menus using controller schemes. This makes it very difficult starting out with the game to learn the controls. Beyond that, it is definitely a game worth playing!

Nice dodge simulator. But i prefer video games. 

Concretely, it's a Guitar Hero but with RPG fantasy. You have to click at the exact timing and each enemy is a new song that you have to know by heart. I hate it.
Fighting is a chore. As soon as you get hit, you are interrupted, which is very painful: Your character no longer responds, it's not smooth. When you block an attack it drains all your stamina. The big good point of the game is its map which is relatively large, full of secret passages, with very varied, epic and "beautiful" environments with a lot of verticality.
But the semi-autistic combat system coupled with the lack of difficulty option makes this game a very bad game. You don't want to give me difficulty options ? Very good, I am not giving you a positive review. ; )

Title: A Grand Finale to the Abyss - "DARK SOULS™ III"

Rating: ★★★★★

"DARK SOULS™ III" by FromSoftware, Inc. is a magnificent and fitting conclusion to the epic Souls series, showcasing the studio's mastery of challenging gameplay, hauntingly beautiful graphics, and deep, interconnected world-building.

Graphically, "DARK SOULS™ III" is a visual tour de force. It takes the series to new heights with breathtaking environments, meticulously detailed character models, and hauntingly atmospheric lighting. The game's gothic and decaying world is both stunning and nightmarish, creating an unparalleled sense of immersion. From crumbling castles to corrupted swamps, every location feels like a work of art, and the overall visual design elevates the dark fantasy genre to new standards.

Gameplay-wise, "DARK SOULS™ III" continues to refine the series' signature mechanics. Combat is precise, demanding mastery of weapon types, dodging, and parrying. The addition of weapon arts adds depth to combat, providing new ways to approach battles. The difficulty is relentless but fair, making every victory a hard-fought achievement and every defeat a lesson in perseverance.

The level design is a masterpiece, harkening back to the interconnected world of the original "DARK SOULS." The world of Lothric is a sprawling labyrinth filled with shortcuts, hidden secrets, and lore waiting to be uncovered. The sense of discovery is palpable, encouraging exploration and experimentation. The non-linear progression allows players to forge their own path and make meaningful choices, enhancing replayability.

Storytelling in "DARK SOULS™ III" strikes a delicate balance between cryptic and accessible. It weaves a tale of fallen kingdoms, cosmic horrors, and the cycle of fire and darkness. While it offers more narrative clarity than its predecessors, it still leaves room for interpretation and speculation, catering to both series veterans and newcomers.

The online multiplayer aspect is as compelling as ever, offering cooperative play and player-versus-player interactions. The game's covenants add depth to the multiplayer experience, providing various ways to engage with other players and earn unique rewards.

In conclusion, "DARK SOULS™ III" is a triumphant culmination of FromSoftware's vision for the series. It pushes the boundaries of what action RPGs can achieve with its stunning graphics, refined gameplay, and rich world-building. Whether you're a longtime fan of the Souls series or a newcomer looking for a challenging and unforgettable gaming experience, "DARK SOULS™ III" is a dark and beautiful journey into the abyss that shouldn't be missed. It's a testament to the enduring legacy of a truly iconic series.

\[T]/ PRAISE THE SUN! \[T]/

Unlike Dark Souls 2, Dark Souls 3 is a massive improvement to practically every feature from its predecessors.  Combat is more fluid, the graphics are beautiful, weapon options are vast and varied and boss fights for the most part are much, much better.

Where DS3 really strives where the previous games weren't as strong was in its requirement that the player be adaptive in their builds.  For DS1 and 2, I never needed to change my weapons.  I stuck with a big heavy sword, and never diverted from it.  DS3, on the other hand, will throw curveballs at you that you need to adjust for.  I bullheadedly smashed my head against Nameless King with the Profaned Greatsword (an incredibly slow, heavy weapon,) and nearly lost my mind to it.  When I still struggled with Sister Friede in the same way, I decided it was time to change things up, and what a difference it made.

The game will absolutely reward you for being mindful of your builds, and approaching bosses strategically.  I was so used to the more blunt approach of DS1 and 2 that it's rather sad it took me so long to learn this lesson, as it might have made a lot of bosses much much cleaner.  Regardless, bosses are much more of a spectacle than the previous games, which makes the fights extremely memorable.  All in all, it's highly recommended as the final chapter to the Souls series.

If you do plan on getting the DLCs, a word of caution.  While I would say overall I still enjoyed the DLCs, there are a small sections of really painful points in them, with terribly long gauntlets that are very difficult to just run past.  It goes without saying that the bosses are much, MUCH harder than the base game, but if you take my previous note to heart about adapting your builds, it wont be something you can't overcome.

It's been quite a journey, to be honest.  Playing Elden Ring was what got me to try the Souls games, and now I've finally gone through them all.  There were ups, and there were downs (mostly downs for DS2) but in the end it was a fun experience, and I'm glad I played them.

An excellent game from the structure to the sound and music, the flaws aren't numerous a few obnoxious grabs some less than fun hit boxes at times but over all getting through isn't arduous most of the time. Some specific grievances first off the layers of hell as I call them, Hell V0.75 Faraam Swamp the poison hell, Hell V1.2 Catacombs of Carthus never enough stamina hell, Hell V2.5 Irithyll Dungeon the why is my health bar gone hell. That aside I've loved playing this game I love helping with bosses I love so many bosses the fights are often fair and feel like you're actually fighting them rather than watching pure spectacles, the world feels a lot more complete with item descriptions you can learn so much. Finishing NPC quest lines tho would be immensely difficult without a guide and while it is somewhat upsetting I frankly don't mind it as it adds to the feeling of this being a living breathing world, I mean how often do strangers you talk to just tell you where they'll be later? After my almost 280 hours of being immersed in this world and its characters I'd highly recommend others play this game, and my advice is to take your time and stay as relaxed as possible so you can focus on everything in front above and behind, dying doesn't mean you failed you just hit a speed bump take your time to squish it.

READ THE FULL REVIEW (Steam has a word limit) HERE: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/hollow-knight---a-review
--
Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

GAMEPLAY

As a 2D sidescrolling metroid-vania with souls-like (roguelike) elements, Hollow Knight is an interesting mixture of things. It gives the Player a Player Character (PC) to control, gives the Player a weapon to use and a vast world to explore. As the Player encounters more and more Characters, finds more and more treasures and defeats more and more enemies, the PC grows not only more powerful, but also more capable at navigating the world.

Improvements such as the ability to jump while in the air, to dash through the air, to use spells, to jump off of walls, to illuminate dark areas and so on are all obtained following some kind of discovery or victory. In addition to that, everything else is also the fruit of some kind of labor – access to shortcuts, access to maps, access to safe spots – it is almost all bound to the Player’s performance and inquisitiveness.

However, this also brings with itself a problem. The amount of mobility and power that the Player gains as a result of their adventures winds up being strongly limited by the Charm system that is in effect – which is the equipment system in the game. The Player has access to only a few notches (slots) for Charms, and certain Charms require a certain number of notches to be equipped, allowing for a combination of 5 or 6 Charms, at most, to be equipped at a time, while there are more than 30 total Charms.

The issue is not that there is choice involved – the issue is that many of these Charms provide abilities that feel as though they ought to be simply had by the PC, rather than bound to the presence of a Charm. However, that is relatively minor by comparison to the other problem that truly plagues Hollow Knight:

 It is a soulslike, which means it is hard and inconvenient for the purposes of being such. Dying when fighting a boss does not position the PC next to the boss’ room, it positions the PC at a particular location that is a decently lengthy amount of travelling and fighting enemies away from the boss’ room. That’s just not conducive to a good experience.

Lastly, there is no value in replaying the game, as there are no alternative endings or builds that can be made use of – everything can be accomplished in one playthrough. The exception is the “die once, playthrough ends” gamemode, which negates the point of making Hollow Knight a soulslike, as the mechanic of going back to where the PC died and reclaiming what was lost is no longer in play.
2/3

PRESENTATION

Hollow Knight looks amazing, for it presents vast 2D spaces filled with incredibly fantastical sights and curious looking Characters who also sound and move in nealy magical ways. That, combined with the music and sound effects of this game create a magnificent meld of color and feeling, which only grows more potent as time goes on and the Player explores the spectacular world.

In addition to that, the themes this game explores in its story are mostly conveyed through the visuals of the game, performing great feats of environmental storytelling that bring great satisfaction and pleasure to the Player.
3/3

STORY

Hollow Knight presents a dead world which is being feasted upon by all manner of beasts, while a tiny number of Characters who have managed to keep their wits about themselves struggle to make do. It tells the tale of a mysterious knight who uncovers his past and his purpose and, in so doing, winds up saving that world and giving it life anew.

Aside from the story of the PC, Hollow Knight also features a plethora for colorful tales that almost always end on an incredibly somber note, yet it also presents a wonderfully vibrant and interesting world that awakens the Player’s imagination in a very splendid manner.

Alas, many questions remain unanswered and many Characters appear to be very unsatisfyingly concluded, as if unfinished and expecting a revalation in some subsequent installment of the story… Which is not nice.
2/3

Legendary Point

Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time? I thought about this. Long and hard did I consider. I remember Hollow Knight with a mixture of both fondness and distaste. The gameplay left a sour taste in my mouth, and the unfinished feeling I got from the story added to it.

 I’m afraid I cannot give the Legendary point to Hollow Knight. It was a wonderful experience, but, alas, not one I would consider “touching”. 0/1

CONCLUSION

7/10. Hollow Knight is a good game. A game that I would not dissuade anybody from playing, but only warn them that it might be a little hard. It could have been better, but it is what it is.

 I tuck it under my belt, another achievement that I proudly display. Even though dotted by spots here and there, it is something wonderful.
--

I've delved deep into the world of countless video games, but few have captivated me as profoundly as Hollow Knight. This is an intricate masterpiece, beautifully crafted and meticulously detailed. From the very start, I was absorbed into its hauntingly serene atmosphere, with an art style that combines whimsical charm and eerie melancholy in a way that's nothing short of poetic.

The narrative of Hollow Knight is a compelling tapestry of mystery, built around a rich lore that slowly unfurls as you progress. Finishing the story was a fulfilling quest, one that left me deeply satisfied, having journeyed through poignant revelations and emotional highs and lows that are the marks of a well-crafted tale. It's a storyline that doesn't handhold or spoon-feed but rather respects the player's intelligence and curiosity.

Exploring the depths of Hallownest was an experience filled with thrilling combat, complex characters, and storytelling that's as subtle as it is impactful. The game's expansive world is a labyrinth of secrets and challenges, with each new area unveiling richer lore and more formidable foes. It kept me hooked, pushing me to achieve that nearly perfect 112% completion.

The combat system demands precision and strategy, and each boss—a work of art in itself—presents unique battles that test both skill and patience. Every new ability acquired opens the map in unexpected ways, making exploration addictive and victories all the more triumphant.

However, my truest test lay in the Pantheons, the ultimate showdowns of endurance. While the rest of the game was challenging, this was a gauntlet that required an almost transcendent state of zen-like focus. It was here that my journey paused, a decision born from respect for my enjoyment of the game rather than surrender. The fatigue was real, but it didn't tarnish my admiration for the game; it merely highlighted the intensity of the dedication required to truly conquer it.

In conclusion, Hollow Knight stands as a testament to the heights indie gaming has reached, offering a seamless blend of stunning visuals, a compelling narrative, and gameplay that's both challenging and rewarding. Though my journey halted just shy of absolute completion, the experience, particularly the poignant story completion, was unforgettable and remains a high point of my gaming life. To Team Cherry - You've created not just a game, but a world that lingers long in many hearts, mine included.

Hollow Knight stands as an exemplary work in the realm of gaming. Its combat system is remarkably intricate, offering a multitude of avenues for players to explore and engage with, thanks to a wide array of charms and abilities. This diversity ensures that each player's experience is unique, enabling personalization to suit individual preferences.

Additionally, the game's captivating ambiance is exquisitely paired with its evocative soundtrack. The meticulously hand-drawn world of Hallownest is nothing short of hauntingly beautiful, making it an artful masterpiece in itself. The synergy between the visually immersive world and the harmonious music creates a profoundly emotional connection, setting Hollow Knight apart as not merely a game, but a profound artistic achievement. It sets a high bar for the potential of indie gaming, making it a must-play for any gamer :)

PROS:

* Similar mechanics to DoS1: interactive world, where your "combat" abilities can often be used during non-combat to find alternative routes, complete puzzles and quests.
* Much improved world building and story. This isn't a story-telling masterpiece, but some moments and characters really stood out as memorable and good, which I can't say for the previous games. (except animals maybe)
* Finally, a RPG with turn-based combat system that doesn't assume I am a gambling addict and keep things tactical rather than letting the dice handle anything. 
* I like how source is translated from being a story device to be a very tangible gameplay element.
* Excellent sound track. (At least the main theme)

CONS:
* Combat feels more stale and repeatative. And yeah, some of this is related to getting rid of the RNG (which I praised) but I do think there are ways to achieve both. As is, the armour system is too binary. A character is either armoured and you can only do damage to it, or it has no armour and you can give it status effects like an imagantive kid playing with a doll.
* Less interesting puzzles. Most puzzles don't utilize the games' systematic design like they did in DoS1.
* I felt the game was too long. I was ready to be done with game by the beginning of act 4.

"Divinity: Original Sin 2 - An Epic Journey with a Mix of Fun and Frustration"

After an arduous and challenging journey, I can finally say I've conquered the tales of both DOS 1 and DOS 2. These classic cRPGs, renowned for their difficulty, presented me with an exhilarating adventure. While the sequel, DOS 2, upheld the tradition of greatness, it also introduced a slew of frustrations stemming from its game mechanics and design. The game boasts a captivating story, intriguing characters, and an enticing premise, but Larian Studios' unique and sometimes bewildering approach to progression leaves much to be desired. Recommending this game proves challenging, even to the most dedicated RPG aficionados. DOS 2 is a cumbersome cRPG that only the most hardcore or patient players will likely see through to the end.

Demanding yet Flawed Combat: DOS 2's combat system is undeniably tough and challenging, but it occasionally succumbs to cheese and imbalance. A more refined and evenly paced combat experience could have made it truly exceptional. The turn-based combat is clunky among all the RPGs, no real initiative based turn order, no turn tiling to pinpoint exactly where you will movement and non-aoe skills will land. Because of how the encounters are built around, you are always on the disadvantage as you always on most occasions start the battle bunched up close with each other, leaving the enemies to just freely nuke you with AOE debuffs and spells for free. If you plan to progress through the game, you have to learn to put up starting of alot of battle encounters on the backfoot. 

Solid Character Cast: The game does feature a diverse cast of characters and companions, although they may not be universally outstanding. While some shine brightly, others are merely decent, rather than extraordinary. Some characters I find overbearing and pretentious as well to be around, The Red Prince and Sir Lora's dialogue and story progression just leaves me more annoyed then enlightened due to their bloated posh overdoned snobby dialogue. Characters like Lohse, Sebille and Ifan are the more enjoyable ones by far.

Satisfying Conclusion: DOS 2 delivers a gratifying payoff at the end, providing players with a detailed explanation of their choices' consequences and the fate of the world of Rivellon, as well as the destiny of their companions.

Terrible Inventory System: One of the game's notable downsides is its incredibly tedious inventory system, which could have been streamlined for a more user-friendly experience. Thank God the weight limit mechanic in the game is very forgiving. I cannot imagine playing the game with this disastrous inventory system with an encumbered mechanic,

Modding Potential: On the bright side, the game offers decent modding capabilities, allowing players to tailor their experience and experiment with various balancing mods to suit their preferences.

Vague Quest Progression: My biggest pet peeve in the game, ne of the most frustrating aspects of DOS 2 is its extremely vague quest progression. Players often find themselves casting specific spells or combining them based on cryptic, non-existent information. Resorting to alt-tabbing to consult a guide after spending half an hour fruitlessly wandering around, making zero progress, is the opposite of enjoyable gameplay. 

In summary, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an epic RPG adventure that combines moments of exhilarating fun with frustrating challenges. Its captivating story, diverse characters, and satisfying conclusion make it worth the journey for dedicated RPG fans, but its unrefined combat, clunky inventory system, and enigmatic quest progression can be off-putting for alot of people. It is one thing to play the game, it's another different story to see the game until the end. Ultimately, it's a game that rewards patience and perseverance but may not be everyone's cup of tea. I wished I had a middle of the road of option of reviews on Steam, because this game is the very epitome of acquired taste, you either like it enough to play through the game to the end or absolutely hate its guts.

Seriously one of the best games ever made. There's not much I can add that hasn't been said by others before me, but I feel compelled to add a positive review to this game after turning it into my most-played game on Steam, as well as after my recent disappointment behind Baldur's Gate 3. Playing the latter left such a sour taste in my mouth, and coming back to DOS2 instantly filled me with renewed euphoria. It's just so damn fun to play!

Now, I'll be honest and say that I don't care much for the story and most characters. It's well written and voice acted, I don't think it's bad, but I'm not really invested in any of it. I actually think there's some cool stuff in the setting, but the moment-to-moment story and plot development leaves me feeling indifferent.

However, for me, it's all about the gameplay. DOS2 provides such a compelling formula for turn-based combat that works so damn well in online coop which I simply cannot get in any other game, CRPG or otherwise. There are plenty of people who might argue for the strengths of games like Planescape: Torment or the OG Baldur's Gate titles but, for me, those are basically unplayable, especially today.

That said, the well of DOS2 eventually dried up even for me a few years ago. I'd done half a dozen playthroughs with friends, seen every ability and every fight. Even "challenge" playthroughs didn't really offer much novelty and ended up incomplete. For this reason, I ended up looking for mods that would offer substantial improvements, or at least a change in pace.

Enter Epic Encounters. What a beast of a mod. DOS2 is a fantastic game, baseline, but with EE on top of it I think it genuinely becomes the single best turn based game ever made. Nothing even comes close to it. The list of EE's changes and additions is extensive and, admittedly, it'd be terrible for new players. The sheer volume of systems is overwhelming even for a veteran. But with a bit of patience and learning, it opens up oceans of depth and incredible build variety that makes you crave your next campaign when you're not even halfway through your current one. It's easily added over 200 hours of playtime so far and I anticipate at least another one or two hundred more as I keep on going. All the while, I remain baffled by how much more fun I'm having than I ever did in BG3. Jesus christ.

In short, I can do naught but wholeheartedly recommend DOS2. If you have any interest in CRPGs or turn-based games, do yourself a favor and pick this up. Do a campaign or two and, if you find yourself getting bored, try Epic Encounters for what I consider the ultimate turn-based RPG experience.
Just get it. I won't presume to know what makes you happy, but I presume this game with make you happy.

I heard about DOS2 a few years ago and everyone was raving about it so I bought it. I played about 10 hours and got stuck and quit. Fast forward to Aug 2023, Baldur's Gate 3 comes out and I'm completely immersed, beating the game at about 150+ hrs and decided I need to revisit DOS2.

I came to realize I was playing DOS2 wrong at the time, I was playing it like a typical modern RPG with a linear story and progression, it's not uncommon to run into difficulty spikes in DOS 2 but that's beauty of this game. You have the freedom to go literally wherever you want or complete whatever quest whenever you'd like. If you get stuck, go work on another quest, gain a few levels, and come back. Baldur Gate 3 and DOS2 really challenges players' expectation from most modern games.

Anyways, DOS2 is awesome, just finally finished Act 1 on a fresh playthrough at around 30+ hrs. It's almost like too-long of a game because I know I probably have another 100+ hrs to go if I want to finish the game and I certainly do.

It's a little harsh to give thumbs-down to such acclaimed game, but I'm not a RPG player, so my review is for those who are also not used to play this genre. I'm a strategy player and came here mostly due the turn-based battles.
However, after 4 hours playing I figured out that battles are highly not recommended. In the early game, the main character and playable NPC's are really week compared to all kinds of enemies, so if you're seeking battles, prepare yourself to have your butt kicked humiliatingly in every encounter. It doesn't take more than two turns for you to be smashed, so if anyone ask you for a fight, just runaway from them.
But that's not the worst for me. Despite being a open world, you have not so much freedom. There are many quests and missions available, very important to pass through the levels, and all of them can be completed in only one way - but you have no clue about how to do it.
So, in the end, completely lost, you have to search for walkthroughs, carefully following every step described to move the chains, or you will just make useless conversations all around. It's very frustrating to read a walkthrough from top to bottom to be able to keep going, I almost never had to do it while playing strategy games (RTS's, RTT's or turn-based's).
But...now that I just bought it and exceeded the 2h limit to get a reimbursement, I will restart a tactical mode splitting the screen with a meticulous walkthrough I found, hoping I can catch on and start to get fun.

Our AI companion told me he was going to be the "God Woken." I told him that I was going to be, just to fuck with him, and he told me I was wrong and got really aggressive. Thing escalated, I told him to suck my dick, he called me a cunt, and said later he would kill me. Then he left our party. My friends were not impressed that I lost our companion that we had trained to be a killing machine, who we would then need to face later on. But I was defending my honor, and he was a prick so I still stand by it years later.

Genuinely thought the God Woken aspect was an interesting touch to the game, we never finished it, but every now and then there would be suggestions in the game that "there can only be one god woken" and was heavily implying that we were going to have to kill one another. Leading to intense paranoia, hoarding of treasures, secrets, and skills. Who would win? 

Our tank? Who was slow and cumbersome?

Our assassin? Strong but frail?

Our summoner/support? Strong with the others but weak alone?

We didn't ever find out, and I still wonder to this day.

A refreshingly complete game with a variety of impressive levels and deep customisation. The numerous weapons and other machine part combinations make for a wide variety of playstyles. Your AC's overall weight, its chosen boosters and the generator determine how quickly you move, how long you can fly, and how fast you can boost; your legs determine  jump height, each type having an unique property (reverse-joint legs spring high, tetrapods hover, tanks can drift).

Buying and testing new weapons as they become available is a lot of fun - everything feels and sounds great. The sound design is really outstanding. Yes, weapons are almost universally satisfying and impactful: but you will have to build intelligently and manage distance wisely in order to hit without being gunned down yourself. In order to reliably hit the stronger, more evasive enemies in the game, it will be important to watch your Fire Control System's red tracking reticle, and choose an FCS that quickly locks on in your preferred combat range. Some builds will tend to kite at range, and conserve energy for reactive quickboosts to evade, while others will assault boost aggressively into melee range.

The monstrously large bosses present some of the hardest difficulty spikes in the game, but they are fair; with time, each enemy seems easier to overcome. After slowly piecing together your personal AC, mastering its playstyle, and beating the bosses, returning to previous missions feels like a new experience. By my NG+ second playthrough, I felt like a speedrunner and greatly enjoyed racing through familiar stages in a destructive flurry. Getting good at this game feels amazing, and you will find yourself trivializing formerly hard enemies. This includes bosses that might have stumped you for hours, who you will likely crush with only moderately better equipment (but a smarter build and better skills). New missions and changes in NG+ add to what feels like a perfect difficulty curve for a second run.

Never played an Armored Core or mech game before but Armored Core VI quickly became one of my favourite games of all time and is my Game Of The Year 2023.

In terms of presentation, Armored Core VI is spectacular. Every single mech piece and weapon is designed with utmost painstaking detail, the vibrancy of particle effects from explosions, lasers, mech thrusters etc. beautifully contrasts the grim cities and desolate industrial landscapes of Rubicon 3, and every weapon sounds and feels powerful to fire due to fantastic sound design and the fast-paced visceral combat is accompanied by an amazing high octane soundtrack.

The gameplay loop of building mechs, testing their performance, readjusting your build, and completing missions to earn money to buy more mech parts is addictively fun. You can spend tens of hours in the garage alone meticulously fine tuning and customising your mech's performance and appearance without getting bored; just about every build is viable, though some builds will perform better depending on the mission you use them on. Sure, if you want to you can brute force your way through the vast majority of the game with a pair of shotguns and needle launchers or songbirds, but to me the most fun part of this game was experimenting with different mech builds and playstyles even if they weren't objectively the most powerful or optimal, they were simply fun. Unlike FromSoft's souls-style games where you spec into a specific build and are locked into using certain weapons until you re-spec, in this game you are highly encouraged to experiment with different builds because you can swap out parts or load entirely different saved builds on-the-go so the gameplay never gets boring and stale.

The two most surprising aspects of this game for me were the story and its characters. I didn't know what to expect from the story since this was my first Armored Core game, but considering this is a mech game I presumed that FromSoft would just prioritise gameplay over story. However, I was pleasantly surprised by just how much I became invested in the story, mystery and overall dilemma of the Coral and Rubicon 3's planetary corporate war. Supporting the story is the plethora of interesting and memorable characters throughout the game, which is impressive considering you never actually get to see what any of the characters looks like, you only get to see their emblem, sometimes their mech and hear their voice. Whether it's a major story character like Walter or a one-off hidden mech fight, each voice actor did an outstanding job at expressing their character and bringing them to life through their voice. I also liked how ambiguous each ending of the game was; there was no strictly good or bad ending, some factions and characters triumphed while others perished because of your actions and each ending made you question and reflect on the decisions you made throughout the game.

The only real complaint I have with this game is the horrendous Easy Anti-Cheat implementation. Just like Elden Ring, either FromSoft or Bandai Namco has yet again insisted on adding this useless resource hog of an 'anti cheat' into Armored Core VI on PC, so if you want to play PvP you have no choice but to deal with this invasive kernel-level, borderline malware piece of software running on your PC alongside the game and doing nothing but hampering the performance of an otherwise superbly optimised game. By running Armored Core VI directly via the exe and in offline mode I was able to play this game at 1440p on maxed out settings at a consistent 60fps with only occasional dips in performance during moments with tons of particles on screen at once. In contrast, running the game online with Easy Anti-Cheat on I would get frequent frustrating stutters that completely destroyed any potential enjoyment of the game. Personally I am more interested in the PvE side of the game rather than the PvP but nonetheless I should not have to launch the game directly via its exe and in offline mode just so I can play the single player PvE campaign at a stable framerate. It's a huge shame that Easy Anti-Cheat has once again ruined the online experience of another phenomenal FromSoft game and I hope they'll stop adding this detrimental digital garbage to their PC releases in the future.

I've played quite a few of FromSoft's souls games so I knew how imaginative and intriguing their worlds and stories are, but somehow I did not expect the same writing quality in a mech game. Thankfully, I was proven wrong and FromSoft have yet again made an absolute masterpiece of a game that I cannot get enough of. I hope this game has sold well enough to warrant a DLC or even a sequel in the future because this game has clearly proven that FromSoft doesn't need to solely develop souls-style games and can branch out and experiment with their game design.

Overall, I cannot recommend Armored Core VI enough despite the performance issues caused by Easy Anti-Cheat, this game is an absolute masterpiece.

Updating my review after completing NG++. Old review kept below for my thoughts after the first playthrough.

High 7/10 overall. 

To start with the good:
- It is EXTREMELY pretty. The slow-mo's when you take down big enemies is fantastic, I have taken many many many screenshots. 
- The vs AC fights are SO SO SO FUN. I have yet to dip my toes into multiplayer at this stage but the story fights are at their best when the enemy is 'just' another AC. 
- Customisation shines after the first playthrough, when you have options to work with. I can't compare it to past games myself. TIP: try out super-fast lightweight builds, and slow tank builds. Once I figured out what worked for me, it was really fun to stomp most missions!

Now for the bad. YMMV obviously, this is just my take. 
Some of the bosses are just... not very fun to fight. Personally, I put it down to fighting AC-sized enemies that have none of the restrictions you have. Hyper-manoeuvrable machines that 2-shot you are just not very fun to fight. Not all bosses are like this; the cavalry are cool and I've grown to enjoy fighting them.

To conclude, this game has started a fascination with the mecha genre. I've watched a few seasons of Gundam after starting Armored Core. Time to go back and play some of the older games.

OLD REVIEW BELOW:

Lightly recommended --- 6~7/10. This will be a slight stream of consciousness style one but I'll try to keep it coherent. To put it to a sentence: I'm not a huge fan of the design philosophy here --- the main missions are easy, but the bosses are ridiculous.

To start off with the good: it is spectacular. The (good) guns feel weighty and the audiovisual design is on point. When things are running, they absolutely go hard.

My main issues with the game are that the bosses aren't so much a difficulty jump as a difficulty spike. They are jarring to fight against, and (at least personally, I know I know skill issue) required an amount of what felt like cheese to beat. 
Were the fights spectacular? Sure. 
Did I also feel like "finally I can get on with the game" when I beat them? Heck yeah I did. 

This feels like an extremisation of Elden Ring's boss design philosophy, which I don't think is a good thing since the context is entirely different. There are no i-frames in AC6, which is fine. However a lot of bosses have chip damage (swarms of missiles). That would also be fine, except this almost guarantees you'll get staggered then one- or two-shot by a big attack. That just ain't fun to me. 

My issues extend also to a couple enemy designs. The largest issue I had were the shield enemies. They were fine in small numbers, even fun since they presented a different challenge. But one mission throws you into an arena with almost no cover, throws swarms of them at you with support, and just doesn't stop. You either counter the swarms and get screwed over by the couple of large enemies that spawn + boss, or you counter the big guys and get swarmed. This mission felt a lot more like luck than skill. 

All in all, I feel like the design philosophy here was somewhat conflicted, or at least I don't enjoy it as much as I hoped. I feel like if they had focussed on maybe longer, more attrition style missions with interesting small enemy encounters, that would have been really good. There's a couple of these missions in the game, and when they hit the mark they are fantastic.

My review after 1.5 playthroughs:

I have read a lot of comments that this is like a Windows XP-era action game, and rest assured, that is correct. However, it is a damn good one. 

Is it difficult? Well, how hard are you? If you have no problem grinding 3 hours on the same boss, you will figure it out. The game is very much worth it, and it feels awesome when you finally get the damn guy. 

The PC port is an exceptionally good one, where mouse and keyboard controls feel absolutely excellent and every thing works like it should.
"I got to tell you, it was perfect. Perfect. Everything, down to the last minute details."

I've played Armored Core since it's initial release back in '97, so yeah, I'm getting on a bit.  I've played them all; some great, some better, some ok-ish.  My favourite generation in particular being 3, Silent Line and Last Raven as they seem to have the right atmosphere, feel, variety of gameplay and story - essentially to me they are peak Armored Core.  6 though ... 6 is what the ten year old playing the first one always wanted, to blast around like in the intro cinematics and feel like an actual Mech God.  This game is for me, the best Armored Core I've ever played and the fact and to say that I was not expecting another game in this franchise is an understatement.  FromSoft improved on the AC formula exponentially here and whilst I understand I have my own fanboi service biases, I cannot fault the game to any major degree.  The sound design is brilliant, the story and writing is fantastic, the mechanics are buttery smooth, the attention to detail is incredible. 

If you haven't played this yet or are in two minds about it, trust me, you won't regret it.  Just be sad that you didn't get to come across OG Baltylad.

***UPDATE*** If you have ray tracing enabled, disable it. This has solved my crashing issues for now.

1.04 Patch has broken the game for me. Game constantly crashes. 9/10 times the game crashes when launching. I'm lucky if I can get past "Press to Continue" before the game hangs up and crashes.

Ignoring this minor hiccup, this is an excellent game that won't be for everyone. Bosses are hard and gate-keep progress, unlike Elden Ring, which lets you go around. A few of these bosses took days of selling off parts and trying out new strats with different legs to either tank my way through a fight or reverse joint legs to jump, boost, dodge and dodge some more and barely scrape by. Second play-thru? Bosses become easy and the new skill check becomes the 1v3 AC battles. If you do not like having to adapt your playstyle constantly, this game will be very frustrating. If you like overcoming the challenge, this game will test your mettle.

Story wise, this won't be for everyone either but is similar story telling to previous entries of the franchise. After completing my first ending, I cannot wait to see the other two. Glad we finally got a new AC game after all these years.
Finally, a mech game that feels like the imaginary battles you had in your head as a kid.

On its own feet this is an awesome game. It is my first in the series.

It is a lot of good ol' fashioned fun. The story while unclear and muddy at first becomes more and more engaging through NG+ and NG++ as you get the alternative endings and start piecing things together. In typical FromSoft fashion there are many questions I don't have answered but I felt seeing all 3 endings left me sufficiently satisfied.

The combat is fast and the missions are well paced. Generally missions are quick but with substance; they simply do NOT drag on forever. In fact, some are just boss fights which I personally love. There are longer missions but the check-pointing system was well done in the spirit of keeping the pace going. The customisation options are great and all the weapons feel good. Having just played through NG, NG+, NG++ and S-Ranking all the missions, I haven't burnt out yet (surprisingly) even if I am a bit tired.

Is it perfect? (Is any game?) Of course not. The game can be both really difficult or really easy at the same time; confusing I know. But basically it comes down to if you build your AC appropriately for the encounter/mission. The campaign difficulty curve was good for base NG playthrough, especially for first timer to the series.

There are builds that can trivialise some (read that as almost all) encounters once you starting getting into NG+ onwards and S-Ranking missions (I'm looking at you Zimmerman shotgun). And it is unfortunately easy to fall into the trap of sticking to that one build when/if you discover it. It can still be satisfying but those looking for a real challenge or a variety of builds for each mission might find disappointment IF they fall into that trap of sticking to a single build and optimising the fun out of the game.

The great thing is, is that I found that so many (if not all) of the weapons are fun and effective if used CORRECTLY and in combination with other appropriate weapons. You just have to make the decision to try them. Fortunately everything you buy from the shop buys and sells at the same price, and so your money is more of a 'budget'. Buy and sell freely and try all the weapons. You'll love it.

In either case you are certainly going to get your money's worth. I am looking forward to any potential future expansions to this, or a sequel.

I also am really glad to have discovered Armored Core and knowing nothing about the previous titles, I feel like I have become a new fan!

An incredibly well-made action-packed mecha game that feels like a love letter to the mecha genre & all who cherish it. You obtain wide variety of parts & weapons, as well as oodles of visual customization for each of them. The characters, themes, designs, setting and music all knock it out of the park. Easily one of the best games of the year, if not game of the year, in one of gaming's strongest ever years.

I recommend anyone to try this game, regardless of experience with the genre or specifically this series. 
 Keep in mind as I go a little more detail this may be the bias talking as someone who has played Armored Core since the first game way back on the Playstation:

This game is about as good as it gets for the mecha genre.  A great balance of having to consider the engineering of the parts behind your mech and exhilarating, anime-esque combat that really tests your ability to react to situations and your thought process to guide your builds accordingly.  Some missions demand certain build considerations, which can feel limiting at time but does encourage you to try out different ideas behind not just your build but your play style as well.  The controls do take some getting use to but they are ultimately straight-forward in their implementation.  The story is bleak, a staple of FromSoftware's titles, and makes you consider that no one is the "good guy" in a universe run by corporations and where mercenary activity is commonplace.  Even with multiple endings, its hard to feel like anyone is coming out on top ultimately. Graphically, this is the best the series has ever looked.  It still may look rough or lifeless at a first glance, but it's a reflection of the world you find yourself in.

The biggest draw though has to be the level of customization for your Armored Core mech.  Not only do you have access to a large variety of parts with different attributes to suit how you want to play, you can lose hours to the visual customization as well.  The colors of your AC along with the ability to add create emblems and decals with a surprisingly robust in-game image creation tool, then apply them anywhere on your AC leads to a truly personalized machine for you.

The biggest turn-off for some players, however, may be the spikes in difficulty.  Bosses are relentless and do not give you room to breathe.  You need to constantly be on the move and keeping your eyes glued to the visual cues coming from your HUD letting you know when something particularly dangerous is coming your way.  You need to find the weaknesses in how they attack and respond accordingly.  While some bosses can be extremely difficult, the feeling of relief after a particularly intense fight can feel genuinely real.

I have seen lots of veterans of the series deriding the simplified assembly process, saying that it's too toned-down from the complex engineering games like Armored Core 4/for Answer where you even had to consider the balance of your mech.  I can appreciate the love for the deep, problem solving mentality that is encouraged by the older games, however a simplification does not mean that it's gone entirely, it's just applied differently.  It's hard to describe this in particular, but I don't feel restricted by the simplification.  If anything, it gives me even more freedom to build the AC I want to pilot.

Multiplayer, as of the time of this writing, is a mixed bag.  Some builds are clearly more effective than other, so much like many build-based multiplayer experiences, you will be expected to learn a metagame to have the best chance of emerging victorious.  Balance patches are starting to come, but it remains to be seen if they will be effective in the long run.  While the meta experience can hurt your individuality, it is also a great source of desire to make your personal build work against it.

Overall, I think this is the best Armored Core has ever been.  If you're looking for a challenging game with a high level of customization for both your mech in terms of both appearance and play style, you're going to have a great time.

I don't know what I was expecting from this game, other than mech warfare. I was seeing posts about "filter" and "git gud" and thought it was going to be a souls-like game I wasn't going to enjoy. It is extremely fun. I wouldn't recommend it to people who want to progress to a game without struggle, but if you embrace the struggle there is no better feeling than beating that challenging boss or mastering a system. This was one of the first Souls-like games I enjoyed, all the other ones (except for Sekiro) felt like the rhythm of battle was "I attack, then you attack, then I attack, then you attack", which I personally don't enjoy.

I'll admit initially I was feeling bored of playing the game since I was using the same AC and specs through the beginning. What turned it around for me was that I watched a video of what the specs mean. I don't remember anything from that video, but it did change how I think about building my mech. I was no longer trying to go from combat to combat with the same build (or to find one that was over powered), I was willing to farm to buy all the items in the store and try them out. You don't have to do this to have fun though. It's just how I had fun in this game. I know some people who are absolute Chads and fought with just pistols and swords, and Chad supremes who fought with just their fists. I applaud them for their mastery of the game, but I wouldn't have found that play style fun.

Anyways I never mastered this game, I never found an OP build, but I still had fun. Even on the ending I chose I was fumbling with my fingers on the boss, and I still came up on top. It was fun. I'll might comeback in time to play the New Game+ and New Game++ missions. I hope if you're reading this review you get the game and enjoy it as well.

I want to clarify this is my first AC title ever. All I knew beforehand was that it's made by FromSoftware, and that it's about mechs. I also went in completely blind.

After my first playthrough, which considering extended idle times bc I didn't want to lose my checkpoint ran for about 30 hrs, I must say I was completely blindsided by this game. The first few stages, it wasn't grabbing me, I found the stages to be a bit underwhelming, graphics also a bit underwhelming (This game is nowhere near as pretty as Elden Ring btw), and while the action combat and customization gameplay was fun, I must admit I was kinda missing souls combat. 

However, all of this changed once I passed the first 2 chapters. Suddenly I found myself wrapped up in a mystery I did not expect. I found myself caring for characters that you never see, people that you only hear, who are never given a face. At most you get an emblem, a title, and a designation. I found myself scouring levels for any log or data I could find, in order to understand more of what was happening.

I never expected any of this. I came for a solid action game with mechs, explosions and customization options. And yes, it definitely has all of that, combat is fast paced, incredibly fun, super action packed, very easy to pick up and understand. Boss fights are interesting. There's a world of unparalleled scale here, where everything seems impossibly large, to the point normal cars and buildings look like toys, and factories are so unbelievably large you can't help but wonder what their purpose even is. Every encounter can be approached in a different manner, and it's simple to change your mech on the fly to try sth else at a particularly difficult fight. All of this is there, and it's good.

However, while I came expecting all of that, I ended up being enthralled by the story and the characters. I got more attached to characters in this game than anyone in a horizon game, FFXVI, or god of war, to put a few examples. All I want now is to do the other endings just to find out the destiny of this planet and its denizens. I honestly can't believe how much of a masterpiece of weird storytelling this game is, and if you're willing to listen, you can get hooked by that too. If you can leave the explosions and the fire behind for a minute, you'll find a different core to this game than you'd believe. It also helps that this game doesn't really hide its narrative like other From titles do, it's all there, quite readily accessible.

As a few final notes, the music has some truly amazing moments, and the visuals, while more on the discreet side, sometimes come together to create some truly insane scenarios, in what is quite a unique aesthetic. The game also isn't that difficult, and if you want you can look up good builds for every encounter, you'll win easily. Performance on my mid-high end machine (4070ti/12700f) was excellent throughout, played at native 4k with everything at max except RT which for some reason crashed the game.

Give this game a chance. For me this is an easy 9/10, and I'd advise to not believe any reviewers who say there isn't a story here. I think AC6 is easily at the same tier as Bloodborne, Dark Souls 1 and Sekiro are, and I'm very glad I decided to stick with a game I thought was a bit disappointing at first.
This is one the most fun games i have played in years, and after 100 hours and getting all the achievements i can say with confidence that you should play this game. It's great.
