Armored Core 6 is a game that you're going to love if you're a certain type of person. I happen to be that kind of person and enjoyed my experience very much.

[b]In this review I will discuss what the game is and isn't, to help you make an informed decision.[/b]

The core activity loop of this game is:
-you go on relatively short missions (5 minutes on average?) to earn money
-you spend money on new mech parts
-you use the mech parts to tinker with your build, to complete missions more efficiently

The activities feed into one another in a satisfying circulation, and the fact that parts can be sold at full value really encourages wild experimentation with assemblies, which is easily one of the main strengths of the game.

The parts the game provides have tremendous impact on gameplay variety of your build, probably most easily felt in case of weapons and legs. For legs, the opposite extremes you are provided is either being an unstoppable armored tread vehicle, a bombardment aircraft, or a lightning fast grasshoper, impossible to aim at as long as piloted competently. There are a lot of playstyle niches being satisfied and made viable, so you are likely to find something that will suit you in particular.

The parts provided are mostly balanced to be on equal footing, each shining in different circumstances, meaning that if a part feels useless, it's most likely because your build is not suited for utilizing it well. [b]That is one of the major things that could potentially turn people away[/b]: the game will require you to tinker a lot if you want to have a decent time piloting your machine. It is relatively easy to put together an unplayable heap of garbage that will make the game unnecessarily difficult if you're not paying enough attention to the assembly process. You are required to at least somewhat enjoy both the action gameplay part and the tinkering part of the game to have an overall good time.
That being said, the campaign is very lenient when it comes to build optimization, and bruteforcing your way through the game with a mediocre build is perfectly doable - you will just need to put in extra work in dexterity department. Which is to say, your skill will need to increase over time either in raw mechanics of the game or the build-making aspect, but you can somewhat neglect one for the other. That also means that you can look up highly optimal builds online and make the game trivial, which I highly advise against - figuring out the game's intricacies as you go is big part of the fun.

In terms of difficulty, this is the easiest FromSoft game I've played. I've hit about two difficulty walls in my first NG cycle, each requiring me to learn to play significantly better and preparing me for the rest of things to come. After the second difficult encounter, the game was never difficult again and I breezed through it, including also NG+1 and NG+2 campaigns. Now that I've both learned to play better mechanically and know how to build pretty good mechs, the campaign missions are trivial, especially since enemy balance in NG+ cycles stays the same.
That's okay though, because the true post-game content is the PvP. It seems that the online space is populated mostly by people who stuck with the game, which mostly means hardcore fans, very competent at the game, so prepare to spend many matches getting completely destroyed before getting any footing in the mode. The 3v3 team deathmatch mode seems like a good and fun way to get eased in into the world of PvP.

The game's feel is very polished, the mechs always feel very good to control. The presentation and feedback are consistent, you can always tell what just happened and strategize what to do about that. The game follows the FromSoft tradition of putting art direction over fidelity, and once again it works. The sound design is very competent, a lot of the sounds are properly satisfying to listen to. The music is serviceable, a bit below usual FromSoft standards, but still featuring some stand outs. The story is serviceable, very predictable at times but also has some genuinely good moments - it's a very mixed bag of the great, the bad and the mediocre. At the same time, I don't think the story is anywhere near being the main focus of the game, so it's fine.

Minor things to note that you might or might not like:
-the missions, while decently varied thanks to some gimmicks here and there, tend to boild down to "clean up basic grunts", especially if there is no boss around. It might be mindless fun for some, but boring and tedious to others.
-the balance is, at least currently, very skewed against very long range builds. If you want to live a sniper fantasy, it's going to be an uphill battle
-you need to complete at least 3 NG cycles (NG, NG+1, NG+2) to be done with the game's content, but on the other hand the campaign is pretty short, completing all 3 in under 30 hours is reasonably doable

Long story short, I recommend AC6 if you are looking for a game that is fast paced, highly customizable and not too difficult. The gameplay is fun right from the get go, and the bite-sized mission length lets you play it even when you don't have much time available to spend in one sitting.

If you like Fromsoft games this is worth a shot if you can afford it.

robots are cool.

I like the simple story and mission structure. 

But the game itself doesn't play very nicely.

There is a bug or something that causes low fps and stuttering on older cpus. A work-around for this exists by running the game without anti-cheat and then disabling and re-enabling core-0 on the process - every time you start the game.

Graphics have an excessively high contrast and visual noise which does not lend itself to fast-paced gameplay.  

Audio likewise is overloaded and difficult to discern. 

The HUD is not good: everything is indicated by identical thin, monochromatic lines which shake all over the screen.

There is a weird stagger mechanic which renders many builds non-viable as they do no meaningful damage. It also allows the player to be completely stun-locked to death. 

Gameplay basically devolves into continuously strafing, dodging, and either holding or mashing 4 different attack buttons, as you wait for the enemy to die (or your ammo to run out). 

In addition to parts being unlocked, they must also be purchased. You can refund purchased parts for 100% of the purchase price. So, all purchases are meaningless and this system only makes it more cumbersome and annoying to change loadouts.

"New-game+ is better", they say.  I don't think so. I enjoyed it much more during my first 10 hours, or at least up until that boss at the end of chapter 1.

There are some nice visuals at least, as you long as you stop moving long enough to process them.

This is my first time playing a FromSoft game, and I did not expect it to turn out to be one of my favorite games of all time. Dying had never been so fun.

Sekiro’s bosses/minibosses are designed in a way that dying to them made me feel a frustration that’s motivational rather than annoying (maybe except for a few like Demon of Hatred and the apparition types lol). The bosses are difficult but fair in the sense that whenever I die, I either learn something about the enemies’ movesets or realize what I’m not doing right yet, so on the next try I have an idea about how to improve. When you start to consistently execute the correct actions, the effect it has on the bosses is immediately apparent. I also used to dislike stealth, but this game showed me that my universal grudge against stealth was unjustified. In Sekiro, stealth can turn impossible fights against hoards of enemies into manageable and enjoyable boss encounters. In fact being able to one-hit deathblow many mobs in a row while grappling/hiding around the environment really do be making you feel like a ninja sometimes lol. Here I have to mention that the sound effects in Sekiro are absolutely INCREDIBLE and play a vital role in making the gameplay extremely satisfying.

Not just the combat, the story and character/world building are also amazing. These were done through a combination of cutscene animations + optional dialogues with NPCs and item descriptions. The way they depicted [spoiler]the sculptor’s fate hit me particularly hard… After seeing Ashina set into chaos upon Isshin’s death and knowing what has become of the sculptor, I went back to the dilapidated temple to only see a lone log of wood in the middle of the room, and Wolf goes on to fix his prosthetic arm by himself... There was no direct exposition of the sculptor’s suffering, but the scene hit harder than if there were. (And connecting this to what happens to Wolf in the Severance ending… *wails*)[/spoiler] Despite the fairly straightforward main plot, there are many small details and optional story content like this to discover, which makes the characters and lore much richer than it may first appear to be.

I guess the only minor complaint I have is the dragonrot mechanic, which sounds intimidating at first but kind of quickly turns into a trivial punishment that doesn't really do much besides making you feel bad about causing NPCs to suffer (until you heal them after defeating a boss).

Sweet LORD what a game.

The sound of a deflection is so perfect that I've lost sleep simply imagining it. Every boss is both brutally punishing and trivially easy at the same time depending on how much of their playbook you've learnt. And that in essence is the journey in Sekiro: you learn the playbook for each enemy until you're the boss.

Getting good at this game was naturally not very easy, but the game clicked for me at Genichiro and I haven't been able to put it down since. The art design and music are tasteful and atmospheric and there are some truly spectacular moments in the game, but the real spectacle is always in the boss fights as you rip your way through a boss' posture bar and land that sweet deathblow on them. 

The combat in this game feels so unbelievably polished that you never have an excuse for a loss. A lesser game would hand you ten losses and you'd blame the game for just being total BS, but not in Sekiro. You step back, take a break, and try again. And again. And again. Until that brick wall crumbles and the light starts to shine through.

Sekiro is an incredible game, and you've probably heard that plenty of times already. Allow me to add to the chorus. Play this game.

Sekiro™: Shadows Die a Lot
Be careful, desks are at risk.

Note that on steam my ingame hours is just 35. But in reality I have atleast twice that. 

[b] Game mechanics [/b]

This game compels you to learn the game mechanics or die trying, This game has arguably the best mechanics souls game has ever had for me. 

Compared to other souls game like Elden ring or Dark Souls 3, I feel like the mechanics are much more refined. For example the parry in other souls game is a joke. Sekiro has a far better definition of mechanics. Its a pure skill based game. In other souls game you can only dodge the incoming attacks for the most part or use there ill time framed unsatisfying parry. Not only that, Sekiro has various different forms of parrying like jumping or mekiri counter that has to be chosen appropriately based on the enemies attack.

[b] Boss Fights [/b]

The bosses in Sekiro are designed beautifully. Various versions of the same bosses with different skill set can only be found in this game. Every single boss that you fight inevitably makes you suffer. But once you have mastered the art of fighting in this game. You become unstoppable.

[b] Game design [/b]

Along with all this, you get to experience the beauty of this game through the game play. From the Ashina castle to the fountainhead palace, every single area of this game was designed to keep you satisfied. 

I only wish that they had launched an expansion pack or something to keep this game alive. I'm just hoping they will someday.

This is one of the best games I've ever played. Game play and Storytelling wise Sekiro offers ALOT. As a souls born fan it first feels counter intuitive how you have to play this game.

You're a Shinobi that hides in the Shadows and if you keep that in Mind, you wont have trouble. First snack the Foe's around the Miniboss and then assassinate him. 

Do not hesitate in a Boss fight, even when a Boss first seems to be overwhelming keep the aggro up, learn the attack pattern and find your Moments to sneak an attack in. 

Listen to the sounds of the blades jamming against each other, once you got the rhythm you never gonna miss. 

Use your prosthetic to create windows for your attacks.

Only thing that bothers me a bit that there are multiple enemies that doesn't wield a sword because the most satisfying boss fights are those against blades.

This is by far the most rewarding combat system I saw in a Game.

At the end, I have to say it. Git gud, try to learn and you will have one blast of an experience.

The game is great, but I could not get the hang of the combat style. I appreciate that the game forces you to think about your fights and punishes you swiftly if you try to brute force your way through any of it, but I eventually found that the challenge was just not fun for me. If you like battles where you have to study each enemies move sets before taking action and don't mind dying a lot, then you honestly might love this game like a lot of people seem to, but definitely not for everyone.

Almost every single combat mechanic in this game is perfect. From the basic things such as attack cancelling, input buffering, deflections and movement to the different combat arts and the prosthetic tools, all of them feel like they work together extremely well and feel very fluid and fun to use. Deflections are crucial to this game. A deflection is when you block at the moment an attack lands. It requires some skill but with a little practice you can do them consistently. If you do it right, you hear a loud clang sound and a visual cue which is great feedback. This makes it a very refreshing and satisfying mechanic that feels great to pull off every single time. Then you have the posture system which is very unique and a new take on melee combat with a surprising amount nuance and depth. I could ramble on for hours about each aspect, whether the music, lighting or writing and dialogue. Most fun i've had with a game in a while.

I know soulslike aren't for everyone, especially if you're not a fan of difficulty or dark fantasy, but if you don't mind them or want to try something new, I would recommend sekiro every day of the week, it's just such a good game.

Really fun game, don't feel like writing more details atm, but having a blast with it. I'm a fan of the Soulsborne series, but given that this is how the game turned out I'm very happy with From's decision to not make another soulsborne

Edit after 100 hours of play: So this has been the most fun game I've played in years probably, so fun in fact I ended up having problems with my wrists cause of playing it so much :(
The fast paced combat, good difficulty curve and challenge, reasonably good controls (safe for the usualy camera being sometimes a bit wonky), fun secondary abilities and gadgets to play around with all makes it a great experience even for multiple playthroughs.
There's multiple endings and you won't see some of the content on your first playthrough most likely, since there's also some hidden stuff. Now over one year after release we get some extra content on top as well.

Unfortunately it doesn't come without the usual fromsoft flaws: The "patented" infinite input buffer where moves come out 5 seconds after input if you got interrupted the first time and then will get you killed without being able to do anything.
Along with the bad wakeup moves that turn some enemy combos into one shots, because if you get hit by the first move and get stunned or knocked down, even if you press to get up faster, you can't really input anything else before getting hit again and if you lay down and don't get up you also get hit, which makes one wonder why the fast getup moves even exist to begin with. Similar with the "getting out of stunned pose", where you can "get out of stun" by pressing dodge, but then just enter a just as long other animation where Sekiro uselessly hold up one arm in front of him and also doesn't accept any inputs anymore.

It's still a very fun game overall, but expect the usual flaws and frustrations

This is hands down the best souls game, if you're mostly interested in combat. It is somewhat different from the Dark Souls series and Elden Ring, in the sense that you mostly parry here, which is the most satisfying game mechanic ever. Also you can't overlevel and the toolkit to beat every boss is fairly basic, so every fight is really well made and tailored around the kit that you have. Played Elden Ring and some encounters were really boring or frustating. On Sekiro each and every one is awesome, and the perfect amount of "hard" for you to conquer it. The only exception here is DoH, that is essentially a Dark Souls boss on Sekiro, and it doesn't fit at all and is a pain in the ass to get through. However combat wise, this is the best a fromsoft game has to offer and it makes every win feel like you mastered the encounter and you are the boss now.

On the other hand, exploration isn't hugely open world, like ER, but there are some shortcuts and different paths for players to choose. For me personally, I loved what Sekiro had to offer without it becoming tedious. There are a lot distinct locations, and the locations that you revisit have a good enough twist every time to keep them interesting. However don't expect the huge content of ER, although it took me around 40 hours to explore most of the game, while on ER it took me 90 to explore a fair amount. So there is enough things to explore, but the main focus are the bosses.

Now, the fact that you can't overlevel and don't have RPG elements is what made me love this game. You can't really make a fight easier. You just have to punch a wall, over and over again, till you break it down and that's the main difference here, and for me that's what makes the game amazing. The feeling I got after beating each boss here is the feeling I got while beating Margit on ER the first time, and Malenia. But not other bosses. Sekiro is just the perfect amount of challenge every time.

It's the best game I have played, but that's because of the challenge. So if you are interested in that, pick it up immediatelly.

And remember, hesitation is defeat...

[u]Overall rating: 10/10[/u]

Sekiro is a third person action game from the makers of Dark Souls, set in Sengoku Japan. The game is a mix of stealth & action where you can silent kill most non-boss enemies but the bosses themselves require a direct confrontation. The game takes place in Japan during the 1500s and features some mythical elements to it as well.

The game features an amazing combat system in the form of "posture", which is like a second health bar that fills up when you block attacks (this applies to you and the enemies). Filled up posture will deplete over time if you stop blocking. While you can block almost every attack in the game (there are a few unblock-able attacks that require jumping/rolling), filling up your posture bar results in a temporary disorientation which can be fatal (damage is very high). On the flip side, attacking an enemy repeatedly allows you to fill their posture bar which can result in a deathblow for non-bosses and partial deathblow for bosses.

So you want to keep wailing on the enemy but also block/dodge when they counter you occasionally. A perfectly timed block (deflection) costs very little posture and allows you to keep going for longer.
This turns the game into a rhythm game where the "clangs" of swords tell you when to time your blocks (non block-able attacks have audio/visual queues too) and is the single most important aspect of improving in the game - Staying calm, attacking aggressively but blocking/dodging the enemy when required.

Enemy variety is high and different enemies will use different tactics on you. That said, there are a few reused mini-boss enemies but those hardly matter when the highlight of the game are the bosses themselves. Every boss has different attacks/mechanics that require you to tackle them in different ways.

Tying together these amazing battles is a story which even has multiple endings as well! The world is a mix of linear and open world which in my opinion, is the best way to make a large game.

The only weak aspect of the game is the lack of fighting variety (no range or basic attack styles) in terms of perks (there are different power attacks but those are hardly usable on bosses).

The music is good and the audio feedback for attacks/blocks/dodges/deflections etc. are phenomenal!

[u]TLDR: Sekiro is a third-person action game with one of the most refined melee combat systems ever created!![/u]

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice stands as one of the best games I have ever played, and beating the game was one of the most triumphant moments I've ever experienced.

The combat in this game is second to none, flawless, and I have yet to play a game with better combat aspects than Sekiro. The fights are very intense, demanding attention, reflexes, and most importantly dedication and patience. The learning curve may appear daunting initially, but the satisfaction when it finally clicks is immense. The game plays very fairly. When you die, it's not because of some cheap reason, you understand your fault, you learn and conquer. This game has exceptional boss fights, and they exist to challenge everything you've learned throughout the game. While some of them may seem unforgiving, you can overcome them, and you will! Delivering the final deathblow to an opponent is a feeling that never gets old. If you are still having a hard time with the game, then all you have to do is not give up. Also, remember not to hesitate in a battle.

Moreover, Sekiro excels in its captivating visuals, immersive atmosphere, and a musical score that beautifully complements the game's lively and captivating setting. All of these elements contribute to a deeply immersive experience. I wholeheartedly recommend Sekiro. Hope you enjoy the game as much as I did.

This is my first true souls game, even though i have dabbled with some of the others. I'm not sure how I can compare it to the other souls games, but for me this has a high learning curve that once mastered, you feel very satisfied. Its a mix of the souls style gameplay mixed in with an actual working stealth system similar to Assassins Creed. Even though stealth is used, the combat is what really hooked me in as it very intense and fluid, and while you fight similar enemies often, the fights never get stale. I also love the movement in this game as from what I've seen from the other souls games, you have so much more freedom in the movement from grappling rope to dodging and running. That's not including the excellent story telling that was crafted by the developers. It felt like watching an old samurai Chambara (Equal to Western/Cowboy movie). I eventually will try the other souls games for real, but this will definitely have a special place in my library. This is a masterpiece.

Game was super difficult in the beginning- so much so that I almost quit completely. Coming from games like Dark Souls I was expecting a degree of difficulty but not of this magnitude. What am I doing wrong? I was dodging everything but I was still getting killed.

I come to find out that you need to DEFLECT attacks in Sekiro, that's the way it was meant to be played.

What's a deflect? Its like normal blocking but you don't hold the button down. You block at the VERY last second. Like right before the moment of impact. That's a deflect. It can be challenging too because different enemies have different attack patterns.

Get enough consecutive deflects and you can strike the opponent with a DEATHBLOW- watch as Sekiro mutilates your foe in a glorious display of blood and power! Very satisfying.

Once you get your bearings straight you will start to build a rhythm. You'll anticipate attacks before they happen. And DAMN does this keep you engaged!

I've never played a game like this before, I hope this deflecting concept catches on with future games. In a way it now resembles an actual sword fight.

I'm glad I stuck with it too because once you get past the initial threshold of the game being BALLS, you get to see some awesome castles!  From Software always has unparalleled graphics I absolutely love the landscapes they put in their games! The game becomes significantly easier once you get the deflecting down.

I would definitely recommend this game.

this game is undoubtedly my favorite game of all time. its not the best game, but its very close to perfect. the combat system is unique and exciting, and provides a fast paced battle that is consistently challenging and satisfying to overcome. people often complain about the lack of customization, and while there is significantly less than a dark souls game there is still a plethora of different ways to approach challenges. with the shinobi prosthetic having a significant amount of usage and different variants each with abilities to use against enemies. combat arts add another layer, creating more moves to master and more tactics to decide upon before battles. parrying reigns king, and its for the better. there are no attacks in the game in which you can not parry, save for those explicitly marked as unblockables. the game offers significant challenges in both the optional and mandatory content. along with this, there are ways to make the game even more challenging, which gives new life to the game after beating it a few times. the replay-ability is like no other game. you can practice for hours and hours, or days and weeks mastering every boss and its attacks, trying to beat the game as perfectly as you can. the story is somewhat lacking, but what is there is interesting and fabulous. the multiple endings are all worth going for as they all serve interesting endings to the story, and are all worth checking out. this is the first game i have ever sought out to 100% because of the enthralling combat and the ever-present feeling of victory. the imperfections lie when the game fails to play to its strengths; most sekiro encounters shine best as one on one duels, and there are many instances of gank-sessions that feel unfair and severely difficult, but it makes up for this slightly by making most of these types of fights easy to run away from or have some other method of crowd control to make it more fair. other than scripted sequences, the game offers little for crowd control. there are a few combat arts helpful for groups, and some prosthetic tools which also help, but largely it comes down it significant skill to deal with these fights. this game is worth the challenges, and worth doing everything, i highly recommend doing a 100% achievement run, and them some, as some minibosses, and other things are not required to get all of the achievements. 9/10 PLEASE MAKE A SEQUEL

[h3] An exploitative, nasty gambling front that you should stay away from at all costs [/h3]

Counter-Strike has been proliferated so deeply by gambling and predatory monetisation that, in its current form, the game is a hollow billboard advertisement for betting.

I’ve seen many of my closest friends become addicted to in-game betting through the likes of FIFA, now EA Sports FC. What initially starts as purchasing their favourite incarnation of Ronaldinho for Ultimate Team, becomes a business-like operation using third party gambling sites to become one of the few players to, on its surface, game the system. Many PC players would scoff at such blatantly exploitative practices, especially when its aimed at a casual console audience, yet what Counter-Strike 2 does is worse still.

Counter-Strike 2 (CS2) players are granted cases (lootboxes) for playing the game, which offer you the opportunity to spend money on a £2.15 key to open. These cases are dangled in front of you, making it appear that giving Valve money is a reward in and of itself. Opening these will literally show a visualised slot machine, which selects a pre-determined skin for you. These skins can be applied on your guns to show off to others, but even worse, can be traded on third-party betting sites which have been given Valve’s blessing.

In-game, CS2 is a hellish playground of flashy cosmetics paraded about like walking advertisements to promote this gambling. In fact, I would sooner find it easier to swallow brand advertisements from major tech companies used on player models than seeing the nauseating number of expensive skins increase any more. Furthermore, there’s no option to turn off other people’s skins from your perspective, meaning Valve would rather bait recovering gambling addicts further than let them play CS2 for fun.

CS2’s primary promotion tool was its new smoke physics. Well, I can’t think of anything more apt for a game designed to cover up such a remorseless vehicle for extracting money from impressionable people’s pockets under the guise of a multiplayer shooter. New, ultra bright lightening is used purely to make cosmetics as noticeable and enticing as possible. 
It makes me ashamed to have 200+ hours on record, which were all gained from when CS:GO first launched without any cases, as I dread to give this game an ounce of endorsement or credibility.

The graphics in Counter-Strike are a big improvement on CS:GO, though hardly impressive by 2023 standards. Updates to the maps are excellent, with a lot more detail and more "junk" to make them feel like real, used spaces - cups on break tables, bin bags in street alleys, that sort of thing - and there's been minor tweaks to the layouts to allow for a lot more cut-throughs and route options.

That's the positive, now the negative... 
No Demolition and no Arms Race, which were two of the best things about CS:GO.
No heavy weapons - the sawn-off shotty and machine guns are all gone.
Less maps - plenty of long-term favourites have not been brought over to CS2 and the only maps you can select (or even load through the console) are the current rotation. No Assault, no Siege, no Aztec, no Dust, etc.
And, lastly, the bots are *dumb*, like really, really dumb. Not an issue if you never play against bots, obviously, but if you do then be prepared for opponents who are only marginally more challenging than the chickens.

tl;dr - graphics better, maps prettier, everything else worse.

Please bring back Global Offensive - it was so much better.

FFA Deathmatch playlist seems to have too many players, can barely move off your spawn point for most maps without someone else spawning where you spawned a second ago. Also has no team option, and again why can't all maps be in rotation and have a voting system to select the next? Still improvements to be made and bugs to be ironed out, should have beta'd it longer before full release from what it seems.

Dear Community and Valve,
In the following, I will explain to you why I gave a negative rating.
First, I would like to address the elephant in the room: The game is absolutely not finished! Releasing the game even though it has so many bugs and lacks so much content unlike CS:GO is just stupid of Valve. This just shows how much Valve cares about the community.... 
A much better plan would have been to release an open beta and really finish polishing the game, but Valve would rather release a broken and bad game.
Aside from the improved graphics, there's really nothing good to say about the game. The servers are bad and even crash sometimes. As a result, all players get 1k elo deducted, even though they didn't cancel the game. Steam support, when I asked them about it, said that they know about the problem but won't do anything. Furthermore, many maps and game modes, also as community servers and workshop maps that were available in CS:GO are not available at all. Don't even get me started on the astonishing amount of Bugs...
I have to say that I was already not a big fan of CS:GO but that Valve manages to publish even a worse game I would not have thought.

Once again I'm asking Valve to add a "Meh" ranking for reviews. I personally don't think the game's bad or anything, definitely worth downloading if you have a PC that can run it smoothly, my issue is the lack of content. 

Only 8 maps at launch. No Cobblestone, no Cache, no Assault.

All the fun "party modes" were removed (Arms Race, Flying Scoutsman, demolition, and their associated maps). 

Dangerzone is gone. 

At the moment there's no CS2 community servers so if you wanted to play surf, you gotta download the csgo demo viewer to be able to do that. 

To remove CSGO and replace it with a version that's missing so much content is just...odd. Like..we'd have been fine waiting another 6 months-a year if it meant CS2 released with all the stuff that's currently missing.

Edit: And while this doesn't cause issues for me, the fact that there's no MacOS support is wack. I've seen countless mac users in the reviews that have hundreds to thousands of hours of playtime in CSGO. These people prolly bought CSGO before it went free, then also prolly spent a lot of money on skins and cases, and now they're just...not able to play. That's shitty as fuck, man.

Edit 2: If you wanna get beamed by obese losers that play too much, hop on in.

INGREDIENTS
▢2 tablespoons vegetable oil
▢2 pounds pork shoulder (cut into chunks)
▢¼ cup cane vinegar or white vinegar
▢⅓ cup low sodium soy sauce
▢6 cloves garlic (chopped)
▢1 bay leaf
▢2 teaspoons black peppercorns
▢2 teaspoons sugar
▢2 cups water

INSTRUCTIONS
In a medium dutch oven or pot over medium high heat, add the oil and sear the pork until browned on all sides.
Add the vinegar, soy sauce, garlic, bay leaf, peppercorns (tied in cheese cloth if desired), sugar, and water, and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium low, cover, and simmer for 1 hour.
Remove the cover and continue simmering for another 30 minutes to reduce the sauce.
Serve over rice!

I'm very on the fence about this game. Once you get into it, it's really fun. It lends itself to fast-paced gameplay, zooming around tearing through enemies, which is incredibly satisfying. Improving feels rewarding, and earning your first few Boss Cells (rewards for completing a run which send you back the start to do it again, with increased difficulty) is really satisfying. The OST is also exceptional and the artstyle, though a somewhat mixed bag, really shines in a lot of the backgrounds for the different environments.

The problems - which to be honest are inherent to the game from the beginning - really start to show themselves once you hit 3/4BC as the game just becomes such a complete slog. 

There is definitely an element of mechanical skill to Dead Cells - you need to be able to react to enemies, obviously. But a large part of getting good at the game is purely knowledge. There are an absurd number of enemies, each with their own attack patterns and telegraphs. Becoming familiar with all of these is the biggest component of "gitting gud". Each biome has its own pool of enemies (some enemies show up in multiple places; others are exclusive to certain biomes), so learning a biome essentially constitutes learning how to read the enemies within it (and re-learning that pool each time new ones are added with new BCs).

Because the game never changes fundamentally between the Boss Cell levels, you're running the same biomes every time. You're therefore faced with a choice - you can just stick to the one route and minimise the amount of setbacks you'll face learning totally new enemies in addition to the BC difficulty increases (which really, is optimal, for reasons I'll get to), or you can mix it up for the sake of variety, but substantially increase the time you spend playing as you get used to dealing with new mobs. In the case of the latter, the variety is largely cancelled out by the frustration of losing what progress you'd made, since your existing mechanical skill only carries you so far against completely new enemies.

So you do the former. And this is what makes sense, as there is quite literally a best route in the game. Sewers->Prison->Sewers->Graveyard->Cavern straight up just gives you more scrolls. And you want scrolls, because the multiplicative scaling is really the best way by far to counter 5BC. Either you nuke everything, or you get nuked. And when one scroll is worth potentially hundreds of percentage more damage, of course you're going to take it.

All of this to say, grinding 5BC essentially just constitutes staring at Toxic Sewers for hours on end, especially if you're doing lots of runs to try achievements, or multiple routes/bosses. It ceases to be fun entirely.

Some other miscellaneous issues:
- The scroll system is poor. As soon as you start scaling, you're locked into a colour and two thirds of weapons become actively detrimental pickups.
- Weapons suffer the same issue as enemies. There are so many that you can either devote hundreds of hours to learning them, or turn on custom mode and engage with a handful you're comfortable with.
- The visual clutter is the worst I've ever seen. The accessibility update options mitigate this somewhat, but it's still not great. Pixel vomit everywhere.
- The game insists on having platforming sections despite the platforming being godawful. The jump feels sluggish and you snap to ledges to mantle them from miles away, removing pretty much any and all room for tight, skilful platforming. It's actually frustrating when you try to make a precise jump past something only to snap to it from halfway across the screen because the game is more interested in catering to people who have never played a platformer before.
- A lot of the "difficulty" comes from cheap enemies that wallhack you from off-screen and just very high volumes of very high-damage mobs that just get spammed more and more as the BCs go up, rather than any tests of mechanical skill, or game knowledge, which is part of what contributes to the sloggy feeling.
- The writing is painful. The game tries to have its cake and eat it too with le spooky mysterious vague lore a la Hollow Knight, but also le epic Rick and Morty taking nothing seriously jokes and banter, none of which is funny. One of the more poignant story beats (though that is a generous description) is undercut by the cringest line and le epic troll middle finger moment I've ever seen. It's like the Marvel "so that just happened!" on crack.
- The super secret ultra final twist boss is wildly underwhelming. One of the blandest, easiest final boss fights I've ever encountered. The rest of the bosses are also nothing to write home about. The game's combat shines better in biomes, at least before the grind wears you down.
- The devs milk this game to an obnoxious degree. Middling, half-hearted updates and DLCs years after launch, balance patches for a single player game - just move on lmao. All it serves to do is add bloat, which is bad for the player, because all these new weapons just take up space in your loot pool over the weapons you actually want to see, unless you're willing to sink potentially a thousand hours in learning every single weapon, but the combination of how insane an undertaking that'd be, and the existence of custom mode, makes me assume that isn't how the game is intended to be played.
- Also on the devs, they literally launched the game without an ending, and while the DLC that added it was free, the rest slotting into the main game despite being paywalled feels a little slimy.

Overall, Dead Cells is a game that seems to discourage you from engaging with it. It's designed in such a way that optimising for the smallest amount of content makes the game most bearable. And given how obnoxious it becomes anyway, maybe that's for the best. If you're content just playing this to 3BC, you'll probably have a blast, but as a full experience, I can't recommend it, especially for a comparatively high price tag (especially accounting for the DLC) as indie games go.

Title: A Rogue-like Masterpiece Unfolds - My Review of "Dead Cells"

Steam's vast library of games has seen its fair share of rogue-likes, but among the myriad choices, there stands an undisputed champion – "Dead Cells". Developed by Motion Twin, this game transcends the boundaries of its genre, delivering an adrenaline-soaked experience that leaves players utterly captivated from their first electrifying encounter to the heart-pounding final showdown.

"Dead Cells" is a visual spectacle that seamlessly blends pixel art aesthetics with modern design sensibilities. The meticulously crafted environments pulse with life, showcasing a diverse range of atmospheric settings that unfold in a symphony of colors. The game's attention to detail is nothing short of awe-inspiring – from the subtle play of light in dimly lit caverns to the frenetic explosions of vibrant energy during heated battles. Each frame is a work of art that engulfs players in a world as dangerous as it is mesmerizing.

The game's combat is a symphony of fluidity and precision. Every slash of your weapon, every dodge roll, and every well-timed parry carries a palpable weight that reinforces the player's connection to the protagonist. "Dead Cells" deftly combines strategic decision-making with lightning-fast reflexes, creating an intoxicating game-play loop that never grows stale. The intuitive controls become an extension of the player's will, allowing for endless creative approaches to each skirmish.

What sets "Dead Cells" apart from its contemporaries is its ingenious take on the rogue-like formula. Death is not an end, but a new beginning. The constantly shifting levels and enemy placements ensure that each foray into the unknown is a unique challenge. The game offers a wealth of weaponry and abilities that can be tailored to suit your preferred play-style, encouraging experimentation and evolution as you uncover devastating synergies. This creates an irresistible loop of progression and discovery, urging players to push their limits and delve deeper into the labyrinthine world.

The haunting melodies and atmospheric soundscapes of "Dead Cells" are an auditory delight. From the haunting echoes of desolate corridors to the pulse-pounding rhythms of intense battles, the music becomes an essential companion on this treacherous journey. It not only complements the visual splendor but also elevates the emotional resonance of each moment.

"Dead Cells" presents its narrative with an intriguing subtlety that beckons players to piece together the story as they progress. The game leaves breadcrumbs of lore and tantalizing hints about the world's mysteries, encouraging a deeper engagement without imposing a rigid narrative structure. This enigmatic approach creates a sense of wonder and curiosity, making the discovery of hidden secrets all the more rewarding.

Ultimately, in the grand tapestry of video games, "Dead Cells" shines as a masterpiece that defies conventions. Its breathtaking visuals, exhilarating combat, and ingenious rogue-like design coalesce into an experience that is as addictive as it is unforgettable. With each run, you'll uncover a new layer of its brilliance, ensuring that "Dead Cells" remains an essential fixture in any gaming collection. Motion Twin has not just created a game; they have forged an enduring legend that will resonate for years to come.

While I haven't racked up a ton of time on this game in Steam, I've been playing [i]Dead Cells[/i] since its release on the PSN in 2018. Hundreds of hours spent; well over 500 runs on that save file.

The game is just all-around great and the amount of updates the devs have offered over the years proves that they still love this world they've made and value its fans. A lot has changed (usually for the better; ask the veteran players how Malaise used to work) but the standard gameplay has mostly remained the same because it was already strong from day one.

[i]Dead Cells[/i] can be tough, but in an accessible way. By the time you've successfully completed your first run and obtained the first (of perhaps many) Boss Cell, you will have amassed a vast inventory of tricks, tactics, weapons, abilities, and allies that got you that far and are more than capable of carrying you further. Things feeling stale? Boss Cells will up the challenge while providing something special. There are optional modes and a mountain of settings to shift around the gameplay. Free DLC ensures that there'll still be something new to discover; paid DLC is fairly priced and opens up new ways to complete runs.

I dare say this game is overrated.
- Difficulty is not determined as much by skill as much as it is by your enemies' numbers being bigger than yours. I'm not saying there's NO skill, but I'm also not saying the game will demand your skill any more than it will demand your patience.

- It was made at the stage of FromSoft's lifecycle where difficulty and dying a lot is the only thing that matters because Miyazaki gets $10 for every time a game journalist says "[insert game here] Is the Dark Souls of [insert genre here]", and it definitely shows.

- 90% of the game's bosses are fought the exact same way; They get close and rush you down while you roll around and maybe hit them once, twice if you're lucky before you go right back to Fred Durst'ing it until the boss's meter hits zero. Plus, the bosses who actually have unique gimmicks like Rykard and Radahn overstay their welcome long after you've figured them out. My favorite bosses in the game are Morgott and Hoarah Loux, but the fights themselves aren't cool, just the CONTEXT of them is cool (more on this later). I consider this to be a failure for the game; for its defining trait to be the least interesting part of itself.

- Despite the presence of a Souls-style leveling system, most enemies can kill you just by acknowledging your existence. And before some wise guy comes to this review and says "bUt vIgOr", it doesn't matter if your vigor is 17 or 70. There are enemies that will flatten you like a steamroller no matter how big your meter is, and the only time you will ever notice any difference with your stats against the area's enemies is when you come back to an area that hasn't been your problem for three weeks.
     “What if you were using the soreseals though? They’re good but maybe they were getting you killed”
     I never used the soreseals, since magic isn’t my primary source of damage. The closest thing I’ve had to a self-inflicted debuff was Fia’s blessing.

- The open world is a joke. All it fundamentally is is just Dark Souls with buffer zones that take a long time to cross. So basically you spend $60 on Dark Souls 3 with even more filler. There's nothing to do in the open world, and the closest thing there is to "something to do" is the mines and the catacombs which, if anyone has ever played Bloodborne, are fundamentally Chalice Dungeons, with no unique bosses, in dungeons that can't be randomized, with your reward being some Enemy Spirit Ash you'll never summon, or a trinket you could get in bulk anywhere else.
     On top of this, Torrent changes nothing. He only exists to justify having these buffer zones in the first place. Does he change the pace of the boss fights? Sometimes. Does he ever change the pace of UNIQUE or ESSENTIAL boss fights? No. There are too many places where this "staple of Elden Ring" can't be used, and there are even more places and events that could have been made better by his presence, such as during the final boss fight, which alone was terrible from a design standpoint because of how out-of-nowhere and chaotic it is. You can't even summon him during multiplayer, or while a Spirit Ash is active.

- To go over some story issues, we need to understand what makes storytelling work. "Show, don't tell" is the golden rule of storytelling. What happens in Elden Ring is that the most interesting parts of the lore are notes you read in some random article of gear, and 90% of it has nothing to do with how you play. For example, the name "St. Trina" has no relevance to you, the player, than to tell you what items are related to the Sleep ailment, but it shows up in the written lore as frequently as trees in a forest.
     Another example involves Mohg, a boss who has the power of "Blood Fire", bright-red flames that inflict the Bleed ailment. This is said to be done by "lacerating the body of the Formless Mother". This info is completely useless because it does not change how this magic works in any way. One may expect blood magic to be cast by using your HP as an alternative for MP, but it simply doesn't. It works like all other magic in the game. As someone who plays FANTASY RPGs to get invested in a FANTASY world, this mundane gameplay with outrageous lore reminds me of working retail, how there's this long eventful story of how a store you work in came to be, but the actual work you do asks nothing of you but your ability to listen, follow directions, and put up with the bullshit that comes with it.
     Dung Eater is supposed to be scary because people tell you he's scary. Rykard is supposed to be evil because people tell you he's evil. Marika is supposed to be great because people tell you she's great. Godrick is supposed to be a worthless failure because people tell you he's a worthless failure. There are way too few moments where the story or personality of a character is SHOWN, and not TOLD.
     To give an example of GOOD storytelling in a Souls game, look at Solaire from Dark Souls. He's a knight who governs a self-founded guild that believes brilliance is achieved by aiding others. This is expressed by Solaire's summon sign appearing the most frequently out of every NPC in the whole game. The only character to ever have this potential is Melina, and she doesn't even do it with the correct boss because of dumb plot reasons. Hoarah Loux? Radagon? Elden Beast? Nope. She shows up for ONE boss; Morgott, who's basically just there to guard a door he doesn't even have the key to. After that, the story writes itself in such a way that prevents her from ever doing this again, despite her only gimmick allegedly being LITERALLY FOLLOWING YOU EVERYWHERE.

- Compared to past games, multiplayer is even more pathetic here than it ever was before. To understand why, let's review some of the basic multiplayer rules established by past games. All Souls games before this one have had 'alive' and 'dead' states. Said states grant certain benefits and caveats. They also dictate what is possible in terms of multiplayer action.
     In Demon's Souls, players had to be in their dead form to enter other peoples' worlds, while players in their alive forms can be found by said dead-form players.
     This rule was much the same in Dark Souls, though it removed the hassle of having to be dead to cast a co-op sign.
In both games, being alive granted players host privileges as well as occasional HP buffs, depending on the game, but at the cost of unconditional vulnerability to invaders.
     In Elden Ring, for no reason at all, the two functions of the games' resurrection charms have been split up into separate items, which completely removes the stakes of granting yourself a substantial buff.

- Speaking of low-stakes multiplayer, invaders previously appeared in past games to play the role of the enemy, which is remarkable for a ROLE PLAYING GAME, for players to present as much a threat to each other as the rest of the game. However, in Elden Ring, these "invaders" need the host's permission to invade them.
     In regular gameplay, without an item called the Taunter's Tongue, it takes the presence of a friendly phantom to make invasion reception possible, which already stacks the odds against the invading party.
     Couple that with a competitive community that has no qualms with over-optimizing the fun out of the game, and you'd be lucky to invade a single world without getting annihilated in a nanosecond by solar flares, weapon pairs tuned to inflict Bleed nearly instantly, decay-inducing fog, and mega-lasers. That's no exaggeration.

There probably were or are good qualities of the game, but after having spent as much time on it as I have, and after beating the game MONTHS AHEAD OF MY FRIENDS WHO ACTUALLY LIKE IT, I am just sick of this game and everything to do with it. The base game has inspired too little faith in the DLC to ever consider coming back. If you STILL want to blast $60 on this game, all I can say is that you brought ALL of the ensuing frustration upon yourself.

The combat feels amazing and most bosses are fair and still difficult but i do feel that some later game bosses are overtuned toward difficulty and unfun to fight. The weapon upgrade system makes the build variety incredible because even the weapon you started the game with can carry you through the whole game. The issue with the system is that you need 12 of a single level of smithing stone but only 1 of a single level of somber stone making it much easier to just get a somber  weapon and be done with upgrading for most of the game. I love that the rolling feels so clean and that there are more attacks that you can jump over to dodge too. Another thing is that this is definitely the most accessible soulsborne game by far because of spirit summons, some of which can solo bosses for you. Along with that they kept co-op so you could also summon a friend, but they removed covenants which does make online much less fun. There is a lot of toxicity in the community from tryhards who want to tell you that you didnt beat the game unless you never used spirit summons or any weapon stronger than a piece of spaghetti, but they have no life so dont worry. I do think you should play this game and even if you don't like the difficulty you could use magic or spirit summons to make it easier or even an overpowered weapon.

You see, Elden Ring is an amazing game. It's a master class on design artistry and gameplay, and it is worth playing it just for that alone, but I'd like to focus this review on how enjoyable and rewarding the game can be. 

In several different moments of the game, I've been baffled by the unbalanced difficulty on certain spots of certain areas. It took me out of the immersion of the game when I had to just dash through all enemies without being able to explore the surrounding areas, or when I had to parkour to a place on the map where I could hit the enemy but the enemy could not hit me (including bosses). Farming and trying other builds did little difference.

Unlike other souls games, I did not feel like the questlines of most NPCs were rewarding. You'd receive items alright, but I felt like their story was lacking. And one of the only NPCs I really cared about got a terrible ending, despite me doing everything that they required of me to complete his questline. 

I understand that not all stories have to have a good ending but [SPOILERS] they didn't have to wreck master Hewg and Roderika like that. It felt like I've spent the whole game pursuing a power to change things to, possibly, the better, but all I achieved was a cutscene of my character sitting on a throne. I already have my life if I want to face misery and disgrace; I don't need a game to do that too.

There is literally no redeeming quality to this game:

- The "art" is more craft here, with 0 ability to edit or create anything that delivers any emotion. In trying to not deliver the "same thing" they delivered a gaudy pile of edge lording nonsense. - The combat is slow and deliberate as opposed to interesting and deliberate like most other games that deliver some reasonable pacing.
- It's open world but MYSTERIOUS so someone else can figure our the riddles and you can google a walk through like every JRPG from time immemorial. Great.
- There are words on the ground so you can know when to google and the reddit community can get a quick handjob sensation. Also a cheap excuse for the game to be always online.

One of the most grandiose games ever released. Providing a big ton of quality content in an open world that merges well the astonishment and the exploration of traversing the lands between with the hardship and the grim themes of previous FromSoftware titles. Yet, the game may always surprise you with the thought: "wait, there is more?"

PROS:
• Amazing art direction, making graphic quality secondary. They've really poured the worldbuilding, and especially the legacy dungeons, with love and all they learned from previous games.
• Build diversity. Its basically Dark Souls II 2, with every sort of build imaginable being viable, adding on topic that more complexity of combat with the increased amount of spells, combos, powerstancing, guard counter and jump.
• Its cinema! Elden Ring bosses are the most cinematic experiences among every FromSoftware games, leaving you in awe with the sheer creativity of the developers.

CONS:
• Soulslike gameplay, and especially replayablity, does not go along with open world. Cryptic questlines at FromSoftware's fashion are hard to memorize in such big map and may require looking through a guide. And in further NG cycles, crossing the lands between over and over may become tiresome.
• Rushed development. The late game areas, much like any other FromSoftware titles, were rushed, not delivering a satisfying exploration, with lack of unique enemies to that areas, and frustrating enemy placement that may not make sense at all.
• Poor multiplayer experience. Probably the worst co-op and invasion system of FromSoftware games. Having horse disabled in co-op halts shared progression by a lot in a big map like the lands between. Invasion being tied exclusively to co-op worlds greatly discourages this unique PvP experience that has been a staple in previous titles. Furthermore, ashes of war being overtuned lead to repetitive and uninteresting multiplayer fights due to the overuse of them, despite Elden Ring combat having more depth than every other souls games. AND BRING THE FIGHT CLUBS BACK.

I played DOTA 2 back on the WarCraft 3 days.  I wasn't an addict then.  Fasft forward to DOTA 2 release, I resisted playing.  Eventually my son asked to play a game that sounded to me like DOTA.  I been addicted ever since, and he's been playing since he was 6 years old.  The new patch I thought is a great way to freshen the game.  I hope they do radical changes like this every year to keep people into the game.   I see quite a few negative reviews.  Anyone who wants no change but is willing to play for 30 years can go back and play the WC3 with the mod, that thing is frozen in time forever.

I have to admit the game is starting to wane with me too, but thats not because of the changes.  Its hard to keep up with the game trends to remain relevant in playing.  

Kudos to the makers of DOTA 2., keep evolving!

best single player game i have ever played.

Story is the highlight in this game, does a pretty good job at it. This is not a game to play if you enjoy difficult combat however. 

I struggled for the first 5 or so levels, but soon as I figured out how monsters attack, it was pretty easy. The main problem with combat is that there are 2 major ways to nullify damage. 

The Quen sign makes it so that you can be greedy with your attacks, going in for extra hits all the time that would otherwise prove fatal in other games. Then there is the sheer ridiculous amount of invulnerability frames that you can achieve. Geralt doesnt use stamina at all for dodging, and you can quickly shift between a light attack to a dodge and back into attack way too quickly.

So the combat gameplay loop is basically just spamming dodges, quen sign, and light attacks. There is never any needs to parry or roll, never any real need to use any of the other signs. I found myself able to take on enemies that were 2 times my level.

Imagine you're working in a 9-5 corporate job, you're done with your work, you come back home, log onto Steam, see your games list for 5 seconds, buy a game on sale that you're never going to play and then switch off your PC and go to a bar. While having a drink, you think of the good times when games used to be fun and authentic. But then you tell yourself, the problem isn't the games, its you. "Its not that games aren't fun anymore, you have gotten older".

And then I play Witcher 3. And suddenly I can't wait to get myself home after work. Do you have any idea how precious that feeling is ? The feeling that you are actually immersed in the protagonist' shoes. I find myself in anticipation and excitement for the new adventures that are waiting for me, I think while driving back home...."Where is this story headed ? What new places and characters I will meet ?" And lets not talk about the characters. I thought myself as a guy who's dead on the inside and somehow these characters made me laugh, chuckle and empathise at the same time. I haven't felt these feelings for a game since 2008 when I played games such as Final Fantasy 12, Metal Gear Solid 3. Was I wrong to think that I was the problem and not the gaming industry that's shelling out mediocre AAA games with no memorable characters or storyline ?

And I got this game for 3$. 3$ !! And that includes the DLC ! I honestly feeling I looted these amazing devs. And I paid twice for games that are not even worth playing. 23 hours in and I still haven't scratched the surface of the story. The side quests are actually fun. I find myself doing the side quests more because its feels like I am watching another episode of the "Witcher 3 TV show". I love this open world, I actually take my time wandering around and exploring every nook and cranny. I haven't done this since GTA San Andreas. I look at some distant island or mountain that I find interesting and I decide to just walk there just for the fun of it. That's how beautiful this Open World this. This is Open World game done right.

Thank you CD Projekt Red. You guys are a gem. I know its 5 years late and I don't know why it took me 5 years to play this, but better late than never. <3

The witcher 3 wild hunt DELIVERS time and time again, every playthrough, something just a little different, and something just a little better than the last. This game truly is what set CDPR on the map for gaming due to its gorgeous graphics, and its amazing story telling. Finally, for me, a game that I can focus on the story primarily and not feel like i'm rushing this game. This is a game that delivers 80+ hours of STORY. 80 hours of the main quest and not including the side missions that you can get lost with. I love that the story missions are kept clean, meaning, I can take a break from the main story line and invest myself into a short but meaningful story line that doesn't feel like i'm starting a whole new plot. The DLC offers so much content, offers so much story, that they genuinely just fit with the main game. The stories intertwine with the main story at times and you forget that its extra content that didn't come with the base game. 

I will always recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played it yet, because its 2023, wdym you haven't played the witcher 3?? wtf is wrong with you??

Overrated as hell. Bad story, boring characters, unoriginal, non engaging combat, dull world, bad voice acting, 2/10. And that's me being nice. Can't even be compared to the likes of RDR2 and Elden Ring. The fact that this is considered one of the greatest games of all time is a joke. I can totally see why people would like a game LIKE this, but NOT THIS. If you want a good fantasy RPG, then play skyrim, elden ring, dragons dogma, dark souls, kingdom come, diablo 2, the list goes on. Literally anything but this. Geralt's voice has to be the most cliche, annoying, atrocious piece of voice acting I've ever heard. I don't know what the devs were thinking when they released this train wreck and called it a game. My biggest issue, probably, is the sex. There is too. much. sex. It dominates the story, ruins the side quests, and is just unrealistic. Half the time it feels like the only point in the game is too see how many people you can smash in an hour. I'm not saying that games aren't allowed to feature nudity, but there's just so much of it. I don't mean to sound like I'm just another Karen, on just another rant, and play this game if you want, not my buisness, but MY advice? Dont play this game. It really is absolute bull. Play want you want, watch what you want, read what you want. Don't let my personal opinion alter your choice. If you think it's a good use or your time and money? Go for it. Its just REALLY not for me.

masterpiece in all aspects

good story, but geralt is a boring af stick in the mud with no real redeeming qualities. He delivers every line flatter than a a coke thats been left open for 2 days. 

Then theres the combat system, yikes. 

A weird amalgamation of animations and hitbox based fighting means that you have no control over your attacks. Want to do a quick attack? its not ur choice. geralt will decide to do a spin move into a slice if you are slightly too far from your opponent for the normal quick attack. the animation cant be canceled, and provides no i frames. Because it auto selects instead of allowing you to choose which attack you want to fucking use, you have no capability to counter attack an enemy attempting a distanced heavy attack whith a quicker lighter attack. In turn this makes the combat feel clunky, and winning boss fights more of a matter of luck than it is skill. It also means you are not rewarded for learning enemy move sets and attempting to predict their next attack. the game punishes you for being a gamer essentially. 

Theres a ton of hype around this game, but to be honest its kind of a steaming pile of crap.

El gameplay, los paisajes y en combate junto con el soundtrack son una maravilla... Realmente un juego como los de antes, donde se nota el cariño que los desarrolladores pusieron para crearlo, un juego donde te da gusto pagarlo para apoyar a la gente que lo hizo...

Mis felicitaciones a CDprojekt por este juegaso que sin duda alguna es una obra maestra... No puedo puntuarlo con un número porque es un juego que va mas allá de eso, simplemente te voy a decir que realmente tenés que comprarte este juego y vivir lo que te ofrece!

Honestly it's by far the best game I have ever played. I always heard about the Witcher games especially the Third one but it never was my cup of tea. I was the fps kid that was playing battlefield, call of duty, counter strike etc. I was always sceptical about the game about a grumpy white haired prick slaying monsters with a freaking silver sword. I couldn't be more wrong. At first the game was a hard dive for me as I never played games like this, but hour after hour I sank in the immersive world presented by CD Project Red. It felt especially close to my heart as I am a Polish and polish dubbing combined with the cultural references were incredible. The story was understandable even for a guy who never read the books or played any other game from this universe. It is for sure the best thing about this game. Main story is brilliant but the DLCs might even be better. The choices You need to make really matter, but nothing is black or white so it isn't really a choice between being a douchebag or a stereotypical brave and selfless hero. Adding to that some choices really allow You to choose how You feel about the situation. I loved the moments  when I was irritated at some character and I had the opportunity to tell them thing or two and show them who the boss is. About the gameplay, it is simple, not overly complicated and because of that it works perfectly. It's just a typical dogde/block and hit combat mixed with using witcher signs(casting fire, using magical shield etc),  but yet I always considered it satisfying and rewarding. Really I can't believe and accept the fact that I've finished the game, as it really became a part of me. The characters you come across are that realistically written you feel like they actually exist. The story is amazing and the gameplay is satisfying. The graphics are also stunning! What can You expect more?  My only problem with the Witcher 3 is that I can't just reset my memory and truly play through this GOAT GAME one more time in my life.

1. A World Like No Other: The game's open-world environment is nothing short of breathtaking. The continent of Temeria is a sprawling, living and breathing world filled with diverse landscapes, cities, villages, and wilderness. Every nook and cranny is meticulously detailed, creating a sense of immersion that few games can match.

2. A Riveting Story: At the heart of "The Witcher 3" lies a captivating narrative. You play as Geralt of Rivia, a grizzled monster hunter and skilled swordsman. The quest to find your missing adoptive daughter, Ciri, leads to a sprawling, emotionally charged tale filled with political intrigue, moral dilemmas, and unexpected twists. The choices you make have far-reaching consequences, ensuring a deeply personal and memorable experience.

3. Memorable Characters: The game is populated with a cast of unforgettable characters, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations. From the witty and sharp-tongued bard Dandelion to the enigmatic sorceress Yennefer, and the roguish bard and friend Zoltan, you'll form deep connections with these characters as you journey through their stories.

4. Engaging Combat: Combat in "The Witcher 3" is a finely tuned blend of swordplay, magic, and alchemy. Geralt's combat abilities allow for flexibility in tackling foes, and each encounter feels challenging and rewarding. Preparing for battles with the right potions, oils, and signs adds depth to the combat system.

5. Stunning Visuals and Sound: The game's graphics are a visual feast, with detailed character models, breathtaking landscapes, and realistic weather effects. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack complements the fantasy world perfectly, enhancing the overall atmosphere.

6. Expansive Content: "The Witcher 3" is packed with content, including a main story that can take over 100 hours to complete, along with numerous side quests, monster hunts, and expansions that offer hours of additional gameplay. The "Hearts of Stone" and "Blood and Wine" expansions, in particular, are essentially full-fledged games in themselves.

Yes, but only at a deep discount. Maybe $15 tops. I have about 70 hours in, but don't load the game through Steam due to some mods.

I ran this on an R7 3700x with a 3070 and 32 GB of RAM. I game at 1080p with a wired PowerA and wired Xbox one controller. Running DX11 with no RT I was unable to get all settings to Ultra+. I have everything on Ultra but crowds on Ultra+. I was getting framerate crashes constantly, but oddly enough in areas that weren't very busy.  HBAO+ was unplayable on my system. Very poor optimization. 60 FPS at 1080 consistently on newer hardware was a struggle. Sadly, this is the new norm. Surprisingly, CP2077 runs much better on my system.

The good...

The story, the world, and the characters. CDPR is lucky to get great IP's for their games. They do an amazing job with them. There's so many great characters in the series. They're portrayed very well here. To modern game companies who struggle to write good female characters....here's a masterclass in how it's done. The world feels alive when it needs to. It's fully fleshed out. The writing on main and side quests is deeper than most games, and well fleshed out (this is what Ubi completely missed the mark on when copying this for the newer AC games.) There's also not nearly as many dropped button inputs common in most modern games. The world is beautiful, but that's not uncommon today. It's the new norm, and not very important to my experience (gameplay is far more important to me.) Gwent....nope...I didn't like Magic: The Gathering either, but it's good Gwent isn't forced on you to progress the story. Side content is also presented well in that you don't need to do it to progress the story (sadly another low standard in modern games.)


The ok...

The combat. I like it. It makes it feel live a vicious ballet. It has some problems with hit box detection (a common problem in every CDPR game.) The NG update made the signs far more usable. Ciri's story is a lot of fun, but could've been done better. You don't get access to any potions or items with her. You only get a new ability towards the end of her time. There should've been more progression on each part. This a game that requires a lot of time. Any main mission can easily last 60-90 minutes with minimal save points. I often have life going on around me, so I won't play any mission without at least an hour available. This may or may not affect you, so I put it in the middle. 


The bad...
It's an empty open world. It's not the worst thing, but traversing it feels bad. Roach sucks. His mechanics are about on a 2005 level of gameplay. Geralt's movement is also very clumsy. He goes from a crawl to a janky stutter in his movements. He gets caught on small objects constantly, He feels clumsy. It's another far out-dated mechanic I'd expect from a PS2 game. This combined with CDPR's poor hitbox detection can make it annoying to loot a crate. That leads into the loot. There's too much useless junk spread around a million crates in a room (the Witcher 1 had a better collection system than this.) The autoloot is essential because of this. The economy is about 25 to 1 on buying/selling prices (the first Witcher was about 5 to 1, and gamers are just used to grinding poor economies these days.) Fall damage can kill you easily considering it's so easy to fall/have your companion push off of something. The level of explaining the game is poor, which is also common these days (anyone who says older games didn't hold your hand is lying, as older games came with very detailed manuals explaining complex systems. This game's manual barely goes past explaining the HUD.) Nowadays devs would rather let Google sort it out then spend money making a manual. I'm not a fan of the way perks are used with the need for having load out slots, but that's me. Much like from the Witcher 1 to 2, my save didn't import this time either. Much like the Witcher 2, this game creates saves that can't be deleted. While I enjoyed the game enough, I didn't bother with the DLC, as the game just doesn't feel polished enough to make me care about continuing to play.

The game is fun, without a doubt. I recommend buying it. I just don't think it's a masterpiece. It's a mediocre game that can be enjoyed despite being made poorly. In a day where game stories are weak, and their worlds shallow, this game gets too many passes for it's low quality programming. It's a testament to modern shill media, and the effect on low standards in fans. I've played all the Witcher games, and CP 2077. The first Witcher was the best IMO because they used an existing engine, known for great games. They don't seem to understand game design without an existing winner of an engine.

If I butt hurt you on your favorite game, I'm not sorry. I've been playing games since the Magnavox Odyssey, and I call it like I see it. I can really like something, but see all it's faults.

Dark Souls is the worst game I've played in the souls-like genre.

I've enjoyed Elden Ring, Sekiro and Nioh massively but never played the DS series, so had high hopes for the widely acclaimed first game. Have to say it is a huge disappointment.

- I was prepared for clunky controls, but not something *this clunky*. Walking/running around is annoying slow. Input lags are even more severe than in Elden Ring. Rolling with the lightest armor felt like fat roll in ER. The combat was mediocre to start with and the controls just made it straight up painful.

- The game difficulty feels way too artificial and ultimately unfair. Git gud is only fun when you feel like you're moving toward achieving something. When you need to git gud just to avoid Crepe Demon's jump attack first thing you enter the door, you're just dealing with the game dev's malice and decide it's not worth it.

- Exploring the map was probably the only fun part but it is undermined by the lack of fast travel/means to avoid combat when moving between bonfires. I was trapped in the bonfire in upper blighttown for hours which basically ruined any excitement I had when I lit that bonfire. (ER/Sekiro have fast travel, for good reasons. Nioh doesn't have fast travel within a level but there's nijutsu that makes you invisible. Hollow knight has neither but running past enemies is way easier than in DS were you can barely run at all.)
confusing and long distances between checkpoints. great game to get frustrated with.

Never joined the hype train on this game over the years, but recently got curious and gave it a try. 48 hours in, I gave up and requested a refund. 
Simply put, this game is incredibly frustrating. You have to walk around vast areas without any saving spots just to be one-hit killed by some random low level enemy and walk all that way again.. Its just such a huge waste of your time, it's ridiculous. Not to mention boss fights, they're just boring.
Yes, it's supposed to be difficult and extremely challenging, and it delivers in that regard.
That being said, it's not what I personally consider a pleasurable gaming experience.
Maybe I'm a "filthy casual"? Perhaps. But if you play games to have a good time and relax, enjoy the visuals and dive into a immersive universe without having to deal with all the unnecessary stress this game brings, you'll do good to avoid it.
