Great remaster, was as good as I remember. I much prefer the more linear souls games over Elden Ring's open world. The warp mechanic is a little annoying in this one and some of the areas are frustrating to say the least. However, if you've not played the remaster, it's worth a play through!

Well, isn't that a shame. If Elden Ring was a recommendation with an asterisk, then this has to be a recommendation with three asterisks at least. Really, it barely eeks out a positive review on the strength of its level design (the structures are a joy to explore in principle) and the fun I had performing the rather consistent parries.

Apart from that, I finally get that age-old "artificial difficulty" argument. Of course, that's always going to be an extremely silly term to call it and thus easy to dismiss, but it does address a mixture of jank and tedium which frequently mars enjoyment of Dark Souls. A lot of the bosses aren't hard per se - being slow, predictable and having a limited moveset, though the DLC is much better in that regard - but they do often take a stupid amount of hits, all the while you have to ensure you don't perish to jank: Questionable hit boxes on certain attacks, stage hazards, getting stuck on random bits on the ground, the camera...

Combine that with boss runs (again, never hard, just tedious) and you're looking at a lot of wasted time, plain and simple. It doesn't help that you're controlling a character that moves like a wet sponge and seems incapable of scaling anything higher than a stair. Your character arguably performs better when keeping what you might foolishly assume are the key tools of locking on (the one useful thing about the O&S fight is that it teaches you to stop doing that) and rolling (since you take additional damage during it) to a minimum. Hence why I say that exploring is fun [i]in principle[/i]. Which is stupid, because you have to, since you're also dealing with general FromSoft obscurity. The bottom line is that Dark Souls isn't hard because it's such a challenging test of skill, it's hard because it's a psychological test of how much repeated BS you're willing to tolerate.

So, feel free to make ample use of guides, because this is a very cool game to experience in many instances. Not that I think you have to experience it yourself; I'd say it's perfectly fine to just watch someone else play it and spare yourself the firsthand frustration. I think between the parries, some fun fights in non-boss sections, most bosses thankfully being easy enough to only take a few tries and the fantastic level structure, I had barely enough fun to make this thumb point upwards, but a glowing recommendation this is not.

This was the first time I played a Souls game. They have been hyped up quite a lot, so I decided to delve into the worlds created by Miyazaki. Many have named the first game of the series as a masterpiece, and one of the greatest games ever made. Personally, I do not think that it actually is. But, it is a great game nonetheless, that reminded me of my early gaming days in the 90s.
The atmosphere is amazing, and the bleakness of the dying world slowly seeps into your soul. It is a difficult game but fair, despite some clunkiness. The majority of times that I died was either due to poor reaction times, or getting to greedy with my attacks and mismanaging my stamina. The only exception would be the Anor Londo Archers (yes, they deserve the capital letters). Lost almost 93000 souls to them and 12 humanity. 
Overall, I did not have much difficulty with the bosses. I beat Quelaag, Nito, Sif on my first try. Artorias, Manus, Kalameet and Ornstein and Smough on my third. And then we have the Capra Demon for 8 and the Bed of Chaos for 11... These two were a case of poor design. Especially in the case of the latter. In general, that part of the game seemed unfinished and it was a real slog. 
I certainly liked the challenge that the game presented me with. It was a long time since I had palpitations during a boss battle, and the exhilaration after I triumphed. This is the essence of Dark Souls. You get good. As simple as that. However, the quality of the game fluctuates especially in the second half. But, I would highly recommend this game simply because the feeling of overcoming the challenges it throws at you is simply the best. Can't wait to move on to the rest of the series, then Sekiro and finally Elden RIng.

[h3]Dark Souls: Remastered can be easily compared to drinking a six-pack of beer.[/h3]
[b]In the first part,[/b] you feel great and chug another beer after another.
[b]In the second half,[/b] you start feeling bad, but at this point, you just push so it doesn't go to waste.
The same can be said for the so-called "remastered" title. 
It's like one of your favorite beers suddenly got a new formula, but after buying it you don't even feel the difference. 
Maybe it's just slightly worse, but you feel like it's just the same beer but in a new can.

Just like with alcohol, you will either like it or not. 
It may be strong, even too strong for you, but with time it can change to be one of your favorite drinks to-go.

This game reminded me of what it means to love games again. The never-ending desire to play more, the repeated question of what could possibly next and an immersion in a fake world that I have not felt in a long time.

The game is Brutal, but it's worth every minute of anger and grinding your teeth cause that dopamine hit is better than drugs.

The Story-telling although mostly through item descriptions and dialogue you have to do special requirements for, is truly a tale worth unpacking as their is a lot to be found within. And is a testament to how thought out the world your playing in is, which just adds to the experience.

I realize I'm very late to this party and obviously got my money's worth on this game (judging by my play time), but I still came away from it with a bad taste in my mouth. I feel that, despite this game's good qualities, it still has a bunch of indisputably bad design decisions that I never hear anybody talk about, so I want to complain about them here.

I wrote an even longer review than this, but it ended up being too long for Steam. So instead of my usual list of pros and cons, I'll just list the bad design decisions that I feel people tend to overlook when extolling this game.

--- Bad design decisions featured in this game:

- As someone who mostly plays single-player games, this first point is one I am emphatically passionate about: if a game is presented as single-player, it should be playable without needing help or advice from other players (specifically, without needing to refer to a wiki). If the game doesn't give me the necessary tools to figure out everything for myself, if I need to read a wiki or find hints left by other players to learn basic information about a game, then that game is badly designed. Arbitrarily hiding information from players isn't making a game "full of secrets" or "mysterious", it's just making it obtuse and inaccessible. Without checking the wiki, there is no way for you to know:
        - How many souls a soul in your inventory is worth before using it (or until Frampt is available). This is especially true for boss souls (since the amount Frampt gives is not always the same as how much it's actually worth).
        - Which upgrade path for a weapon is best (you can only see how the weapon's stats change when upgrading to the next level, not the maximum number of levels nor the stats for each level). Additionally, once a weapon is upgraded, it's impossible to know whether a newly acquired weapon can be upgraded higher than the already-upgraded one or not. There is NO REASON this information couldn't have been made available in the game, and the game is not better or more fun for having this information withheld.
        - The necessary ingredients for boss weapons. The game won't even show which boss weapons can be crafted if you don't have the correct kinds of ingredient weapons in your inventory.
        - That equipment load affects run speed and roll speed. Also, there is no in-game way to know equipment load levels, which determine whether you do a fast/medium/slow roll. Considering how central combat and rolling are to this game, this is a major, inexcusable oversight.
        - What staggering is, and when/why some enemies stagger.
        - What being "hollowed" is, why this is relevant to the story, why the player character being hollowed is different from enemies being hollowed, or why enemies only attack you but not each other.
        - That being un-hollowed allows summoning help in boss fights. There is no other benefit to being un-hollowed (as it allows invasions), so it's easy to go through the entire game without realizing this.
        - That there are illusory walls (if you haven't discovered any by accident).
        - What invasions are, or when they are NPCs (which can be reasonably defeated by a sufficiently skilled player) or other human players (who have no visual indication of power level and may easily one-shot an unprepared player out of nowhere).
        - Which items are dropped by which enemies and how often. This is particularly important if certain weapon upgrades require rare materials, but there are not enough of them in chests around the world to fully upgrade a weapon (without going through the hassle of new game plus), so you need to grind certain enemies to get enough of them. There's no reason the game couldn't have had a codex that gets filled out with enemy information as you defeat them.
	
Besides hiding useful information from players for no reason, this game has plenty of other bad, stupid, and unjustifiable design choices:

- The game's entire move set is dumped on you in the very first level. If you don't master jumping and parrying, you may never be able to get back to this area to see the instructions.

- This game has no story, just unrelated events that happen in sequence. The "story" - if it can be called that - merely consists of the player character traveling to a series of different regions and killing boss monsters, usually without any information on who these monsters are, why they were important, nor whether the player character has any idea why they're doing this in the first place (aside from, "Well, I'm playing a video game and I guess this is the way forward."). This is where defenders of the game will give the weak counterargument that the story is in the flavor text of in-game items. To this I reply: reading item descriptions is a mediocre excuse for storytelling. Compare this to the storytelling in Subnautica or Skyrim: all information necessary to those stories is presented through dialogue and cut scenes, and most text is just for additional flavor and worldbuilding. And - most crucially - this information is presented in places where you'd actually think to look, like in-world books or highlighted entries in a codex, not fricken' item descriptions which are so often unhelpful, boring, or obtuse that you just learn to ignore them. Integrating storytelling with gameplay is the superior approach, and if Dark Souls had been well-made enough to do things this way, its fans wouldn't need to defend it. Extra points are deducted for weapons that have special effects which are only documented in flavor text.

- The fantasy elements in this game don't feel like they're from the same world. Sure, each different monster looks unique, but the bosses in particular feel like a grab-bag of fantasy elements, not parts of a consistent style or system.

- The world doesn't feel alive. All characters and enemies are just standing in place waiting for the player to come along and interact with them. Compare this to Skyrim, where NPCs have set routes and will walk from their house to work and back, or will even join you on quests to other locations. Additionally, the various towns you walk through in Dark Souls do not look like they were designed for actual people to live in (no beds, no bathrooms, no markets, unnatural layouts). This makes them feel very artificial and video-gamey.

- If you don't understand how "builds" work (that is, upgrading your stats to focus on damage vs. speed vs. magic), you can get yourself into a situation where you have to grind a lot to be reasonably leveled. Magic is particularly clunky to use in this game: you have to stand still in place for a second or two to cast any spell. Considering this leaves you wide open to backstabs and that enemy attacks can interrupt the spell, it doesn't seem balanced compared to combat. So in the early game if you spend several upgrade points on magic in the hopes it will get more powerful later, all that time and grinding will prove to be a waste, and will increase the cost of future upgrades for the stats that actually matter.

- There are places where you have to sit and wait for 30 seconds to be transported somewhere. In all other situations in this game, if something doesn't immediately happen when you take an action, this means you're missing a necessary item or have to complete some task elsewhere first. Having places in the game where you actually need to wait 30 boring seconds doing nothing is inconsistent and infuriating.

- The process for accessing the DLC (Oolacile and the Abyss) is unjustifiably obscure. It requires revisiting the least fun area in the whole game and killing a specific but otherwise nondescript enemy for no discernible reason. This isn't fun or challenging, it's just obtuse and inaccessible. (Plus, the process for downing Kalameet is similarly obscure and arbitrary.)

I had a really good review for this game, but for some dumb reason I decided to change it to a dumb Dark Souls quote.

After playing through to the end of Dark Souls: Remastered, facing the 4 lords and learning the attack patterns of enemies I must say this is an excellent title. I like the lore, even though is can be very vague and the universe itself is shrouded in mystery, decay and hopelessness, but in the same vain there is still "hope" in the kindling of the first flame, there is beauty in the broken landscapes and dilapidated structures, Anor Londo was a big focal point of the game, at least when establishing the "ruling hand" of Lordran. When understanding the dynamic between the ruling class, what happened during the ancient Dragon wars involving the everlasting Dragons and the 4 Lords, as well as Gwyn, it makes you really feel just how bad things had become when you come in.

Gameplay in my opinion is SLOW, compared to even Dark Souls II SoTFs, and a snails pace compared to the likes of DSIII and Elden Ring. I won't say it's a bad thing, as it was much more challenging than Elden ring, the 4 Lords were easy enough even without help. The bed of chaos was, something? I feel that could've been done better. Gravelord Nito was difficult at first, but slow, and like much of the rest of the bosses, once you learn his attacks, and when to dodge, he becomes trivial. The four kings were more difficult, as at the time I'd say I was under-prepared in terms of DMG output, and as you continue to fight them off more "clones" appear. This was annoying to say the least, but he went down after a couple attempts. Lastly, Seath the scaleless was an okay fight, the curse infliction was a difficult obstacle, but once again, a couple attempts and a few thousand souls to level, he too went down.

The only negative things I can say about the game, is the collision of weapons in small corridors, on posts, objects etc. This has killed me many a times, but it is avoidable with proper kiting. 
I've mentioned it before, in my previous review. Invasions suck. It wouldn't need to be that way, If the latency wasn't such an issue. This seems to be an issue in DS 1-3 and I can't really see it any other way. Getting struck through blocks, getting struck when obviously out of range of an attack, it's not fun. Thankfully, you don't NEED to be human for any apparent buffs or bonuses, unlike in later titles. 

I think if you enjoy the fantasy genre, and want to challenge yourself as a gamer, give Dark souls a try. If you get mad take a break and come back later, I can certainly see why this game is held with such high regard.

I have played Dark Souls more than any other Fromsoft game and while I don't think it is objectively their best work I can't help but feel the same charm I did back in 2011 when I first launched the game on our PS3 with my dad. This game has had a huge influence on my taste in games and is one of my favorite games of all time. It also introduced me to one of my favorite developers of all time. I can not recompensed this game enough.

'A magnificent action-RPG that redefined and re-contextualized the importance of difficulty in videogames', THIS is the basic gist/summary I have heard from countless sources, now that I am finally playing it, I can see the appeal, It's difficult but fair, It likes to troll with you but also gives you a meaningful sense of accomplishment, there will be times where you will be genuinely stuck in an area or a boss for hours, this is where the community aspect as well as online aspect of the game comes into play, this makes the game a social experience yet no one ever talks with you, with the exception of gestures, interactions are limited yet sense of connection with people who are going through the same ordeal as you, feels tangible.

> Level design is excellent many areas in the game are built like a maze - essentially... a single area, say, shrine for example can lead to a dozen different places all interconnected in their own intricate ways.
> Graphics and lighting are excellent for a seventh gen console title, and still looks great. thanks to the games moody and interesting art direction,
> There is a looot of content in this game to dabble into....
> Sound and music is great though not amazing, it works and compliments the world.
> It is a story light game, there is a ton of lore here for the curious ones...
> Bosses are the real highlight of this game
>There is a slight bit of jank to movement...it is certainly not a platformer, but you can get used to it as you play...

....Haven't completed the game yet, but i highly recommend this to anyone that likes a good challenge, a good rpg and an amazing world to explore...

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

First off, lemme preface this by stating that this is far superior to the Scholar version by a long shot. Let's go through the positives and negatives of this game.

Positives:

-Smoothest difficulty curve in the franchise.
-Creative and unique boss encounters.
-Fantastic level structure.
-Rich lore being amongst the most intriguing in the series.
-Large diversity of fun and creative character builds

Negatives:

-Adaptability is a concept that should've been explained a little better and refined more.
-Questionable hit detection if Adaptability isn't at 20 at least.
-Lifegems are a good idea but feel like a band-aid solution to lack of healing options
-The structure of the world can make it feel a little disjointed and confusing without a guide.

Overall, this is a worthy sequel to the fantastic Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition, and while it does stumble in a couple areas, I still feel like this game should have a lasting legacy as a diamond in the rough alongside Fallout New Vegas when it comes to rushed game development.

Dark Souls 2 gets some heat for being a "B-team project" that "Miyazaki Hidetaka didn't even work on", so "it isn't even a real Dark Souls game", some of which is true, but hear me out: as many differences as this game has from Dark Souls 1, it is still a Souls game, and it is still a good game. The net code, last I checked, was leagues better than the last game, and the work in so many aspects was such a jump in quality in only three years. The team really put their elbow grease into this, and it shows. 

The various gameplay changes-- such as the introduction of life gems, power stance, and two extra ring slots --were interesting and engaging, and while some were left behind, others made it into games that followed. Dark Souls 2 was daring and that was, more often than not, rewarded. 

It's a whole different world in there, and buddy, it's worth exploring.

A game that has a legendary reputation in the Souls community and for good reason. It is seen as the worse Souls game in the entire franchise and I can't really fault anyone for saying that but I will defend that it is a good game at it's core still. The major problems this game faces are it's reliance on Humanoid/Armored boss fights compared to other games where it had a good ratio of monsters and humanoid, it's janky hit-boxes that will get you hit when you are not actively in a spot anymore (I have a theory on that), and it's rather bland map choices and inconsistencies. On the first point yeah there are way too many boss fights against dudes in armor. Even though most have different movesets it is not fun to fight them. The second is the hit box issues. When you dodge roll away or even the enemy does a wide swing and you aren't there you will get hit by their attacks sometimes. For me the worst offender here was the Smelter Demon whom you already have to fight in a tight ass room, you don't need this bullshit to make you second guess how well you are doing. The theory I have is two pronged. I think that the hit-boxes for some enemy weapons are more squared instead of being their weapons shape. So imagine a sword but it hit's like a rectangular plank in terms of size. Even if you dodge the point of the sword if you get hit by the invisible corner of the plank then it counts as a hit. The other issue is the new stat Adaptability which gives you more I frames when dodge rolling. In theory the game will give you more the more you put in and even though it says it does I think it derps out sometimes and reverts it to the base low dodge chance and will make you get hit when you should be in the middle of invincibility. I could be wrong on both fronts but that's the best I could think of after 7 runs on the PS3 and PC of this version of DS2. The final complaint is the maps and yeah I can't understand what they were thinking for some of these areas. Some are absolutely some of the coolest in the series and others are the absolute worst. One in particular has my ire and that would be the Black Gulch. Its essentially a long straight area with a few places to explore on the sides. It is surrounded by statues that spit poison at you that stun lock you sometimes if you get hit, oil on the ground that houses trap enemies, worms that come out of the walls that smack you off the sides to your death, and a Boss that is so boring I would skip every time if I could. Now that I've shit on this game for a while let's talk about some of the positives for a bit. It introduces a mechanic that makes it my favorite Souls game to try builds with, the ability to RESPEC! I don't know why for the life of me From refused to put this in the other games but this is an absolute game changer. For one playthrough I would play a mage, another my best Guts cosplay, and another a holy cleric out to smite the heathens of the land (before the heavy lightning nerfs hit anyway). Definitely adds to the replayability. It also has some of the coolest fights I've seen in a while with the Mirror Knight bringing back a mechanic from Demon's Souls. The combat is livened up a bit with the ability to dual wield certain weapons together to create new combos to overwhelm enemies easier. The story and characters are relatively weak as far as these games go but I did like Lucatiel and the Maiden. For all the shit this game gets (rightfully so in some areas) as a Souls fan I would still say it is worth playing. Now as you have the option of picking this or the SOTFS edition that version made things a lot better by adding new balancing and enemy placement but I would almost say play both if you can just to see the changes yourself. For this version though as it stands today I wouldn't recommend for more than $30 for the complete package. Also a note, From has shut down the servers to this game "temporarily" but that's looking like we might not see them come back, making some of the achievements damn near impossible to get because of poor item drop rates. If you are a hunter please be aware of this.

Contrary to popular belief, I think this game is a good sequel and it stands the test of time. It is quite challenging and a blast to play after learning the ins and outs of the game. If you like to play games that are brutally unforgiving at times, this is for you! You will die many times lol

So, the game isn't bad in any way. I'd say, it's enjoyable, a very good RPG and soulslike. It takes skill and understanding. Patience and planning is mandatory, without it it's just pure frustration. Not as hard as I thought it would be (Scholar of The First Sin didn't do it any favours). It has more to offer than DS1, but it's executed worse. Also the graphics feel downgraded and upgreded at the same time compared to the first enstallement, which I find odd but fascinating. The art style is... unique I say. Enemy design is good. Boss design is acceptable, with a few golden examples and quite a lot truly AWFUL encounters, that make you question how fair the game was made. The main problem is often too many enemies.
Story is good, better than in the DS1 i'd say. Some new mechanics are truly creative and some just... Makes you want not to play this game.
Overall, it's 75/100, which makes it the second worst out of the Souls Series, a few levels above Scholar of The First Sin edition. Buy the base version with DLC than that pile of garbage.

Great game overall, but I can see why some Dark Souls fans don't like it. I think it's also important to recognize all of the cool features that this game pioneered, like power stancing, bonfire ascetics, and different level layouts on New Game+. Heck, two out of three of those awesome features haven't even been done in any other Souls game, which is a missed opportunity. Plus, this game has a great and interesting story more concerned with the unending flow of time and the slow erosion of memory than any of the other Dark Souls games.

 If you're a big time Souls fan, you owe it to yourself to check this one out. But if you've never played a Souls game before, I'd say go try Elden Ring first.

[h1] The Elden Ring Beta [/h1] 
Dark Souls II has a bad reputation in the souls community despite it being highly praised upon release. This still persists today although is slowly diminishing. It suffers from what most sequels do; having to live up to expectations. It has to be challenging, it has to have more of everything; Lore, Bosses, Weapons, Armour, Quests, Areas, NPCs, Magic!

DS2 is in a sense a beta version of Elden Ring but it failed to meet the lofty expectations because of poor leadership; and too big a scope for the technology and experience they had at the time.

Despite all this it's most certainly worth the money and the time; it's a great game that experiments with the Dark Souls formula and succeeds in many areas just as much as it fails. 

The only thing that disappoints me about it is knowing what could have been had they been more experienced at the time and didn't squander so many years of development.

Actually even more disappointing than that is the fact that in Dark Souls 3 FromSoftware seemed to be scared to break the mould again and not only retcons the vast majority of the story and lore of DS2 but constantly leverages cheap call-backs to DS1 instead of being creative and giving us entirely fresh stories and locations free of the shackles of the previous titles; Something they are very capable of as shown by other works: Bloodborne and later Sekiro.

Different from Dark Souls 1, where Stamina and Health are all you need to finish the game, Dark Souls 2 was balanced correctly and each status can give you advantages. My recommendation on this game is to - restart every time you feel your character out performing some boss. Play around with the stats, learn the strengths and weakness from each boss, choose multiple weapons - only one single option is not enough for all the encounters. Some enemies are placed on hard to reach places, and having ranged weapons makes easy to defeat them, but you don´t want to go full ranged or it will be hard to fight against bosses.

Dark Souls 2, offers a world inspired by mortality, ancient gear, the occult, medieval architecture, and danger. The world does not offer guidence, and relies on persistence to overcome uncertainties.
The characters are off-putting. They have grim, personal, and convoluted background stories.

During play, explore the world, revisit locations, uncover gear, and become more powerful through combat. Slaying adversaries will strengthen a protagonist, and slain adversaries will reappear eventually.
To win, journey through a maze of different areas, and to the final chamber. This path becomes increasingly more difficult to get through.

It is possible to empower and modify a protagonist, and battles push back a protagonist's progress when it is killed.
Both enemies and allies may be encountered.

The Dark Souls series is something completely different from any other game I have played so far. But don't get me wrong, this peculiarity is not due to its complex levels and bosses, that is something that any Mario Bros or Ninja Gaiden has. What made Dark Souls different and preferable to me was the way the story mode intertwined with the multiplayer in either cooperative or competitive mode: having to fight against an other human player or back to back with a sunbro in order to progress through the level, the rewards you could get for playing online which could be extremely useful in both pve and pvp, the variety of ways in which multiplayer could be played represented a significant amount of the fun I would find in this series of games and the main reason I played them again and again, experimenting new and different builds which could be more or less adequate to different covenants and multiplayer play stiles.

[h3]My Dark Swols Experience:[/h3]

This game is a masterpiece, and everyone knows that. So, let me just share my personal [i]Dark Swols[/i] experience. For those unfamiliar, it involves doing 10 push-ups, pull-ups, or any exercise reps each time you die in the game. After stumbling upon a Steam review about it, I decided it would be cool to give it a shot. After all, I did git gud through my experiences with Dark Souls 1, 2, and Elden Ring, so I wasn't dying frequently in this game. Surely, it wouldn't be that hard... I couldn't have been more mistaken. It turned out to be a grave miscalculation, as the game grew progressively more challenging, pushing me to my limits, especially during certain boss fights. I became excessively cautious and significantly extended the game's duration for me, much more than I should have. But in the end, I finally did it, and my god, it was such a journey.

I recommend taking on this challenge for a more suffering-inducing adventure. If mental strain alone isn't sufficient for you, add a physical dimension to it as well. [i]Git gud or git ripped, casul![/i]

Dark Souls III has changed my perspective on what a video game can be. The bleak atmosphere contrasts perfectly with the feeling of achievement when beating a difficult section of the game. One piece of advice for new players: Don't ignore the online experience like I did for my first couple of playthroughs. Playing together with other players can be a lot of fun and the PvP is very rewarding.

If the first Dark Souls depicted a world gracefully drifting towards the apocalypse, Dark Souls 3 shows one on a spiraling, feverish descent directly into it. It’s a fierce and punishing behemoth that dares you to take a step forward before knocking you back, again and again and again. But with a bleak, yet beautiful world that’s enthralling to explore and packed with secrets to find, I always felt compelled to come back, eager for that familiar thrill of overcoming even the most exacting challenges.

Dark Souls 3 does suffer from occasional framerate dips and a few underwhelming boss fights, but beyond that, its epic scale, aggressive obstacles, and rich development of existing lore make it the grandest and fiercest Dark Souls adventure yet.

The Kingdom of Lothric and the lands that lie beyond contain some of the most visually striking places developer From Software has ever crafted. Even though many of its locations do recycle ideas from familiar locales (like the Catacombs and yet another poison swamp), they're distinguished well enough to feel distinct from their past game parallels. There was never a moment when I didn’t feel captivated by their strong sense of place and the amount of gorgeous detail put into each environment. I stared out in awe atop the crumbling medieval stronghold of the High Wall, taking in the view of its surrounding valleys and snow-capped mountains, while all around me the fort’s frenzied denizens turned to stone and wood mid-prayer. I trudged through the poison swamps of the Road of Sacrifices while battling seething, cross-bearing beasts, braved Irithyll’s chilling, Tower of Latria-like dungeon, and got lost in a multi-story maze of curse-ridden bookshelves in the Grand Archives.

Every level is not only full of breathtaking architectural marvels and the most minute environmental embellishments, but also dense with things to do and see from moment to moment. But those views are more intense than Dark Souls 3 can handle – dramatic framerate dips (which we saw even on an ultra-high-end PC with two GeForce GTX Titan Zs) caused a lot of these fantastic looking areas to drag along, sometimes down to 20 to 25 FPS. But the rest of the time, when it is running at a smooth 60 (on PC only), Dark Souls 3 is a sight to see.

Exploration of the aforementioned places is the cornerstone of this series, and Dark Souls 3’s world does a lot to reward an inquisitive and thorough nature. You could spend hours in a single area, diligently investigating every dark corner or side road, and be consistently rewarded with some interesting story revelation, new gear, mini bosses, and even entire secret areas. Illusory walls make a triumphant return, driving me to compulsively slash away at suspicious-looking dents or bricks in search of precious equipment. I got a pretty high rate of return on doing that, too, from the earliest levels to the very late game. Crystal lizards also must have had a breeding season, because there are a ton of them slithering around, ripe for the slaying and with lots of twinkling titanite for leveling up special weapons.

Dark Souls 3’s world isn’t as openly interconnected as that of Dark Souls 1 (where you can freely move between high and low-level areas), but individual areas still weave their own branching paths together seamlessly, creating twisting mazes of overlapping passages and shortcuts that were a joy to lose myself in. Perhaps it’s because of this lack of interconnectivity that Dark Souls 3 feels larger than the first game. Early and late-game levels don’t directly connect as often, so the more you progress linearly from level to level, the farther it seems like you’ve journeyed.
Your progress is marked by massive landmarks, which lend the world a cohesive quality. In several early levels, I could maintain sight of the High Wall from which I’d originally come; while trying to extinguish a series of beacons as part of the entry process for a boss, I scaled a huge ladder through the thick canopy of trees blocking my view and could see clearly where I was in relation to the first level. I recalled seeing nearly this exact place too, from another spot on the High Wall.

This solid sense of space and geography elevates Dark Souls 3’s level design beyond the relatively weak blueprint of Dark Souls 2, making a mostly triumphant return to the kind of large-scale, world-focused journey of Dark Souls 1. Perhaps the only things sadly missing from Dark Souls 3’s environments are the kind of interesting platforming challenges present in places like Dark Souls 1’s Sen’s Fortress or Crystal Cave.

Kindling Friendships
There are plenty of interesting characters to meet throughout Dark Souls 3, some new and some returning. The voice acting is great as always and characters have a ton of dialogue to exhaust, offering up plenty of new emotes to perform, dropping useful hints about the world and your role in it, and generally cementing themselves as the next in a line of odd, yet lovable Souls personalities. Like in past games, NPC questlines remain mysteries to be solved over the long term of your adventure, so in my first 35-hour playthrough they weren’t all completed. I let a couple characters die because of my failure to encounter them in certain areas or meet certain circumstances, but in keeping with true Dark Souls fashion, even death has its rewards: those conclusions still had something interesting to offer in the way of tragic closure, sometimes tied to other plot details in startling ways, or neat new items. 

I look forward to following these questlines more closely in future playthroughs, but I worry that a few bugs I ran into in my first one might impede that. Early on, one particularly sneaky character appeared to ask me for forgiveness for a past misdeed, but it was my first time meeting him in Dark Souls 3. I later found out that he was supposed to show up at a certain spot much earlier, but he must’ve missed his cue. Another character who showed up after I’d spoken to a covenant leader swore the two of us were enemies from then on, even though I had never met her prior to that. I wasn’t even part of the covenant – even though joining any one of Dark Souls 3’s eight covenants is now as convenient as snapping a badge in place in your inventory, I hadn’t done that here. But I suppose for this disgruntled NPC, just talking to the leader is good enough.

The Art of the Kill
The brutality of Dark Souls 3’s worlds and the beasts that roam there are matched only by its vicious new moves called weapon arts, which add variety and style to an already strong combat system: one moment I’m crushing enemies with the devastating weight of my greatsword, the next I’m turning the giant hunk of curved steel into a graceful propeller of destruction.

Executing these skills use up focus points (FP), the newly added blue bar below your HP and above your stamina that also acts as mana for casting spells and pyromancies. When your FP runs out, some weapon arts, like the aforementioned greatsword propeller (Exiled Greatsword – seriously, use it), start costing stamina instead – a sensible and acceptable trade-off. Certain other skills, like a lightning spear that lets you charge at enemies with an electrifying blast, let you complete the move without the elemental damage until you recover FP, so running out of FP isn’t necessarily urgent or mood-killing. It becomes far more important when you’re a spellcaster, because the amount of spell charges you have depends on FP, but the system is actually more generous than it is limiting. That’s because of a new reusable item called Ashen Estus.

Should you get it: Yeah
Should you play it as the first Dark souls: Maybe.. This is in my opinion the easiest dark souls to learn as you are not dropped into the deep end nearly as much as Dark souls 2 nor are you faced with the lack of "quality of life" features of Dark souls 1, however it is the hardest dark souls to play. 
Does it have the Bosses design of DS1: partially, it's hit or miss
Does it have the weapon diversity of DS2: Yes but closer to the "this is an [x] but different" feel of DS1
Does it feel like a Dark Souls: Yes, in my opinion it seems to capture the feel of both 1 and 2 but also add a strange finality.

After beating all the bosses in the base game + its DLCs I gotta say:
This game is overhyped as hell.
As the [i][b]FINAL DARK SOULS GAME[/b][/i], it doesn't feel like it's very final. For a franchise that prides itself on difficult boss battles, and for just being difficult generally, I didn't find it all that hard (save select bosses [i] from the DLC[/i] and base game).
I don't think its difficulty being relatively easier than the other FromSoft titles I've played wouldn't be as much of an issue if it weren't [b][i]THE FINAL DARK SOULS GAME[/i][/b], yet I still had a decently fun time with it.
This is a recommendation with a citation that [i]the base game[/i] isn't that difficult, but the DLC elevates it slightly higher due to its bosses.
Don't make the same mistake I did thinking this would be a grandiose, balls-to-the-walls finale in the base game; play the DLC, and it gets brought up from a C to a B+ (if I had to give it a letter grade).
Horror juego, hay que terminarlo.

After getting all achievements for this game, I can confidently say this game is one of the best in the franchise. The bosses are consistently great with very few bosses that are poorly designed. Even with Elden Ring, there is still some challenge to DS3 and is definitely worth picking up if you haven't played before. The only slight issue I have is that the map layout was nowhere near as interconnected as the likes of DS1, but this game makes up for it with the quality of bosses and NPCs. I will give this game an 8.5/10

Here are my personal strengths and weaknesses for this game.

Pros:
- Great boss fights, some of my favourite bosses of all time are from this game.
- Very memorable NPCs and characters with fun side quests
- Very good progression system which isn't too confusing and isn't too basic
- Areas are visually amazing. as well as an amazing soundtrack 

Cons:
- Linear map design, not as intricate as previous titles but there's still elements of exploration

The dark souls games are not as good as the reviews they generally get. They are not as much hard as they are a game of memorization. Once you know where the enemies are and what their attack patterns are, it is relatively easy. Until then, you will die over and over in cheap ways because the game is intentionally designed to be annoying on your fist play-though.

There have been so few changes to the core mechanics of the game since the original Dark Souls. It almost feels like a DLC for the original game that just added more content. There are so many game mechanics that could improve these games so they are not a chore to play through the first time, but multiple games in and they have yet to change anything, and fans of the franchise are so stubborn that they refuse to admit the franchise's shortcomings. Here are just a few ideas that would make the Dark Souls games infinitely better:
[list]
    [*]Speed up the process of restarting. Don't make me wait for slow animations like standing up from a bonfire. reduce the size of the maps so there is less walking. Make the menus quicker. Add an option to immediately respawn when you die rather than having to wait multiple seconds while it slowly shows "you died." It just all needs to be sped up a lot.
    [*]Add friendly fire for enemy attacks. then we could learn attack & hitbox timing while playing it safe and manipulating enemy positions
    [*]Add a time rewind mechanics (like Prince of Persia)
    [*]Add a ghost mode trigger-able from fire pits that lets you explore ahead to analyze the map without interacting with anything, and upon leaving ghost mode you would return to the fire pit you triggered it from
    [*]Add a meditation mode trigger-able from fire pits that lets you train against enemies so you can learn their attacks before facing them for real
    [*]Add a spell in the beginning of the game that reveals (wall hacks) all enemies for a period of time
    [*]Add a Libra spell obtainable in the beginning of the game (see Final Fantasy if unfamiliar with "Libra")
    [*]Add a ghost clone spell (similar to the clone ability in Halo Reach) that creates a ghost  clone of your character that runs forward and agro enemies so you can see the enemies and prepare
    [*]Add teleportation spells (similar to "mark" and "recall" in Elder Scrolls: Morrowind) that let you warp backwards to re-assess your situation if you are surprised by a new enemy
    [*]Add an icon that shows how many enemies are currently agro-ed to you (similar to most stealth games such as Shadow Of Mordor)
    [*]Add a spell, character upgrade, or game setting that adds a mini map that highlights enemy locations/directions
    [*]Add a way to find bonfires so you don't accidentally skip them
    [*]Add an item that will automatically trigger a dodge or perfect block before you would take damage but prevents you from attacking. This way you can learn the timing of the enemy hits and then unequipped the item when you are ready to go on the offensive.
    [*]Add circles around enemies to show their agro ranges
[/list]
Any/all of these mechanics would make the game less about memorization, and it would make death more justified as you would have an actual chance to avoid it your first play-though.

The physics have always sucked in every dark souls game. Several of your deaths are bound to be due to the piss poor physics such as not being able to run over a 0.5ft obstacle on the ground. The real enemy in these games is the god damn furniture.

The game also has numerous technical issues. The game has really bad screen tearing that require you to go into Nvidia Control Panel and force VSYNC to be enabled. The sound effects also often glitch out when multiple sound effects play at once. The game is also locked at 60 FPS and while it doesn't have very much slowdown, it shouldn't be locked to 60 FPS in the first place. This is a AAA game; it should have an unlocked framerate. There are mods out there to unlock it, so why have they not done so to the official release?

One of the biggest complaints I have though is that the game does not support cloud saves. If you uninstall the game or move the installation you can lose your entire save data. You cannot play the same character on both your Steam Deck and your PC because there are no cloud saves.
I can't stop playing this amazing game.

Well, as you saw, my LOVE of HK is just show on my playtime.
My best friend introduced me the HK and when I saw his playtime is 99 hours, then I know it must be a legendry game……I trusted him so much that I forgot there was another possibility is that, the game may be too difficult to pass. Well, I just found it out when I was exploring the Crossroads. Like too expensive to buy crucial map tools, too easy to die, and had LITTLE guide. I can hardly remember how I get through these difficulties at first, all painful memory like being killed by the Groze Mother and False Knight and Hornet, again and again, and spending hours and hours in exploring the map and dying and back to the bench and setting off again. 
I had asked myself that, so hard and so much death the game brought me, then why I never give up and lay on the bench forever? It mustn’t be I have a knack on setbacks.
Then I came to realized that there is love, my love for HK grows more and more as I traveled farther and farther from the Crossroad. I love the raindrops in the City of Tears, the sparkle crystal on the Peak. I love adventure in the bugs’ world, greenly and lively the Greenpath, snowy and windy forever at the Kingdom’s Edge, bubbles and dreamlike fog flow in the Canyon. And surely I can’t forget to love those soft and cute fungus and grace mantis and furry bees in the Hive. When the unique BGM of every area flows, 
There is still something more than love. MOVED. Quirrel, Hornet, Myla, Cloth, Cornifer, Grimm and the shop keepers. They are just alive, and help me a freshman in the Hollownest. I still remember the first NPC I met, the Elderbug, I talked with him and he told me to sit on the bench, be a company with him. When I was tired of risk in the underground, I’d like to sit there for a while. It feels that the bench in Dirtmouth is another homestay. I can’t forget the beautiful voice from Myla either, I like her song most in the Hollownest world. She has a really simple dream but it just can’t survive in the Hollownest. Quirrel and Cloth showed up in the fights that I had thought as a tough one to one, the Hornet face the fate of Vessel with me together. The little knight is lonely but also not lonely, at least at those moments.
The mission of Vessel is tough. The fade of the Kingdom is unchangeable. Most thing I saw here is tragedy. But exploring story and secrets in the world, and fighting and taking adventures through areas has a special charm for me. I felt sorry for the fate of the world, while also being moved and love the game.
There are still too much I haven’t mention. If you see this long passage and decide to enter the HK world, it would be the best and you won’t regret.

A disappointing game. 

The good:
 - Has ability to map movement to WASD and can click a button to use weapon

The bad:
 - No way to use the mouse
 - Keybinds are confusing
 - Terrible Dialogue
 - Very bad explanations about how to get started. I.e. until you get the map sorted out the game is impossible
 - You die too fast. No easy way to drop difficulty level. Even for seasoned players
 - Could use better visuals, Some vocals and better sound effects. 
 - Jumping mechanics pale in comparison to Ori, Free Cell, Celeste and the like. Here you just fall of ledges if you're off the hitbox even if the graphic makes it look like you should have stuck. 

Other thoughts:
 - Game clearly made for controllers and absolutely sucks when using keyboard. Why on Earth would you need to hold a key longer to jump higher?!?? Press the button again, like every other game does. Unintuitive controls like forces really long learning curve. But since the game isn't fun, I don't see why anyone would do that.

As you delve deeper, you'll discover a world rich in detail and brimming with intricate layers. The diverse range of bosses keeps the gameplay fresh and challenging, while the combat mechanics and character movements are seamlessly fluid. Push past the initial learning curve, and you'll find an experience that's immensely rewarding.

DOS2 was my very first PC game - my fiance had been wanting to game with me for a while, and I finally decided to try it and I am so glad I did! I had so much fun with my custom character (a lizard wizard) and having the co-op feature was really helpful as a new player trying to get a feel for turn-based combat. I think this game is a really solid first-ever RPG game because the story is so interesting and the combat is so vibrant! We finished the entire game and decided to replay it because we had so much fun!

Interesting storyline, satisfyingly large world, and interesting repercussions of character choices. Character development options are broad for roleplaying and mechanics. Difficulty levels allow for enjoying casual play or significantly harder tactical challenges.

I played it for 100+ hours, so it's hard to imagine it wouldn't be one I'd recommend.

I started this game a year ago and quit once I got off the ship in Fort Joy.  I had not played the first Divinity and hadn't played a good turn-based RPG since the 90's-00's.  I spent a long time on the ship and was totally lost in how to play the game so I put it aside.

A year later and I decided to give it another spin.  I now see why I bought this game in the first place.  It's really good and giving me the experience I originally had hoped for.  It's got a good story and with me being a little more patient, I have learned that it has great game mechanics.

This is a game that has come to drag me into it and I look forward to playing it.  Also, it's great on the Steam Deck too.  I didn't think it would be, that it'd be impossible to read the content on the deck, but it is legible and I'm glad to be able to play this when I'm on the road on it, or on my PC at home.

2 thumbs up and 5 stars if you're looking for a traditional turn-based RPG.  Even better if you can snag it on a sale!

For a game that wants to force you into combat at every opportunity...the combat is terrible.  I swear it was designed around the assumption that the player would save-scum before every single encounter and grind it until they got the favorable outcome.  And for a system where 0HP equals instant death the inability to resurrect outside of combat without a scroll is a terrible design decision, especially in early-game where you don't have access to such things.  Why bother even having combat if your encounter design just kills the player by pitting them against multiple enemies with AoE DOT attacks.  I honestly don't know what game everybody else is praising, because this is one of the worst RPG experiences I've ever had.  I've beaten a number of old-school RPGs, including some TSR games and Fallout 1+2, and none of them felt like they were out to destroy your fun like this game was.

And so, the final game in the saga of Rivellon's fate has concluded. Overall, I must say I enjoyed the game. Among its strengths, I can highlight the non-linearity of the plot, a vast array of quests, an extensively developed magical skill system (the most developed in the series), beautiful graphics, atmosphere, and pleasant music (though it must be acknowledged that Kirill Pokrovsky is irreplaceable).

Despite the many merits of the game, there is one important aspect that somewhat dimmed the joy of playing "Original Sin 2." I'm referring not to the color palette (brighter than in previous games) or the turn-based combat system, which some may have reservations about. Unexpectedly for me, Larian Studios disappointed in the narrative department. While playing the latest installment in the series, I couldn't shake the feeling that it was loosely connected to the previous entries, particularly "Original Sin 1." The creators of the game chose to radically alter our perception of the divine from Divine Divinity. Lucian (the divine figure in this game) is portrayed as an extremely contradictory character who used weapons of mass destruction against his enemies and practically wiped out the elves in the process. As the story unfolds, we are told about many other killings committed by the divine figure in pursuit of his goals. It's worth noting that in the other games of the series, there was no hint of anything similar, including in the latest game, Divinity II: Ego Draconis, where the divine figure was portrayed as heroic and unequivocally positive.

Another narrative peculiarity was the storyline involving the gods. Here too, the creators wanted to surprise us: it turns out that the gods, who once created the ancient races and the mages, are not gods but former rulers (local leaders) who seized magical energy (the source). The created races are only useful to them for obtaining energy. Such an approach somewhat diminishes the enjoyment of the gameplay, as this is a fantasy game, not a scientific lecture, and such details seem out of place. It feels like in the sixth installment, the employees of Larian Studios wanted to share their personal views on religion, leading to a significant change in the mythology of the Rivellon universe. From my perspective, it turned out to be highly inconsistent and unsuccessful: in other parts of the series, there was a sense that we were living in a great era and undertaking grandiose actions to do something good. In "Original Sin 2," we have a rather peculiar divine figure (from the first part), the absence of real gods, and very strong inconsistencies with other parts of the game.

Perhaps the studio simply grew tired of the Rivellon universe and ran out of ideas. Well, in any case, thank you for the amazing journey through Rivellon and Nemesis, and good luck with your future projects!

This is a timeless favorite.
Divinity 2 is a game made for people who enjoy being creative in Tabletop RPGs.
The game gives you vast options in how to solve problems.
Locked door in a dungeon? No worries, let's break it then!
Fighting system is similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, with a nice twist of elemental magic changing the terrain and giving you many, many options!

Throw a fireball in a barrel of oil, set your enemies ablaze!
Cast a rain spell to put down the fire, and zap the water with electricity to stun anyone caught in the blast zone!
There's just so much one can do, it's madness.

If you enjoy a well made RPG with good combat, easy-to-understand/hard-to-master mechanics, awesome soundtrack and artstyle, then do yourself a favor and play this.

I'm not usually into RPGs, but this game contains such a cohesive blend of intuitive game play mechanics, interesting art direction, and intriguing story, that I've played for over 100 hours.

For "light" fans of RPGs, I can highly recommend this game. For "hardcore" fans, I'd recommend it too. 

The only flaw that I perceive is the highly fantastical world, which can create a tone that comes across as a bit childlike or whimsical at times. Other than that, this game is an absolute masterpiece. 

As someone who grew up playing D&D, it's wonderful to have a game recreate that experience so vividly.

Highly recommend.

Couldn't have been more disappointed.

For some reason I remember the game being less tedious.  There's not the same conveyance of where enemies are or what things will do.  Good example are the "Formations" which will see your party go lurching off in some random direction at the start of combat or cram neatly into a corner for the enemies to AOE bomb you because apparently you approached combat and your lead was facing 15 degrees to the left?  No idea what causes it to happen, but the fact that having the lead even a mediocre distance ahead can leave my rear companion literally out of initiative makes me wonder wtf they were thinking.

The story is paper-thin and so are the companions.  The depth is all in the combat system and the various builds you can make, but the game all but hard punishes you for playing any kind of "pure" class, since even the smallest bit of dabbling can get you teleports, haste, invis, etc.  There's way less emphasis on playing a "Role" in this RPG and instead just kitting out whatever build will break the game the hardest and mow through combat.

It's clear the shortcomings with BG3's inventory were products of Div2, because lord all the same issues are present.  Additionally while definitely an unfair comparison to modern games, it's hard to not feel like everything in this game is made of play-dough with how the visuals look.

Tl;dr:  Between the vague story, barely-there "companions", an overly-gamified combat system that begs you to break it, and all the other shortcomings Larian left behind when they started work on BG3, it's really not worth your time.  Just play BG3 - it's a superior experience on every level.  Even with all its tedium and 1% misses, I'd even consider hours on XCom before even bothering with this again if you just want a tactical experience.

I got this game early access. Played Act 1 with friends several times. Played through the whole game with friends once. Skip a few years, and decided to play through solo. I realize now the only reason I enjoyed it before was because I was playing with friends. The game doesn't stand up on its own.
Pros: well-supported co-op mode, dynamic combat system, sense of progression, variety of skills, one song at the end of a particular quest line
Cons: story and writing is (mostly) bad, unfun spikes in difficulty, 'cheesing' some encounters is often the optimal and expected strategy, looting and inventory management is a massive pain if playing by oneself
I wish there was a mixed recommend, because this game has a lot going for it. i certainly recommend if you have friends who want to play with you. 
The one song I mention as a pro is actually what made me realize what the game's story lacked: heart. The writing simply isn't high enough quality to allow for much investment in the world or (most) of the characters. It sucks, because I really tried to get into the lore, reading the books and talking through all dialogue options with anyone I met. It was wasted effort. Reading  a wiki summary of the characters and world is more likely to entertain than the actual writing in the game.
There are good moments. I enjoyed a romance option. The humor is frequently funny (particularly with animals). But I can't recommend this game for single-player. And there are probably other games you can play with your friends that you'd have more fun with.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a masterpiece of RPG goodness. It has everything you could want in a game: rich story, deep combat, memorable characters, and tons of choices. You can play solo or co-op with up to three friends, and create your own custom hero from six unique races and over a dozen classes. The world is full of secrets, surprises, and consequences for your actions. You can even talk to animals, if you have the right skill. Trust me, you don't want to miss this game. It's divine!

Pre-edit: 45 hours and I have managed to get laid, get into a drunken brawl, be robbed, die to a lesbian witch kissing me, kill someone with knowledge and many more fantastic memories. 10/10 game.

Now having beat the game with my 4 mates, I'd like to catalog the journey we went through.

I'd like to start by saying that this game literally took just over a year to beat, due to the fact that we have very conflicting ways of playing a CRPG. While funny, this would lead to big break intervals in our playthrough and I definitely missed/forgotten a lot of the experiences. This doesn't change that this is one of my favourite games ever made however.

Now to begin; the aforementioned happened in the first 45 hours or so of playtime, this was after leaving Fort Joy, I never mentioned the experiences there... So,

Learning of what's to become of us, we tried to rough up almost every noble/soldier who was assumed as the opposition, leading to a lot of resets (lol) - moments before departing Fort Joy, we do a major fight on the docks, we were being massacred having not only being at level, so there was challenge to the fight, but massively outnumbered. Odds were looking slim, then suddenly, a great void worm emerged from the ground, which context wise, was after us for story elements I'll not disclose. Somehow though, this worm single handely shifted the fight in our favour by taking the aggro of all the enemy NPC's, and likewise, had it's aggro on them. The worm made short work of majority of the enemies but sadly was put to rest by the little remaining. In honour of this worm, we dubbed him "Chuck". He will be remembered. 

After arriving to the next destination, we steadily progressed through the campaign, however along the way, doing some side stories, one of my mates finds this Phoenix egg, we had the option to sell it for a decent chunk of cash, or keep it and let it hatch later on. Unanimously we kept it as we'd thought we'd have a pet. Nothing came of it (yet), only for it to be important later, which I'll come back to.

Timeskip a fair few hours into our playthrough, one of my mates decide to ally with the God King, a big mistake. While he was offered immense power, it was limited, along with being binded by a contract in which he'd be considered evil. Us not knowing of this were baffled by the continuous challenge presented as this same friend was the persuasionist of the party, leading to all of the worst dialogue options. Later we removed this binding from him and things seemed good.

Now to the end of the game, we were there, at the end of the game, we endure a tough fight all in order to achieve the story goal. Something happened though. There was a choice. What ending did we want for our journey? Having mixed decisions, the game put us into a fight to the death in order to see who was strong and determined enough to seek out what they thought was just. My friend and I ended up without discussion, choosing the same option, which teamed us against our two other friends. They chose different options form each other, which pitted us in a 2v1v1. The fight was glorious, as we had a big advantage being damage dealers and tanks, while they were more glass cannon types. They were massacred. 

Then came the end of the game, we done it. A year and 3 month journey was concluded. All excited we finish, we were regrouped in a hub area, with all of our allies we made along the way congratulating us. A ally we didn't recognise until interacting with it was the newly hatched Phoenix egg, which had a flaming chook with us. 3 of us were talking about how cool it was to bring this guy along with us for so long while he was still in egg form, while talking about this, one of my friends had other plans. With quick succession, he leaped into the air, bow drawn, and fires an arrow into the Phoenix, killing it upon impact. Our friend lasted mere seconds upon that happening.

Overall, this game was incredible. I haven't experienced anything like this as it was my first co-op CRPG, and ultimately led me to getting into DnD and Larian's recently released Baldur's Gate 3. I can without a doubt place this in my all time favourite gaming experiences ever - 10/10

The game is an improvement over the first game in every way.
Graphics, spells, story, character voicing, handmade map. You can feel that Larian has really worked hard on everything.
The game has a strong start, but gets worse and worse the longer you play it.
------------------
I really like the world, I really enjoy the game, but even after playing it for over 100hrs I can't bring myself to finish it.
------------------
Enemies from Act 2 onwards constantly break the rules of combat, they have almost no cooldowns on their spells. 
Every battle is spamming save-load to see what unfair trick turn which enemy got from the developers.
------------------
I don't mind overthinking the game and the battles, but for every enemy at the same level as you to have huge advantages in the form of infinite moves, infinite summons or insanely high attacks - it just gets old after a while.
------------------
Practically every battle since Act 2 has had its - "Haha we caught you!" moment. If you can't read the future you have to lose the battle - reload your saved position - change your gear and skills - and try again. 
I wouldn't mind that at all - IF IT WASN'T IN EVERY BATTLE.
------------------
For most quests, I have to google their solutions - because the game log is absolutely worthless. There is no way to know what is completed, what is important, what is unimportant. Horrible.
------------------
The new armor system is a complete oversight. It's not fun it's just annoying.
------------------
It breaks my heart because I know a lot of love and care went into the game - but I can't recommend it even after playing it for over 100 hours. The game gets worse and worse towards the end.
------------------
Unless you're an obsessive min-maxer who tries to cheeses or break the rules at every battle - you won't enjoy the game.
------------------
As a family man, I don't have the energy to constantly alt tab and read through tutorials to find out what to do and how to keep playing. It's not fun, it's a tedious chore.

I had no previous experience with Armored Core games, but i played all "Souls" (ds1, 2, 3, bloodborne, Sekiro and Elden Ring) except for Demon Souls.

This is definitely not a Soulslike game, but the Fromsoft "signature" is all over the place, in many design elements and how boss fights play.

Once you familiarize with the controls they feel smooth and natural. Missions are generally short and exploration is encouraged with extra gear, (sometimes hidden) mini bosses and lore items. The game is divided in 5 chapters, each with a powerful, epic Main Boss at the end.

Half the game is playing around with your mech build, testing weapons and parts to suit your playstyle (and/or to figure out the best counters for the mission)

Combat is of course excellent, it never gets old and it's incredibly fun. The story is presented via audios from the game's different characters , with top notch voice acting , and it's great. To fully experience the game you need to finish the game three times and follow certain choices in order to get the "true ending ", so a guide to follow on the third playthrough is highly recommended.

As a long time fan of the series, and a more recent hopper on of the souls-like bandwagon, I could not be more pleased with ACVIFOR.  The combat is incredibly challenging and encourages, nay requires constant adaptation and that is the essence of the joy that is armored core.  Taking apart your robot and putting it back together with cool new stuff, then dominating AI controlled smack-talking augmented humans.  With a story that albeit under realized, (or leaving just enough to our imagination, depending on which From Software fan you ask) is quite compelling, ACVIFOR has broken new ground for an Armored Core game.  I personally greedily charged through to NG++ to experience the full story and get my hands on certain goodies, and still want more.  Such is my only complaint, as while great games oft leaving us want for more, ACVIFOR has left a sharper sting than most for this megafan of the series.  Still, 5/5, would recommend and will probably play again.

I loved this game! The story, characters, and gameplay were all outstanding, and Fromsoft did an excellent job delivering a well-written storyline (that was much more accessible than their other games!) The voice acting was also phenomenal. Some of the bosses were truly a visual treat. I was stunned by how beautiful Balteus looked on my screen. What I appreciated most was that despite having the DNA of Souls, the game never felt like a Souls game to me, which was a pleasant surprise.

The combat is fantastic, the animations are great, and the mechs are badass. The new stagger mechanic is rationalized by an Attitude Control System, adding a welcome layer of depth to combat.
My only complaint is the color palette of the environment. It's pretty bland. I understand that it's a post-apocalyptic warzone, but still, a little bit of color couldn't hurt. At least you can customize your AC to whatever color you want.

EDIT: Okay it didn't take me long to fall in love with basically every aspect of this game, color palette included. I have about 100 hours in this game now. One complaint I do have is that the PvP matchmaking is pretty bad. 
Lastly, I need the sequel, and I NEED IT NOW. I WANT MORE ARMORED CORE!!!!1!

For note, I'm not a Fromsoft fan nor a mech fan, although I've always think that mechs in fiction works are cool.

But for some reason, this game ticks me on the right spots, especially the customization.

Update: The issue with 4-core CPUs has been resolved, I'm off to enjoy the game (:

The game seems great and I'm excited to play it, but it has a technical issue with frame times being extremely inconsistent on 4 core 8 thread CPUs. There is a workaround that requires disabling EAC to change core affinity, but I was hoping the first patch would resolve it, considering that it took quite a while. Will update this review if this changes.

If you waited over a decade for a reboot to the original mech series...it's here. It's balanced a heck of a lot better, it's beautiful and it demands the skill we never really had to have because bosses and arena weren't as strong or demanding for skills required. The game is faster paced, and wonderful.

Downsides, the online is from the 90s. It's unstable as all get out. One disconnect will kill a whole room. And it isn't exactly stable enough to assure that various errors won't cause a disconnect. But it's amazing. Even with that.
You're heavy but also zoom around, and there are many guns and the only girl is a voice in your head. A bit like high school in America I suppose.

This game is great, but not for everyone. The game feels good to play and although I had to change some keybinds, the controls felt great once I got used to them. I myself am a keyboard and mouse player, so I technically have no clue how this game is on controller, but I'd guess that controller would be the better experience. The UI appears to have a lot going on at first, but once you figure out what is what, it honestly seems really simple and easy to understand, though this may just be a personal thing for me. Ultimately I'd say the best thing you can do to determine if you want to play the game is watch someone play the tutorial mission, then if you want to buy the game, do the tutorial mission, and decide if you want to refund or continue from there.
One of the endings has you crash a space ship into a big tower, I rate it 9/11 and strongly recommend.

This game is definitely a lot of fun but it's not the most straight forward game in the world. It is a Fromsoft Title which means some of it's missions can be a bit esoteric and Not exactly what I'd call balanced. However it has very straight forward controls and with tinkering you can master it easily. Now I've never played any former AC games so I cannot say how it compares but from what a big AC fan friend said to me it largely plays like an AC game with no 'bad end' from poor financial management so it mostly focuses on the story by comparison. Which to me is one of the games strongest aspects. The story and characters of Rubicon are some of the strongest I've encountered in all my years of gaming. IF you ever find yourself needing help I recommend searching youtube for good builds or tutorials as the Discussions page is a mess of Fromsoft fanatics and low tier memers who scream 'git gud' ironically or unironically with no intention of providing real help.
