This is my subjective, personal, totally biased opinion as a person who has no interest in PVP.
In short:
Game's around a 7/10. A good game which is most of the time fun to play. I dislike some mechanics though.
It's a mix between AC4, which I loved and AC5, which I strongly disliked. In the Beginning there are a few big roadblocks, but after you clear Balteus it opens up and is more accessible. Since Patch 1.2 this should not be an issue anymore.

In long:
I strongly dislike most of the bosses.
I am indifferent to the story.
The soundtrack is uninspired and bland, especially if you compare it to the OST of other mech games like AC4 For Answer or Brigador.
The repair mechanic is bad. It's just in the game because mission design is out of whack. A desperate attempt to make light weight and high weight mechs viable for all missions by removing one of their defining features. This does not translate to pvp since repair kits are not available in arena fights.
The stun mechanic could have been left out, but it's not too bad I guess. It has it's ups and downs. It ruins the boss design for me though. Plus I could swear sometimes AI controlled crafts are unable to be stunned out of some animations. Could be wrong about that one though.
Still, in combination with other choices in game design the stun mechanic invalidates long range combat. At least it's not as bad as Pulse shields I guess. 
The refill stations are a bad solution for the problem, that mission length and enemy health are not compatible with the health pool and ammo capacity of your AC. Also they ruin the surprise for most boss battles.
After reviewing some footage, helicopter bosses (for me at least) reside around 40% of the time out of bounds. Now that wouldn't be too much of a problem, but in this iteration of AC these are impassible mission walls. Quite immersion breaking in my opinion. And the moment that your laser blade is blocked by an invisible wall, a few centimetres/inches before it can reach the stunned aircraft? Now that's really sad.
The debt mechanic is as good as gone. That's been a trend for a long time now. I still am slightly miffed about it.
Checkpoints add to make the game more accessible for newer players and the do reduce some of the glaring problems in regards of the mission design. I quite like them.
Gun play is really fun. Especially in the arena or against MTs.
Energy blades now have a separate energy pool from your AC. Reduces the impact of your chosen generator when using them. I am indifferent about that change.
Pulse shielded Enemies can go away though. Very strong dislike. Give me back my PA please. I do miss me my passive war crimes. PA shields were a way better solution by combining stun and pulse shields in a single mechanic. Do you remember the odd missions where PA was deactivated? Not gonna happen anymore.
I miss my stabilizers too. Those were fun.
OC Tuning is... not Tuning anymore? And why are basic functions locked behind OS Tuning? Why do I need to invest OC points so I can manually purge weapon systems? When the ammo is used up I can drop my weapon just fine.
Why do I need money to respec my OC Points? I know the amount is negligible, but that makes it even more obvious that any amount of money isn't needed. If your different AC designs use different OC tuning you need to pay money and manually respec your OC points. I need to admit that I don't know if the OC setting is saved anywhere but honestly? Why? I mean, really. Why would you do that? 
Oh yeah, by play through 3 you have enough OS points to have every perk. That was really dissapointing.
Back to perks where I wonder why they are an unlock: Why am I able to punch without problems, but Kicking needs OC tuning? Why do I need to spend OC points to fast turn? At least by unlocking Assault armor via OC Points, it is now separate from your generator. But it also has an ammo count now. It's a slight dislike/ I am indifferent?

Sound effects are really nice though.
Graphics are really good.
Art direction is really nice too. Some may find the lack of color bad, but I think it's quite fitting to highlight colorful ACs and Coral effects.
I only had one crash until now, so I think it's really stable. Frame rate is quite stable too.
I hope the game will be tweaked in future updates and or future titles. And I also hope that the coming DLC policy will not screw us over. I am carefully optimistic about that one.
That's all I can think of right now. Hope it helps.


p.S. What are the requirements to S Rank for the mission "Attack the refuling base"? I just can't get it.
its good for my first in the series

Pros:
- Some of the missions have really fun objectives and premises
- Difficulty balance feels just right for the genre (not nearly as hard as say sekiro or souls but also not a game where you can be mindless)
- Some really cool looking environments
- The sound design is very satisfying
- Combat and movement feel real slick
- The game is a tweaker's paradise 
- The part variety does an excellent job allowing for players to satisfy a wide variety of mech fantasies
- Straight to the point game design with very little fat or padding
- The amount of characterization done with the limited time Fromsoft has to develop them is simply incredible. There are a good variety of characters in this game that I ranged from caring deeply about, to hating, to loving to dunk on/screw with.
- The NG+ loop(s) really show you how much better an AC pilot you've become and the missions with in were some of the best in the game

Cons:
- The sound track had some bangers in it, but it was mostly kind of mid/forgettable
- I would have loved it if there were just a few more parts as the parts list feels a bit lighter than prior AC games
- Multiplayer for the game isn't super fun. Alot of folks just use the same not fun builds and there isn't really any game mode variety to spice it up. Mostly just an occasional distraction.
- With so much content in the NG+ loop(s) of the game I kind of just wish that From had most or all of that content available from the get go and just had the campaign have more branching paths rather than the current system of replaying the old missions to get to the juicy new stuff.
- The game feels like it should have around 2 more bosses

Conclusion:
I had high expectations from one of my favorite game devs bringing back a series I enjoyed from the grave, and I must say fromsoft has met my lofty expectations. AC6 is not by any means a perfect game. But for what it is trying to achieve, it comes pretty darn close. For folks wanting a mecha game where you get to customize and tune to your heart's content AC6 is your game. For folks who want slick mecha combat that feels good no matter if you are some lumbering behemoth that is armed to the teeth or a nimble wasp, AC6 has got you covered. On top of us getting both of these things, we also get compelling characters in a no nonsense package.

Apart from the game design, which is fun enough despite having nothing to do with the previous entry of the franchise, technically speaking the game stopped working after the 1st update, crashes all the time, PC is above recommended specs but there's no solution, posting on the Steam forums is useless as usual for every Bandai Scamco published game.

You may be lucky and get a working game, do not recommend especially since Steam refuses to refund a broken product.
its good, would play again

That kid, he just wanted his own callsign.

He just wanted to prove himself, and I tore that dream from his clenched fists. He's not the protagonist of this anime, he's not the hero. He's just another target, and it's just another job. But I felt more in that moment, listening to his last words, his lament that all he wanted was to keep up with a real mercenary, than I did in the entire twelve and a half minutes of frustration, dodging and mindless slaughter involved with taking down the massive piece of The Game Awards 2023 bait that was the STRIDER.

---------------

I'm late to the party on this analysis, but I'm glad I at least figured out what it was I wanted to say eventually. 

I think the main problem with this game, on first blush, was that From needed a way to draw in the Souls crowd, so they threw a whole bunch of fat health bar heavily armored non-humanoid/tetrapod mechs at you during "story" missions so that you could feel like you were slaying some great and terrible monster and ease you into the idea that this game is built different. And yeah, there's some big setpiece bosses that kinda irritate me like the STRIDER or the fight where you fly endlessly through a swarm of warships or other stuff that's not really fighting other AC units, but once I got the entire scope and breadth of the game under my belt I realized that they're really a very small part of a much bigger experience. Every fight in the game that *matters*, that you really need to care about (except for the Ice Worm), is against other AC units, and they NEVER blue-ball you and put you against one of these fat healthbar setpiece bosses when some major decision is on the line or you're experiencing the consequences of one of those decisions. Instead, they always throw you at some amped-up form (or in some cases just a really well-piloted version) of a machine that yes, you absolutely can build -- albeit later, in a heavily neutered form.

That's kind of an issue, I guess. The old AC games let you go ham with the busted ridiculously powerful parts or do things like create energy-neutral machine builds that let you hover indefinitely because your energy regeneration outpaced your usage, and stuff like that. I've seen a lot of complaints that the hidden weapons and parts in this game are underwhelming, and a lot of speculation that they're underwhelming because From wants there to be balance in PVP fights (hence the inevitable nerf of the Zims and the Stun Needle launcher), and I guess I can see where that's coming from.

Personally, I would just exclude those parts from being used in arena fights or give PVP different stats from single-player, but I'm not From and I'm not really sure if what I've heard matches with reality since I haven't really engaged with the online fighting. I do think it's unusual that your feet have to be firmly planted on the ground for a while in order to start regenerating energy, but I was never too deep into the mechanics of the old AC games to really know or care about that sort of thing and I'm pretty sure most normal people won't care either. If you do, though, that's not a bad thing; you've just probably got a laundry list of other complaints that I'm not interested in covering here and wouldn't really think too hard about even if I did know about them.

As far as tech goes, the game's running good on my machine but I've, like a lot of the other "works on my PC" guys who have been upping this game, got an unfairly good spec, so I feel like that's not going to help the people with real problems. I hope patches fix this; for the most part, it appears that From is listening to player concerns. I have no doubts that further improvements will come.

Despite my complaints, I had a real fun time with this game. It feels to me like a return to form with the general style of AC2 and AC3's controls and less of the heart-bursting high speed fights that I don't think I could handle now from AC4. I don't really like the setpiece missions, but I do like the man-to-man duels a lot and the fun twists the game throws at you when you're repeating missions on the second and third playthrough. I don't think there'll be any post-launch content for this game. Maybe that's a good thing. It's certainly a very complete package as-is, and I'm glad for it.

Also, From achieved the impossible and managed to make me care about the cast of characters in one of their games instead of just one meme character or whoever the level-up waifu is.

What can I say that hasn't already been said?

First of all, this is my first official experience with the Armored Core franchise. And I must say, as a newcomer this is one of the most amazing action mecha experiences I've ever had.

- The handling and feel of controlling the AC just feels so right. Smooth, intuitive, and reactive, it really felt like an extension of my hands on my controller. 

- Rewarding action gameplay and combat. Yes the difficulty is there, but it's done tastefully. Each encounter and skill benchmark you run into truly feels like a test of your combat experience, skills, and knowledge of your AC build.

- Interesting and memorable characters. YES even though they're faceless, they all oozed with personality just from their dialogue and voices (I played in English voices).

- The AC customization was in depth but still user-friendly enough to not overwhelm me. You 'll get all the weapons and parts you need and immediately know how to put them together to create a build that suits your preferred playstyle. Aside from 1 or 2 bosses that require a specific build to beat, you can totally beat them all with your own custom builds.

- A story that doesn't give away too much too soon and leaves a lot for your to discover as you progress through the game. Nothing  mind-blowing, but it serves as a great backdrop for the game's main focus: the mecha combat.

TL;DR: Gurren Lagann meets Bloodborne on a world where you work as a freelancer piloting your custom-built RGB PC-Gaming Chair hybrid trying to either stop or start the Human Instrumentality Project depending on which head voices you listen to.

Literally the best Mecha game out right now, amazing customization, amazing gameplay and tons of replayability. There's tons of weapons and parts to make your own mech in your own style and the gameplay is challenging but fair. There's also a ton of content to explore as the game adds more and more content on consecutive NG+ runs, including new missions, parts and lore.

Don't listen to people calling it a souls-like purely because of the fact that it has an Estus style healing mechanic as this game doesn't play like a souls-like in the slightest. The game is hard but that's because AC is a difficult franchise, not because "oh FromSoft is a souls game company".

Overall. this game is amazing and is honestly the definitive modern mecha game experience currently available.

If you are looking a good mecha game, THIS IS IT.

really pretty to look at (scenarios, mechs, explosions), mecha is fully customizable, runs surprisingly good even with just above min specs, responsive controls, free ominidirectional movement (very anime-like), HUGE explosions, memorable boss fights, arena fights, the difficulty is really up to you and how effective you pilot your own custom made ass-whooping machine.

A really enjoyable experience overall. worth buying if you see it on sale.

Ost is disappointing, 90% of it is unmemorable droning while the other 10% is really good. unfortunately no FreQuency songs either. I feel like the classic AC music genre from gen3 and gen4 would have fit well.

No parts like weapon arms, sniper cannons, or back chain guns. No shoulder parts either, though that is fine, as they werent as important. Only 2 quad legs and only 3 tank legs, what the fuck? Only 1 semi auto rifle (I count linears as snipers).

Also long range combat is non-existent, everything ricochets off at about 350 meters.

Everything else in the game is amazing, combat feels great, story is good and it is fun as hell.

Let me start it off by saying,
[h1]I don't like Armored Core 6.[/h1]

That's right. I am not happy with this game- or rather, as "Armored Core". 

By the way, don't take my play time as a reference since I mostly spent those time making waifu decals and meme builds. 

On the previous review, I simply noted as "do not recommend" complaining how NOT armored core this game is- and I still stand by to say that the game essentially is the reskinned Sekiro-You are [u]not[/u] playing as a pilot of the mech, but you play as the mech, if you know what I mean. And please, it has estus flask...or should I call it "mechstus flask", that's straight from souls series.

However, after playing some more and put some thoughts to it... I felt that it wasn't fair.

Allow me to just get rid of the negative sides, because I got plenty of those.

Your mech build barely contribute to your play style but rather by your weapons. Even that is restricted by overwhelmingly emphasized "stagger mechanic", which restrict most of your weapon choices to being short distance such as shotgun being overpowered. [b]Let me add on the fact that the game does not offer sniper build, which is something that was there for the entirety of series[/b]

Unlike past game, most of the "customization" comes as an upgrade instead of some way of expanding your build or exploring different strategy. In the older series including 5th gen, generators are either made for nimble light weight but low power output, or a heavy tank with high power output. You can of course mix together but must overcome the consequence of such build, as light weight would not be able to hold much weight, therefore sacrifices weapon load out. AC6 does offer something similar, but not as exciting fashion. It just tells you that you need to upgrade xxx parts if you want yyy to be upgraded. Kind of like getting a new car for a Need for Speed, why would you use 90s sports sedan if you have modern lambo now, besides making it as a challenge?

There are many aspects of the game that really tried to reuse some of the movement assets from souls series. Humanoid boss battles are quite notable, as it doesn't move like a machine at all- it's like seeing a robot forming a [i]kamehameha pose[/i] before shooting a laser. If you're a robot, you know you could just pull the trigger.

Overall, you can definitely feel that this wasn't a "major breakthrough from souls series" as Fromsoft made exclusively the same genre of game for a decade, but attempt to yet again reuse the same formula in a totally different game that doesn't mix well. 

[h2]So why would I recommend it, if I didn't like it?[/h2]

Well, 2 major reasons. 1, because of stupid Steam® rating system. 2. because I can tell the effort they tried to put in, despite its problems.

First of all, they needed to make bunch of new models, as none of the older games had scifi-mech 3D models. Maybe trees could be reused, but that was about it. You can tell that these aren't cheap models either, as it has variety of motions in each parts. For example, each core has its unique animation for their cooling mechanic. 

You can also find many references to an old series, like "Patches" character showing up, which actually first introduced in 4th gen, before Dark Souls. Some game mechanics are straight from old gen. Shields are nice welcoming return from 2-3 gen, but more functional. You also saw the cinematic trailer, probably, and those aren't cheaply done either. That 1 large scaled boss fight, Strider,  was truly impressive.

And then... you find lack of parts. Why are so many redundancy in biped, while offering very little on different parts like reverse, quad, and tanks? If customization is so important, you would think that they would add more variety in parts, right? 

My guess is... they ran out of budget and time. I have a feeling that making Armored Core costed way more than any of the recent games that From released, at least from marginal profit aspect (games sold - cost to make game = marginal profit). 
Elden ring is more polished souls game that could carry over directly from older series to reuse many assets that it had, so they could spend more time on building the game mechanic, which was open world setting. The game was also hyped by MANY people and did sell very very well. Armored Core needed a lot of things had to be made new instead of focusing on core game system, which makes me believe why the game feels so close to souls game than any of the Armored Core series. It also makes sense why the lack of complexity in mech build as well as part variety with over redundancy of biped legs. 

Of course, I haven't done a thorough research on this theory so this is solely a hypothesis. I would love to hear other's thought about this.

Before the update, game balance was total wack. Some bosses were way too difficult, and some weapons were game breakingly strong. Now, some updates balanced out the weapons and boss fight, it's actually quite enjoyable.

I was upset before about the game because I thought Fromsoft made Armored Core as a cashgrab, by slapping Armored Core title on souls game. Now, though, I realized how wrong I was. Armored Core was never a major title that brought people's attention, and making whole bunch of new models would costed more than they could sell for. I now think Armored Core 6 as a passion project that became out of their hand and needed to be sold prematurely. 

So I'm recommending this game solely because I want Fromsoft to stop making souls game. I want them to be different. I want Fromsoft to make another mech game with the assets they have made. Maybe Armored Core 6.5. For that, they need their game to be sold. 1 positive review wouldn't do a shit to their sales, but negative one wouldn't help even more.

I can't believe how good Armored Core 6 is.  Like, From has to miss eventually, right?  I figured this was time, they were going to stray from the Souls formula that has guided them through their recent success, and they were going to misstep, trying to revive a franchise from yesteryear.  Like, I did not think that AC6 was going to be bad or anything, I just didn't think it was going to be the best game of 2023.  I was wrong.  

Armored Core feels so good.  It took me a little bit to be entirely comfortable fighting, but once I got there, the wait was worth it.  I would end up in these crazy fights with missiles and things flying everything from every direction, yet felt fully in control and capable of dodging and retaliating.  It feels new and refreshing, it does not have the rhythm of the usual character action game attack, doge/parry, attack.  You are incredibly mobile and you are tanky, a few stray hits here and there mean nothing.  

In service to getting comfortable, there are a massive amount of mech parts and weapons.  While somewhat complicated at first, the systems are pretty easy to grok, and once you have played the game for a bit you will start to figure out how you like to play and what loadouts make sense for you.  You can customize your mech down to very small details, paint it different colors, add decals, various levels of wear or shine, etc.  It all looks great.  

In From tradition, AC6 is steeped in melancholy and despair, it permeates the entire game.  The lore is interesting, some things only hinted at.  While mostly an action game, there are some lore chests to be found, and some hidden optional battles that give more information as well.  The actual lives of the humans on Rubicon is never seen and almost never spoken about.  The Coral, the finding of it, the mining of it, the controlling of it, and the elimination of it seem to be the only things that matter.   Its so oppressive, it only feels natural that many of your allies and enemies seem to welcome death when it comes.  Personally, I was fascinated the entire time.  

The games visuals are perfect.   The mechs are incredibly detailed and interesting, the world has some spectacular ruins and vistas.   The game ran butter smooth on my 3060ti at 60fps, making combat so fluid and enjoyable.  

In order to play every mission, see everything, and unlock everything you need to play through the game three times.  Normally I would scoff at this, but the game is so great in every aspect, I was thrilled to play more.  I may even dabble in the online multiplayer at some point, although I haven't yet.  

10/10
This is the gold standard that fromsoftware always delivers. I cant wait for the next installment of my favorite franchise.

I was a fan of the series since gen1 back in 97 I was just a kid then, and I didn't understand anything.
Coming from that experience, I really like AC6 as an introduction to the franchise.
It's really easy to pick up, but after that the difficulty is up to the player. Sure, you can play a METAGolem, but where this game really shines, for me at least, is in making that cool build and making it work. Your preferred build won't always work, so there will always be adjustments to be made, where the player's skill fails them.

The story isn't as buried as it can be in other Souls games. It is worth experiencing in its entirety, with some cool a-ha moments I had going through NG+ and NG++.

All in all, I would recommend it. It's not for everyone, you will have to pay a bit attention to what's going on on the screen.
Manage that, and you'll do just fine.

A game in 2023 with no micro-transactions, no battle pass, and no immediately apparent bugs or glitches on launch. An incredible game from Fromsoft, and a great 6th entry in the series.

The game itself is very easy to get into, yet hard to master, and it is easy to start the series from here story- wise. The story isn't presented to you in the way it might be in a story-driven game like The Last of Us. The only visuals we get for characters are their emblem, and an AC, if they have one, letting you decide what they look like.

Gameplay wise, it shares many elements with the Ace Combat series: Each mission is presented to you in the menu, you get a briefing on what to expect, and then you go shoot giant robots. 

PvP is hosted in rooms, and has 1v1 and 3v3 options. It doesn't seem like an afterthought, but it left me a little confused when I first got into it, simply because of the lack of a "Find Match" button. 

Weapons feel great, and are well balanced for both PvE and PvP, though some guns have perhaps needlessly low ammo counts. 

All in all, great game, would buy again. I suggest buying if you like giant robots and explosions.

Sekiro is nothing short of a masterpiece. FromSoft have obviously mastered the formula of delivering the best gaming experience that is both brutally challenging and incredibly rewarding.

The combat system in Sekiro is where the game truly shines. Every swing of the sword and every parry requires careful thought, making every victory immensely satisfying. The thrill of overcoming seemingly insurmountable foes is unmatched, and the game's steep learning curve only adds to the sense of accomplishment.

The story is just as captivating. The narrative is beautifully woven into the gameplay, revealing a tale of honor, loyalty and revenge.

I played the game fully on Steam deck and I have to say it runs flawlessly and the graphics are absolutely stunning and jaw-dropping. The attention to detail in character models, environments and lighting effects makes it one of the most visually appealing games I have ever played.

In conclusion, Sekiro is a must-play for anyone seeking a challenging and deeply rewarding experience. If you're up for challenge and appreciate finely crafted game, Sekiro deserves a spot in your library

[/list]

I absolutely and entirely love Sekiro. I played it first, ahead of all the other From Software games -- I was told that if I play the DS games first, I'd have to unlearn mechanics to get through Sekiro. So I just went ahead and played it first.

It was incredibly hard -- every single boss gave me a tough time and I ended up cheesing as many as I could. But as I played the game, I realized that learning the mechanics is actually extremely rewarding. And by the time I reached the final boss, I was totally enamored. Play through #2 was delightful -- all those mechanics I learned taught me just how satisfying the game was meant to be.

About 6 months after I finished the game (aka all steam achievements), I kind of wanted to give it a try again. And this is where it REALLY took off for me. I did everything I didn't bother doing the first time -- NG+1 to +7, Demon bell + No kuro's charm, gauntlets + all those item and enemy randomizer mods. It was nothing short of incredible. How can the same game be so rewarding to keep replaying? How can the same boss fights be so much fun when they're harder? Not sure really. I've played through DS1 since then and while that was fun, Sekiro is what I keep returning to.

I've gotten as much out of this game as I've gotten out of Hollow Knight (and that's a whole fricking lot).

TL;DR: Some of the most satisfying gameplay mechanics I have ever seen in a game. It's difficult, but fair. You need to get good at the mechanics to progress, but when you do, it is utter bliss.

After playing Elden Ring, I knew I liked the challenge of FromSoft games. Sekiro does not disappoint!

I thought this was just a medieval Japanese swordfighting game, but I was wrong. I won't spoil it, but a few hours into the game, there was something that caught me completely by surprise in an epic fashion and hooked me into wanting to know more about the game's universe.

This game has the most satisfying melee combat mechanics of any game I have ever played. The deep enemy design is a classic staple of Fromsoftware nowadays and is even better than ever in Sekiro - as the game has been designed entirely around your set of tools. 

[b] Weapons [/b]
With a more concise toolset than previous Fromsoft games, your weapons are better integrated into the combat. You have katana as your main offensive and defensive weapon throughout the game. In your off-hand you have nothing, briefly, until your hand is literally sliced off; then, you acquire a prosthetic limb with tools that add lots of spice to the combat. Your prosthetics range from shurikens to flamethrowers and they all fill certain useful niches.

[b] Enemies [/b]
I loved the vast majority of enemy designs in Sekiro. There are very few enemy designs that I was not a fan of. Namely the Headless', who I will return to later. The Snake Eyes' had a little too limited a moveset to be worth being put in twice too. The Ogre is a good tutorial on dodging but isn't that interesting to fight, in my opinion. The Demon of Hatred feels like playing a Souls boss in Sekiro; it's alright but not as fun to fight as the other bosses, even with its incredible visual design and moveset animations.

[b] Adventure[/b]
The world design is beautiful and fun to explore, and again in typical 'Soulslike' fashion you can see certain landmarks in the distance which eventually turn out to be levels you can visit (albeit not as much as in previous titles). Some of the levels in this game are the most beautiful I've seen in the Souls genre and are worth progressing to blind.

[b] Combat [/b]
This is the first Soulslike FS made with a jump, and it goes high - but it has a little wind up so you can't abuse it too much for evasion in tight combat scenarios - you will need to rely mostly on deflection instead. Deflection involves a well timed block which will damage your opponent's posture. Once you damage your opponent's posture enough to break it you can inflict a fatal blow that finishes off weaker opponents. This system cleverly pushes players into more active and risky combat as players who engage with it will defeat opponents in under half the time it'd take to stab and slash their standard HP to 0.

[b] Headless [/b]
The headless, as I mentioned earlier, are optional horror creatures that will pull your soul out of your arse if they kill you. They block your dodge and build up "terror" (an instakill debuff) on every non perfect deflect. some headless are underwater and  with these even perfect deflects build up terror. It feels unfair to critique them for this though, as they are not designed to be a standard and fair fight - they are purely optional and very easy to avoid if you want to. That said, I like to fight everything in these games so I wasn't a fan of these guys.

[b] Story [/b]
Speaking of other changes to the standard design, Sekiro's story is more hands-on than previous Soulslike titles. I don't have much to say about it, it was a decent story. I'm ambivalent to the story. I haven't watched as many lore videos about Sekiro as I have the other Souls games so perhaps its more hands on nature has made me a little less interested in its story.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
All in all, this game is incredible. If you're already a fan of the Souls genre you should give this a try. It will take a little bit of adjusting to but if you stick with it you'll learn to love it. For newer players or those unfamiliar with the Souls genre and are feeling a little intimidated by the difficulty - if you have the grit to overcome its challenge and improve your skills, this game will reward you massively for it. It's a power fantasy that you earn, which (imo) feels so much better than games that just give you a power fantasy.

"Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice" is an absolute masterpiece of a game that sets a new standard for action-adventure titles. FromSoftware, the developers behind iconic titles like Dark Souls and Bloodborne, have truly outdone themselves with this exceptional creation.

One of the most striking aspects of Sekiro is its breathtaking world design. The game's setting, a beautifully realized feudal Japan, is a visual feast filled with intricate details and atmospheric environments. From serene cherry blossom-covered landscapes to dark, foreboding castles, every location feels like a work of art.

The gameplay is where Sekiro truly shines. The combat system is both elegant and brutal, requiring precise timing, strategy, and a mastery of the game's mechanics. The protagonist's arsenal of deadly samurai tools and the ability to parry and counter attacks make each battle an exhilarating dance of death. The difficulty curve is steep, but the sense of accomplishment when you conquer a challenging boss is unparalleled.

The story of Sekiro is a captivating tale of revenge and redemption, woven into the fabric of the game's world. The protagonist, Wolf, is a silent but compelling character whose journey is filled with intriguing NPCs and memorable interactions. The narrative is delivered in a subtle and immersive way, allowing players to piece together the lore as they progress.

Visually, the game is a work of art, with meticulous attention to detail in character design, animations, and environmental textures. The lighting and sound design further enhance the immersion, creating a world that feels alive and teeming with danger.

Sekiro also boasts an outstanding musical score that perfectly complements the on-screen action. From haunting melodies during tense moments to the adrenaline-pumping battle themes, the soundtrack adds another layer of depth to the overall experience.

In conclusion, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is a gaming masterpiece that combines breathtaking visuals, challenging gameplay, a compelling story, and superb craftsmanship. It's a game that demands dedication and skill but rewards players with an unforgettable journey through a beautifully realized world. For fans of FromSoftware's previous works or anyone seeking a gaming experience that pushes the boundaries of what's possible in the medium, Sekiro is an absolute must-play. This game sets a high watermark for the action-adventure genre, and it will undoubtedly be remembered as one of the greatest games of its generation.

Once it clicks, the most satisfying sword gameplay ever. Incredible game. Elden Ring doesn't hold a candle.

several years later this is still the best gameplay experience offered by FS: combat punishes you for not being good, without artificial cheats to make the game "harder". cheesing is not an option, enemy attacks are not tracking movement unless it is consistent with the laws of physics and input reading is used in the most balanced way possible. on this side some exceptions are present but are so scarce and sporadic they get a pass. after elden ring, seeing bosses having actual down times or openings after big damage/reckless attacks, not having 10+ hit combos is a huge plus. With sekiro I never had to wonder why bosses don't use their best move on repeat to win 100% of the time, because there is actual balancing in damage dealt/exertion required from the performer of the attack: this creates windows of opportunity for  retaliation that makes winning a fight consistent and logic. 

lore and world building are solid and are classics from FS in terms of not being 100% clear but you know what you need to enjoy the plot (on this side, dark souls definitely has an edge if you like lore speculation and analysing every small detail).

ultimately one just wonders what went downhill with elden ring's development...

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice marks the fifth FromSoftware title I've had the pleasure of experiencing. My motivation was to test my gaming skills, as Sekiro is widely recognized as FromSoftware's most formidable creation. While I concur that Sekiro's combat is undeniably challenging, I firmly believe that no other game can rival the sheer exhilaration it offers. The indescribable sensation that washes over you when you flawlessly parry and evade a boss's relentless assault is beyond words. Sekiro also boasts an array of unforgettable bosses.

While most of FromSoftware's games are known for their cryptic storytelling, I found Sekiro's narrative surprisingly accessible.

In my opinion, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice deserves a perfect 10/10 rating and is an absolute must-play for any gamer.

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is simply phenomenal. This my second game from FromSoftware, the other being Elden Ring.

Even though it is the same developer, these two games could not be more different mechanically I feel.
Sekiro demands of you to meet it at its level of difficulty and master its core mechanic (the combat, and specifically the parry system) in order to beat it.

There is no way around it. You will bang your head against the wall, dying to mobs and bosses, if you do not engage the game in the way it wants you too. It is truly fair in this regard in that your deaths and lack of progress, will be the result of your failures, misjudgment and drop in concentration rather than some unfair bullshit that the game throws at you just to be difficult for difficulty’s sake.

It’s important to say that Sekiro is not perfect in this regard as it has some situations that prompt you to say "Come on, what the fuck was that???" but this is such a rarity that it can't possibly cause you to uninstall and say how its unfair garbage meant to needlessly frustrate you and waste your time.

The main takeaway is that the game encourages player growth and when you beat it, it is only because you learned and became better, you fought and earned your victory. No one else.

The only negative I would say is the lack of variety in enemies, even though personally I didn’t mind I can see how someone might get tired of fighting primarily humanoid bosses and mobs. The environments, while beautifully crafted, also suffer from the same problem mentioned above. 
The soundtrack is extremely well composed, evocative of Japan set in the Sengoku period, fitting the games style and themes. Two tracks particularly stand out and you will surely recognize which ones I mean during your play-through.

All in all, I can’t recommend Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice enough. Expertly crafted and challenging in the right way, it will definitely be worth your money and time. And one very important thing to remember: Hesitation is defeat.

Valve made a massive change to the game that no one asked for and forced it on people by replacing the original game with it.

CS 2 only has a fraction of the maps and game modes that CS:GO had and Valve also deleted all of the old achievements, so if you were like me and proud of your 100% completion of CS:GO, Valve has ever so lovingly told you to go screw yourself.

Additionally in updating the game to CS2, Valve has somehow managed to completely break the near flawless anti-cheat system that was present in CS:GO, meaning the game is now absolutely riddled with hackers and script kiddies.

Not to mention the fact that this update was Valve taking an 11 year old game that ran fine on pretty much any system and replacing it with a game that runs like absolute dog crap unless you have a high end gaming PC. They took a game that people already purchased and made it virtually unplayable on older systems, essentially forcing people to either no longer play a game that they paid for or upgrade their computer to continue playing. Heck, I have a 3070 TI and even I frequently have frame rate issues in CS2, a problem that was non-existent in CS:GO.

Now Valve has said that they're working on updating the remaining maps and gamemodes to CS2, however if all the content wasn't ready then they should have either delayed the release or made it an OPTIONAL beta/DLC instead of replacing the original game with it.

Valve has been making an ever increasing amount of bad decisions in the past couple years and CS2 is one of them.

they took away left-handed view-models and all the achievements 

[Updated Oct 24 2023] 
Still no sign of left handed view models. I'm suspecting that Valve now sees mirroring the texture on a first-person view model as an infraction towards the sanctity of weapon skins. 

If Valve allowed me to use a predominately left handed view model while playing again, all of their weapon skins that included text it would look like this "ӘИIИЯAW" instead of this "WARNING". 

Using left handed view models would "break" any merchandise with text on it, and potentially cost Valve the sale of a key or marketplace transaction fee. Taking away the ability to use mirrored view models ensures I can always see the pretty text on expensive things "the way it was intended", and remain a possible customer. 

Valve has removed what was to me a core mechanic from the game I paid for many years ago.
I remain dissatisfied until I either get a complete refund for for all the keys and resulting skins I purchased with the intention playing with them mirrored or, "cl_righthand 0" is returned.

I've played CS for over five years, but to be honest I'm tired of the bullshit between players. If you're new to the game, I'd try something else as its population is full of established players who squabble and whine over the game-play of others. There's no words of advice or encouragement to be found and they'll simply treat you as a hindrance to their arrogant mastery of the game. They abuse the voting system to repeatedly attempt to get team-mates ejected from the match or even worse, never stop babbling, so distracting others trying to listen for footsteps. I eventually turned off chat because although it should be enabled for teams to work together, it's just used to call other players. CS2 is a great upgrade and game, but you may as well play with bots, unless you like being shouted at by armchair warriors proffering unsolicited advice from their parents basements. I wouldn't say the fan-base is toxic, but they're way too intolerant of noobs and perhaps have lost context of that CS2 is just a game!

They are at least attempting to fix some issues like fucked hit boxes but still, you knew we didn't want CS2, yet you still got rid of the original CS:GO and absolutely obliterated the competitive mode so we would play your fucking premier; which we already would have played without the complete butchering of original competetive. It has been a little over a month since CS2 has taken the place of our beloved CS:GO and just a reminder that commitment and doubling down is what left the TF2 team feeling dried out and the game itself in the state it was in durring the bot crisis (which is still a partially present issue). Also dragging hitboxxes that follow the player about a half second behind, an issue most seen in TF2, is prominent in this new and "improved" CS2. How do you manage to bring back a 15 year old glitch in to your game that you didn't have in the previous version? If you've ever played ARK, it has a similarly outrageous glitch where the non-dedicated session tethering setting will change the swimming move speed of dinosaurs such as the Moschops and Raptors. Meaning multiplying the extraordinarily small tethering range by 9999x (which barely allowed full movement across the entirety of The Island map, a twenty-something square kilometer map), will in turn multiply the swim speed of a Raptor; an already really fast dinosaur, by 9999x. This 9999x multiplier on swim speed is enough to jump half of the entire length of The Island map just by swimming into a rock. Glitches like these are insane and maybe I don't have enough knowledge on how game code is constructed; but to me these issues just don't make sense to even occur and doubt that it makes any sense to anybody else, especially in a soft remaster of an eleven year old game made by a multi-billion dollar company that is appraised for saving the PC gaming industry.

This is the first time ever playing CSGO/COUNTER-STRIKE and it's not bad. I come from Valorant/OW/COD etc and its up there with real competition gaming. The only gripe I have is the knife skins are SO DAMN EXPENSIVE. The cheapest skin is over $100 USD. I think they should make it affordable for all in regards of price. If you get a container, you still have to pay real money to buy a key to open it through steam. I dont like the fact when ADS its toggle no matter what and wish they can add a hold ADS option. Other than those two things I like the game. I have played 13.5hrs in 2 days of install. Yes its a major learning curve and so far the teams I have played competitive on have been friendly and understanding I come from Valorant and no clue the maps or call-outs yet. I still avg 10 kills a game. I recommend they game. Good game to get into.

Dead Cells: A Masterful Metroidvania
Dead Cells is a roguelike metroidvania that has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time. It's a perfect blend of challenging gameplay, rewarding progression, and addictive atmosphere.

The game's procedurally generated levels are always fresh and exciting, and the combat is fast-paced and brutal. There's a huge variety of weapons and abilities to experiment with, and each run feels different from the last.

I also love the game's sense of progression. As you play, you'll unlock new weapons, abilities, and items that will make you more powerful and help you reach new areas. It's incredibly satisfying to see your character grow stronger over time.

The game's atmosphere is also top-notch. The visuals are dark and atmospheric, and the soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful. It really sucks you into the world of Dead Cells.

The new Return to Castlevania DLC is a great addition to the game. It features new levels, enemies, and bosses that are inspired by the classic Castlevania games. It's a great way to relive some nostalgia, and it also adds some much-needed challenge to the game.

Overall, Dead Cells is a masterpiece. It's a must-play for fans of roguelikes, metroidvanias, or just great games in general. I highly recommend it.

Amazing game. Has the typical hardships and difficulty curves of a metroid-vania game, but feels good when you get further as you get better and as you unlock more stuff. The bosses are cool, levels are cool, weapons are cool, and all the DLCs are sweet.

Dead Cells was one of my first games where I truly exclaimed to myself, 'Damn, I'm having so much FUN!' There was a growing excitement within me as I progressed, encountering new enemies, exploring new biomes, and acquiring new weapons. Every step and jump I took was an absolute blast.

The game offers incredibly smooth and satisfying combat, accompanied by a mind-boggling array of weapons and abilities to choose from. The combinations of these elements frequently complement each other. The variety of enemy types encountered throughout the game is refreshingly diverse as you navigate through each level. The artwork, animations, and soundtracks are all fantastic, amplifying the overall experience a hundredfold. What I enjoy the most in this game are the boss fights. Game have some incredible boss fights and the satisfaction of defeating a boss never gets old.

I highly recommend this game, and I hope you'll enjoy it as much as I do. :)

Dead Cells is a high speed platformer action game that tries to mash the roguelite and metroidvania genres together. Unfortunately I didn't find the result anything special.

The art is really pretty with high quality animation and detailed pixel art backgrounds, while gameplay is designed to be fast paced with branching paths that take you towards different areas each with their own enemies and bosses to face against. Each step of the way you get access to random upgrades, unlock permanent improvements, and there's a variety of game modifiers. Sadly this game jumps on the 'souls like' train so you know what that means.

Souls-likes always suffer the same problem - every enemy becomes a knowledge-gate instead of a skill-check. There's more to be learned from souls games than just ramping up the volatility but few designers pick up on that and gamers foam at the mouth to be whipping boys for this style of arbitrarily hard gameplay. The result is you either waste weeks learning each knowledge gate or you put the game down and get meme'd on by everyone suffering from sunk cost fallacy - either way there are no true winners.

Overall dead cells feels like it has the potential to be a pretty solid game but squanders it. I can't see the combat design as anything other than lazy and while it tries to make up for it with fast gameplay to get you back in the action this just results in an incredibly repetitive experience without the substance to make investing in it worthwhile.

Easy...easy now. Let me explain. Yes Elden ring is a thumbs down. I have finished DSR, DS2, DS3 and Sekiro before this and i really liked DSR and Sekiro. But when i had reached DS3 midd-game i was starting to get full.
Repetition, repetition and repetition. Learn the the bosses moves and run to the next boss in a game with a 
storyline as dead and lifeless as the statue-like carachters you encounter along the ride.

Elden ring is exactly like the previous games. Yeah yeah it´s open world, you can fast travel and you can craft things. But the fast travel is the only real progression for the series. The open world is completely dead. It´s not like the Witcher world or other open world games. What From soft has done is basically just to smash down all the walls in DS3 and make it big. But it functions just as a filler and adds nothing of value. It´s still just three main things to do in the game, except killing bosses, and that is:

-Collect golden tears, collect sacred tears and collect smithing stones. Just like From softs earlier games. Sure you can run around in the big open world and colllect buffs, ashes of war and other things - but you certainly don´t need to. I chose a strong weapon in the start of the game (by killing an optional boss) and then i upgraded that weapon and collected all the flasks (estus flasks as they were called in previous games) i could find. And that was enough. The bosses were very easy. I killed most of the bosses in under two minutes head to head melee. And after i finished Margott, the omen king i was just as bored as i was when i got to midd-game DS3. But this time i stoped playing. The story is crap, the world is dead and the characters are as lifeless as a brickwall. Kill the boss and head to the next area and kill that boss too. That was enough five to ten years ago. Now its boring and predictable. Like eating corn flakes.

And why should i craft something? I didn´t craft a single item on my journey because i never needed to. And i never used an ash of war to buff my weapon. The crafting, the open world and many of the strengthening armamanet just felt like fillers. Pointless fillers.

Sure, i can see why ppl like the game. Especially ppl that never played From softs earlier games. But for those who know the DS-series should be tired of this by now. There is nothing new to the game. At least nothing that matters.

From software has created a bunch of really good games with the DS-series. But now its time to either evolve or move along. Elden ring felt old really fast.

I have never felt so conflicted about a game in my entire life. 
On one hand, the combat is fun and engaging with some amazing boss fights that are incredibly grandiose and epic, but on the other hand, I can not for the life of me get into this world and its story. The more and more I learn about it, the more I just despise it. The vast majority of the bosses are entirely optional and there is not any real motivation or justification to fight them, even among the remembrance bosses seeing as you just have to kill two and it literally does not matter which two since you don't have much motivation beyond getting the great runes you need to progress. A boss should mean more than some equipment and levels.
This world is also just exhausting to play in and explore. It is so massive and just jammed packed with stuff to do and enemies to fight that there is very few places where you can just relax and take a breather. They tried to use the round table hold for this, but it is entirely disconnected from the rest of the world and sometimes just feels like a glorified menu, lacking the comfort of say Firelink Shrine. Also, because of the scale, the few moments of meaningful and fun character interactions are either entirely missable if you aren't looking for them or so scattered they get drowned out by everything else.
Every ending to this game feels meaningless and in the end I am just left asking what was the point of any of it. 
Having only recently beaten Dark Souls 1 for the first time, the contrast between the two games is immense. Few games have captivated me with their world as much as Dark Souls was able to, and it didn't even feel like it was trying to impress me. 
It feels like this game wants you to care. 
It feels like it wants you to be amazed and intrigued. 
It feels like I've wasted 100 hours.

Summons trivialize most fights but are fun to watch them run around. Would recommend to anyone to try to defeat the bosses without spirit ashes first and use them when you get frustrated and feel like you have experienced the boss enough to move on.

In a good percentage of the boss fights it feels like they designed the boss encounters, had playtesters provide data on the attack timings and then offset them all by a half second. Trying to sight-read most of the boss attacks in the game is almost a futile endeavour as so many attacks are timed to roll catch you. It breaks some immersion as the boss holds the giant weapon in the air for 4 seconds providing ample openings for some attacks when other attacks come out lightning fast. Takes some of the fun out of it and forces you to intimately learn the bosses moveset. This is most definitely the intention of Fromsoft but it increases frustration in many encounters.

Platforming is required in some sections of this game and the control you have over your movements feels VERY insufficient. It works great for large running and jumping actions but the minute control required to do parkour between floating platforms and thin wooden beams is not something this game does even close to good enough.

I am only 18 hours in and this is the first From Soft game I have really gotten into but plan to give Sekiro another try when I am taking a break from Elden Ring.  Simply, this may be the greatest game since Zelda: Ocarina of Time that I have played.  I am in my 40s and gamed my whole life off and on.  The ways to approach situations are very open and lack of skill can be overcome by farming your stats a little bit in more familiar territory if desired.  The world is open and expansive and the enemies are as varied with their attacks as they are artistically.  I cannot give enough praise to this game.  10/10 and will age gracefully.  Well Done.

Pior souls da franquia

Sinceramente, o game é entupido de bugs e totalmente mal otimizado, os graficos não são incríveis mas mesmo uma 3090 tem dificuldade para rodar, rodei tranquilamente Horizon Zero Dawn no Ultra que é 10x mais  lindo que Elden Ring e um mundo muito mais preenchido e não tive dificuldades pra manter 60fps, enquanto alguns inimigos nesse jogo fazem o FPS dropar para 25fps.

Gameplay, os inimigos combam infinitamente, leem os comandos que você da no teclado e como se isso não fosse suficiente, eles podem segurar os ataques e iniciar animações e imediatamente cancelar para outras, então boa sorte indo lá dar um golpe no boss enquanto ele ta na animação de recuperar, porque ele pode simplesmente cancelar e iniciar uma sequencia, na qual você não consegue esquivar porque esta preso no ultimo comando que você deu e quando levantar vai levar outro hit porque o jogo vai tentar executar o ultimo ataque por conta do input buffering ridiculo que esse jogo tem e nem preciso dizer da esquiva, qualquer um que joga Elden Ring sabe que leva 2s pra sair a esquiva depois de apertar o space.

Fora que não da pra trocar os inputs do game, cansei de morrer porque dei um ataque pesado que usa o (botao direito e esquerdo junto com o shift) e logo dps do ataque pesado saiu um ataque rapido por conta do input buffering gigantesco.

Os bugs daria pra fazer uma lista gigantesca, serio, NPC que some, NPC que revive, NPC q fica do mal sem motivos, quest que buga se vc der TP, itens que ficam inacessiveis se vc não seguir uma sequencia perfeita, tipo o slot de amuleto q se matar o boss dps de ter 3 slots o NPC n te entrega o slot porque ele só entrega se for menor que 2(incrível programação)

Balanceamento

Bosses com HP enorme, como pode o Margit ter 20k de HP, se você não grindar antes de ir para a luta, vai ficar 2h só pra matar o boss, fui tirando +650 por hit e levou 25(+  ou -)golpes pra finalizar o inimigo.

Dano, qualquer inimigo é praticamente one shot, serio, usar armadura e não usar armadura é praticamente a mesma coisa, 70%  de absorção de dano, ainda tomo 80% de dano pro Crucible Knight, jogo é feito pra vc nunca levar um golpe mas esqueceram de te falar que leva 2s dps de apertar space para a esquiva sair.

Design dos bosses é horrível, muitos só são bosses repetidos ou lutas onde eles colocaram 2 bosses mas não programaram pra eles lutarem com sinergia, eles simplesmente fica indo um em cima do outro spamando ataques sem parar, serio, Dupla do Godskins, só sabe ficar spamando o feitiço um após o outro sem nenhuma brecha pra atacar e não da pra trocar hit porque são 2.

De fato é pior souls da franquia, só recomendo jogar com Seamless Co-op, torna a experiencia menos frustrante e mais divertida, já que até o multiplayer original do game é um terrível.

Dark souls 2 >>>>>> Elden Ring

[h3]Elden Ring is by far the best game I have played in a while.[/h3] I should probably add I've never played any Dark Souls games before so I'm new to the genre. 
The combat while difficult is rewarding and engaging. Even the simplest enemies can harm you if you don't respect them, and even the biggest and most epic monsters can be beaten if you're patient and learn their moves.
The world of Elden Ring is simply stunning, all of the zones are packed with fascinating places, NPCs and monsters. The game indicates where to go not by using arrows or markers, but simply by being well designed. There's always somewhere to go, someone to talk to or someone to fight.

The boss fights are something else, everytime there's a cinematic leading to a major boss I'm getting shivers. They are [b] EPIC[/b].

If you decide to play this game do not be discouraged at first (as I was), the game IS difficult, but if you overcome its challenges, you feel rewarded. It's a game everyone should try.

This review is my opinion. Other opinions are valid.

This game is kinda mix of Witcher 3 and Horizon Zero Dawn in Graphics and Dark souls in gameplay. But gameplaywise in comparison to Witcher  3 or Horizon Zero Dawn  many things are bad, simply bad. 

Leveling and pacing. You can grind or cheat runes and it will make combat easier for casual player. In Witcher 3 or Horizon or Skyrim there was no need to grind to fight bosses or progress in story.

Map navigation = there is no minimap, if you buy or find a map no markers will be shown,  not even points of interest or sites of grace, which was the case in Witcher 3 or Horizon Zero Dawn.

Bosses and many regular Mobs Combat is too complicated for casual and normal player. Blocking with shield does not work properly - many mobs or bosses like banished knights either have attacks which instadeplete your stamina with 1-2 hits ( this with maxed out stamina ! ) or even if you succesfully block and do a counter-hit they do fast follow up attacks which interrupt your counter-hit and do heavy damage or kill you. Magic attacks cant be blocked at all with shield. Stealth attacks or after stance break are random - one millisecond pressing button too long or standing wrong does only normal attack - in Horizon or Skyrim stealth attacks always worked.

Upgrade system is pure grind = finding smithing stones is grind. Witcher 3 solved it much better with runes and schematics for witcher gear and breaking down loot to resources.

NO bestiary diary = in a game with hard  dark souls combat not to include a bestiary like in Witcher 3 or Horizon Zero Dawn where weakness of enemies was shown what time of damage etc. and also some lore is awful. 

Fazit : Buy only if you are a Dark Souls fan, if you are a Witcher 3, Skyrim or Horizon Zero Dawn fan dont buy.

Elden Ring is a game I genuinely enjoyed. It's not often that I find myself completing a game, let alone achieving 100% completion, but Elden Ring drew me in quickly. I didn't even start playing it until about a week after its launch when someone told me what it was. I decided to get a hold of it after watching my friends mess around with Comet Azur and the Sword of Night and Flame. It's no surprise that it earned the Game of the Year title. This game is a rarity, one of those experiences that justifies both the launch price and the time invested.

The world they've crafted is expansive and filled with secrets and challenges that kept me engaged throughout my three playthroughs, each with different builds. The combat is satisfying, and, of course, it can be frustrating at times, but that was part of the appeal for me. I actually appreciated the fact that this wasn't a game I could grind for 10+ hours in one sitting. It made me appropriately frustrated, forcing me to return with a clear mind or after a good night's rest (especially when dealing with those dragon bosses everyone but me seemed to think were easy). If you're in the market for one of the best video games, give Elden Ring a go. It's a game I truly enjoyed and if you choose to wait for a sale that's okay too. A DLC should be dropping for it soon enough so that's something we can all look forward to.

Thanks for reading.

Pros:  World layout is great and nice to explore.  Great graphics and best animations.  Diverse enemy behaviors and attacks.  Mounted combat is ok.  Good amount of content.

Major cons:
Terrible PC port
Interface is made for console with no/very poor adaptation.
Can't remap all hotkeys.  Can't use all keys as an hotkey.
Menus and inventories are inconsistent.  Sometimes you are forced to use Esc to exit, sometimes another key, sometimes you can click, sometimes you can't.
Map navigation does not recognize remapped keys.  The entire map interface is terribad.  Can't even click on a desired destination but have to slowly scroll a cursor up to there.  w.t.f.?
Some menus forces you to use X and Z to navigate for example.   You can't even click instead sometimes.
Everything related to the quick pouch is terrible also.  Quickaccess are placed in a cross pattern for controller but does not indicate which hotkey is which.  No effort whatsoever in keyboard adaptation.
Can't drag anything: for example view angle in character creation, map view, moving content of inventory to storage or equipment pieces, etc.

The game is just made artificially difficult by imprecise mechanics:
Movement and attacks are imprecise and excessively clumsy to a point it is unfun.
The UI lacks audio feedback (for example to know if an action has been queued, or if stamina is lacking, etc.)
Forced to rely on a disappointing and inconsistent locked target auto-targeting attack system instead of properly aiming attacks and blocks.  It also locks the camera.  It is bad in every combination of settings options.  Minimal movement of the mouse can change the target to some irrelevant animal in the vicinity.
Locked target auto-aiming spells or projectiles make combat so boring.
Several deaths are caused by camera derping around near a wall, close to a large boss or inside a tent.
Some boss enemies attack cues are intentionally misleading.  This could be fine but only when progressed further in the game.  It is just forcing the players to tediously waste an excessive amount of time to learn bosses abilities or to use guides from outside the game.  If you used such a guide to learn how to beat a boss then that is a proof of this flawed design.  At first glance, those guides and videos seem to be numerous.
The core combat gameplay is mostly: learn the various boss choreographies, then patiently wait for your turn to poke in a few attacks, repeat.

Poor balance and design choices:
Your first battle is against an enemy you aren't meant to beat which is totally pointless and confusing.
The tutorial doesn't do a good job at letting you learn and experiment because those enemies are super slow, weak and die in one or two hits.
Many abilities seem pointless because under-tuned while some other seem too strong.  Therefore, the numerous attack options are reduced to only a couple useful ones.
Normal enemies are almost blind, you can kill one member of a patrol squad without a reaction from the rest. 
Most normal enemies will also give up chasing after 30 meters.

General annoyances:
Multiplayer messages are typically just spoilers and annoyance as players intentionally put them in the way to interfere with items to pickup or to activate.
It sucks that rolling and sprinting are forced to be on the same key.
Some random software crashes where you can lose progress and then, the game annoys you even more by giving you the "You should quit the game properly" message.
Resources gathering and crafting feel mostly pointless partly because the beneficial effect duration of consumables are very short.
Dark ambiance is well achieved although story is vague and confused.

I very much enjoy difficult games when the controls and camera are good but unfortunately, it is not the case here.  For better combat try out any of those: New World, Valheim, Tera, Black Desert Online, Skyrim or pretty much any aimed combat game designed for computer.

There is still some fun to be had.  However, I can not recommend this product until they replace the fake keyboard + mouse interface by a real one.

The game is amazing, one of the best souls genre out there. The world is beautiful, maybe the most beautiful game I have ever seen. If you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients
- To Make the Dough
375 grams (3 cups) plain flour
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 eggs
1/4 cup (50 ml / 3½ tablespoons) olive oil
1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) water
Extra flour for dusting 


- To Make Cheese Filling
15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese
5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) "3 Cheese Italian Blend" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago)
Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend.
1/2 cup cheddar cheese
2 eggs, lightly beaten
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon pepper


- Extras
Your favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana)
Parmesan cheese
Basil
Fried vegetables
Shrimp
Fish slices
Chicken pieces 
Make the Ravioli filling.

- In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork.
- Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper.
- Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency.
- Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. 

Make the Ravioli dough.

- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.
- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.
- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.
- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.
- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.
- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).
- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesn’t suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor. 

Fill the Ravioli shells.

- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.
- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.
- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a “homemade” touch as well.
- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.
- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. 

Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.

- Roll the dough into two sheets
- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.
- Fill with the ravioli mixture.
- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.
- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.

Cook the Ravioli.

- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.
- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.
- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest 
- Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed plates

Serve it up.
Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy the Formuoli

Dota 2

Dota 2 is hard, but there's a huge reward for those who commit. On the surface, the game is a like-for-like reproduction of the genre-creating (and still updated) Defense of the Ancients modification for Warcraft III, now transferred into Valve's Source engine. The game's punishing design is sometimes enough to drive you up the wall, but it's worth sticking the hours in: success in Dota 2 is about learning to effectively juggle both the broad strokes and finer details.

If you're not aware of the basics of the burgeoning MOBA genre, two teams of five players spawn on corners of a map. Each team needs to work together with the goal of ultimately destroying a central structure--in Dota 2's case, the Ancient--in the opposing team's base. With most games lasting around the 40-minute mark, and occasionally edging past an hour, watching the enemy fortress dramatically crumble and sink to the ground feels like an exhilarating payoff.

Aiding these two teams, named the Radiant and the Dire, are waves of AI assistants, called creeps. Batches of creeps spawn at 30-second intervals and charge merrily up the map's three pathways. In the clumps of remaining land lies a jungle, where numerous AI opponents spawn, offering lucrative benefits to players who take them on successfully. Finally, and in a bid to stop both teams from simply marching into one another's base, each team gets three powerful towers on each lane that easily shred through enemy players at the start of the game.

Your individual ability to control and affect the rhythm of the game comes from how well you handle your hero. You mostly control a single unit in Dota 2, though there are exceptions: some heroes can summon controllable allies, such as bears, gargoyle babies, or wolves; one exceptionally versatile hero can split into three; and one item lets you take control of certain creeps. For each rule in Dota 2's impressive house-of-cards design, there's usually at least one character who completely ignores it, or finds a way around it via one of 130-odd items available from the in-match shop. For instance, try negating magic attacks with the black king bar, returning damage with the blade mail, or pounding out two ultimate abilities in quick succession with a refresher orb.

The aim for most players is to accumulate as much gold and experience as possible, with income being delivered mostly by scoring the killing blow on enemy creeps and players. It's almost always easier to gang up on stray enemies as a group, which is why it's rarely a good idea to run about on your own. Then it's a case of splashing all your hard-earned money on some ultra-powerful items from the shop, while levelling up your base stats and abilities, and then clobbering the enemy team into submission via a few five-versus-five team fights. Rarely does it feel that simple, however.

At the time of writing, 102 of the original Dota's 112 heroes have made their way into the sequel. Each hero has a handful of unique abilities and generally works best in a specific role, such as supporting other players as Omniknight, roaming around the map looking for opportunistic kills as Spirit Breaker, or evolving throughout the course of the game into an all-powerful vehicle of carnage and destruction as Phantom Assassin.

There's only one map, unlike in many other MOBA titles, although Valve has not ruled out the addition of more over time, and has previously offered game-changing modes with seasonal events at Halloween and Christmas. But Dota 2's single sprawling map sets itself apart from the competition by being larger, more intricate, and packed with greater detail than the rest of the genre. Unlike in League of Legends, the jungle area is riddled with far more tangling pathways, the lanes feature additional shops selling exclusive items, and savvy players are given more opportunities to use the environment to hide, flee, and ambush their opponents.

Often the game's dizzying scale is seen as off-putting or simply too complex, but the truth of Dota is that it can be entertaining as a new player to just sit down and let all those extraneous factors play out around you. Getting down to the brass tacks of the game with a group of like-minded friends is a lot of fun: start by buying your characters' recommended items, try your best not to get caught out of position, and get into the habit of buying observer wards. And watch out for Riki.

As you'd expect from Valve, this is a beautifully presented game, with the Half-Life and Portal maker running victory laps around its competition in terms of UI, voice acting, and showing how to deftly add real personality to its characters. Only recently has the developer turned its attention to gently easing new players into the proceedings, however, and even now, mastering the basics feels like learning to swim by jumping in at the deep end. Efforts are being made to remedy this, though: right now there are a couple of tutorial levels, some well-designed AI bots, and a newbie playlist that restricts hero selection to just 20 of the most frequently picked characters. And with community-created hero guides now built directly into the game itself, Dota 2 is much easier to get started with than it has been in the past.

Play a match every evening for a couple of weeks, and you start to see how Dota 2's wealth of disparate systems and mechanics combine into their own harmony, and you begin to understand how there are hundreds of elements that affect the game. Dota 2 is a tense war of accumulation and attrition. The biggest problem, which is coincidentally where the real excitement of the game lies, comes from struggling to process and interpret dozens upon dozens of mitigating circumstances while simultaneously trying to keep your cool.

It is a complicated and exhausting game, and for the first few weeks, it's challenging just keeping up with the general rhythm of a match. But invest enough time into Dota 2, and you develop an almost unconscious ability to keep up with the game--performing actions such as sending the slightly fiddly in-game courier over to the faraway "secret" shop to get some rare items, for instance. After a couple of hundred hours of Dota 2, what once felt like spinning plates just happens automatically.

While Dota 2 has transferred the core of the original Dota into a cleaner, modern engine, the fact remains that losing is uniquely painful. Death in Dota 2 not only gives your opponent money, but robs you of some of your own and leaves you waiting up to a minute to respawn. By the time you've trudged back across the game's massive map--or spent money on a teleportation scroll--your opponent is now stronger and richer. Die two or three times in quick succession, which is easily done, and a match of Dota becomes a painful experience where you spend the next half hour getting bullied by an increasingly superior enemy. Other games in the genre have tried to mitigate this punishment, but Dota 2 positively revels in its complexities. The rich just get richer.

The original Dota was an unexpectedly powerful blend of clashing genres and disparate elements that ended up taking over the world, and Valve's successor retains the original rules and characters while adding in a cheery free-to-play model and slick production values. The experience of playing Dota changes day by day--some evenings will be exhilarating, while others will kick your morale to the curb--but there are few games as worthy of your time investment as this. Those who choose to commit to Dota 2 will find many happy hours within this immaculate update.
