Ridiculously good game which I've played several times over the years. 

I don't like Patch 4.0 however. The graphical updates make the game stupid slow and I'm forced to play the game in 1080p on a system that runs other modern games at 4k high settings. In addition many of the balancing changes were unnecessary in a single player game. I wanted to finish a playthrough where I was in Toussaint and my build (5 decoction euphoria) is completely botched. Granted alchemy was overpowered, but nerfing acquired tolerance + heightened tolerance + manticore armor seems like overkill, and I can only drink three decoctions without having to spam stamina for ekhidna HP regen to offset losing health. In addition a bunch of my decoctions are gone from the inventory.

Probably I will have to just drink a potion of clearance and reset everything. But I don't know the extent of all the balance changes and feel like I have to relearn everything, which feels like a big chore on a game this old. I'd bet there's a way to roll back the update, but if I were you and I'd played the game before and like it as is I simply wouldn't update it.

This is updated post "Next-gen update." 8 years after release this is still one of the best looking games out there. The gameplay has aged like fine wine as well. If you're looking for an absolutely massive game world DENSE with things to do - this is it. It looks and plays better than most games released today.

[b]Pros:[/b][list]
[*]Incredible visuals
[*]Absolutely massive game world
[*]A story so deep it rests right above the earth's core
[*]A [b]PLETHORA[/b] of side quests and random events that you can stumble upon
[*]Easily over 100 hours of gameplay
[*]Crafting and loot system
[*]This game leaves nothing to the imagination when it comes to fleshing out characters
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]A metric ton of exposition[/b] - I mean good god the dialogues in this game are longer than the lifespan of a turtle - and there's a fuckin' billion of them. Be prepared to watch dozens of hours of cutscenes.
[*]Take no damage dropping 2 feet, yet die at full health from falling 3 feet - I recommend a fall damage mod to make this a non-issue.
[/list]

Overall a great game, and years later it still holds its own as one of the absolute best games of all time.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a game that will blow your mind with its epic story, stunning world, and thrilling gameplay. You play as Geralt, a witcher who hunts monsters and searches for his daughter Ciri, who is chased by a deadly force. You will explore different regions, meet various characters, and make choices that matter. You will fight with swords, magic, and gadgets, and customize your skills, gear, and look. Yes.

Edit - This was a positive recommendation (it's a great game, no doubt) except...

CDPR, why? For whatever reason when I try playing the non ray traced version (classic version), it just refuses to open. Plus they've also included their Red Launcher with installing this game. I've spent a couple hours trying to look up and troubleshoot this issue online but can't seem to find anything on how to fix it. 

Ironically though, the Ray Traced version works fine, but is quite demanding. The classic version worked perfectly a couple years ago when I played the first time.

I mean get this game if you have a beefy system that can handle the new update, but if you're hoping to play with the old graphics, beware. Might not work for you.

Edit x2 - So I managed to finally get it to work. I needed to install Visual C++ 2012 64 bit for a missing DLL (I never got the error for the missing DLL by launching the game through Steam, but found the witcher.exe file in Witcher3>bin>x64>witcher.exe. Opening that gave me the dll error and I finally figured out the issue).
Not sure why Visual C++ wasn't auto installed with the game (they generally are), but at least the game works now.

I put off playing this game until a few weeks ago because of the gigantic backlog and MMOs eating up my free time, but I finally got around to it, 7 years late to the party but here I am!
I don't think I can say anything that hasn't already been said. This is a masterpiece, and I don't throw this word around lightly. This is far and above my favorite western RPG and it is not even close. The amount of detail that was put into the world, with all the side quests that are as interesting, and in some cases more, than the main story, along with tons of NPC dialogue as you pass by, really make the world feel alive.
It is also rare that a western RPG has a memorable soundtrack, but this game has done it, the music is fantastic, with some stand outs in particular. 
Gameplay is good, although a bit on the easy side, but the difficulty settings exist to tune your own experience, for people who want a decent challenge, I recommend the difficulty below the highest, it struck a nice balance of difficulty without becoming annoying, and actually made me interact with the games' various systems such as the potions, crafting etc.

This was honestly a magical experience that will stay in my mind for a very, very long time. If you are on the fence at all about playing the game, just do yourself a favor and start!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The game has not aged well. If Elden Ring was your first From Software game and you want to see 'where it all began', I would recommend playing it. But only then. 

This is my first ever review, but since everyone seems to criticize the remastered version for being an overpriced patch and I just wanted to know if the game is a good choice for newcomers, I wanted to share my toughts on the game as someone who has no nostalgia connected to it. 

I have never played a Dark Souls game before (Elden Ring was my introduction) and never thought I ever will (too hard, too frustrating), but since Elden Ring is my favourite gaming experience since The Witcher 3 and Red Dead Redemption 2, I thought I finally had to give it a try (discount...). And although Elden Ring pulled my in right from the start, Dark Souls 1 never really reached me. The mechanics, erratic questlines, weird npcs and the interconnected world - it is all there, but (for me) Elden Ring is just the way superior experience. In every aspect.

Even though I - of course - did not expect it to be as good as ER, I still was disappointed. I don't really know why I never really enjoyed the game, but one reason is that there is almost never any music, which in ER greatly enhanced the atmosphere for me. In Dark Souls 1 the only things you hear are your own too loud footsteps and the monsters/fight sounds. That can be immersive in tight dark corridors - but it never was for me. The parts I liked the most were the very first area (dark clouds, a fallen castle, thunder rumbling in the background: excellent), and the very last area (mostly because of the visuals). Here the game really shines.

Speaking of visuals: usually, I do not care much about graphics, especially if it is a game from 2011, but I have to say, except from the lighting in some areas: this game does not look good, especially the late game areas reminded me of Gothic 1, a (great) game from 2001, that was already graphically outdated when it was released. In DS1 many areas are pretty big, but also feel pretty empty. I don't want to spoil anything, but often they are just bland: too huge (but of course smaller than in ER) to really fill them, so you have some items and some enemies here and there and that's it. I never was fully intrigued by this world and was never motivated to think about the story of this decaying land as I was in Elden Ring, where every part of the world seems to breathe story and atmosphere. The same thing is said about Dark Souls 1, but at least I did not have this impression.

My biggest concern before playing was the difficulty. After playing Elden Ring (and Sekiro) the game is pretty manageable. The bosses almost move in slow-mo compared to the two and should not give you too much trouble, if you have played ER or Sekiro. But even here, the game could not convince me. While ER felt like a fair and rewarding challenge, the gameplay in DS1 often just annoyed me due to just annoying design choices. In one notorious area for example 1 hit (arrow) of a certain enemy type is enough to change your status into toxic - at the beginning of the area. Have fun to explore and fight! The said enemies don't respawn and you can use an item against it (if you know about it), but it is still a cheap way to artificially increase a difficulty that is not challenging but often simply annoying. Another example: you can get a curse that halves your HP, even after you died - good luck finding a cure. Not to speak of one of the most annoying boss fights in video game history. Many will say that this is the typical Dark Souls experience and it certainly is. But ER never annoyed me this way, while still being an actual challenge (learn movesets) and providing a breathing and mysterious world.
 
Just a newcomers perspective. I only finished it once and I do not know if I will ever play it again. So why still the thumbs up? Because I absolutely love Elden Ring and can acknowledge its promising beginning in DS1.

As a player starting the Souls genre with Elden Ring, this feels similar and still different. I do appreciate the consistency with which FromSoft tackles game mechanics and you clearly see the evolutionary path up to the point of Elden Ring.

That being said, a lot of the quality of life improvements are still missing here, which is a good thing. The world feels much more condensed, raw and deadly. The atmosphere is phenomenal and clearly sets this game apart from ER.

I got it on a deal for roughly 20 bucks, but if I wasn't on a tighter budget right now would have bought it at it's regular 40 bucks as well at some point.

I think there's no need to argue the quality of this game anymore. Graphically it works just fine setting a very distinctive tone. Sound design and music is top notch.

All in all I highly recommend Dark Souls to anyone seeking a good challenge and to players familiar with newer FromSoft titles who can live without some of the quality of life things like fast travel and an in-game map system.

The game often feels more like a puzzle to solve instead of a difficult challenge to overcome.  Solutions are not always obvious but figuring them out feels very rewarding.  The combat is usually slowly paced and methodical, it feels more like a turn-based game than an action RPG at most times.  The boss encounters are usually one-note and the exuberant feeling after defeating one is mostly due to not having to do the boss's run-back again.  Overall, a very impressive game with a reputation the precedes it, and a new player experiencing the game for the first time over a decade later can still have a memorable experience playing it.

I fucking hate this game. Aside from that, it was a incredible experience some of the areas unbelievably stupid hard but other than that it's an awesome game. Recommended to all those who deem themselves worthy.

The game's PvP is completely neutered by the removal of dead angles and ghost strikes, so the backstab meta is much stronger (hard to imagine I know) than in the original and you have less ways to defend against it. 
Another thing that fucks everyting up is introduction of the dogshit DS3 style matchmaking, which no longer allows you to invade infinitely up and also locks you in a specific weapon upgrade bracket, so the pool of available players to play with is by default much smaller than in the original no matter the online activity.

The PvE is pretty much the same, hitboxes of certain attacks from certain bosses are a little more forgiving (Smough's ass slam, Ceaseless Discharge tenticle slams and swipes, Stray Demon AOE blast, etc.) due to the game now running natively at 60fps, so that is nice. The lighting is worse than in the original, a lot of the metallic armors look like they're made out of plastic now. The game graphically took a small step back it feels, the upscaled textures look like complete shit sometimes, the original was a bit more grainy looking but it worked in its favour imo. 

If you're only interested in PvE and don't want to bother pirating PTDE and patching the shit out of it to make it playable, then go ahead I guess. 

If your intent is PvP, then please don't bother.

Dark Souls. 

An iconic name, rhyming with difficulty and despair. 
It is true to an extent. 
I wanted to try it for myself, even if I'm not a hardcore gamer. And what a journey ! 

I finished it in Normal Game and in New Game +. 


The art is one of the points that surprised me the most. The remastered version is beautiful and smooth, the dark fantasy, bleak but nonetheless medieval fantastic atmosphere is something that I missed in games. Just look at landscapes from Sen's Fortress and Anor Londo, and you will feel a real medieval Lord of the Ring's Weathertop, Osgiliath and Minas Tirith or Berserk castles vibes. I also really loved the forest/ruins environment from Undead parish. 

The music is non existent while exploring, it gives a real feeling of vulnerability since you are startled by the smallest environmental noise. It is also epic and terrifying while fighting bosses. My favourites ones are those from Ornstein & Smough and Kalameet. 

The scenario and lore are quite difficult to find, you have to look up the item's descriptions to gather informations. Even if it is rewarding to understand the puzzle bit by bit, I was often lost with the lore and I don't think I could understand it without videos and wikis. Also the NPCs dying or going hollow if you didn't talked to them at a specific point or didn't do something to keep them alive (even if you didn't know) is a tad frustrating. 

As Sartre said "Hell is other people". Well, in Dark Souls you'll start to think it's true. Especially when you try to return to the bonfire with enough souls to level up and a bloke invade you while you have no more estus, let you get rammed by monsters and emote on your face after backstabbing you... Unforgettable experience.

The difficulty is one of the most iconic part. The fact that you can't choose the difficulty is THE BEST. It is something that you never experienced before. At first I took three weeks to reach O&S because I was scared to die. But after beating NG, I got like "f*ck it we ball" and played normally. Dark Souls is one of the best gaming experience I had with Nier: Automata. The feeling when you triumph from an area that gave you nightmares is unique (I'm looking at you Tomb of Giants, you were the first area to make me ragequit in 20 years of gaming). Or after beating monstrous boss (Ornstein and Smough of course, but also Artorias, Manus, or Four Kings in NG+... They nearly crushed my spirit). You'll have to keep your mental resilience in check and never yield. My advice is to take small breaks (5 minutes to a few hours) when you begin to get tilted, and come back with a renewed spirit. 
 

Dark Souls is an experience, a proof that you can do it. 
Forge ahead, and don't go hollow.

It's the exact same game under the hood, but with an improved engine and higher-quality assets built from the same source material. Newer optional mechanics such as optional room passwords (to get around level limits) are also available for those co-op sessions. This release is objectively the best way to play the game, and seemingly does not change or remove anything else unnecessarily.

However, if you prefer a more polished and straightforward game you can start with Dark Souls 3, and then play the other titles afterwards.

I think what makes this game special is the map design. The interconnectedness of the world creates a sense of exploring through an abandoned land, not just areas put together in a linear form. For example, you can see Lost Izalith from Tomb of the Giants or you can see Firelink Shrine from Blighttown. These little nuances increases the immersiveness of the game. After 12 years it still holds up. A must play for any FromSoftware fan.

Best Souls game by a mile. It's janky as hell, literally looks like PS2 era graphics, has terrible, literally atrocious, hitboxes, and often feels downright unfair, not to mention the ridiculous commitment to actions, absurdly slow healing, and weird hit directionalization. Cannot put this game down. In all seriousness tho, yes, I do think this is the best souls game, purely for the highs and lows this game makes you feel. You will feel some of the most intesne rage at trying to complete areas or fighting bosses, or fighting the run up to bosses, and it will make you grind your teeth to ash with rage. Then, you will experience an orgasmic, near divine feeling of joy and satisfaction upon completing those areas or killing those bosses. But what really makes this game peak souls is the vibes. No other souls games makes you feel so bleak, so downtrodden, so helpless as this game does. The gameplay reinforces the themes and emotions of the game: you feel frustrated and angry at the controls because you feel helpless, much like your character is supposed to feel helpless in the face of the inevitable fading of fire and the futility of the choice they are given in the end. This game, for all its jank and issues, is a masterpiece

Dark Souls II is a game that is very controversial among the community. A video Ill be referencing is "In The Defense of Dark Souls II" by Hbomberguy. I figured I'd agree with him. I watched his video while playing Dark Souls I. I heavily disagree however and its funny because the reasons he defends it I agree with. The problem is all the major issues he COMPLETELY IGNORED. (love you hbomberguy lol)

Movement - An important core part of DARK SOULS. It defines your life and death... and this games movement is horrible. I found as I moved around something didnt feel right, I would turn and snap into a certain direction. On top of this while moving, my character seemingly wanted to move towards the direction the camera was facing. I came to find the there are only 8 directions of movement. As if this is a 2D old school top down game. This is horrible. This is pivotal to parkour and fighting, and it has caused me to die CONSTANTLY. IT S DOWN RIGHT HORRIBLE. Moving across tight platforms even had me zig zagging across them with a side ways camera angle running away from enemies in a tight position because of the 90 degree snap Id do left and right.  90% of my deaths have not been because of lack of skill or anything but falling to my death, or not moving properly in battle because the game isn't designed to well at all. This is down right, unacceptable and ruins a core aspect of the game.  I'm not even done yet though.

GENERAL COMBAT - The AI in this game is incredibly dumb. If there's a bump on the ground they cant get to you, if you aren't on the same ground level of them they don't know you are there even if you are in front of them. They also kill themselves accidentally allll the time. other games are known to use this as a strategy, but its blatant and a massive problem in DARK SOULS II. Also, combat in this game is as slow as molasses. Its personally very much so not my thing, and its quite bad. Especially when things like parries are heavily delayed. It feels right in the other games but very not so here, just feels weird. Also, side note, your weapons brake insanely quickly now... It just makes you sit at a bonfire, and stops the flow of the game. Which I loved because at least this game had teleportation unlike DS1. This game loves snaps, because lock ons can provide ridiculous snap on attacks, with a side of enemies also doing so. There is a hammer enemy that you can dance around all day and dodge spam if you wanna, but he will like spin snap to you and squash you, this rarely happens when you lock on to enemies too. Its clear why this is a problem for locking on, but maybe not so much to everyone fighting an enemy. You could argue once you know itll be ok, or that you just get used to it but it just feels dumb and unnatural. It also makes it hard to time when they are acting like you are still in that direction and then suddenly in a milisecond snap to you. Locking on can also be horrible in general because you can dodge and when you attack instead of hitting the lock on it will attack in the direction you rolled, how terrible is that!?!  again dark souls 2... UNACCEPTABLE!
(Also, backstabs like never register for some reason... When they do, they require two taps now because its a back wack and then an attack, 50% of the time on top of the already hard to activate move thats super precise, it will fail and the second hit wont register while you are either A hit, or B the enemy just rolls away somehow...)

HITBOXES - This game has perfect hitboxes sometimes, and othertimes... THEY ARE SHIT, and inaccurate. You will be hit when you shouldn't be. Its important that the game presents to you when, or how you will be hit, and this does not do that well sometimes at all. This can be frustrating and dumb. ADP will fix it though! Then YOUR HITBOXES someitmes dont hit when they should, in a game where mistakes can mean death, this is unacceptable. Sometimes I got hit by enemies that Id kill and they wouldn't get to swing and the swing that doesn't exist would HIT ME AND KILL ME!! alternatively, sometimes the enemies should be hitting me but swords go through me like I'm a ghost. Other times explosions would kill me through walls, other times arrows would kill me through walls. These bastards are just using no-clip now! THIS IS CONSISTENT. You probably think its just a few moments of video game unfairness, but unlike other games, this game is consistent and common with it... UNACCEPTABLE. 

ADP - You have got to be kidding me. If I didn't look this up I would have had an even worse time in this game. This alone is unacceptable. This stat, seems on the surface to just increase agility and resistance to poisons and etc... BUT ITS NOT JUST THAT ITS ALSO I FRAMES!!! aka invincibility frames in your roll! This is explained or shown NOWHERE. This is important, most players will run through this game unable to dodge for shit, itll probably make them fall back to using a shield and you know why? BECAUSE THEY HAVE TO ALMOST FRAME PERFECT ROLL BECUASE THEY DONT KNOW TO UP ADP!!! This is also just insane absolutely insane! MAKE SURE YOU DO THAT BTW! ADP! ADP! ADP!!!! (which gets OP when you can TRIPLE that amount, this can be INSANELY OP!) ((ITS ALSO BAD IN TERMS OF RPG CHOICE MAKING!!!))

HEALTH DEPLETION - After every death, even over dumb parkour issues you will be having because of movement problems (and combat scenarios like all the time.) you will be punished severely. This is a game where you are expected to die a lot. This game doesnt make you think: "ooh ooh I should make sure I dont die and try harder!" It makes you not be as open and free to testing things out and be aggressive. On top of this, this game that expects you to die shouldnt punish you by dying, especially that half a health bar can mean EVERYTHING when this is a game where you can die in 1-3 hits. Very dumb mechanic. Its like its just hard for the sake of being hard, absolutely terrible.

LEVEL DESIGN - Some areas are poorly designed and lack depth, a lot of areas of the game are also just OP status effect screwing you over. It makes playing this game a chore sometimes, and makes you not want to replay it, some areas are just annoying.

BOSSES - So easy, and most of them are reskins, or super forgetable. Its really bad. I beat most of them first try. Some of them suffer the AI syndrome of sucking as well, not being smart and also easily able to circle around. Seriously, kinda made me wish they were doing the bullshit snap on. (They could learn how to make them use wide sweeping attacks like bosses do to react in the other games but ig screw that!)

Now for some more minor problems:

Soul accumilation - You gain wayy too many souls in this this game. You level up wayy too much. Its pretty bad. This ruins the balance. The other souls games makes sure you dont tackle everything and punishes you for it, as you should go down a certain build and plan. On the other hand its cool that you can explore many areas and even embarassingly maybe all areas in this game, but you just get so op...

FINAL OVERVIEW: Dark Souls II is a disaster with really good moments... Its something you wish was good but is not... Its rotten to its core in problems, that could be fixed and it'd be much better of a game. Its not a horrible and bad game though, its just decent at MOST. These problems are massive, but when they aren't happening, this is a decent game. Its the biggest of them all, I didn't complete it all though, just a fat chunk of it, I couldn't bring myself to finish it... The story is quite good too, but this is definitely the weakest in the series, with broken horrible problems in it.

7/10 - Dark Souls II is undeniably the worst in the series, a game that was just second hand during Bloodbornes development. The best all went over to work on it. This left B team working on DS2. (P.S. NEVER GET SCHOLAR OF THE FIRST SIN! ITS EVEN MORE BROKEN!)

i played this game for the first time almost ten years ago. to this day, i still remember struggling with some of the boss fights for several days. ive yet to play another game as AWESOME as this game is. tons of challenge, the story is great. ill forever chase the feelings i had playing this game
broken piece of shit game

I am very sad that I even am writing this right now, and before I even begin, Save yourself the heartache and trouble and stay FAR AWAY from Dark Souls 2, I came into this fresh from Dark Souls 1 and every. single. mechanic I had painstakingly learnt throughout the first game had to be entirely relearned due to "new mechanics" all of which suck and take every little ounce of fun right out of this game, furthermore, these "new mechanics" are bugged out as all hell and dont even work properly most of the time, not even half! most! The developers of this Entry to the Souls series should be ashamed of themselves. Enjoyed the feel of impact your weapon had in the first game? gone. Your good at dodging? well too bad now you have to dump unnecesarrily large amounts of levels into the dumbest new addition to the series, The adaptability stat, what a JOKE. Youll take damage in the middle of your rolls and every single boss needs to be fought PERFECTLY there is no room for mistakes, I fought about 8 bosses and nothing new opened up, Nothing special happened, I didnt receive any cool loot there is ZERO sense of progression at all and when you finally do unlock something new the devs just say "Screw you!" and throw huge swarms of enemies that can only be beat with the precision of jesus himself, there is zero fun to be had in this game, every corner I took i just wanted to rip my hair out!! I love the souls series, I have played and FINISHED games from the series, This one? hell no, i know garbage when i see it, and this is garbage, Everything in this game seems like a DIRECT DOWNGRADE from the game BEFORE this one, Sorcery and all form of magic have the laziest animations ive ever seen, it looks terrible! not fun to play at all and Melee is just the same, Re used animations for completely different weapons and what a joke "powerstance" is, It just puts the same moveset over what could be 30 different movesets, but no we only get about 4 with powerstance, even with a plethora of weapon combinations WHAT A JOKE! This game is just downright bad, theres no arguing it, You like this game? good on ya i guess, you sick Masochist.. what a waste of money

Replaying this game in 2022 to complete it for a second time made me realise just how terrible it actually is. Combat and controls are very clunky and slow, and the made focus of these games, the bosses, are so bad. Most of them you can do first try, and the others are incredibly slow, with massive openings for attacking and a tiny moveset. Almost all of the bosses can boil down to dodge one or two times, get a couple hits in, and repeat until dead. No creativity with movesets, nothing to look out for ect. Fromsoft also now took the servers down with no news on them ever coming back again. The level design for the first 1/3 of the game is quite good but it becomes very tedious and unimaginative later in the game when they just shove a massive amount of annoying enemies before a boss room leaving you with a choice of failing most of the time to run past and get into the boss room without being killed, or to waste 10-15 minutes of your life killing every single one of them before you enter the boss room everytime.

April 2022: Cannot recommend this game without multiplayer.

Original Review: Huge replayability, cool PVP system, great character progression diversity.
Some mechanics tied to frame rate (because it's a console port), but still and all around fun game.
Servers still down with no updates other than a quiet removal of the multiplayer tag on steam.

I wouldn't recommend purchasing this except for on sale. The game is basically the same as DS2:SOFS (I can say the same in either direction - you only need one copy of the game if you're on a budget) with varied enemy placement. This version basically does not have the 'spambushes' of scholar, so the enemy placement is overall very different. It is mostly for the better. However, some areas seem just randomly stuffed with enemies without care whatsoever. Scholar also slightly improved hitboxes (it seems) as well as improving the damage on boss attacks (ancient dragon in this version is much worse than in scholar - my hardcap vigor character with good armor is getting one shot by every move).
Overall, it's a fun way to re-experience the game (if you started with scholar first).
A big issue I have with this version is the prevalence of one shots that enemies have: the ancient dragon and the mounted overseers are designed to one shot you no matter what. Even with god mode activated on a trainer, these two enemies do so much scripted damage that you are supposed to get one shot no matter your stats.

While I have enjoyed this game over the years, I can no longer recommend it. Fromsoft/Bandai have taken the multiplayer/co-op servers down since a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability was publicly exposed a month before elden ring's launch. The RCE issue has apparently been in all of the Dark Souls games on PC since Dark Souls PtDE, they were aware of it and did nothing about it until they were publicly shamed into fixing for their new cash cow, elden ring. Now the Dark Souls series is listed as single player, no longer as multiplayer/co-op (aside from the user tags, which aren't official). Since they don't appear to intend to fix the servers for their back catalog of souls games too, like they should have back in the days of Dark Souls PtDE, they don't deserve a positive review.

ds2 us a marvelous sequel to ds1. fromsoft rectified a lot of their previously made mistakes and added some very enjoyable new additions like powerstancing and life-gems but unfortunately fromsoftware struggles to create a difficult game without adding a shit ton of bullshit to annoy the player.

before I start naming the flaws this game has, I'll list the improvements the devs added like fixing the bad lock-on camera and overhauling the combat system to the point of which it feels genuinely smooth. 
build variety in this game, is excellent. 
power-stancing weapons is a great feature and trying to dissuade the player from turtling up behind a shield, is even better. 
the lore is fantastic and dragleic is an amazing place in regards to lore. 

that unfortunately is all I can praise this sequel for. 
there are too many issues in ds2 that makes it one of the worst sequels in the souls franchise. it's the most contentious topic amongst the community and with good reason. 

this game has no beautiful vistas like ds1, despite it being graphically superior. 

life-gems are great but unfortunately they completely replace estus flasks because of how slow the flask animation is

adaptability is the worst skill ever conceived in gaming. most who played through this game blind - like myself on the ps3 - would have claimed the hitboxes in this game are far worse than ds1 but it's not true. your i-frames are bound to this skill.
there is no rhyme or reason to this. maybe they wanted to make the game more difficult? or maybe they wanted to copy monster hunter even more by making it similar to evade-window? I honestly can't tell but I can safely say it's unnecessary and only serves to annoy the player.

then there is the fact that some enemies have infinite poise even if you smack them with dual colossal swords. again I don't understand why this is a thing or why the devs insisted on it but this further adds to the fact that most of these encounters become a red light/green light game that leaves the player with massive disadvantage. 

furthermore, the enemy- & npc-placement in this game is laughable. almost everything is a gank for no reason. why throw a bunch of exploding enemies next to an npc? why place a bonfire next to a group of enemies that will immediately aggro once you stand up? 

why add so many humanoid bosses that are so easy to fight? srsly the generic trash-mobs in this game are more challenging than the bosses. why throw 3 of those generic humanoid bosses in a boss arena? why are there so many gank bosses? 

because fromsoftware lacks the ability to create a good and challenging game but unfortunately even with their efforts focused on making the game more difficult, the entirety of the content is too easy. 
I have played through all souls games and up until bloodborne this franchise was nothing but an afterthought with incredibly good lore. ds1&2 are infuriating games because of how poorly both titles have been playtested. 

to wrap this up, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone, because it fails to be competent sequel and instead of learning from their mistakes, the devs further add more infuriating things like adp and ganks to annoy the player. 
honestly if anyone is interested in a fair but difficult game, then try out nioh. team ninja is still king in regards to combat.

Despite what you may have heard this game is quite good even when compared to the original Dark Souls. It certainly never drops to the tragically low levels of quality that are found in Dark Souls final third, and is more consistent in quality throughout. My main gripes with the game would be the animations/attacks don't feel as impactful, with a decent amount of the reasoning for that being the sound effects I believe. A simple bandit axe would do comparable damage to a massive Greatsword, but would sound and look like you were hitting the enemy with a balloon. I'm also not a big fan of changes made for New Game+. Generally, remixed enemies could be a fun change, but the ones added in this game just serve to be incredibly annoying, especially considering a lot of them are player-like red phantoms that are extremely annoying and unfun to fight. 

Regardless, I still enjoyed the game quite a bit, and I think anyone who liked the first would like this one as well. Just be prepared to approach the combat in a different way, as a lot has changed due to the focus on multiple enemy encounters and the re-introduction of consumable healing items which are easily acquired. The battles are a lot more focused on the short term engagement rather than the long term of preserving your estus as you carefully pick through an area.

I am quite disapointed with this game.


First of all they did not fulfill their promise.
Their trailer/ teaser showed a huge graphics overhaul and the lighting mechanism.

I don't care much for graphics, i think they are ok, what i do care about is false advertising. And showing graphics and then not living up to them is lying. Same goes for lighting. I was kind of excited for this but never had to use a torch. Another thing they didn't implement yet showed on their trailer.


What impression does this give me?

" Let's build hype so the pre-order are super high."
" Rush this product, we need money and then we can already start with DLC."


At any rate this is the least of my concerns with not recommending this game.

The pre-order bonus weapons are plain useless, why even include them? For me it would have been fine just having OST and that comic. But then again ==> impulsive buyers, younger crowd, etc..

Now the part that made me quit this game on completion.

There is barely any difficulty in this game, it is all replaced with artificial difficulty.
Most deaths occur to being stunlocked and combo'd to death, a vertical slash swiping horizontally to follow your roll. Hits that do not hit your character, yet take away health.

Rarely do you face loner enemies like the black knights in DS 1 for example. Which were worthy and dangerous adversaries. In DS 2 you will most of the time find yourself outnumbered. And for a bunch of depraved corpses they can move damn fast and have lots of stamina.

This also includes magic homing attacks, yes Amana it's about you..

The same goes for invasions etc. there's lag, which causes overall frustration especially if you are in a tough area where you finally managed to progress and some invader beats you down especially if he lags very hard or the hitdetection messes up, which it does quite frequently. The fact they put out the red eye orb infinite usage doesn't really stimulate much invasion, which i don't really mind but would make it a boring grind for me if i wanted to invade.

Then again there's quite the amount of cheaters in the game like in DS 1 that roam freely. Again From fails to do something about it.

The bosses are ok for the most part. The looking glass knight was refreshing though i dislike him summoning players in the game but  it's a nice touch. Most bosses though don't feel rewarding for killing. How many times i got sucked into a grapple animation while being slightly out of reach. The overall of bosses is not so satisfying and some are even copy pasted from DS 1 or mobs in DS 2.

Some bosses even get mob thrash in order to be difficult like Freya. It's to make the game difficult but i think it's not really adding anything to the challenge. It makes the artificial difficulty higher though.

Then NG + is supossed to be harder which it was but again tweaking artificial difficulty. Sinner gets some red ghost pyromancers to help, there's more red phantoms everywhere. In short ==> swarm tactics. Again upping artificial difficulty and not feeling so challenging but rather unfair.

I noticed differences in playing DS 1 and DS 2. In DS 2 i'm more relying on spamming health items and other stuff while in DS 1 i try to refrain from using healing items until the boss fight so i have the biggest chance of survival. Which could lead to this impression: die in DS 2, just buy more soulgems, herbs, rouge water whatevs. Outtank the problem.


Soul Memory is not popular, i don't really care that much but what i do find nasty about it is that if a hacker would invade you or you invade one that has 99999999 souls and he jumps off a cliff or so, you get a very high soul memory and you'll get invaded by people way bove your paygrade.



the story itself is not bad, it's ok, DS 1 had better story and atmosphere IMO.
Bonfires had much more weight and meaning in DS 1 as in you could not just teleport everywhere at the start of the game. It was used to level up, become human, kindle. there were fewer bonfires making them very precious.

in DS 2 some areas are riddled with them, you can teleport from start and they only replenish Estus and reset the mobs. Leveling up, you always have to go to the herald, listening to her ramblings over and over, same with estus shards. Everything has to be done with the herald. Which is not gamebreaking i just find it annoying. Bonfires always had weight in DS lore but now they don't get that much importance anymore.

I could be wrong since i rushed through this game with a walkthrough after having enough of this game. I just wanted to see the end story, but i haven't seen a single firekeeper in the game, and aren't bonfires supossed to douse when firekeepers are dead. Besides the 4 witches in things betwixt there aren't any keepers.


In short: i do not recommend this game at all. It's a step back from DS 1 maybe because of all the hype and attention over the years and Bandai cracking the whip, maybe greed, i don't care. The results count and for me, it's a mediocre game at best.

I'm about 26 hours into a second attempt at the often maligned and decried black sheep of the Souls series. It is, I think, every bit as good as the first one, with several quality of life changes that might even make it surpass it's predecessor.

Here be dragons, invisible walls, traps, environmental puzzles, and a deeply rewarding adventure for those that love exploring.  Just like before, their are fragments of lore scattered about and story telling the revolves much more on design and ascetic than simply shouting at your face, "this was a bad dude." 

The only issue the game has is there is no online play. That means you won't see phantoms of other players running around the world, or soapstone signs with poorly translated hints, or encounter the true boss fights of the game, other players. Even so, as a solo adventure there is plenty to see and do, and if your like me and like finding things out yourself, will feel all the more rewarded for it. There are still NPC summons if a particular boss proves to difficult, and the branching paths of the game mean you can bounce between 2 or 3 areas at any given time to make progress when you feel you hit a wall in one.

I recommend this game if you're looking to recapture the feeling of playing Dark Souls 1 for the first time again, but only if you aren't looking to play multiplayer.

DS2 has hitbox issues the likes of which no other souls game sees, and also has rolling upgrades and lifegems, nerfing estus. Also probably has the worst casting overall in the entire series.

What does it have that's good? The best hub location & music, some really pretty locations, No-Man's Wharf and Iron Keep, which I will not discuss in detail, and an insanely broken Lightning damage type that makes you feel powerful until you start playing the DLC's.

Overall? Fucked up game. You can tell the B-team made it. However, it's still fun, even if it wants to make you rip your hair out at times (and, realistically, every Souls game does). 

[i]Now, what about SotFS?[/i]

Never liked it. SotFS was described as a remaster that fixes a lot of the game's issues - and it really only fixes a handful. Tweaks some stats on spells and hexes, some weapons (insignificant at most), changed to run at 60fps natively, and changed item locations (like Branch of Yore being available from the Hag at Cardinal Tower early on). What it also changed was enemy locations.

Heide's Tower goes from easily being a SL1 area to complete enemy spam. No-Man's Wharf is worse. Iron Keep makes you hate yourself. Shaded Woods is also complete enemy spam, on top of already being a poison level. And these changes seem to be bipolar at best, because it seems incredibly backwards-thinking; certain parts in locations where there are supposed to be several enemies (challenge areas) now have very little. 

Apart from those changes, and a native resolution change, the games are indistinguishable from each other. What it does well is insignificant, what it does terribly is glaring. It's for that reason alone that I would recommend base DS2 over SotFS, and overall, I would recommend playing DS2. It's not a bad game, but it is fundamentally different from other Souls games in a lot of ways, and you'll have to adjust if you're used to those. DS2 rewards patience far more.

Worst of the trilogy. Anybody who disagrees is wrong. I know games look good in nostalgia glasses but this is the worst of the trilogy.

Not taking points away for this but something to note, the default controls for PC are disgustingly terrible. DS1 EE and DS3 have near similar default PC controls to each other and their controls are just betters. DS2 is very different and objectively worse.

Some of the good aspects of the dark souls series is learning and exploration. Dark Souls 2 actively punishes the player. The hallowing mechanic in this game lowers max health which punishes the players for exploring or not already knowing something. The controls are clunky and delayed compared to DS1 EE and DS3. I wouldn't recommend for PC. 

Rolling is also bad. They made rolling bullshit and shitty even with lower load.

Edit after finishing:
The late game is better than the early game by quite a bit. The early game is absolute bull shit. They tied rolling to a stat and didn't give a viable shield until after pursuer. "Guess I'll Just git gud". The late game is pretty decent and it has the best DLC of the dark souls series. It definitely gets a lot better but I can not recommend a game with such an atrocious early game. It's a good game but no, I do not recommend it.

Honestly, this game is really awesome and probably one of my favorite games to this day.

The concept is nice, and the story you'll discover by getting further into the game.

The PvP, though, can get very frustrating at times, but you'll learn overtime to do it. You'll learn how to improve yourself when it comes to PvP experience.

This game is about learning from mistakes and trying new things to overcome them.
You'll adapt to new environments and terrains as well.

Also you can help people out; you can be summoned into other peoples world and assist them on killing bosses or clearing out areas to help them advance onto their adventure.

Or... you can invade them, causing havoc onto their world!

The multiplayer is well done and the mechanics are pretty straight forward with some reading.

The music in the game is also very well done and makes you feel alive when fighting bosses.

If you're new to Dark Souls franchise, don't worry, this game doesn't make new players ashamed to be new because we all have made the same mistake at some point in our playthroughs.

This game also gives a lot of replayability

I rate this game a 10/10 would play again

The basic gameplay loop hasn't changed from the original. Two is better than Dark Souls 1 in some ways, but worse in others. Overall, it's still fun, but, as before, it's the kind of fun that you have to enjoy while enduring frustrating annoyances. Here's what changed:

The good: fast travel is available from the start of the game, there are four ring slots, the vanilla game runs at 60 fps and is actually optimised, there are a lot of fun dual-wielding options, and the game's manual is much better than the originals.

The bad: the targeting system is more crap now. There is an annoying delay between an enemy dying and the lock-on switching to the next enemy, so you have to do it manually; and in a group of enemies, the enemy in the very back of the groups will often be targeted instead of the enemies in the front. And even when you are targeting the correct enemy, it is now possible to attack in a direction away from your target, meaning that, for example, if you roll sideways to an enemy and immediately attack, your attack is going to miss by miles; you have to wait for your character to get up and actually face your enemy before attacking. The camera is somehow even worse than in the original, and turns around at inconsistent speeds depending on how long you've been turning it and on your immediate environment. There's been minimal effort to improve kbm support, but it's still crap: everything is just a rebind of the controller's buttons, and there is a very noticeable and unacceptable delay after clicking to attack where the game waits to see if you meant to double click or not -- even with double clicks disabled in the game's settings.
what can i say, it's Dark Souls!

It's a good time. The areas are decent, but not the strong point. The linearity makes the game's exploration suffer, and when combined with the instant access to teleportation, diminishes the rollercoaster of dread and relief that I think helped give bonfire discovery in Dark Souls 1 its magic. Functions really well as a boss rush, though. The 2015-2019 run of Bloodborne, Dark Souls III, & Sekiro are where FromSoftware's bosses peaked, and boy does this game (including DLCs) have some great bosses. Weapon variety is kinda bad, though, as most weapons are the same except +2 to damage. Similarly, armor all functions the same. Overall though, pretty good introduction to 2010's FromSoftware gaming.

Spent a decent amount of time on this game so here's my little review. As the time of writing, i have not experienced any other soul-like games.
Regarding the lore: this is the 3rd part of the triology meaning that all of the events in-game are the aftermath of the first two series. If anyone interest in the storyline and wants to understand it sequentially, do consider. 
Regarding the difficulty: Soul-like genre is widely known for its difficulty, as a newcomer, i can confirm this. Things can be overwhelmed at first (admittedly, i died too many times because of mobs before reaching bosses.. u live and learn ig or just run) but later on, the game gradually becoming enjoyable for me (but not with farming). You can always call your friends for help if you are in trouble. If you dont have any, the ds3 community is really supportive too. Shout out to them for making my 1st time experience more memorable. 
Regarding the world design: it is linear, some views this is a cons but i say it's great since i don't have to worry about getting lost.
Regarding the theme: DS3 theme is dark as the name suggests but there's beauty in it. Some location in-game are known for their breathtaking scenery. Currently using a screenshot in-game as my wallpaper. 
Regarding the graphics: its graphics quality, imo, the best in the triology( it's the most recent one) 
Regarding bosses: one of the reasons why i chose this game as my starting soul-like game. I was fascinated by many of them. Some of their intro cutscenes even gave me goosebumps. Their variety of movesets combinated with their beautiful ost making the battles even more epic upon defeating...and they will even more so if you know their lore. There are great bosses and not very good bosses but overall, this game has a good mix. 
That's all for now, thank you for reading my review this far. I really enjoy the game so i try to write it as honest as possible even though i never good with words. Have a good day!

So what i highly recommend you to do before activating " Play online " or going online in this game is >>> Back up your ds1, ds2 and ds3 file :) How do you do that? Go to >>> This computer or This PC > Users > your computers name  > App Data > Roaming and click on ds3 or any of the ds games :) So now you've got a folder thats  " Users ID " that folder contains inside of it a file, That file is your in game progressing save :p Please back up that file by manually copy and pasting it from time to time or even better everytime you close the game ^.^ Paste it into your other Hard Drive ( HHD) or anywhere you feel like it'll be safe in :)

Why do you wanna do all of that? Is firstly because Steam Cloud doesn't support this or any ds games :) So it's not like Csgo, dota2 or many other games that save automatically in your steam account :) so because some hackers with bad intentions not only kill people unfairly and gain little to no fun >.< But they also have bad ways to force a bugged or a hacked item into your inventory that can cause a soft ban or corrupt your files :/ or simply dropped hacked items for you to pick up if you are new to the game that will ruin your system :<

My honest review and opinion of Dark Souls III
If you just want to know it it´s good and worth playing, YES, it is.
Now to the "review" part.

I have to mention, that this is the VERY FIRST souls like I´ve ever played, 
which is why it has a special place in my Heart. 
When I first started playing the game, I thought it was good idea to play it with Mouse and Keyboard.
It wasn´t. In the first few hours I got owned by the Tutorial Boss, locking on and dodging were foreign words to me.
Some hours later, I opened the doors of Lothric and got hit with the breathtaking view of Lothric Castle in the Distance.
I got my first pieces of Armor, Shields and Weapons, and made my way through the High Wall of Lothric. Until this Point the Game was fun, but left me with the feeling of "thank god it´s finally over". That changed when I encountered the Abyss Watchers. This Boss took me at least 40 tries to beat, but the feeling of victory, the rapidly beating heart and adrenaline rush was more than worth the struggle. Even though it´s just a game, I was sitting in front of my Desk, screaming "I DID IT" for 2 minutes straight to my friends in VC. After the Watchers I purchased their sword and spent many hours by spinning my way through the following areas. Pontiff took me some tries, but wasn´t too bad. Right after Pontiff I got invaded by some guy who quickly noticed that I had no clue what was going on, who he was and why he was in my world. In the end he escorted me all the way to Anor Londo, dropped me a Large Soul of a Hero and black crystald out. Absolute Chad <3
Many hours later I reached Grand Archives and struggeled with Lothric and Lorian, until it "clicked". Despite having an Elevator, the way back to the Lothric and Lorian Bossfight is unnecessarily long and packed with enemies. Why Miyazaki, why. After the Twin Princes it was time for the final Boss, and my god, this fight was so good. Soul of Cinder kept surprising me with several mid-phase changes between "classes" but was a great experience to fight. Some time after beating the game, a friend gifted me the DLC´s and a had more content to dive into. The DLC´s were great, had many cool weapons, especially the Ringed Knight ones. Sister Friede took me some tries and surprised me with THREE FUCKING PHASES, but went down relatively quick. The Ringed City had it´s highs and lows, but rewarded me with one of the cooles Bosses I´ve ever fought in a Game. Slave Knight Gael took me hours, but holy shit, this fight was an absolute trip and I wish I could fight it again for hours. This fight, the music, the moves and Gael switching weapons MID AIR made this my all time favourite Soul Boss. 
After beating Vanilla Dark Souls III and the DLC´s, I wanted to take some time off, but couldn´t stop thinking on how play it again, more efficiently, using different weapons. 
New Game plus, despite being the exact same but a bit harder, was still an absolute blast.  I rolled through the Game with the Black Iron set, Havels Ring and Heavy Caestus +10, buffed with Lightning or Poison. Past obstacles like Pontiff were a lot easier now and more fun as well. Just imagine beating up a 5m Tall priest with Fire and Magic swords while wearing Boxing Gloves with Metal Notches inside them, it felt so damn good.

After beating several new games, I forced some friends to play Dark Souls with me and it was a whole new experience. Despite some arguing against it, Dark Souls is even more fun when you´re playing with friends, goofing around and beating the game dressed up as Peasants, armed with nothing but a flaming pitchfork. The PvP Experience is also surprisingly good in Dark Souls 3, some encounters end rather quick or even get resolved by one of the players beginning to emote. I´m not an active pvp player and yet I have to say it´s fun, even Invasions can be fun. Some Invasions had actually respectful individuals that bowed down and waited until I cleared out nearby mobs to 1 v 1 them afterwards. 

And then there are these individuals that invade with cheats, such as using Estus Flask SEVENTEEN TIMES, having infinite stamina or reviving themselves after being killed, just to instantly apply the curse effect on you and the point down. These Individuals are lower than low and have to Cheat in pvp, then point down in order to feel anything in their lives. 

The only two things I dislike about this game are cheaters in PvP and the fact that this game DOESN´T HAVE CLOUD SAVE. Fromsoft please, with Dark Souls "remastered" you pretty much released the exact same old game and it has cloud save. 

 Every now and then I still start a new DS3 run and get reminded of how much fun this game can be. 
9/10 for me.

Fantastic game, aged like fine wine so far. The graphics are still good despite being 7 years old and most areas are great. PVP is solid (best in series IMO). 

If I were to compare this game to Elden Ring I'd say the first 1 or 2 completions are much better than this game, but the fact Dark Souls 3 is linear it has far better replay-ability. When I play Elden Ring I find myself at the start of the game just running around picking up items, and it really take away from the experience as its quite tedious, but the fact this game is linear, despite many people criticising it, works to its benefit during future play throughs, at least in my opinion.

I will say that getting the DLC's are a must as they are easily the best part of the game. If you're tight for cash and you can only get one or the other, Ringed City is definitely the buy. 

I hope we see a Dark Souls 4 in the future, but if they keep making games equal in quality to this or Elden Ring I wouldn't complain either. Get this game, its worth it even at full price (though it does go on sale quite often) as it truly is my favourite game of all time.

[h1] Dark Souls 3: A Brutal Ballet of Death and Resilience [/h1]

Dark Souls 3 is the kind of game that makes you question your life choices, but in the most masochistically delightful way possible. It's a dance with death, and you'll stumble more times than you'll pirouette gracefully. But therein lies its twisted charm.

Imagine a world where death is not a setback but a lesson, where every foe you face is a masterful choreographer of doom, and where you feel simultaneously frustrated and exhilarated. That's the essence of Dark Souls 3.

The game greets you with open arms, then promptly kicks you into a pit of despair. The difficulty level is like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube blindfolded while balancing on a tightrope. It's not for the faint of heart or those with a fragile ego. But if you're the type who enjoys a challenge and finds solace in the feeling of achievement after countless deaths, then welcome to your personal torture chamber.

Dark Souls 3 doesn't hold your hand; it holds your impending doom. It rewards patience, precision, and a hint of insanity. The meticulously crafted world is dark and brooding, with a twisted beauty that beckons you to explore its secrets.

The boss battles are nothing short of epic. Each one is like a tango of death, demanding precise timing and strategy. And when you finally emerge victorious, you'll feel like you've conquered the universe (until the next boss stomps your soul into oblivion).

The multiplayer aspect adds an extra layer of complexity, with invasions and co-op play that can either be your salvation or your undoing. It's a high-stakes game of hide-and-seek with swords.

In summary, Dark Souls 3 is not a game for everyone. It's a dark, punishing, and relentlessly challenging experience. But for those who embrace the brutality, it's also an exhilarating journey that pushes your limits and rewards your perseverance. It's a game that, despite the numerous deaths, manages to make you feel more alive than ever. So grab your controller, steel your nerves, and [b] prepare to die – again and again. [/b]

Even after a span of seven years since its launch, it continues to stand as an enduring masterpiece.

This game is roll spam + straight sword simulator unless you want to be anally gang banged by enemies with 8 hit combos and whom themselves sponge enough hits to force you to dump your entire stamina bar to not even kill them. Poise doesn't exist, miracles and sorceries and pyromancies suck just spam light attack idiot. Why use 1 heavy attack for 150 damage when you can use 2 light attacks in that same span of time for 120 damage each? The devs didn't give a fuck.

The bosses are the only good thing about this game and even then to reach the good ones you have to sludge through shit like Crystal Sage, an overly drawn out game of wack a mole whilst you get belted by magic that will do 50% of your health bar then stun you for long enough for another magic spear to hit you. And then you have to do a 2 minute long run back only to wait for the twat to stop hiding underground and appear with his shadow clones. Or, how about Abyss Watchers? The most overrated pile of shit ever. A gank where the enemies can combo you to shit with long ranged fast as hell sword swings and by the time you stunlock them to death you have to face a phase 2, literally just the same enemy except now their sword hitbox lingers. Fantastic design guys. Then there's the DS2 boss they snuck into the cathedral like we wouldn't notice and right after Wolnir, the most disappointing boss I have ever faced in a video game. What an amazing design wasted on an atrocious gimmick fight, another fight comes to mind just like that too later in the game hmm...also, Pontiff is a bad fight. You either trivialise it with parry or you're spending 90% of the fight dodging this dude's DMC combos and praying he doesn't use one of his unreactable attacks that reach half way across the game's map.

The Ringed City and the stretch from Dancer to the final boss carries the hell out of this game.

Hollow Knight is difficult. "Only the pure come unscathed from the crucible."
This game is a good challenge, one of my favorite games even having only 12 hours in it. It isn't too hard and it teaches you brutally how to cope with the enemies in the dark caverns of Hallownest.

I will also say that I hadn't held a controller in nearly 6 years before picking this up and it has very much carried my learning curve up and beyond in just a few bosses. Most controls are intuitive, most strategies require puzzle solving and creativity.

This game is brilliant in atmosphere, story elements, combat, environment, map design, enemy design, NPC design. I'd give it 5 stars for every category. Can't wait for Silksong!

Having completed the game now, I can confidently say that this is still one of the greatest stories, games, and experiences I have ever had. Genuine beauty exists in few places on this pale orb called Earth -- Hollow Knight is one.

This game has challenges I still think about while trying to sleep. The sheer enigma of such feelings dwells vast in my psyche as I contemplate my memory of events. A true artpiece.

I played this game in 3 hour increments on my Twitch channel almost every Tuesday from January until September of this year. Of course, by this point many people have played and loved this game, I almost thought perhaps my review would be extraneous at this point. HOWEVER, I would like to say that the way I played this game, I think, made this an even more special experience. 

When it comes to games like Hollow Knight, remembering where you've been and where you might need to go back to later on is imperative to progressing in the story. Most people will speed through the game in the span of a week or two, with everything fresh in their minds. Playing in one chunk once a week was such an interesting experience. I remembered  being places where floors shook, or paths were blocked, but when I got the upgrade that allowed me to progress past these points, I had to explore almost the whole world again to remind myself where these places were, because it had been over a month since I'd been there. This made me feel like a part of the world of Hollow Knight in a way that made this game very special to me. 

It felt like a whole experience. I have loved many games, but very few have made me feel like a part of the story in the way this game did. 

Please play this game if you haven't already, and remember you don't have to speed through it. In fact, I'd recommend you don't. it's okay to take it slow, and experience it one chunk at a time, every once in a while.

Metroidvania is a tricky genre. It's extremely hard to balance unbound exploration while at the same time giving the player enough guidance and progress so they don't feel overwhelmed or unprepared for the task. Hollow Knight is the golden standard for this balance.

A gold standard for all Metroidvania games. Was an absolute blast to play through with a fantastic world, memorable bosses and Christopher Larkin's beautiful soundtrack. If you enjoyed this, the sequel, Hollow Knight Silksong is available right now to play! You should go check it out. Go ahead. I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

Spent 4 hours fucking around in the tutorial area, another 4 hours dying to lvl 3 guerrilla-trained crocodiles, all while delving into the most incredibly immersive narrative and deeply rich gameplay I've ever seen. By far.

I doubt I've played through even 1% of the game, yet I can already see why this is hailed as one of PC gaming's all-time greats. 100% Recommended.

Edit: Actually I kind of hate it lol. Story mode advertises itself as "for the fun and fantasy, not a rigorous challenge." Yet even here, my team gets one-shot by traps and enemies (at our level). After 12 hours, the game basically turned into "reload simulator."

According to the internet, if you have problems with story mode, the solution is to "git gud." Which is 100% fair in a game that doesn't advertise an idiot mode! Normally I'd approach such an unforgiving game with a guide. But I didn't, and now we're 12 hours in, with a lot of guides suggesting we do a full restart if we're struggling. Honestly, as cool as the game is, I'm not willing to discard a full day's work for troubleshooting...

No qualms against the game's difficulty. Just disappointed at how it advertised itself. No matter what mode you play on, this game is hardcore old-school. Be aware of that.

Have to give this a thumbs down, just because I think this game should sit at "Mixed" as an honest representation of the overall experience.

Pros:
1 - Great world-building, interesting story
2 - Character stories are generally engaging, if a little two-dimensional.
3 - Multiple ways to resolve stories, though sometimes it boils down to killing/not-killing someone.
4 - Combat has a lot of potential for interesting "tactical" scenarios, though it becomes overwrought (see Cons)
5 - AI has some interesting ways of resolving combat, you won't find too many games with the kind of depth you see in enemies here.

Cons
1 - The Physical/Magic armor addition in DOS2 completely changes the strategic use of crowd control. Enemies, even at Classic level take a lot of chipping away before your skills take effect. The enemy, on the other hand, rarely experiences this issue.
2 - Those enemies are frequently more powerful than you at the same level: more armor, stronger attacks,  more actions per turn, and skills you don't even have access to. It feels less like a straight challenge, and more like the devs put their thumb on the scale because they couldn't find a way to keep the difficulty up without being cheap.
3 - The Source mechanic: underwhelming powers that take waaaaay too many of your action points, which involves a wonky and unwelcome resource management. 
4 - The fire. The endless, annoying fire. This game is a virtual Being-On-Fire simulator.
5 - The Special Fire that you can't put out normally, but have to manage your Source. Fun!
6 - Combat takes a goddamn year. The computer will jump turns, CC you to death, and leave you sitting there watching it play itself for 15 minutes.
7 - The uninspiring character progression - most of the time you're just adding a point or two to an attribute or skill. 
8 - The poorly-realized and ambiguous crafting system, the mind-numbing inventory management, etc.
9 - The overly-cryptic puzzles, and special combat scenarios that (after you get done making a sandwich waiting for the computer to play by itself) are not intuitive at any level.
10 - Did I mention the fire?
11- I could go on...

Look, I liked DOS1, and there's a lot of love in this game. But after playing through a couple times (not finished, yet), I just feel like it's so much wasted potential. I haven't found it too hard, it's just worn me down. The combat feels like a chore, and the only way to get through fights is to juggle resurrection scrolls. To me, that isn't "strategy". I hope there's a DOS3, I really do. And I hope Larian learns something from making an actual D&D game: the goal of an RPG is to inspire players to overcome challenges, not to constantly cheap them into submission with contrived combat scenarios, and ambiguous structure. Could have been one of the Greats, but Larian leaned in far too hard here, and wound up with a meh experience.

Without writing the novel of a review this game probably deserves, I'll keep it concise.

This game is regarded as one of the best turn based RPGs of all time. I am pretty superficial about specific things and one of those things are the visuals of the ugly ass portraits I have to stare at throughout the game. Why does Sebille have a longer neck than the lock nose monster? Why does Lohse look like a hobbit that grew too tall?
I also feel like the actual storyline of the game is fairly weak with terrible balance when it comes to certain builds, while also simultaneously plateauing after act 1, with spells just being better versions of older spells without being something new altogether.
I can understand that some people love this game and have played countless hours of it, but I genuinely strugged to play 20 hours of it without feeling something is missing; this, however, could possibly be because of the BG3 release just being a significantly better version of this game.
If you want to check out the game, go ahead, but be prepared for immense disappointment of a highly prestigious game.

Title: A Fantasy Odyssey of Unparalleled Depth

Rating: ★★★★★★★★★★ (10/10)

Review:

🔮 Prepare to be ensnared in a world where magic dances with strategy, where choices echo like ripples across dimensions, and where storytelling is an art of unparalleled craftsmanship. Divinity: Original Sin 2 stands as a triumphant testament to the power of imagination and role-playing mastery. 🔮

🌍 Rivellon, the realm you'll call home, is a sprawling tapestry woven with rich lore and intricate details. The graphics paint its landscapes in vivid hues, from the shadowy depths of ancient crypts to the sun-drenched shores where tides of destiny converge. Each character, every blade of grass, is meticulously crafted, bringing this fantasy world to life with cinematic beauty. 🎬

📜 The narrative is an epic saga that unfurls with the weight of prophecy and the whisper of intrigue. Your tale is yours to weave: shaping your character's backstory, forging alliances, and navigating the intricate webs of diplomacy or deceit. The companions you gather are not just fellow adventurers; they're kindred spirits with stories as diverse as the realms they hail from. Each dialogue choice, each action, carries the weight of consequence, weaving a tapestry of fate that's uniquely your own. 🗡️

⚔️ Combat is a ballet of strategy and spell, skill and synergy. The intricacies of elemental interactions ignite the battlefield with endless possibilities, turning battles into exhilarating puzzles where every move can shift the tide. The class system is a symphony of variety, allowing for creative character builds that match your preferred playstyle. The turn-based nature of combat adds layers of complexity and satisfaction, making every victory earned, every defeat a lesson. 🔥❄️

🎲 Beyond the main quest, the world of Divinity: Original Sin 2 teems with intrigue. Side quests and hidden secrets beckon, drawing you into tales that rival the central narrative in depth and emotion. Environmental puzzles and interactivity create a sense of immersion that few games can match, making exploration not just a task, but a journey of discovery. 🕵️‍♂️

👥 Multiplayer transforms the game into a cooperative canvas of shared storytelling. Collaborate with friends to overcome challenges, solve mysteries, and make choices that shape your collective fate. The unique twist of competitive multiplayer, where alliances are fragile and betrayals loom, adds an extra layer of intrigue to the experience.

In summation, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a masterpiece of role-playing craftsmanship. It's a captivating journey where every decision matters, every story finds its place, and every moment is an opportunity for immersive gameplay. From its stunning visuals to its intricate mechanics, it's an odyssey that leaves a mark on your heart and mind, proving the power of the RPG genre to create worlds where your imagination can truly roam free. 🌌

Super Disappointed.  Games like this, like the Godwoken, appear to be great, but at the end of the day it's just a game that appears to give you choice, but then silos you into a specific story regardless of that choice.  The multiple dialogues between extremist groups are the exact same fault as Fallout 4 and its Factions:  there is no middle ground and there is no real choice you can make, only choices the developers choose for you.  At the end, what you have done to get to that point it meaningless and the end leaves you wondering: Why did I even play this?

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an absolute masterpiece that immerses players into a world of unparalleled depth and wonder. From the moment I began my journey, I was captivated by its intricate storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and engaging gameplay.

The game's attention to detail is astonishing. The richly crafted characters each have their own distinct personalities, and the choices you make truly impact the unfolding narrative. The intricate web of quests and interactions keeps you engaged for countless hours, and the world is so beautifully realized that I often found myself lost in its fantastical landscapes.

The combat system is a true highlight, offering endless strategic possibilities. The ability to combine spells and skills in creative ways makes every encounter a thrilling challenge, and the cooperative play adds an extra layer of excitement. Whether I was exploring the depths of ancient ruins or engaging in intense battles, I was constantly reminded of the game's immense care and dedication to creating a memorable experience.

Furthermore, the game's soundtrack is a symphonic masterpiece that perfectly complements the mood and atmosphere of each moment. And the level of customization, both in terms of character development and the world itself, is nothing short of astounding.

In conclusion, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a shining gem in the world of gaming. Its intricate world-building, captivating storytelling, and innovative gameplay combine to create an unparalleled adventure. This game is a true testament to the artistry and passion of its developers, and an absolute must-play for anyone seeking an unforgettable gaming experience.

This game is worth the price for its value. 

The expansive world has a lot of hidden secrets and NPCs waiting to be discovered. What mostly stands out are the characters, who are the heart of this game. even side characters are easy to get attached to, each with their own stories and unique reactions to your choices. the game has more than just simple labels of good and evil; characters exist in shades of grey.  I found myself in love with Magister Loke, despite his affiliation with the villains. His vulnerability and loneliness struck something, evident to the game's character depth.

While the main storyline may not be groundbreaking, it keeps one engaged and curious as it continues. many twists and side quests unexpectedly intertwine with the main storyline.

the romance, its execution might not be as strong as desired. despite choosing all male origin characters as companions, the romantic aspects only show up a couple of times per character. Nevertheless, the interactions with companions are enjoyable, aside from the occasional annoyingness  of certain characters, like the Red Prince's fixation on the Red Princess.

my playthrough was with mods, particularly "NPC Resurrection" and one that allowed me to recruit any NPCs, which made the game so much better.

I wholeheartedly recommend playing the game.
