I love RPG.s I love what this game tried to do. Take the turn based RPG and turn it into a more tactical fight. It's more involved and requires more skill than just mob grinding until you out gear and or out level the enemies that you want to encounter to progress in the game. That being said, the combat is really killing this game for me. Not that it's too hard, but just that you are always at a deficit when it starts. I've read all of the suggestions. "Always initiate, move your ranged to high ground, don't clump your melee together." In theory, great! In actual practice it doesn't play out like that. Unless you are moving the camera ahead of your party constantly instead of just letting it center over you as you walk along,  you are going to just bump into people who want to fight you. The first thing that enemies do is drop an AOE on you and everyone is on fire or poisoned right from the start because you are clumped up just from normal party walking around mechanics. I'm only level 4 and just playing on normal difficulty and almost every fight starts out that way, with ranged attackers already in high ground positions, leaving me to either walk towards them and just get rekt in the process, or walk backwards and kite them. Your own AOE abilities are indiscriminate. So any mage or poison caster is hitting your own team mates and again, you are always on fire or poisoned, or shocked by lighting. There is always some large pool of something bad underneath you that is just waiting to ignite on fire.  I've had an enemy just start the fight by lighting me on fire, I use a water ability that takes several rounds of cool down after usage to put out the fire, and then next turn, the same enemy has no cool down on his AOE fire ability. You are ALWAYS ON FIRE!!!  

My last try I was fighting some woman who was behind a tree, lobbing AOE fire and earth damage abilities at me with the tree in the way. I go to cast spells at her, I can't. The tree is only in MY WAY. So I can either walk towards her for an entire round of combat while she gets off free attacks (And of course I am on fire) or "kite" her away because that's the "Proper Strategy" that I need to "GET GUD". Well she doesn't come after me. Why would she? She's tucked away safe and sound behind a tree that apparently likes her more than me. My main character was stacked with the most gear, and she focused him with 3 attacks and he was nearly dead in the opening round. The thing is, even if I "Play Properly" I am still drinking potions and using resurrection scrolls every fight to the point that I am out pacing what I can earn to keep up. 

"Use CC" great advice. The problem is that you have to melt away the magic or physical armor to do so and with all of the tactical positioning that you are supposed to be doing, you know, because that is what the GUD  players do, and you are burning through that to ACTUALLY BE ABLE TO USE CC....it's at least 3 rounds in. You have already at least drank one potion, and of course.....wait for it.....you know what's coming......YOU ARE ON FIRE!!!!

I wanted to like this game. I really did. But it's not really a tactical positioning game. It's the same tactic being used against me on every fight. Enemy starts out with massive tactical advantage. I lose half my health trying to mitigate the advantage, then when we are finally on an equal playing field, I have to drink potions to survive literally every encounter. PRO TIP, a real one and not just GET GUD KID, don't use poison damage characters. Too many enemies are healed by it and it is really weak. I wish that I had chosen a pyro caster to start the game. Even if I set my characters on fire in the endless puddles of flammable things, they were already going to be on fire no matter what. At least I can burn the enemies in the process instead of heal them with my poison damage.

It would be redundant to be the millionth person to discuss the merits of this game so I'm going to share a short story instead, how the AI pulled a play so insane that me and my friends are still bringing it up whenever we discuss strategies in turn based games. During a late game fight an enemy casted Shackles of Pain on our ranger, the squishiest member of our party. The spell makes it so that every point of damage taken is reflected onto the target, discouraging targeting that specific person until the spell expires to avoid causing damage to another party member. After taking a couple hits our poor ranger was very low on health and I gave the suggestion to just try to run away from the fight and hopefully get far enough to disengage from it. Two enemies, a fighter and the caster started to give chase, but due to their lack of mobility skills they couldn't make it to him. Noticing the distance and the fact that shackles of pain would expire the following turn the AI did the unthinkable: the fighter hits (and crits) the shackles of pain caster, reflecting the damage on our ranger and killing him. The only think that stopped us from screaming in amazement was the fact that we were playing very late at night. 

On that interaction alone I give this game my highest recommendation.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Divinity: Original Sin 2"[/h1]

Después de Divinity II en 2009 se tomaron un tiempo para publicar una nueva entrega, pues ahora buscaban algo más cercano a lo que antaño hizo destacar a los CRPGs. Es así que en 2014 se estrenó Divinity: Original Sin, y tal fue su éxito que dio lugar a una campaña de crowdfunding aún más exitosa para financiar su secuela en 2017.

La maestría de Larian Studios en Divinity: Original Sin II deja en pañales al primer juego, que por sí mismo es excelente pero que se queda corto en comparación de su secuela, ahora aún más abierto, versátil, complejo y dado al rol y la interpretación.

Ademas de dar lugar a diversos papeles a interpretar o a formas imaginativas para resolver un conflicto, también dota de absoluta importancia al escenario en cada combate y permite que el jugador se desenvuelva a su modo y de formas muy imaginativas.

Es tanto un CRPG como un Sandbox y brilla en prácticamente todo lo que se propone, véase los NPCs, la compensación por la exploración, los personajes con orígenes preestablecidos, las características innatas de cada raza y las diversas e imaginativas situaciones que se dan a lo largo de Rivellon.

Y además es artísticamente precioso. Visualmente es muy destacable y la banda sonora es preciosa, la música del menú principal es maravillosa.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Imprescindible en la juegoteca de todo amante del rol, un exponente del genero en tiempos modernos.
Great game with friends. Everybody arguing over dialogue options, and battle strategy makes the game really engaging.

Imagine DND, but where every character can use every skill or ability, including magic. Now make, by some miracle of mathematics, the game actually BALANCED despite that fact and that is Divinity. The game is surprisingly good at supplying enemies who can deal with whatever weird characters/tactics you can think up too, so the combat is always fun.

If you like freedom in how you play a game without being constrained to meta builds, this is the game for you. The story is a bit meh, but good enough given the amazing gameplay.

I don’t think I’ve ever been more disappointed in a game; I’ll give a list about the things that I felt were disappointing. Honestly, the best way to describe this game is that one horse meme that people use to talk about the seasons of tv shows where it starts out a perfectly drawn horse and then as the drawing goes in it gets worse and worse until your left with a derby horse face.  Because the beginning of this game was actually fantastic, I really enjoyed the game up to about the 30 hour mark about halfway through reapers coast (ACT 2) But here is the list of things I didn’t like. If you want to know why I didn’t drop the game, well I was too far in and was stubborn to see the end. 

1.	The inventory system
      a.	I wanted to throw my computer in a pool of lava, it’s the 2nd worst inventory system after Stranded Deep. No Organization, thank God there is a least some form of sorting within the player’s inventory.  You get one chest which if you want to store things in you then must manually drag every item in the chest, with the chest having no sorting system. People say there are ways of sorting your inventory by putting things in bags but even then, that takes time to manually sort all your stuff and it gets seriously annoying trying to find stuff. 

2.	False Promise of “Freedom”
     a.	The game promises a lot of freedom which I feel like it didn’t deliver on. Now when it comes to character creation, there is a lot of freedom. The description of the game says “Unlimited freedom to explore and experiment. Go anywhere, talk to anyone, and interact with everything! Kill any NPC without sacrificing your progress, and speak to every animal. Even ghosts might be hiding a secret or two…” 
     b.	Well you can’t go anywhere so the first point is moot, the game region locks you as you progress, so once you leave an area you can never go back. So if you are a collector like me who likes to collect every unique item in the game. You must do it before moving on with the story. Which is why I gave up on collecting the Unique’s since most become useless after a level or 2. 
     c.	You can’t kill any npc without sacrificing progress, there are a number of Npc’s essential to the story. So that’s a lie. Though many NPC’s you are forced to kill for sake of xp (I’ll explain more in the next part)

3.	The Story/Lack of impact. 
     a.	So my main issue with the main story itself is that its damn short, and very linear. Yes, I’m aware that I have 80 hours in game, but my save is only 62, and most of that was spent doing side quest and making sure I killed everyone for xp. The main story itself was maybe 15 hours but because in order to get to the next part of the main story you have to spend all your time doing side quest for xp and making sure every enemy on the map is dead. The main story on Fort Joy was nice and honestly the most enjoyable part. Reaper’s coast was okay, albeit very simple and short. Nameless Isle and Arx were just plain awful and made me want to drop the game. 
     b.	Lack of Impact, I felt your choices in your quest besides a few decisions like picking your party members and the end of their quest. Have little impact on the story, the only impact the really make is maybe a change in the long end credit scene but you don’t really get to see your choices make an impact in the world around you. Now there are some that do make an impact, maybe if you spare someone you can get help later on in the story. But because xp is so limited, I felt forced to kill certain people for xp. 

4.	Points of No Returns between each act/island. 
     a.	I hated this part of the game, a game that offers “freedom” and roleplaying should not restrict where I go, no I would have understood it, if it was just limited to areas of the game that were past the point of the story since it would have interrupted the flow of the story, but if I’m in arx (the final island) and I want to go back to reapers coast for some unique item I forgot about, I should be able to. 
     b.	On top of that, this game in the transition from act 1 to act 2 forces you to chose 3 out of the 6 followers, to have for the rest of the game. That’s not a decision to make that early since I know next to nothing about them.

5.	Everything about the game is Scripted (Both a Pro and a Con)
     a.	Now normally everything being handcrafted would be a wonderful thing and in some cases it is. Everything feels natural, but because of this we run into certain issues.
     b.	That issue being the xp system is which is unbalanced and take note that this is based on the XP system in the DE, after the XP patches. Which cut a lot of xp out of the game for a lot of different decisions. Now because of how the xp system favors killing everyone in order to get enough xp to be appropriately leveled for the next act, you are forced to do every side quest, forced to hunt down every monster. Since certain decisions give more/less xp you have to pick the decision that gives you the most. Despite me doing every quest in the game (except of few side quest in arx) and killing every enemy npc by the time of the finale I was only level 20, which is the same level as the final boss. The only quest I skipped in arx were because after a quick google search I learned I wouldn’t have gotten to level 21 even after doing those quest, I decided it wasn’t worth my time.  I was already sick of the game at this point. Now of course if you are super good at the game and willing to go at the quest under leveled by all means go for it. But that wasn’t the experience I wanted. 

6.	The Endings
     a.	I won’t go into detail, but I was really disappointed by all of the endings. And both versions of the final boss fight. I ended up watching a few videos to see any other endings i may have missed and even than i saw no reason to replay the game.

it's a good game, or I should say a good idea on paper, but in video game format its... its a WIP.

open world: sure! in the same sense WoW of 2006 was an open world. you can go anywhere, and die shortly therafter or while in transit.

Party: the screens are helpful and useful, damn shame enemies seem to know your weakest character AT ALL TIMES.

The map: Filled with quest markers, completed and not completed. both use the same symbol, both sound like they are current. you have very little control over the map. you can create ONE custom destination, and thats it.

But the downright most annoying thing EVER is the damn spell mechanics. not a lot of spells, all fo them are underpowered. My guy with a crossbow can three hit someone. Minions die in two hits, have VERY little movement, and require 4 seperate spells to access different abilities EVERY SINGLE TIME you summon it. also, immediatly dies after 60 seconds. oh, and its damage is terrible as well (better than the spellcaster though).

Introduction:
Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a crowning achievement in the realm of role-playing games, offering a rich tapestry of storytelling, strategic combat, and boundless player agency. Larian Studios has masterfully crafted a world that responds to the player's choices with astonishing depth, making every decision feel meaningful. With its captivating narrative, dynamic gameplay mechanics, and intricate world-building, Divinity: Original Sin 2 stands tall as a masterpiece that redefines the RPG genre.

World-Building and Exploration:
The land of Rivellon is a mesmerizing and intricate realm brimming with lore and secrets. Each corner of this beautifully realized world is teeming with life, from lush forests to foreboding swamps and towering cities. The interconnectedness of the regions and the attention to detail in environmental storytelling create a sense of immersion that few games can match. Exploration is rewarded with hidden treasures, intriguing quests, and opportunities for discovery that enrich the player's journey.

Story and Characters:
The narrative of Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a tapestry woven from diverse and captivating threads. The player's personal story intertwines with those of their companions, each with their own unique motivations, backstories, and arcs. The freedom to choose the party members' fates and engage with their personal quests adds a layer of depth rarely seen in RPGs. The overarching tale of gods, power struggles, and the blurred lines of morality is a testament to the game's thematic complexity.

Choice and Consequence:
Larian Studios has raised the bar for player agency with a staggering array of choices that reverberate throughout the game. From seemingly trivial decisions to monumental moral dilemmas, every action shapes the narrative and the world's reaction. The degree of freedom in solving quests is awe-inspiring, allowing for creative problem-solving and unexpected outcomes. This level of choice ensures that no two playthroughs are alike, fostering a sense of ownership over the story.

Combat and Strategy:
The tactical turn-based combat of Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a thrilling dance of strategy and creativity. The combination of elemental interactions, environmental manipulation, and diverse character abilities encourages experimentation and planning. The synergy between party members' skills and the adaptive AI of enemies keep battles engaging and challenging. The ability to engage in both cooperative and competitive multiplayer battles adds a layer of versatility to the gameplay.

Character Customization:
The game's character creation and progression systems are a testament to Larian Studios' dedication to player empowerment. Players can craft their characters with intricate detail, from their appearances to their backstories and talents. The diverse skill trees and ability combinations grant players the freedom to shape their playstyle, allowing for a wide range of strategic approaches.

Music and Atmosphere:
The game's hauntingly beautiful soundtrack sets the perfect tone for Rivellon's diverse landscapes and rich narrative. Each musical composition enhances the mood of the moment, from tense battles to poignant story beats. The voice acting is impeccable, bringing life to the characters and immersing players in their struggles and triumphs.

Conclusion:
Divinity: Original Sin 2 stands as a monumental achievement in RPG design, redefining the boundaries of player agency, storytelling, and strategic depth. Larian Studios has created a world that is not just expansive, but reactive, a canvas where player choices paint an indelible mark. With its intricate world-building, captivating characters, and rich gameplay mechanics, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a definitive RPG experience that will be celebrated and remembered for years to come.

The developers seem too focused on "PVP balancing" and are sacrificing the play quality of the story for it.  Rather than just patch the PVP side to tone down some weapons they have instead patched them across the entire game.  This could get long-winded, but the short of it was there were other ways to fix the problem than making some builds much more difficult to use in combat.  PvE and PvP are entirely different experiences.  PvE tends to put you up against drawn out fire fights, enemies with special powers and resists, and generally a more target rich environment than PvP.  The stun mechanics are hard to balance for PvP as they mean whoever gets the stun off first wins, and that's a failure of the developers for making the game reliant on stun mechanics... it is not a reason to nerf the campaign weapons so I am stuck behind a Dark Souls style die/repeat grind loop waiting for that one "perfect" run.  That's a horrible game loop and it denies me the flexibility I once had.

Don't buy this yet.  Wait to see how badly they destroy it for the PvP whiners.

I'd love to PvP, but I refuse to put up with you children to do so.

Very much enjoying this game, although it took me awhile to get comfortable with the pacing of battles and essentially fighting with 4 weapons at once. However, practice makes perfect, and now I do enjoy strategically planning a build with a certain attack style in mind, and then challenging myself to win using a variety of builds. Played through the entire game 3 times for all the endings, which gave this game a surprisingly intricate narrative (although it's FromSoftware so maybe not terribly surprising). Played a 4th time through to pick up all the battlelogs to achieve the final coral weapons and try new combinations. 

Even post-patch, favorites loadout is coral redblade + plasma rifle + songbirds on a light bipedal build OR coral redblade  + therapist/66EG shock gun + stun needles on a slightly heavier bipedal build. Electricity buildup is similar to BLEED on Elden Ring, and it's very exploitable on almost every boss, and particularly extremely mobile bosses in late game (NG+, NG++). Spent a lot of time using the baby tank treads/wheelchair with gatling guns to move through the first playthrough. 

Wish MP was a little bit cleaner and faster to jump in an out of. Also, sorta bummed there is no way to leave messages for other players a la Elden Ring. 

Would purchase a DLC if they brought one out.

After 186 hours of gameplay (which includes many hours designing emblems in the image editor) and 3 playthroughs and different endings, the verdict is a no-brainer: Game Of The Year 2023. Brilliant gameplay, stunning visuals of industrial environments perfectly merging with the planet's natural scenery, engaging story with great characters (you don't ever get to see ANY living being in this game, yet the dialogues and excellent voice acting do a great job in shaping the characters). 
 The movement in flawless. Move or boost to  ANY direction,  use 4 different weapons at once to delete your enemies.
 Customizing your build to meet the demands of each mission is a joy. Each boss is a different challenge. Ignore reviewers who talk about impossible to beat ImBalAnced bosses. They probably have the nervous system of an amoeba. Bosses are hard only for casual players who don't have the patience to learn how to play. Combat system is excellent.
 Audio design is fantastic, weapons and explosions all have unique sounds. 
 Only negative is the music. The music is horrible, I am not even kidding. Seriously From Software, what were you thinking with those dissonant guitar melodies? 
 I am still playing the game, trying to get better ranking on each mission - which tells a lot about re re-playability of this game. I haven't even started with PvP, still practicing to get better at combat before I head into the PvP arena.
 Looking forward to a DLC.Nough said, this is a MASTERPICECE. A solid 9/10.

After completing the game thrice for all endings, I feel like my review will be more accurate.
Breaking the game into 2 categories: PVE and PVP.

PVE
The bosses are challenging enough to force you to change your build and the way you play. The customization has more depth than most games on the market, and the weapon choices are very varied. You have to carefully balance your loadout to reach max performance, which is reminiscent of MechWarrior games.
The story is a solid 8/10, with well written characters, great voice acting, and a morally gray theme. Depending on your choices during missions (complete the mission or accept a counteroffer), you will unlock new endings.
The music is pretty lacking compared to previous title and even the Daemon X Machina 'ripoff' though.

PVP
This is where the game is pretty lacking. The lack of matchmaking, progression tracking and rewards, host ping display, statistics, and more chat options are making this part of the game less satisfying. There will always be people using dirty builds, but you can counter any build with your own. Also a definitive plus is the recent balance changes released that nerfed the shotguns.

Despite the concerns previously mentioned, it is well worth the full price tag.

After waiting 10 yrs for a new installment, I was not disappointed.  The game has a large variety of parts and weapons that encourage build experimentation.  The campaign has branching story paths, and the arena is once again present with a lot of challenging fights.  I found the majority of the missions to be really enjoyable and provided quite a few unexpected encounters.  The story telling is still very "soulslike", however its much more clear what is happening than in previous AC games.
The game also encourages multiple playthroughs( its worth it).

I never got the chance to play previous AC titles but it always seemed appealing to me. I played demos of the games in the store while my parent's shopped, back when brick-and-mortar stores had console displays and full gaming sections. I had an idea of what to expect, and the game shattered my expectations in the best way possible. 

TL;DR : Armored Core 6 is really good. Laser focused on bringing tight and responsive gameplay. I have gotten all three endings at the time of this review. Story is mid. Your skill will be the only thing to limit your use of any build to complete the game. I have not noticed any major bugs or glitches.

You want to know what it feels like to be a gundam pilot? 

This game plays exactly like the trailers. It feels so good to play that I couldn't put it down. I think about Armored Core while I'm playing it. I think about it while I'm at work, while I'm eating dinner, while I'm buying groceries. When I talk to my friends I peddle Armored Core like my bill money depends on selling copies of Armored Core. This is the first game I've played in years that has been able to hold all of my attention at once the entire time I'm playing it. There is nothing going on in the background of my world while I'm playing this game. Nothing else matters to me except ARMORED CORE VI.

The overall feel of the game is razor sharp. 

The it really feels like the dev team knew what they wanted and stayed laser focused on it from start to finish. Weapon types all feel unique. Everything has a different style of use, a different range of engagement, and different situations in which a weapon system excels. The weight classes really make an impact on your play style, when you add/reduce weight you can really feel it in the movement of your AC. The different parts are, for the most part, all usable in some way or another. I found myself gravitating towards one type of AC over most others early on, but as I unlocked and bought more parts I found my interest in the other styles increasing. I played primarily lightweight for the first two play-throughs with a mix of medium and light for the third play-through. As I've gone back and starting replaying missions for extra parts, rankings, and COAM, I've experimented with medium-heavy builds and really enjoyed the change of pace. I went from hyper-active to slow and methodical. It's been an absolute joy to experience all of it.

I wish there was more to the arena. 

It feels more like it's just there for you to test your AC against the various 'mini'-bosses from throughout the story. You can't progress all the way through it from start to finish unless you've already beaten the game through NG++. You unlock more of 'the ladder' as you progress through the story, I think because it ties into the story/stories. I just would like more of it. More enemies to face, maybe more options to fight multiple challengers at a time etc. Multiple 'waves' like halo:firefight with co-op could be pretty cool. Once I finished I didn't go back and play any of the fights again. I just didn't have a reason to.

The story is passable at a glance. 

It's got some themes and it's got some characters. But they are a backdrop for the game, not it's focus. Like arena I want more from it, but my story telling standards are high and I'm not going to begrudge the game much for not meeting them. I would say if you are looking for a strong, deep, and rich story, you'll be disappointed. I think due to the multiple endings it sort of needs to have a more fluid story line. But I have more questions after finishing the game than I did when I started. It has a story arc and will keep you invested until you've finished all the endings, but it's not really what the game is here to do and I will gladly give the story a pass as favor for the phenomenal game play that has been delivered.

Is it hard or easy? Yes. 

You can really make the game as hard or easy as you like. You can tank up and cheese your way through the game with double Gatling and stun-needle launchers without ever even thinking about your health. You can take a laser knife to a gun fight while wearing paper for armor. The game really shines when you let what feels good to use guide your build. Don't think so hard about the numbers, any build can beat the game. You're skill is the only thing that will limit your build potential. 

I do not think there are really any 'bullshit' moments in the game. 

There are only a few times that I can think of that made me mauld out, but after I calmed down I always found that it was my own ability that was lacking. That I was just a rung below where I needed to be to beat whatever challenge I was facing. Only twice did I succumb to a meta build to beat a boss fight, but it was because I just wasn't good enough. I could take the boss down to the last bit of health but I couldn't cross the finish line. I'm a big fan of the fast, paper thin armor builds, and they have a hard time taking damage from some of the late game bosses. But I will beat them on my own terms with my own build. The game makes me feel like I can do it if I just practice a little more. Now that I don't have the pressure of game completion any more, I feel like I can settle in and just practice these boss fights. To just sit down with a boss and make attempt after attempt until I beat it with my own build. It's the feeling of relentless pursuit of perfection that this game gives me that keeps me coming back even after completion. 

State and stability of the game as of writing this;

It has been patched a couple times. I did not play the game on release, from my understanding a few fights have been nerfed, some stats had been changed before I'd had a chance to play at all. The most recent patch that really affected me was 1.03, a bunch of movement tweaks and some changes to weaponry where made. It felt much more balanced and fluid to me after this patch went live, but it was also about the time I had gained enough skill with the game to start taking note of such things; so take my opinion and observation on it with a grain of salt.

I have not noticed any major glitches, bugs, or game crashes in my time playing. 

I did have a few really weird really bad frame drops [like sub 10 fps] from massive plasma/hardlight effects a couple times during one play session, but this was also during a time when I decided to take a break from some schoolwork and play a couple missions. The PC had been on all day, running multiple instances of Firefox [at least one or two of which was still open], Discord, OneNote, and a half dozen other programs still running in the background, so I consider the event an outlier in general but I mention it as I did need to restart the whole PC in order to fix the frame drop issue. At the time I was not running the latest NVIDIA driver and it was pre-1.02 patch. I only experienced it the once, and I've updated the drivers and not attempted to replicate the conditions so it may be hard to pinpoint what may have been the issue. 

My specs and settings :

My rig is completely air-cooled, running an i7-7800x, 64 gb RAM, gtx 1080ti FTW3, with the game running off a 970 evo m.2 SSD. Load times are sub 10 seconds. Graphical settings are set to max; Except for AA, shaders, and water quality which are set to high. FR cap set to 120, motion blur, vsync off. res : 2560 x 1080.

It took me 60 hours to get all 3 endings, and I probably spent [i]way[/i] more time than necessary on the missions because of how terrible I am, but it didn't matter. Enemy mechs go boom. The game never crashed, it always looked beautiful, the missions are well designed and engaging, with plenty of secrets and optional content to exploit. What's not to love?

About the only thing that annoyed me were the few escort / tower-defense missions, but that's just a mechanic I loathe in general, so I can't really hold it against From for including it. Radio chatter more than makes up for that, up to and including your enemies singing your praises while you cut them down. From really brought this game to life with all of the audio and voice acting; I genuinely felt bad for my various betrayals and tough choices, all in pursuit of the end goals of my handler or those manipulating my decisions.

There's a real gem here, and I hope they keep it up in further releases.

Amazing game!

Don't expect a super complicated game with a super deep story or whatever with one billion mechanics and one trillion side quest, this is a very simple video game type of video game. You pilot a mech and shoot at other mech, that's it.

First, I want to adress the point that this is a souls game and not an ac game. This is so ludacriss, and nonsensical, I don't understand how people with more than two neurons can even think this, but let's look at the fact. One series is known for mech fight where agility in 3 dimensions is met with high amount of led, lasers and explosions, managing credits earned through short mission with various objectives and side objectives to get additional credit or that will remove credit, also credit loss when wasting ammo or due to repair costs, that currency allowa you to customize your mech based on various restrictions  which allow you to customize your playstile, the other is known for melee sword fight with stamina management and a dash (roll) that gives you iframes, and level design that creates various interconnected routes, as well as incredibly difficult bossfight and a currency system lost on death with the chance of getting back that currency before the next death, currency that is used for both purchases and levelling up. I'll let think for yourself which category of games fires of rubicon  fits better into. And for those that's say, "well they changed stuff" or" they removed stuff", well of course they did you clown, it's a full priced sequel, I'd be pissed if they didn't change anything, if you want to play the og armored core, just play the first one on the ps1.

Second, I want to point out just how fun this game was to me, it might not be your cup of tea, but holy fuck, was the controls tight. The camera is not that good, and even with sensitivity at max, I found it was still to low, but maybe that's due to me playing super agile build, I love reversed joints.

Third, the graphics and audio are incredible, just amazing.

Fourth, the story is irrelevant, but some characters are good, and voice acting is pretty decent at least in english. However, the writing can be painfully bad at time. "don't get shoot, or your ac will get damaged" "don't die if you want to get out of there alive" that  kind of stuff. (not quotes from the game, but to me, some one liners, felt this bad.)

Fifth, difficulty wise, it's fine, if not too easy for a Fromsoft game. There was only two bosses that gave me trouble in the entire game, and one of them is the infamous one from act 1. Maybe that's just me who sucks at souls game or maybe I am just good at this game, because I am almost left dissapointed by how easy it is, but at the same time, I often one with very little health left. If I wasn't expecting this game to be hard, then maybe I would've had a better experience, because the difficulty is really good, for a non souls game, but if you were to treat this as a soul game (why would you), then it's way too easy.

Sixth, build variety, I heard a lot of complaints that you can only play a certain way, mainly people saying that since it's impossible to dodge attack, the correct stats is to go quad leg, with full armor and the best damaged weapons in the game, to those people I say: git good. I beat pretty much the entire game with reversed joints and 4 shotguns, just jumping in peoples face blasting them and dodging their attack. 

Seventh, this game is incredibly short. Even when doing almost all of the arena, and messing around building my AC, I still finished the game in roughly 15 hours, and that includes all the time I had to restart due to crashes, which brings me to my following point.

Eight, crashes and glitches, didn't encounter many glitches, not any that I can remember, but SO MANY CRASHES. Always at the same place, by going back and forth from assembly to shop, which made customizing the mech a pain. I had maybe 30ish crashes during my playthrough, almost all of which going back and forth between assembly and the shop, and maybe 3 while loading a mission. I don't remember ever having a crash while in a mission.

Ninth, performance, I had graphics at max I believe, and yet I was still hitting the cap of 120 fps during mission and 60 out of mission about 100% of the time, VERY smooth. Though, I do have a 4090 and a 7950X all watercooled.

Tenth, price, I recommend waiting for a discount, while I would still rank this game close to a 9/10, it is way too short for a full price AAA game, though these days, some AAA games ask for even more, but whatever. If you have unlimited monney or just really want to play it now, go ahead, it's a good purchase, but I'd recommend that the more patien gamers wait for at least 25% discount.

I want to start this off by saying that I want to like this game, I really do
But this game just does not hold up very well
Lets start with the good
1. the story is interesting and keeps you somewhat intrigued the whole time
2. the mech customization is fairly good
3. the arena battles are great
4. there is a lot of weapon variety in this game accommodating many play styles
5. the game looks very nice when it decides to do more ambitious environments
Now lets get to what I disliked
1. the games balancing is wonky at best, I did not die for the entire first chapter and the entire 3rd chapter, and I did not die almost at all for the rest of game outside of the main bosses in chapter 2 and 4, said bosses however, are horrible, unbalanced messes of color and fire, most of which do not feel satisfying the fight, they either go down in seconds or take way to long where if you make 1-2 mistakes you die and restart the fight
2. the environments are very, very similar, most of them are quite flat and devoid of life besides the intended path, there are a few that stand out to me towards late chapter 2, but so far, thats pretty much it.
3. many of the weapons seem non-viable, usually because they just straight up do not have enough ammo or do little to no damage, an example would be the napalm gun, its quite cool and does good damage, but it runs out of ammo in 12-15 shots, making it somewhat useless against this games chunky bosses
4. many of the characters in this game are boring and uninteresting
5. most of the other legs are unimpressive, losing mobility options with the tank and reverse bipedal is rarely worth it, and i was unimpressed with quadruped's "hover", but thats mostly personal taste there
In short, while this game has good concepts it fails utterly in putting the "pen to the paper" in most regards, 
this game is like a 5/10 - 6/10 in my opinion
pick it up if you have any interest while its on sale
have a good day and thanks for your time

Edit: This games NG+ makes a lot of my previous critiques invalid, its a blast to playthrough, that and the endings are great!  its a slog to get here, but if you do definitely keep going, its well worth the extra hours of your time. revised review score, 9/10

First hour review: I've been playing AC games since about their inception and they have always been decent in the sense that when it comes to mech games we were always kinda happy to take what we could get. Although AC was one of the games with the highest levels of customization available in the genera, it always missed the mark to one degree or another in terms of combat. This installment seems to have rectified that...at least to the extent I have been able to play it.

ARMORED CORE VI FIRES OF RUBICON as a renaissance of the series, and in general a breath of fresh air against the background of what was released in 2023.
The game was initially extremely sceptical. largely because of reviews and opinions that I heard. I myself involuntarily began to think: robots and robots what to complain about, and most importantly what to admire here
But how wrong I was, perhaps this is the case when it is better not to listen to anyone's opinions and just try it.
Already in the first hours the game pleasantly surprises and skilfully captures attention as a universe, and the possibilities of building. I do not know how the developers did it, but even through the specific presentation of the plot in the course of the game permeate the characters, with whom you want to fight and destroy as possible, with whom the same tears come to tears during the battle.
It is worth noting that the appearance of the game and the whole universe strikes the imagination, being in a huge mech you don't feel big, on the contrary, you feel insignificance in comparison with the whole environment.
The music is in its place and gives the battles an unforgettable feeling and emotion... I can fly...
However, having passed all the missions on S rank I realised that the game is very short, but it was competently stretched in the best traditions of Nier series, and in general Japanese games. And you can understand this decision, the series of games was in hibernation for a long time. But now, when the ground has already been probed and the fanbase of the game has grown a lot, I think the next part will be much more extensive, let's wait.
Overall the game is definitely worth a look!
621/10

And lastly, ARMORED CORE is much more than mechanical robot battles.

P.S. release Bloodborne on PC!

Armored Core 6 is a game I absolutely recommend for anyone wanting booster-fueled combat coupled with mech customization and epic mission setpieces. I have played Armored Core on every console generation stretching back to the PS1, and can confidently say that AC6 is a fantastic revival of the series after Fromsoft's absence from Armored Core for nearly a decade.
------------
Combat in AC6 is a faithful Armored Core experience and a strong middle ground of past AC titles with new additions. Mobility is not nearly as grounded/limited as AC5, while also not having the energy supply for near limitless aerial movement like ACFA. The introduction of the Stagger Meter to AC is a welcome addition that formalizes weapon hit impact from past AC games into something more fleshed out and very important in boss fights/AC duels. Most weapons feel satisfying to use, and the intricacies of AC melee combat have been refined and well polished with nearly every melee weapon having a unique moveset. The controls overall feel good, I have used both controller and Keyboard/Mouse and both are great to play with.

In regards to AC customization, it is solid but could be better. I think in broad terms the total catalog of parts has a lot of options and is well varied, but old AC players like me will miss the absence of handless weapon arms, shoulder extensions, and other staples from old titles. Quad legs and Tread legs don't get as much love compared to humanoid legs in terms of selection options. That said, there is still plenty of ways you can rollout with vastly different builds, and a lot of the fun in this game is messing around with the myriad possible combinations. For anyone new to AC, I highly recommend examining/comparing parts using the ingame expanded stats sheet, as there are many important stats not displayed in the default tab that will greatly impact your AC's ability to fight effectively.

This game also has a lot of replay value, with a surprising amount of extra content beyond beating the game for the first time. My first playthrough took about 20 hours, but I quickly found out that subsequent playthroughs unlocked more story, AC parts, and other things. Only now after NG++ am I closing in on the finish line to 100%ing the game. The story can be cryptic at times in typical Fromsoft fashion, but I found the story and cast enjoyable and the various endings were satisfying to experience.
------------
Overall AC6 is an incredible game, and I can't wait to see what Fromsoft does with the future of Armored Core now that it's back. Thank you Fromsoft for making this old Armored Core fan very happy, and for remembering the series that shaped you long before Souls.

I have not played prior Armored Core games, however now, after finishing the three story routes, I would call myself a fan. Armored Core VI is a new entry point for the series where you really don't need any knowledge of previous games to play, so don't hesitate for that reason.

Armored Core VI has amazing combat, a variety of combat styles thanks to a wide selection of different weapon types and building options for your "Armored Core", and an interesting story to pull you in. Fun and challenging boss fights with good world and story building allows the bosses to feel even more rewarding to beat and enhance that feeling of achievement when doing so. 

Highly recommend the game to fans of From Software's popular previous works like the Souls series, Elden Ring, Sekiro, and Bloodborne.
Also highly recommend it to fans of the Ace Combat series, both of these "AC" series share similar structures of game design and story-telling.

I think for anyone who enjoys this game enough to finish the story once should absolutely play-through and finish all three story routes to get the full story and not miss out on any of the missions or boss fights.

Three playthroughs in and I'm still finding reason to jump back on. 
The gameplay is incredibly responsive and addicting. Optimizing your armored core to your play style feels very rewarding.
While the game isn't as difficult as other FromSoftware entries, it still makes a good challenge that is satisfying to overcome.
Characters and writing are memorable, and the ending was entertaining in an unexpected way. Works on the Steam Deck really nicely, i had fun swapping back and forth while out at work and at home.

I had to choose between this game and Starfield. I was not disappointed with my choice, in fact I am very happy to have chosen this game. After all my hours and after finally 100%'ing the game, I've concluded the following things.

1: The story is phenomenal and really hooked me.
2: The music is just too good to not put into a playlist and listen to on the go.
3: The PvP could use a little work, but if you get into a community of people who just chill in lobbies, then it's a decent experience.
4: S ranking for some missions is really stupidly easy, some are stupidly hard. It's just a skill issue and you can adapt after about an hour of retrying.
5: Taking breaks is necessary, or you'll burn yourself out. If a mission is too difficult, that's probably your queue to take 10 minutes or so.

...and finally, some advice for those that are on the fence about buying the game. Don't worry about complicated mechanics or a lack of a massive competitive scene, just play the game for the experience. For those that I've convinced to try this game, let's see how far you'll fly... on borrowed wings.

The salient point of this review is that the PC port is by far the most technically competent version FROM Software has produced. Despite using the same engine as Elden Ring, gone are the shader compilation stutters that continue to ruin their previous effort. The PC version boasts graphical options that can push the visuals beyond the console version as well as support for a 120 FPS cap, with fast loading times, a reasonably good UI, and excellent mouse and keyboard controls. In short, if you felt burned by the port quality from the developer's previous games, the large majority of those issues have been resolved. Bravo, FROM, I genuinely never expected this.

The game is also great. Mecha action brought into modernity with style and flair. The core appeal of building out your custom AC to tackle a variety missions and arena fights is preserved while being balanced out with action combat that rewards skill and snap decision-making. Beefed up melee options and a balanced quick boost that allows for fast repositioning while rewarding careful energy management. However your build generally matters far more, determining your playstyle and making flexibility the most important part of your approach, even if the game makes some concessions to modern controls and shelves the holy turn speed stat of traditional Armored Core. Most of the game is combat, and the combat strikes a great pace for me, without the dizzying speed of previous generations nor the measured your-turn-my-turn of FROM's more recent action offerings, giving you access to powerful offensive, defensive, and movement options all at once.

All of this is coupled with a mecha anime-esque story that I got more invested into than I thought I would. Despite being presented in an extremely dry way through voice over and mission briefings, there are strong characters and memorable moments. The setting and atmosphere are also top notch, and the game gives you lots of details to dig into. It's never mysterious or vacuous but the web of character motivations can really draw you in. Even the English dubbing is compelling with everyone over-acting just enough.

I've also sunk many, many hours into the PvP. I think this is more that Armored Core 6 is basically the only game in town as far as deeply customizable mecha action multiplayer games on PvP, even if the offering is barebones. The dynamics remind me a lot of Custom Robo, where there isn't a ton of balance, but there is a lot of variety if you're willing to dig into the parts kit. That being said, the PvP is the most obviously flawed part of the experience. It's nowhere near as fully featured as some of the previous games, having only rudimentary 1v1 and 3v3 modes, with a skeleton of a lobby system missing basic features. The netcode may be the single worst technical aspect of the entire package. It is just barely better than Elden Ring which was an incredibly low bar. Expect latency to be handled poorly, but you could be playing on the same network switch as someone and still get boost kicked from 100 meters away, with an animation that misses on both of your clients. Visual effects are missing like assault armor which is incredibly deceptive and cheap, the spectator mode is a mess, and yet somehow I keep coming back to it on the strength of the core gameplay. That's a testament to how good Armored Core 6 actually is, but I'm really hoping they take their newfound technical competence and extend that to a multiplayer-focused entry next.

I first reviewed this game after 23.6 hours of playing it and completing my first NG run. 

After I got all the achievements at the 65 hour mark, I thought I'd be done with this game and could put it away for a bit before returning.

Instead, I felt compelled to go through the entire gambit again just because I wanted to.

So, here I am at the 95 hour mark after completing the secret ending once more. I still have to redo my S-ranks, but that can wait until later.

Here's just a couple random thoughts of mine, coming from a fan of FromSoft's games since playing Demon's Souls in 2011, though never experiencing any of the AC games prior to this one:

- If the Souls games and Elden Ring are basically playable Berserk anime, then Armored Core VI is a playable Gundam anime. You'll find that most of the enemies just get sneezed on by any weapon of your choosing, until you come across another AC or worse. Hell, some of the bigger tank enemies can pose a threat early on when you're still coming to terms with your build. 

- The story is intriguing and is elevated by some top-notch VO performances, though it can be a little vague at times (kinda FromSoft's tradition at this point). I do wish there was an way of tracking which missions still have data-logs to find, similar to how they track which missions still have unclaimed combat-logs.

- While the core (heh) of this game is to customize your AC and try different ways to approach the various missions, it certainly is possible to find a build early on that can carry you throughout the game and possibly S-rank many of the missions. My advise: push yourself to try new builds. Not only can it help off-set some of the repetitiveness by using new weapons or legs, but it might help you improve your previous builds too.

- This game has a lot of stats to juggle about compared to Elden Ring. More often than not, I'm constantly looking at the detailed breakdown of these parts since the small snippet of stats shown never gives an ideal picture of why you would want a specific part over another. For example, while core pieces will show you how much more EN output you'll get out of your installed generator, they don't tell you other things, like how much your booster is enhanced by your selected core. It might have been more useful to default to the full breakdown of stats OR highlight the advantages that a specific part excels at (i.e. show the melee specialization stat on arms with higher than average values).
	- Also, a video or tutorial explaining some of these more obscured stats wouldn't have gone amiss. Still don't know how much of the "Firearm Specialization" I should be aiming for and I shouldn't have to look up Youtube videos to figure that out.
		- Also, the boost stat isn't even accurate for when you're hovering with quad legs or using tank treads, though I figure that might be fixed later on down the road.

- That being said, if you can wrap your head around managing these stats and pick the parts that fit juuust within your allotted energy budget, it can be a blast just ripping through waves of fodder and ACs alike. Whether your hopping/hovering around with the reverse joints/quad legs raining destruction from above, or drifting around ACs with your tank treads letting miniguns loose and popping off missiles and cannons, [url=https://www.youtube.com/shorts/WpmHM1S9_J0]or just driving a pile bunker into your staggered foes[/url], you always have means of tackling even the toughest bosses.

- On the topic of S-ranking, it's a mixed bag for me. On one hand, it can feel rewarding figuring out both the optimal build and path to take that will net you an S-rank. On the other-hand, what counts as an S-rank is woefully under-explained. There's a brief tutorial window that tells you to minimize ammo and repair costs and to not restart at checkpoints. What it doesn't tell you is that you should [spoiler] always be destroying fodder along the way, even if the mission doesn't reward bonus pay for destroying additional targets. This makes high reserve, low ammunition-cost weapons more valuable, but can hurt build experimentation when you don't know if using a large cannon or railgun would dig too much in your ammo budget to reliably net you that S-rank. [/spoiler] I wouldn't say no to a hint system that tells you what you *could* do to improve your A-rank runs, though I suspect any improvements might have to wait until future DLC/newer installments drop.

- I said this the last time I wrote my review for this game, but I do wish there were some co-op options available. Granted, the multiplayer aspect of this game is quite limited (no I haven't touched PvP, not terribly interested in dealing with *the pvp meta* at this time), but like Elden Ring and Souls-likes, I do appreciate being able to help others through the tougher parts of those game and wish I could do the same here. Then again, I am aware that AC V kinda bent itself backwards trying to integrate multiplayer into its campaign missions, so I'll give FromSoft a pass for not wanting to repeat those mistakes here. Still, the ability to cooperate with others, whether helping them in their campaigns or in a horde-like mode fending off waves of attackers, wouldn't go amiss in future installments.

I think that's everything I wanted to say for now.

While the game's not perfect, it was good enough for me to complete it in its entirety...twice. If a game convinces me to play through it again not long after the first run, then that's typically a game that's got something special going for it. I certainly am looking forward to whatever FromSoft brings next to this series.

After you get through the first mission, the rest of the game makes you constantly feel super cool. I have loved my time with this game so far and I'm excited to continue playing this game :D

The fighting is way more modernized in comparison to the old Armored Core titles in a very good way. You can see they are trying very hard to SPECIFICALLY not copy Mechwarrior, to an extent of even removing mechanics/parts already in previous titles. This could be them trying to not get lawyers involved or being straight up lazy.

It really doesn't shake the nostalgia bones outside of the art form and vague story telling.

Why the negative outside of what we all expect as gamers from a full priced title these days.

1. It does not have matchmaking.

2. There does not appear to be in game ladders for multiplayer which were very much used and loved for the team and duel tournaments. (this game is all about mercs/corps and mech fighting wtf?)

3. The lack of live service from FromSoftware in every title they pump out leaves little chance much will change at face value, what you see is what you get. Thankfully no bugs or hiccups for me, have been able to play smoothly without interruptions.

4. Not a ton of usable variety with items, once you find something that works/meta you can stick with it most of the campaign. Funny enough some old AC metas are alive and well. I can only see NG+ needing item swaps between missions for shield breaking really. This is especially disappointing when realizing if you build a mech that works, probably everyone else is making that same mech. An attitude that just doesn't place the player in the universe, and removes the desire to mech design or really explore the store.

5. Completionist catering, or more laziness, many items appear to exist simply to earn rather than to use or even test out for yourself.

6. It's honestly hard for me to personally judge an Armored Core game having played most of the old titles. Meaning I'm expecting several years of development and a decades jump in technological advancement... For them to provide something I was expecting 10+ years ago today. Seems kinda scummy, and just a name profit much like GamesWorkshop titles go.


Will you enjoy playing it? I think so for the majority, it's a fun and instantly rewarding dopamine type game. BUT in 2023 and with the hundreds of thousands of game titles available. Armored Core is clearly very down on the list for actual Quality and Customer Service in comparison to how much the game was requested by it's fans, years of development from a world renowned developer, and full price cost while lacking a litany of features.

Conclusion add another full price game to the tally of titles released unfinished.

I haven't played an Armored Core game since the Xbox 360, and ever since then, mech games have been pretty scarce. I've bided my time with Titanfall2 and Daemon X Machina, but at long last, an Armored Core sequel is delivered to us in the year 2023!

I have exactly ONE (arguably) legit complaint about the game, and it's that the new melee weapons can't be doubled-up on. You can only wield melee weapons with the left hand, and you can technically pack two melee weapons once you've unlocked the shoulder-mounted weapon bays, but you cannot just go in dual-wielding melee weapons. Also I guess you can't exit your mech at will, a'la Daemon X Machina, or Titanfall, but that has ever been the case with the Armored Core games, so there's NO reason to expect otherwise.

I love everything else about this game. The sense of scale frequently shocked me, the game performed smoothly and I hesitate to describe the action as anything short of elegant. The sound design is appropriately heavy and chunky, with the speed of rapid boosts rivaling the anime absurdity of Gundam.

Weapons hit hard, shoulder-mounted SONGBIRD cannons SLAM backward as they launch massive explosive rounds at hefty quat-legged walking bulwarks armed to the teeth with missile salvos.

Please bear in mind, however, that this is NOT a Soulsborne game. There are no i-frames. and the primary solution to all problems is not just "git gud," but also "build and prep for the situation." In a way, that makes this immediately either more or less accessible depending on the gaming background you're coming from. The time you spend in the garage tinkering with your Core is just as important, if not MORESO, than the time you spend piloting said Core in a given mission.

I'm hoping this game's success brings us more titles of like design, takings risks and doing exciting new hybridizations and things with the mech genre. I'm also keen to see if we get any DLC in the future, particularly featuring more quad legs and treads. I swear, every time I finished a chapter and received a notification that new parts were available for purchase, I'd run to the in-game shop like a kid on Christmas.

Until then, have fun customizing with loads of parts, custom paintjobs, and an extensive custom decal toolkit.

A game where you play as a mercenary mech warrior forced to come to a desolate alien planet to try and pay off a life-ending debt, and will end up playing a big part in determining its destiny.
The main gameplay loop is to customize your mech for the needs of a particular mission, play the mission, get paid and use the money to buy more equipment to customize your mech further; tuning the mech to your playstyle and needs has always been to the center of the Armored Core series, and it was very well realized here:
The mech controls amazingly and super responsively, and its movement can only be described as liberating: you can fly freely and boost up ahead at breakneck speeds, while firing a barrage of missiles to anyone standing in your way; taking down this game's intricate bosses by mastering its movement and weapon options is truly exhilarating.
The customization is very in-depht, as not only are there tons of different body parts and weapons to build your mech with that all play very differently, but the game also offers an extensive editor for the mech's appearance, letting you change its paintjob with very intricate options and a full-blown emblem editor.
As for the story, I wasn't expecting much going into this, and I was very pleasantly surprised to be met with an involved plotline that takes you for a fun, at times emotional ride; the plot also gradually reveals more of itself over the course of multiple playthroughs, which is only an encouragement to keep playing even after the end of the initial (decently short) playthrough.
This game offers fun, addicting gameplay alongside a very nice story, never lets up the high-octane action for even one second, and is over before overstaying its welcome, while offering rewarding additional content for those who want a bit more; I really recommend it.

It's been a long time since the last Armored Core game, about a decade since Verdict Day? This game is pretty great and feels like a mix between the PS2 games and the more modern games (it's not as Too Damn Fast, Too Damn Furious as Armored Core For An Answer though). There is heaps of customisation, collectables, secrets and multiple endings, there's also multi-player for those who want to test their creations against other players. 

However From Software (famous for Dark Souls/Demon Souls/ect...) are still patching the game to make it more competitive in multi-player, so don't expect the meta to stay the meta forever (hopefully). There is also a wide variety of missions from protecting/escort, destroying objects and other ACs, even a stealth mission. This game also harkens back to the difficulty of some of the other AC games, so if you're used to getting your butt kicked like you would in Dark Souls/Demon Souls, you should feel at home here, just remember to change up your AC design (the one design generally will not carry you through the whole game, you need to adapt to the mission). 

One thing I did particularly dislike in this game is the stagger system, I generally dislike stagger systems in games (I really hated it in Final Fantasy 13), as I feel like it reduces the amount of viable builds and weapon loadouts. It encourages an aggressive play style that heavily focuses on dealing constant stagger, if you're not dealing constant stagger, you're wasting damage potiential/ammunition. The game also has a heavy focus on melee and close combat, long range combat is not a big thing in this game because projectiles do not travel fast enough to hit most a lot of targets in this game. Hence why this AC games does not have sniper rifles and has had to have some patches to make other weapons like Rifles and Handguns more viable.

Overall, I really enjoyed the game despite my minor gripes, and the difficulty was satisfying, especially after multiple play throughs. I hope we either get some story/mission expansion DLC or some DLC that adds more parts and weapons to the game. Seeing as this is one of the most successful AC games made, I hope we won't have to wait too long for a sequel.

Single Player: awesome. Finished this all the way through newgame++. The boss fights are epic and challenging (you'll cuss and die dozens of times but so satisfying when you win), the missions and locals are varied, graphics and performance wise, doing great with an old 1660. They do force you to learn new weapons and strategies for each boss which is great (unless your someone that just wants to mindlessly blast through). 

PVP: A game so good deserves better. The game has gone through several balancing patches but the pvp is dominated by max dps tank builds or meta builds that just get annoying. I would love to dodge around trading blows with another fast mech, not dodge an OP tank build until they connect once and the match is over. Wouldn't be that big a deal if there were more than 10 people online at a time and there was anything but 1vs1 available 99% of the time. If they had capture the flag or other game modes would be so much better. There are no rankings in pvp, no matchmaking etc, extremely lazy effort for a PVP that could be so good. Guessing there are not enough players to support that variety?

I'm normally not much of a fan of big robots, but these ones have warmed my heart to the concept. It's the perfect mech game for people who didn't like Hawken and don't use their titans in Titanfall. An AC in this game on average stands about the height of a midtown apartment complex, and moves at a third of the speed of sound, they are anything but sluggish.

Also, Armored Core 6 is ridiculously easy to get into for the first time, when compared to the previous games in the series. It's far more focused on the actual strategic construction of your mech than it is about the technical skill of piloting and aiming. Your grandparents could probably have fun playing armored core. The PVP scene still has a high skill ceiling though, so returning fans won't be disappointed.

The biggest thing that surprised me about this game is the replay value. I am not going to spoil anything about the story missions, but anyone playing the game for the first time should know that you will want to replay the campaign at least twice to see everything the campaign has to offer. Also, it's a Fromsoft game, so you don't need a new save file to experience the other story paths, you just go into NG+ and keep all your parts and upgrades after reaching any of the endings.
The amount of things you can customize in this game was absolutely fantastic. It was so much fun, and there is so much replayability.

I'm almost done with my fourth playthrough. So yeah, I'm fan, lol. As someone coming from the Dark Souls trilogy, Elden Ring, and Sekiro, I found combat to be overwhelming at first, but eventually got into a grove -- my only achievement left is S-ranking every mission. There are lots of builds and lots of customization. The story is compelling too; I love the voice acting.

My only big gripe is that there's only one save file. I hated when Dragon's Dogma did it. I hate it here. Some times it's fun to just start a fresh playthrough and do things with more experience. It's a shame they hindered that option.

Fresh and new Armored Core experience.

This Armored Core title feels different from the previous titles and when I say "different" I mean that as a Good thing, it is a unique AC experience. I have gotten all the parts, missions and endings. Starting at the beginning, back then this series wasn't compatible with Mouse & Keyboard and for this title they did M&K right. How your AC will turn and follow your mouse to the best of its ability (especially with the right parts and upgrades) making it a very good entry for the PC demographic. I have an old setup and using some medium-settings I was able to complete this game with a PC that has a GTX 1050 ti and my experience was mostly smooth. (Only a few times did I experience crashes.)

The way this game does its first mission is different from the rest and gives an impression on what to expect. In previous titles the first-missions would be to just take out the enemy MTs and get use to handling your craft. This game takes the first mission many steps further, giving you tips and clips of how the controls work and missiles being locked to one or multiple targets which is an exciting feature I wanted to have done in an easy manner. While finishing on a challenging boss at the end of the first mission, requiring you to put all those skills to good use, the quick boost, assault boost, knowing when to boost and instantly recharging your energy by being grounded for a short while. I was able to luckily take down the Helicopter boss on my first try by reminding myself that I have missiles.

At the start of progressing in the Arena, you get the feel for the challenge for some enemy types like the Tetrapod MT at the 'Destroy Transport Helicopters' or fighting the D-Ranks in the arena, they feel like challenging bosses when you first fight them. As you progress and gain more parts and upgrades those same bosses (even the harder ones) feel easier as your skills are better honed (or your knowledge of how the enemies function).

The few cons are that there are a few LARGE bosses (Arms Fort-like) i.e. the spaceships and the Strider, another is that there are a few number of part types (one melee weapon per type) one kind of pulse blade and one type of solid-base weapons and only two different Quad-legs (or Tetrapods in this case). Hopefully this will be different if they release DLCs and expansions to expand on the number of parts.

My third review on this game and hopefully the last. As of now I have around 160 hours on the game and I still die a lot so ig some things just don't change when it comes to Sekiro. If you're looking for a relaxing experience you're fucked, but besides that shit's awesome, the combat especially. The parrying, mikiri-countering, dodging, mixed in with a bunch of techniques and tools it's a lot to handle. But once you get the hang of them, It's like an experience like no other, which is the exact thing that pisses me off about other games, is there isn't really any other out there quite as good as Sekiro. Sorry Ghost Of Tsushima, but you're gonna have to step down for this one. Compared to the rest of the FromSoftware franchise it's different since it's Samurai based, colorful and as I said just has sick combat. And just like the other Souls games, this one is even better with mods. You should definitely check out Elden Arts or Ressurection mods for some extra spice and download some sick fits and effects just to keep it more interesting. So to sum it up; I do really recommend it, it's very unique, hard and enjoyable. Should also mention that it takes a while to complete If you're planning on going achievement hunting. But otherwise just try not to die to much.

The second best game FS had released (the first one being Bloodborne - still hoping for the remater :)). 
The combat system - which I'd compare to a dance with its fluidity and rhythm - is unforgiving but fair. If you die (expect more than twice), it's on you. It's simple on the surface, but once you dive into it the complexity appears. Especially on subsequent playthrougs with most of the things ulocked. The combos you can pull are very satisfying.
The story is different to what we're used to from FS. It's not as cryptic, is straightforward, and the premise is simple. But of course, the world is beautiful, filled with an enviromental storytelling and details. The power to pull you in and care about its characters is there.
Shame we didn't get a DLC :)

This game often gets lumped together with FromSoftware's "Soulsborne" games but in my opinion it stands apart from them and also above them in some respects. 

While the map is slightly "open" it is presented in a fairly linear fashion and you will not get lost as easily as in their other games. It also has verticality because you can leap relatively high  and zip around buildings with a grappling hook like Spider-Man, it makes the world more fun to navigate. Most RPG mechanics have been stripped down, there are no stats to spend points in, only skill trees and a tree for your secondary tools which enable you to do things like throw shuriken, blow fire et cetera. 

There is a fairly well designed difficulty curve in my opinion, it obviously gets extremely challenging at parts, but with challenge comes the immense feeling of pride and relief after victory. The fighting is very fast-paced and engaging, it feels very rewarding to grasp it; basically you build an enemy's Posture with attacks, counterattacks and especially parries to the point you can use a finishing blow; and you do this twice (sometimes more or less) on bosses. You don't have a stamina bar, instead blocks (which completely negate damage) will fill your own posture which will result in a broken guard if it fills up entirely. Obviously this is different from their other games, so it's important to approach this game on its own terms without any preconceptions from other titles. 

I will point out however that sometimes you will have to "grind" for experience or sometimes even currency to get an upgrade that you want or need. Because the combat is so fun this isn't _that_ tedious but you definitely won't level up every skill on a base playthrough. The skill/arm trees hide future abilities from you that are gated behind upgrades, and you should know there are skill trees you may or may not discover through your playthrough (I recommend unlocking them all). This is a bit annoying because you may realize too ate that you wasted points on something that doesn't have anything interesting or valuable behind it and then have to go grind points for the brand new skill tree you unlocked that has a really good ability at the end of it. Occasionally useful combat abilities will be hidden behind innocuous passives like more money/drops or something like that. Therefore it may actually behoove someone to look up the skill trees before hand and decide what to invest in so you don't waste points/materials.

I think that anyone who really enjoyed this game should support the title "Sifu" which borrows certain ideas (namely posture and resurrection) and also expands the combat system quite a bit to the point of being uniquely special. I think coming from Sifu, a game which also emphasizes parrying, really helped me understand Sekiro quickly, and the skillset definitely transfers across both games. 

Disclaimer I only did the "Severance" ending. Note: there is a decision midway through the game which determines the course of the remainder of the game, and without spoilers I highly recommend the SECOND option as the first option will make the game end much faster. 

All in all, this was definitely a special experience and one of the best games I played in a long time.

This is my favorite game but...
- This game is not compatible for most gamers. Meaning the average Joe will NOT enjoy this game. (or beat it)
- Sekiro requires a decent level of emotional intelligence and mindfulness to play in a healthy way. (Most ppl don't have one or either)
- This game rewards players with good mind over matter. Perseverance and tenacity will help too.
- If you are a rage monster and determined to play this, go practice meditation and mindfulness first. Learn to LOVE making mistakes and failing. (you can only improve by accepting you are a noob or unskilled)
- This game excels at giving the best possible combat experience of any game to date even after ELDEN RING.
- Sekiro is FAR from perfect... Certain level and enemy design withhold this game from the heights Elden Ring but this game far exceeds any and all expectations for raw combat.
- The path of mastery is an amazing one. This game allows for anyone to try that path. Even after defeating bosses I find myself coming back to them wanting to PERFECT them and ultimately PERFECTING MYSELF. - THANK YOU DADDY MIYASAKI

This was my first game in the Souls-like genre. It blew me away.

The Look: This game is unbelievably beautiful. The environment artists managed to fill this world with deep macro and micro detail. Every zone is filled with stunning detail and it makes this world so rich, immersive, and exciting to explore.

Gameplay: Combat was a challenge unlike anything I've experienced in a game before and I absolutely loved it. Every single enemy needs to be taken seriously; this requires a high skill level, but the game does a great job of making that process fun and it makes the victories so much sweeter. Did I "cheat" by looking up videos for a few bosses? Yes, definitely. But that didn't make those fights easy.

The story wasn't particularly noteworthy by itself, but it was engaging, clear, and easy to follow. I still certainly enjoyed it.

Even if this isn't a game you would usually play, I would still suggest trying it out. You may surprise yourself.
