Without a doubt the most polished Fromsoft entry. The core combat and boss roster are second to none. 

The linear approach does hinder the exploration, but this freedom allows Sekiro to take a hard stance on the pace of its fights. There is never doubt about the effectiveness of an alternate build or the correct defensive approach to a boss' attacks. Sekiro merely lays out a set of fundamental tools and compounds on them in a constantly rewarding manner.

This game will put the balls on your feet. The weewee in poopoo. I've played done 5 playthroughs of this game and gotten all the endings across PS and PC. This game is probably the most satisfying FromSoftware game. Getting good just means being an utter badass by the end. Your pickle will be tickled and the veins will be popped. Just be patient with learning parrying. You'll learn the tells across all enemies if you allow yourself to fail and learn from that failure. First playthrough I was ass. By my 3rd playthrough  I was the one kicking ass. 5th playthrough I could get by almost every single boss in the game with only one attempt. (Also try out the mods. A lot of cool ones out there)

Short version: 9/10, recommended if you like pain

The most relieved I've ever been to finish a game. 

This game has some really amazing moments, and beating a boss that was whooping my ass for hours was definitely relieving, and usually satisfying.

I don't know if I was able to Git Gud to the level I'd like to after beating the game, but can fairly confidently say this is low on the list for playing again for several reasons.

1) I want a big sword or hammer to bonk stuff with. The fast combat is very well done and feels really cool when you get into a tango of slashes, parries, jumps, and dodges, but something in the pacing of many fights just didn't feel great to me.

2) "Bugs?". Lets start with the for-sure bullshit. Some of the hitboxes for attacks are just ridiculous, so learning their bullshit is key to success. The rest, I don't even know if these are legit or just me on copium. This happened mostly on some of the later bosses, but I would be fighting a boss and he would go into hyper-mode and start firing off attacks that are usually warned by the red symbol without any tells. Sometimes they would go from the end of one attack chain directly into an attack that I had only seen halfway through another combo, or link multiple multiple combos in a row, then never do it again. I'm sure some of this is simply more infrequent moves being shown due to the amount of attempts I took on some of the bosses, but I think some of the high attempts were also due to unnecessarily confusing fight logic that took a long time for me to learn. The timings on moves seemed to change just enough so my learned timings were wrong, a lot, especially as I got deeper into the attempts. Maybe my brain was just turning to mush, but I said "What" with varying inflections more than any other game I've played so far.

3) Lack of numbers. I love damage and health numbers, and the tease of a poise bar being at 99.9% and going for the expected deathblow got me more times than I'd care to admit. If I could see the actual numbers on why events did or didn't trigger that would be awesome and help with the feeling of being screwed. I guess it would take away from the visual flow of the game, but I still love my numbers and seeing them change as my build and skills do.

"Similar" games I've played: Dark Souls 1, Monster Hunter World.
DS1: Oh how I wished for a true strength build in some of these encounters. A little piece of candy and some confetti just doesn't match up to my halberd. Sekiro's idol (checkpoint) system is way more forgiving, and warping between the many locations for vendors, farming, quests, and whatever else you might want felt really nice. The boss run-backs are all really managable, and getting repeat ganked by mobs on the way to the boss is a rarity. If you feel like you need some currency, farming is quite easy and fast with a few of the idols. I absolutely loved my first playthrough of DS1, and while this was also an amazing and beautiful experience, I think I enjoy the less-samurai combat more. I'll keep playing through the Soulsborne catalog as things go on sale, but am definitely looking forward to getting my weapon and equipment freedoms back.

MHW: A few of the fast weapons in MHW feel kind of like the fighting in Sekiro, but they play so differently I think the combat is the only similarity I can think of. And maybe the grapple thing but Sekiro's is way more fun. That said, now that I've beat the main story of both, I've continued to put time into MHW, and after just beating Sekiro, I really don't think I'll play it again, unless maybe a buddy gets it and I'll go through it again with them. There were times in Sekiro that I really just wanted to Git Gud and be done. I have consistently fun play sessions on MHW with very little frustration, and I can't say the same for the same percentage of Sekiro sessions.

Conclusion nobody will make it to:
Sekiro is a great game and mostly very well polished. Some of my frustrations with the game could be simply my inability to play well enough, but it felt bad in a way I hadn't quite experienced before somehow. The satisfaction of learning a fight wasn't quite there compared to the time it took me to learn them, but that could just be my ego talking. Steam says 51 hours played, I'd guess maaaybe 10 of those were idle time where I forgot the game was running. At a solid $30/40+ hours of gaming, I'd say it's well worth the money, because I got the have so much of an experience in that time.

Looked all over Steam for a decent shinobi/ninja/stealth game and this was the highest recommended. After playing and loving DmC 5 and similar games I decided to give this one a try though I knew this one would have a DS-like approach in terms of difficulty. All that said, when the game has sloppy programming behind it, I just have to complain. I'm fighting that chained ogre in the earlier levels and the dude literally did an instant, 0-frame 90 degree angle in midair when he dove to grab me *after completely evading him.* They got some messed up hit boxes up in this game. If you're looking for something fun, prepare to invest DOZENS of hours to become a master first to THEN start having fun. There's rarely an instance where you could interrupt your opponent with a slash... especially considering your character isn't the fastest sword swinger to begin with (at first anyway).

If you approach this game with the mentality of "I know I'm gonna die 1,000 times on the first level" and have the patience of a saint, then you're good. Otherwise, steer clear of this game.

(Edit: meant to say 90 degree angle originally but said 45. Also forgot to mention that I wasn't in front of him at all since I had dodged)

Great game, very challenging, satisfying, and rewarding. It looks incredible, both graphically and artistically. The animations are fantastic, hands down the best of any FromSoft game in my opinion. Finally getting the deathblow on an enemy you've been struggling with and deflecting all of their attacks once you've learned their moveset is so satisfying - visually, acoustically, and mechanically. I'd say Sekiro is probably more difficult than any Dark Souls game, but the revives and prosthetics are clever and fair ways of easing the difficulty when it's needed in really tough fights. 

Now, for the issues: 

The camera and lock-on systems are easily Sekiro's weakest feature. Both are very rudimentary, and don't seem to have changed much since Dark Souls or even Demon's Souls, games from 2011 and 2009 respectively. The lock-on and camera in those games was already poor, and with Sekiro's increased focus on both the player and various enemies moving further distances more frequently during combat, the problem is exacerbated. They are a frequent cause of frustration, especially if you get backed up against a wall or are in an enclosed space, are fighting multiple enemies, are fighting an enemy that moves around a lot (double glaive monks are the worst offender here), or have to look upwards at an enemy or a grappling hook spot. Throughout my playthrough I couldn't help but see the revive system as a band-aid fix for the frustration caused by deeper design flaws such as these, and it's a wonder FromSoft hasn't improved either the camera or the lock-on considering the amount of work and care they put into developing almost every other aspect of their games.

The platforming is awkward, especially when the sprint button forces your character into a dodge every time you start moving while its held down, which is annoying when you need to sprint on a ledge or a rooftop. 

Several bosses and enemies are so loud that they cause the game's audio to peak, which was incredibly irritating and may hurt some people's ears. The audio peaking was worst when reverb was involved, such as the bell-wielding Taro troops slamming the ground or the Guardian Ape thrashing around in the water. 

Some of the mini-bosses are more difficult than the actual bosses (Juzou the Drunkard and Ashina Elite, for example), and the game has loading screens in 2019.

While there are things to be improved, the gripes I have are relatively minor compared to how great I think the game is overall. Highly recommend it to any fan of FromSoft's games, just be aware that it has its fair share of issues.

CS2 is a tactical first-person shooter game that combines strategic gameplay with fast-paced action. It is a must-play for both new and experienced players, with stunning visuals and immersive gameplay. Players can choose to play as either terrorists or counter-terrorists, and with a wide variety of weapons and maps to choose from, every match is unique. Counter Strike 2 is a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat, with intense battles and heart-pounding moments. If you're looking for a timeless classic to add to your gaming library, Counter Strike 2 is the perfect choice.

Here are some of the key features that make Counter Strike 2 a masterpiece.
Counter Strike 2 is a game that rewards both strategic thinking and quick reflexes. Players must work together to complete their objectives, while also being prepared to react to the enemy team's actions.
Counter Strike 2 features stunning visuals and immersive gameplay that will transport you into the heat of battle. The game's sound design is also top-notch, with realistic gunshots and explosions that add to the overall experience.
Counter Strike 2 offers a wide variety of weapons and maps to choose from, giving players the freedom to customize their playstyle and experience.
Whether you're a terrorist or a counter-terrorist, the adrenaline rush of playing Counter Strike 2 is unmatched. The game's intense battles and heart-pounding moments will keep you coming back for more.

If you're a fan of first-person shooters, then Counter Strike 2 is a must-play. It is a timeless classic that offers something for everyone.

All-around masterpiece from this developer.

A game which I keep find myself coming back to again and again. One of the most satisfying game loops in the Roguelike genre, and with a dev team that actively listens to player feedback and pumps out quality updates. Been playing since Early Access, and I always point to this game as one of the success stories of Early Access done right. They even include some weapons and skins from other indie games, such as Risk of Rain, Hyperlight Drifter, Blasphemous, Hotline Miami, etc. to keep things spicy at no extra cost

Can hop in and hop out for a few runs at a time, get frustrated at getting ganked by a bunch of enemies and take a break, then hop right back on again the next day. An utterly satisfying experience, if you are willing to tackle the challenge. Assist mode makes the game more accessible (have turned on infinite deaths now and then to guarantee getting some unlocks here and there), but being able to go toe-to-toe with the base game and its mechanics is such a rewarding experience. Easily one of my most played games in my library, by a pretty wide margin.

Dead Cells is an adrenaline-pumping and addictive action-platformer that will keep you hooked for hours on end. With its dynamic combat, procedurally generated levels, and stunning pixel art, this game offers an unforgettable experience that leaves you craving more.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
The pixel art in Dead Cells is a visual treat. Each environment is meticulously crafted, from hauntingly beautiful dungeons to eerie forests and treacherous castles. The attention to detail and smooth animations add depth to the game's world, making every moment visually engaging. The blend of dark and vibrant colors sets the perfect mood for the game's challenging and atmospheric gameplay.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Dead Cells' gameplay is where it truly shines. The fast-paced combat is a joy to master, offering a satisfying mix of sword-slashing, arrow-shooting, and spell-casting. The game's "Roguevania" approach, combining rogue-like elements with the exploration of a metroidvania, creates a compelling and ever-changing experience. Each run feels fresh, as the levels, enemies, and loot are procedurally generated, keeping you on your toes and encouraging experimentation with different playstyles.

[b]Audio:[/b]
The audio design in Dead Cells complements the gameplay perfectly. The ominous soundtrack sets the mood for the intense battles and exploration, while the sound effects provide visceral feedback to your actions. The clashing of weapons, the creaking of doors, and the eerie echoes of the environment immerse you in the game's dangerous world, adding to the adrenaline rush of combat.

[b]Story:[/b]
While not heavily story-driven, Dead Cells offers subtle hints of lore that pique your curiosity as you progress. The game's mysterious narrative and enigmatic characters encourage you to piece together the game's world and history bit by bit. It's a testament to the game's design that even without a prominent plotline, players find themselves drawn deeper into the game's secrets.

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
Dead Cells strikes a satisfying balance between accessibility and challenge. The initial stages provide a smooth learning curve, allowing new players to get accustomed to the mechanics and enemies. However, as you progress, the difficulty ramps up significantly, demanding quick reflexes and strategic decision-making. Each death feels like a learning opportunity, motivating you to return and improve your skills.

[b]Grind:[/b]
The grind in Dead Cells is thoughtfully balanced. While gathering cells and blueprints to unlock new weapons and abilities requires some effort, it never feels like an overwhelming grind. The diverse and rewarding upgrades make the progression feel worthwhile, encouraging players to explore different paths and strategies.

[b]Game Time:[/b]
With its replayable nature and ever-changing levels, Dead Cells offers a significant amount of gameplay. Depending on your skill level and desire to uncover all its secrets, you can easily spend tens to hundreds of hours immersed in the game's challenging and addictive world.

[b]Price:[/b]
Dead Cells' price is well worth the experience it offers. The depth, variety, and replay value justify the cost, making it a standout title in its genre.

Dead Cells is a triumph of game design that sets a new standard for action-platformers. Its addictive gameplay, stunning pixel art, and engaging audio create a seamless and immersive experience. If you're a fan of challenging and rewarding games, Dead Cells is an essential addition to your gaming library.

This is the game I always wanted and never knew. 

MOST IMPORTANT PART: Originally, I never picked up this game because I heard how soul crushing, Souls games were. I'm just too old and tired and averse to frustration, to do 1980s arcade style repeat over and over again frustrating encounters. That said, I enjoy very challenging experiences (like playing Skyrim on Master), but don't want to do “one wrong move and you die” and lose everything. I also was very turned off by everything I read about lack of quest and dialogue journals. I don't need my hand held tightly but again I'm an adult with many cares in the world, I can't possibly remember conversations, lore and directions from days ago after a long week of work. Well, if you're like me, forget your fears.

As I told a friend, I dk if I can ever get passed a single boss, or will get stopped along the main quest bc of that, but I don't care. I have 25 hours in the game, and I LOVE LOVE LOVE everything I see. And the more play, and learn, the better it gets. Don't worry about the above fears. You can explore the world endlessly (so it seems to me, although I'm only the first two provinces? Maybe it's one province? I'm not sure) and never fight a boss. Often times, if you are clever and quick, you can even loot part of the boss areas without getting caught. I really don't care about main quests. I put 300 hours in Skyrim and Witcher before I ever finished their main quests. 

Also, at least so far, dying is not a big deal, really. First, you have (a single) chance to recover the Runes (money) you lost if you die. If you do, no harm no foul. If you die again, then you lose it all. BUT, you find Rune alternatives everywhere that hold their value even if you die and you can trade them in for money. Also, every time you rest, everything comes back to life. Annoying right? Not really. Skryim regenerates monsters after a month I think, and Witcher after only a day or two. So big deal. Also you can fast travel or ride quickly on a horse, past "cleared" areas, so you really lose no time at all, you don’t have to retread “regenerated” ground if you don’t want to do it. It's not needlessly repetitive unless you want to keep fighting things to improve your technique.

Speaking of technique, the combat is the most fluid I EVER HAVE SEEN. It puts poor Skryim (1,200 hours love you) to ... I won't say shame, but retirement. Picture Call of Duty responsiveness but D&D style combat. Your choices absolutely matter. Your loadout affects your abilities and weight which also affects your effectiveness. And if you make a mistake on your “build” I believe eventually you can respec quite freely. I'm using a Prophet (just bc I thought it looked cool) but am experimenting with all kinds of stuff for now.

Monsters themselves are some of the most diverse I ever seen. Stuff I never imagined before. Even “boring” ones you have seen time and time again like goblins and undead, can surprise you with different loadouts and weapons and abilities. And their abilities and loadouts are not just for show. And, many creatures are grouped together quite naturally. You will very early on see a group of ... I dk sentient undead? With peasants, village guards, actual knights, champions, and court wizards, all naturally fitting together perfectly. I mean, really some of the most consistent and logical creature group designs ever.

The graphical environment is on par with Witcher 3. I am not kidding, but I spent quite a bit of time simply sitting on my horse, upon a cliff, overlooking the ocean, just watching the sun rise, rays coming off the sea through the trees.

The real beauty though (although this is the most fun I ever had with D&D combat) is the exploration. That's the reason I live for in these games. I ignore the quests and just walk or use the horse to go on the same trails back and forth. At night things even change. I can't tell you how many times I have traveled back and forth just to find a new crypt that was hidden somewhere in the brush or under a building.

In summary, if you're like me, and too afraid and tired to be frustratingly crushed over and over again, DON'T WORRY. There is plenty to do, while ignoring all that. As I told my friend, if I spend 50-100 hours just exploring the world and fighting "regulars" and finding treasure and stuff without defeating a single boss, it was worth it. The one caveat is that you do sort of have to pay attention to NPCs bc they don't often repeat themselves and there is no question or lore journal and that is my only complaint. I don't need to be told go here, but I would like a record of information I have collected. Grr.

Final note: Don't be afraid to experiment generously with mechanics and settings. I couldn't hit anything at first bc I foolishly turned off "LOCK ON" during settings bc I thought that cheating. Eventually, I learned ways around it, but I found odd and frustrating problems like there was no "side step" so when an enemy jumped to the side of me I would try to side step to sort of keep my shield in front but move to the side, but instead I turned around and exposed my flank. If you play with LOCK ON, you do sidestep and always face front. BUT, if you need to dodge roll far away (to safely drink a healing potion) you can't if you are locked on (you can roll not far away). So, I learned to LOCK ON, LOCK OFF. Stuff like that. I went from losing most battles to winning most of them :)

The game itself is great. Good story, good mechanic for the most part, interesting locations and enemies, but the camera. Holy damn the camera makes me want to rub my dick against a cheese grater. How can they get something so important so wrong? Ill target lock a massive, building sized golem, and then somehow be chasing an eagle after i roll through his legs. You have to be so incredibly careful to not touch the right stick AT ALL or else you're not going to be aiming at you want to be anymore. This is only most of the time. Theres plenty of inconsistency where you can pull the camera a little bit more in a certain direction while you are locked on. Never know if you are allowed to look somewhere or if the game is going to fuck you. Not only that, but if you managed to stay locked on to something the spinning of the camera will make you sick. Its so damn hard to tell whats going on beyond a flurry of legs and arms. It makes looking around the most difficult part of the game, far harder to deal with than any boss pattern or situation the game presents. Worst camera I've ever dealt with no exaggeration. Even though i wanted to keep enjoying the good parts this is literally game breaking and ruined the entire thing for me.

I had never finished a souls game before Elden Ring.
This hasn't change after my Elden Ring play through. Gotcha didn't I?

Great Game though.
To enjoy the game you must:
1) Accept that you WILL die.
2) Accept that you WILL die hundreds of times.
3) Accept that you WILL die hundreds of times on the same boss.

If you enjoy a hard but fair game, awesome boss fights, and building a character for facing any challenges, buy Dark Souls 3, because Elden Ring offers nothing of the sort.

It's a game set in a beautiful world where every single enemy can delete your character with one, maybe 2 attacks.
I've got some complaints but overall really solid game. Make sure to check out Dark Souls if you haven't already.

I didn't think I would honestly like this game for how difficult it is. I haven't even broken anything.....yet

But pro tip- NEVER mess save data is was a terrible idea it broke the game and kept saying "failed to load save data" if this is happening to you here are the steps to fix it. :)

STEP 1:

Right click on the game in steam library then go to -> Properties -> General Tab -> (DISABLE) Keep Games saves in steam cloud for ELDEN RING.

Make sure to disable it.

STEP 2:

Delete the "ELDEN RING" folder located in:C:\Users(your username)\AppData\Roaming

Shortcut- Windows + R -> type %appdata%

The game will re-create the folder when you log in with a fresh non-corrupted copy!

Everybody was talking a lot about this game for a long time so i thought i would try it, and yes it is hard. My problems with this game, is the wonky controls. The 'tutorial' is a bunch of boxes that don't show anything, it doesnt translate with keyboard and mouse, and there is significant input delay. The game doesn't really have a story, but it gives you options, just not at the start. The beginning of this game is pretty much come back after you have leveled 15 times so you dont get oneshot by the boss it sets on the natural progression. I regret buying this game not just because it is difficult, but because its a bland game with no story or intrigue. You will be googling for an hour why doesnt this thing work, or how do you add to the hotbar. I'd give this game a 4/10.

9 / 10
This is the perfect example of an AAA Soulsborne game. Sadly the Endboss is completely unpolished. 

Radagon (phase 2 / 2)
1. HEAVY input reading
2. animation cancel from various windups and even out of his own teleports INTO his next teleports
3. tracking from some attacks is also off (dude just curves to you in a 90° angle mid dash)
4. and lastly the infinite attackchain where he spams up to 12 consecutive lightnings or light hammer attacks. If you fail to dodge one, the followup will kill you.

And of course phase 1 & 2 / 2 from Elden Beast is running simulator with additional
4 spammable large AOEs
3 gimmick one shots
and 1 grab attack (also 1 shot) you have to stack every holy resistance in the game in order to not restart 

Worst 2 bossfight(s) i ve ever fought in ANY soulsborne game, EVER.

Ironically this game also features my favourite bossfights of all soulsbornes i ve ever played.
Mechanically it s Morgott. Even with his windups he just feels genuinely clean to play against, i even like him more than Godfrey, despite Morgott appearing 3 times i never get bored fighting him.
Visually it s Dragonlord Placidusax. The theme, the surroundings, the animations.. kinda speaks for itself..
One word; stunning.

What this doesn t show is that i also played this game somewhere else and i managed to get into the late / endgame with most major build this game has to offer, excluding some nieche hybrids that are probably just as fun.

builds
favourite: FAI + DEX hybrid (multiple times; ancient dragon lightning, blackflame)
FAI
ARC
FAI + INT hybrid
DEX
STR
INT
Every single one of them was fun to play and experiment around with. 

The graphics are outstanding.. like they re just something else..
If you like soulsbornes, it s a must have.
Note that the multiplayer / Co-Op is horrible but thankfully there are mods to aid with that. About modding, there are some really neat mods in general.
